HEADLINE: U.S. TAKING ACTION AGAINST JAPANESE IN ONE TRADE CASE

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration decided today to initiate sanctions against Japan for failing to live up to promises to allow Motorola Inc. to penetrate the lucrative Tokyo cellular phone market.
The decision on Motorola, which officials said would be announced on Tuesday, had been in the works for months, with a deadline that happened to fall on Feb. 15. It involves a 1989 trade agreement between the United States and Japan and was not part of the eight-month-long broad-based talks intended to open Japan's markets for autos, telecommunications, insurance and medical equipment. Those talks collapsed on Friday, after a meeting between President Clinton and Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa failed to resolve differences.
 
 
A White House Warning
 President Clinton warned today that he would soon decide on other measures intended to force Japan to open markets. 
 Asked if he was afraid that American sanctions on Japan in the Motorola case might set off a trade war, Mr. Clinton did not rule out the possibility. But he warned Tokyo that with its weighty dependence on the American export market it would have a lot to lose from such a tit-for-tat.
Speaking of the prospect of the United States' and Japan's slapping one another with punitive tariffs, Mr. Clinton told reporters at the White House: "It could be. But I think they would have to think long and hard about it."
The mounting trade tensions have been pushing the dollar lower against the yen for some time, and the decline accelerated today with the dollar plunging 4.7 percent, to a six-month low. [Page D1.]
 
Interesting Timing
 Administration officials said that even if the broad-based talks had succeeded, Washington probably would have decided anyway to retaliate now against Japan for its failure to live up to the 1989 agreement to give Motorola equal access to the lucrative Tokyo cellular market.
But in view of the failure of the trade talks, Administration officials welcomed with relish the chance to use the Motorola decision to send a rapid-fire signal to Japan that if Washington could not open Japanese markets through negotiations, it would find other means.
In the Motorola case, the Administration is likely to impose punitive tariffs on Japanese phone makers that sell in the United States, until Motorola is given equal access to the Japanese market.
President Clinton told reporters of the Motorola dispute: "While it's coincidental, it is a problem which is illustrative of our general problem. There's no question that Motorola provides a world-class product fully competitive in quality and price on that."
While the Administration continued to review what additional steps it might take against Japan, Mr. Clinton said: "I'm going to make a decision within a few days. We need to clarify what America's approach is going to be. There are a number of options open to us, including some that have not been widely discussed that may offer great promise."
In the meantime, the Administration's strategy appeared to be to try to raise as much anxiety, and uncertainty, in Tokyo as possible -- in hopes of driving up the value of the yen and driving down the Tokyo stock market. Administration officials apparently hope that uncertainty about what Washington will do might create pressure from the Japanese business community that will force the Government to make concessions, and obviate the need for further American sanctions.
A stronger yen tends to make Japanese exports to the United States more expensive while making American exports to Japan cheaper -- a quick way to ease the trade imbalance.
Administration officials denied that they were deliberately trying to talk up the value of the yen. But, then, they do not have to. Just the uncertainty of the moment is enough to spur speculators to act.
President Clinton added fuel to that mood of uncertainty today by refusing to rule out a broad array of sanctions on Japan. "I'm not ruling anything out," he told a news conference.
Mr. Clinton stressed that Japan's reluctance to set numerical standards for determining whether Japan was really opening its markets was "an unsustainable policy."
The speculation about a possible trade war, in which two countries pile ever-higher tariffs on one another's goods, arose after Japan and the United States reached an impasse last week over the Administration's demands for new approaches to opening Japanese markets. Such conflicts tend both to drive down the level of trade and increase consumer prices.
The Motorola situation has its roots in the 1988 Trade Act. That act requires the United States trade representative to review by March 31 of each year the effectiveness of all trade agreements regarding telecommunications products and services, to make sure countries are in compliance with the terms.
 
Quarrel Over Access
 In early January, the trade representative's office advised Tokyo that it would move up to Feb. 15 its annual review of the 1989 agreement betweeen Japan and the United States on cellular phones. It was moved up in hopes that the meeting between President Clinton and Prime Minister Hosokawa might be able to resolve a dispute over the 1989 agreement, which stipulated that there should be the same access for North American cellular equipment in the Tokyo-Nagoya market as there was for Japanese companies.
The 1989 agreement grew out of American complaints that Motorola was being frozen out of the Japanese market to give Japanese companies a chance to catch up with Motorola's leading-edge cellular technology.
The dispute over the 1989 agreement arose because the Japanese set up a competition between two consortiums for the huge Tokyo-Nagoya market, where 60 percent of Japan's population resides. One consortium was led by Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, or N.T.T., and included the Nippon Idou Tsushin Corporation, known as IDO, a Japanese cellular phone provider.
The other consortium was led by IDO, and Motorola was assigned to this consortium by the Japanese Government, even though Motorola did not see a need for a partner and was competing effectively elsewhere in Japan. In other words, the leader of Motorola's consortium was also a prinicipal player in the competing all-Japanese consortium.
Not surprisingly, IDO sided with its partner N.T.T. by favoring its transmission technology over Motorola's. This was in part because N.T.T.'s system was compatible throughout Japan, while, American officials say, Motorola's had been prevented by the Japanese Government from having such broad access. As a result, the number of Tokyo residents who have signed up for cellular phones supplied by the N.T.T.-compatible system is 318,000 and the number for the Motorola-compatible system is 12,000.
 
Working on a Product
 In the meantime, as N.T.T. was seizing market share and customer loyalty, it was also able to develop a line of cellular phones that experts say has a strong resemblance to the market leader -- Motorola's Micro-Tac lightweight fold-up design.
The United States trade representative's office reviewed the situation and decided Japan was in noncompliance with the 1989 accord. Now that the Clinton-Hosokawa meeting failed to produce a breakthrough, the trade office has decided to act.
Once the trade office declares Japan in noncompliance, the office has 30 days to publish a list of Japanese products that might be subject to retaliatory sanctions. That list would probably include Japanese cellular phone products sold in the United States. Those Japanese manufacturers, and their American customers, have the right to a hearing to argue against sanctions, but if the trade office is not convinced, it can then impose sanctions.

HEADLINE: Stocks Advance Despite Trade Tensions

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The winter skies cleared over Wall Street yesterday as the stock market rose despite the darkening trade relations between the United States and Japan.
The tensions between the two nations pushed the dollar down by nearly 5 percent against the yen, with much of the selling coming in the afternoon. Stock prices also stumbled briefly, But most of the major market indicators recovered in heavy trading. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average ended the day at 3,904.06, up 9.28 points.
Some stock traders may have interpreted the selloff in the currency markets as beneficial to stocks, at least in the short run. The cheaper dollar is expected to help American exports. But the surge in the Japanese yen could also hurt Japan's ability to rebound from the recession.
 
 
'A Bad Thing'
 "For the U.S. economy, people are going to erroneously see this selloff as a piece of good news" because it lowers the price of American exports, said David F. DeRosa, a director of foreign exchange trading at the Swiss Bank Corporation. "I'm not a diplomat, I'm just a trader. But this is a bad thing because it's in our interest to see Japan come out of this terrible recession."
Stock traders are likely to focus on the turbulent currency markets today, even though much of the economic news this week is expected to be good. The Government is to report on January's industrial production today and January's Consumer Price Index on Thursday.
Investors continue to be skittish because of the rise in short-term interest rates. "The market is looking for an excuse to trade down," said Gregory A. Nie, vice president of technical research at Kemper Securities Inc. in Chicago. "It's looking to get disappointed."
Meanwhile, some traders are looking for the yen to possibly reach a historic level of fewer than 100 to the dollar if the Japanese central bank does not intervene to support the American currency.
 
 
Dow's Retreat
 Yesterday's sharp selloff in the dollar culminated around 2:15 P.M. in a sharp drop in the bond market, possibly because of fear of renewed American inflation if Japanese-made goods rise in price. That in turn cascaded into a 15-point retreat in the Dow industrials within 15 minutes.
Currency traders were astonished to see the Clinton Administration follow up the bitter breakup of the trade talks on Friday with the threat of sanctions. Traders interpreted the threats as a deliberate attempt to bring the yen-to-dollar ratio to 100.
Still, the stock market recovered somewhat from the afternoon shakeout. Along with the Dow, the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closed with a slight gain for day, up 0.05 of a point, to 470.23. The Nasdaq composite index also closed up, rising 4.06 points, to 785.45.
But the New York Stock Exchange Composite Index dropped 0.05 point, to 261.26. The American Stock Exchange composite index closed down 2.32 points at 474.91.
Volume on the Big Board totaled 263.2 million shares, up from 213.7 million shares on Friday, when a severe snowstorm in New York City forced stock trading to end 90 minutes early.
Paramount Communications was the most actively traded stock yesterday, closing down 3/4 at 76 1/8 on volume of 4.7 million shares. Traders and analysts widely expected Viacom to win the long battle for Paramount after QVC Network reiterated yesterday that it would not sweeten its bid for Paramount.
Spectrum Information Technologies, the troubled company shaken by management disputes following the sudden resignation of its chief executive, John Sculley, was the second-most-active stock at 4.7 million shares. It closed up 1/16 at 37/16 .
 
 
Rockefeller Center
 A notable decliner yesterday was Rockefeller Center Properties, which fell 1 3/8, to 6 3/8, on volume of 1.93 million shares. An article in Barron's questioned whether Rockefeller Center was recovering enough from its rent to cover its interest payments.
Investors bid up the shares of economically sensitive stocks yesterday. Led by United Technologies, which rose 2, to 67 3/8, such companies as Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, Philip Morris, Boeing, Caterpillar, General Electric, I.B.M. and General Motors contributed the most to the 9.28-point rise in the Dow average.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasury Issues Mixed

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, with longer maturities lower on concerns that economic data due this week would be strong enough to signal another interest rate increase by the Federal Reserve.
The breakdown of trade talks between Japan and the United States also worried the market, analysts said. 
 The price of the 30-year bond fell 1/2, to 9715/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, rose to 6.44 percent, from 6.40 percent on Friday, when many markets closed early as a result of the snowstorm that hit the Northeast.
The intermediate maturities were unchanged to slightly higher, and short-term maturities were mixed.
Matthew Alexy, a goverment trading strategist at CS First Boston, believes the market's task on the economic reports this week will would be to sort through weather-related distortions while waiting for data on inflation.
With the last increase in short-term interest rates still fresh on investors' minds, traders are waiting to see if this week's reports will give the Fed grounds to tighten credit again. The central bank has already made it very clear that it will take a tough stand against inflation and economists believe that the Fed would rather have a weak economy than to have rising inflation from a strong one.
This week's economic reports begin with January industrial production today, followed by January housing data tomorrow and the January Consumer Price Index on Thursday. The index, considered the most important report of the week, is expected to be up three-tenths of a percent, according to economists surveyed by the Reuters news service , compared with two-tenths of apercent in in December.
Some traders say the data should cause the 30-year bond to trade in a range between 6.25 and 6.50 percent, with the range holding at least until the February economic data starts to come in, they said.
The market is also concerned that the Fed's last interest rate increase may have been one sign in a series, traders said. '
'I think we have reached some turning point with the psychology of professional traders turning negative," said Mark J. Grant, managing director for fixed income at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross. "Any statement by the Fed on the short will be felt by the long end as well."
Bad inflation numbers could force another move by the Fed in February or early March, he said. But he does not see an exodus from the fixed-income market. "About 70 percent of fixed-income money remains some place in the debt market without any great dislocation," he said.
Mr. Grant said the market lacked any follow-through trading on concerns that a trade war might develop between the United States . and Japan after trade talks collapsed on Friday.
The Japanese stock market, which closes hours before the United States market opens, was down sharply in what was seen as disappointment over the failure of the talks. "This may have set the tone for our own market at the opening bell," Mr. Grant said.
Analysts at C. J. Lawrence said some people in the market believed that the dollar's drop against the yen could cause Japanese investors to sell dollar-denominated holdings, much of which are in Treasury securities.
 
Release of Economic Report
 The only economic report released yesterday was the December business inventories report, which had little impact on bond prices. Besides being old data, the number was unchanged from the six-tenths of 1 percent rise in November, and pretty much what the bond market expected.
Elsewhere, yesterday's weekly auction of new Treasury three- and six-month bills was regarded by some as another solid auction, while others viewed it a little sloppy that left dealers holding a sizable chunk of the auction issue.
The average rates at auction rose a few basis points from the previous week, with the three-month bill up to 3.28 percent from 3.24 percent. The rate on the six-month bill rose to 3.43 percent from 3.40 percent.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Employer Health Costs Still Rise

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
The growth in medical spending by employers is easing, but their costs are still rising much faster than the 3 percent general inflation rate, according to a national survey released yesterday.
The survey showed that the average cost of care was $3,781 an employee last year, an increase of 8 percent, compared with 10.1 percent in 1992 and ending a five-year string of dougle-digit growth. 
 Corporate benefits managers said that in spite of efforts to control costs, health care continued to be a big problem for them and their employees.
 
 
Costs 'Out of Line'
 "We still have a crisis," said Margaret Jordan, a vice president for health care and employee services at Southern California Edison, a unit of SCEcorp. "Costs that are almost three times the rate of inflation are out of line."
Employers and politicians are closely watching the cost trends as Congress weighs proposals for sweeping changes in the health care system.
David Rahill, a principal at Foster Higgins, the benefits consulting firm that conducted the survey, suggested that some Clinton Administration cost estimates were unrealistically low. He said an employer's average insurance premium for a single employee would be $2,175 in 1994, nearly 13 percent higher than the Administration's projection of $1,932.
But Walter Zelman, a senior health care adviser in the Administration, said premiums were high "because millions of uninsured people are being paid for by those who are insured." In the new system, he said, "more people will be insured and the cost of each policy will come down."
 
 
Rise for Open-Ended Plans
 A growing number of employers have shifted to lower-cost health maintenance organizations and managed-health-care plans, which include networks of doctors and hospitals that offer discounted fees. The steepest price increases were in the increasingly popular open-ended H.M.O.'s, which permit members to select an outside doctor if the patient pays more of the costs.
The survey of 2,395 employers was conducted by Foster Higgins with help from the Research Triangle Institute, a nonprofit research organization in North Carolina.
Mr. Rahill attributed the slower growth in employer spending last year to rising competition among managed-care plans and a movement by doctors, hospitals and insurance companies to delay price increases temporarily "in the hopes of heading off Draconian health care reform measures in Washington."
 
Varying Rates of Increase
 Uwe E. Reinhardt, a Princeton University health care economist, said medical inflation typically abates when the subject is being debated in Congress, only to "explode whenever a medical cost law is written and the lawyers and accountants teach everyone how to get around it."
The cost per employee of traditional health plans, which give employees complete freedom to choose a doctor, rose 7.1 percent, to $3,500. The discount networks, called preferred-provider organizations, were up 5.5 percent, to $3,317, and costs for H.M.O.'s without the open-ended feature rose 6.5 percent, to $3,276.
Open-ended health maintenance organizations were the least expensive, at $3,266 an employee, but their cost increases averaged 8.9 percent.
Health care costs in the Northeast were highest, at $4,267 a worker, up 10.1 percent, the survey said, compared with $3,262 in the South, the least expensive region. The increase in the South was only 6.6 percent.
Donna Lynne, executive director of the New York Business Group on Health, a group of employers, said the greater prevalence of open-ended H.M.O.'s in the Northeast might account for the big jump in costs for that region.

HEADLINE: Fight Looms on Tax Cuts in New Jersey

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Feb. 14

 BODY:
New Jersey residents are virtually certain to get some level of state tax relief this year. But a struggle over the form and size of any tax cut is just beginning.
In the month since Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, a Republican, took office with a pledge to deliver the largest tax cut in state history, even the Democrats have weighed in with tax-cutting plans of their own. 
 With Republicans controlling the State House and the Legislature, whatever tax-cut plan emerges will bear their stamp. But a number of Republican legislators have questioned, as have the Democrats, whether the Whitman plan goes far enough to help the middle-class taxpayer.
Some Republicans have also openly hinted that with former Gov. Jim Florio, a Democrat, removed as a political foil, they might be more willing to listen to Democrats' ideas than they were during the last two budget debates.
 
Other Plans Follow Whitman's
 In her inaugural address on Jan. 18, Mrs. Whitman surprised the audience and many legislators with a call for tax cuts retroactive to Jan. 1. They would reduce the state income tax by 5 percent for all taxpayers, eliminate income taxes entirely for people making $7,500 (the cutoff now is $3,000) and cut the state's corporate tax rate to 9 percent, from 9.375 percent. She said it was the first step toward keeping a campaign promise to cut taxes by $1.5 billion, including the state income tax by 30 percent for some taxpayers, in her first three years in office.
Since then, four tax-cut plans have emerged in as many weeks -- two unified and nearly identical Republican bills that would give the weight of law to Mrs. Whitman's ideas, and two separate and widely differing bills sponsored by two high-ranking members of the Democratic minority who say their ideas are more equitable to the middle class.
"It should be encouraging for Whitman that she now has many of the people in her camp who were arguing that she couldn't or shouldn't cut taxes," said Dr. Milton Leontiades, dean of the Rutgers University School of Business at Camden. "The argument now is over details."
There is a wealth of politicking behind each party's tax-cut plans.
 
G.O.P. Has to Follow Through
 Republicans took control of the Legislature two years ago by campaigning against Mr. Florio's $2.8 billion tax increase, and Mrs. Whitman was able to unseat Mr. Florio last November largely on the basis of her late campaign promise to cut taxes.
With their political fortunes on the line, the Republicans, especially Mrs. Whitman, are compelled to follow through on some kind of cut, even in the face of daunting fiscal problems, including a potential $2 billion gap in the next state budget.
"It's relatively easy when you are running for office to say you are going to cut taxes," said Dr. Leontiades, the Rutgers business school dean. "The devil's in the details, and that's what Mrs. Whitman is up against now.
"The first retroactive pay cut of 5 percent is going to be the easy one because there is money left over from the Florio administration to pay for it," he said. "The next one is the 10 percent income-tax cut and she doesn't have the money set aside, and that is going to cause a little more head-scratching. And the third cut is really going to run into problems."
Politically, the Democrats -- who backed Mr. Florio four years ago in the largest tax increase in New Jersey's history -- hope to use taxes in the same way the Republicans did against them.
Even if the Democrats' tax-cut plans do not reach the floor for a vote, they will still gain political capital by publicizing the disparity of benefits in the Republican plans between middle-class taxpayers and wealthier ones. If the Republicans are pressured into adopting some of the Democrats' ideas, it will give the minority party clout far beyond its numbers.
Asked during a news conference last week about Democratic tax-cut plans, the Assembly Speaker, Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, initially responded that they were "dead on arrival," but immediately backed off and said they would be considered.
Mrs. Whitman has asked the Legislature to have her initial tax-cut plan in place by March 15, the date of her budget address. The new budget must be completed by July 1, the start of the state's fiscal year.
Prodded by Mr. Haytaian, the Assembly moved within a week of the inauguration to back the Republican Governor and introduced a three-bill package that would achieve Mrs. Whitman's first year tax-cut goals.
Senate Republicans introduced an identical package on Feb. 1, but went one step further than the Governor and the Assembly by committing $285 million in surplus money to pay for the proposed cuts.
Last Tuesday, the Assistant Senate Democratic Minority Leader, Richard J. Codey, introduced tax-cut legislation that he said would shift the financial benefits away from the wealthy and toward lower- and middle-income taxpayers.
Two days later, Mr. Codey's Democratic counterpart in the Assembly, Wayne R. Bryant, offered a fourth tax-cut plan in which middle- and lower-income taxpayers would benefit through increased deductions instead of lowered tax rates.
Each of the plans has been advertised as a middle-class tax cut.
But previous legislative attempts to fashion tax cuts to benefit middle- and lower-income taxpayers have been more about politics than windfall benefits for those economic blocs. In part, that is because of the state's graduated tax structure.
For example, each plan would eliminate income tax entirely for people making $7,500 or less, producing an average tax saving of $66 a year for them. But it also would mean that the first $7,500 of everyone's pay would be exempt from state income taxes, regardless of income. The same standard would apply throughout the ranges of tax liability.
 
Whitman Cuts Favor Richest
 According to the nonpartisan Office of Legislative Services, that would mean that under Mrs. Whitman's plan, the nearly 1.5 million families in the income range of $7,501 to $40,000 -- the largest single bloc among the nearly 3.2 million resident tax filers in New Jersey -- would save, on average, $24 a year. Resident filers making $150,001 to $300,000 -- there are 63,347 of them -- would average $517 in tax savings.
The centerpiece of Mr. Codey's plan is a proposal to cap Mrs. Whitman's 5 percent tax cut at $100,000 in income for married couples and at $50,000 for single taxpayers. He would then give bigger tax breaks to those with less income -- 6 percent cuts to those making $50,001 to $80,000; 7 percent for income levels of $20,000 to $50,000; and 9 percent to those making below $20,000.
Under Mr. Codey's plan, those in the $7,501 to $40,000 income range would save $40 a year on average ($16 more than under the Whitman plan), and those with $150,001 to $300,000 would save $216 (more than $300 less than in Mrs. Whitman's plan.)
Mr. Bryant has gone far afield of the other plans by abandoning all tax-rate reduction strategies except for the idea of exempting those taxpayers making $7,500 or less. Instead, under Mr. Bryant's plan, deductions for a married couple making under $150,000 would double to $2,000 and the dependent deduction for each child would double to $3,000.
He also would allow a deduction up to $100 for income interest and dividends, in a bid to give middle-class families an incentive to save.

HEADLINE: Reviews/Television;
Diagnosis for a Dismal Emergency Room: Incurable

BYLINE: By JOHN J. O'CONNOR

 BODY:
HBO Showcase drifts into commercial-television territory with "State of Emergency," the kind of hospital story that has been a staple of prime time ever since we all loved Lucy. There is a difference. Not in thrall to advertisers, HBO can be grittier and tougher. Starring Joe Mantegna, a leading member of David Mamet's personal repertory company, as a bitterly overworked and underappreciated physician in a Los Angeles public hospital, "State of Emergency" refuses to play television's typical uplift game. It can next be seen on HBO tonight at 8.
Dr. John Novelli (Mr. Mantegna) is already juggling 20 patients when a Mr. Anderson (Paul Dooley) is wheeled into the overcrowded emergency room, the victim of a car accident. Suffering from head injuries, Anderson desperately needs a CAT scan, but the hospital's apparatus is not working. That's not unusual, but this case is different. Neither poor nor desperate, Anderson is a middle-class executive with a wife (Melinda Dillon) not about to tolerate what she deems to be neglect and incompetence. 
 When bad gets worse, Dr. Novelli, who insists that "it's not my fault that trickle-down economics never got around to trickling down," finds himself trapped in the hospital's ambitious and -- as the film implies -- immoral plan to close its public clinics and evolve into a high-tech facility. In theory, everybody should have a place to go when they're sick. In practice, this is just, as someone says, "another crummy public hospital" costing the taxpayers money. "State of Emergency" should be required viewing for all lawmakers considering new health policies.
The film can get preachy. "It's a war zone down there," we're told. "Too many people and not enough resources." And some of its statistics sound strained. Supposedly, one in three Americans will wind up in an emergency room this year. That's hard to believe. Some, obviously, will be more frequent visitors than others.
But this HBO presentation vividly illustrates that the average hospital emergency room is, as Dr. Novelli puts it, "your basic apocalypse." It's hardly surprising to learn that Lance Gentile, who is listed as co-writer with Susan Black, is himself an emergency-room doctor. His harrowing portrait is brought powerfully to life by Mr. Mantegna and company.

State of Emergency
HBO, tonight at 8.
 
Directed by Leslie Linka Glatter; written by Susan Black and Lance Gentile; director of photography, Frank Byers; editors, Hubert de La Bouillerie and Tracy S. Granger; music by Robert Folk; produced by John P. Marsh and Jay Roewe for Chestnut Hill Productions; presented by HBO Showcase; Jeffrey Lurie and Colin Callender, executive producers.
 
WITH: Joe Mantegna, Lynn Whitfield, Melinda Dillon and Paul Dooley.

HEADLINE: A Piece of Fiscal Folly

 BODY:
Two Senate hearings are scheduled today on one pesky proposal -- a balanced-budget amendment to the Constitution. This idea is fiscal sleight-of-hand at its most devious, a solemn pledge by the current crowd that some future Congress will finally balance the budget.
The amendment stipulates that the budget must be balanced two years after ratification -- or in 2001, whichever is later -- and forever after, except in wartime or unless three-fifths of both the Senate and the House approve a deficit. 
 The amendment's rigidity is folly. Fiscal policy must be flexible; the amendment is not. The sponsors say it doesn't rule out deficits in recession years -- if a three-fifths majority in Congress approves. But that means a two-fifths minority could call the shots, refusing to go along with a deficit unless the budget met minority members' demands. In effect, this would raise the rationale of the Senate's hoary filibuster rules to the level of national fiscal policy.
Proponents also argue that state governments live with balanced-budget requirements; why not the Federal Government, too? States typically balance revenues and operating expenses, but borrow for capital expenses. The Federal budget does not separate the two. States also concoct all sorts of gimmickry to make unbalanced accounts appear to be balanced. The amendment would invite the same kinds of trickery in Washington, starting with spurious estimates of anticipated spending and revenues.
Finally, if a deficit developed without prior approval, how would the amendment be enforced? Courts are not equipped to make fiscal policy, and Federal judges are not elected; they are Presidential appointees, for life. If indeed there were a "violation," they would be asked for political decisions: What did Congress mean by a "receipt"? An "outlay"? The effect would cripple the constitutional separation of powers.
The amendment's chief sponsor is Senator Paul Simon, the Illinois Democrat who heads the Judiciary Subcommittee on the Constitution, with hearings at 8:30 A.M. today. The 54 co-sponsors are liberals, conservatives and in between. If the full Senate approves their simplistic scheme, by the two-thirds majority required to amend the Constitution, it is expected the House would, too. It would then have to be ratified by 38 states.
The President is against it. So are George Mitchell of Maine, the Senate majority leader, and House Speaker Thomas Foley of Washington. So is Senator Robert Byrd of West Virginia, chairman of the Appropriations Committee, whose hearings start 90 minutes after Senator Simon's.
According to the Constitution that Senator Simon wants to amend, Federal spending and revenues are the business of the President and Congress. Cluttering the document with mischievous language will not get them off the hook.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Misperceptions Permeate and Poison Our Relations With China

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In "Chinese Economy Threatens to Pull Ours Down" (letter Feb. 3), C. K. Chen attributes the growing United States trade deficit with China to China's failure to reform its internal markets more rapidly. In doing so, he repeats an error that permeates and poisons our relations with China: that is, treating China as different, distinct, unique. 
 Any economist will verify that our $23 billion trade deficit with China has at least two other, more important causes:
(1) It reflects simply a spreading around of our traditional imbalance with Japan and Taiwan, a deficit in excess of $100 billion, which is now shifting to China as the manufacturing facilities of those countries move to the mainland. Why blame China?
(2) Our "East Asian" trade deficit is in effect forced upon these countries by our own Government, which enters the bond market every year to borrow the roughly $200 billion needed to finance our budget deficit. When United States savers prove insufficiently abstemious to come up with such sums at home, where else can we look but to our Asian neighbors (who love to save)? Why blame Asia?
But how much easier, always, to place blame elsewhere. And so we hear the drumbeat begin, calling together an improbable triad of anti-Communists, human rights activists and domestic protectionists, who hope to force tariffs on China's exports up to Smoot-Hawley levels. I agree that we must engage with China on all these issues.
However, using most-favored-nation status to induce change in China is about as finely calibrated as a car bomb. Push the button, and the impact, on us and on China, will be disastrous.
 
BRUCE L. REYNOLDS
Editor, China Economic Review
Ithaca, N.Y., Feb. 5, 1994

LENGTH: 1407 words

HEADLINE: What Is 'Universal' Is Center Of Fight Over a Health Plan

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15

 BODY:
Universal insurance coverage has become the touchstone of the debate over health care. President Clinton threatens to veto legislation "that does not guarantee every American private health insurance that can never be taken away."
But what precisely does universal coverage mean? How would it be administered? Would everyone voluntarily enroll in a health plan? Would the Government force people to buy insurance? 
 By exalting universal coverage as the paramount goal of a health plan, the President has made the definition of the term a central part of the political fight developing on Capitol Hill.
 
Every Legal Resident Protected
 Mr. Clinton's plan calls for every legal resident of the United States to have protection against health care costs at all times. Employers would bear most of the costs for their workers by paying health insurance premiums, but workers and other consumers would be expected to contribute. The Government would raise new revenue by increasing tobacco taxes and would subsidize coverage for low-wage workers and the unemployed.
Other proposals before Congress are also intended to provide universal coverage.
Nearly 39 million Americans, representing 15.4 percent of the population, lack health insurance on any given day, acccording to the Employee Benefit Research Institute, a nonpartisan organization whose members include businesses and labor unions. Over the course of a year, as many as 53 million people may be without insurance for a month or more, the institute says.
There are many reasons universal coverage may not equal 100 percent. Finding everyone to be covered is one problem. The Census Bureau tries to count everyone in the country, but by its own estimate it missed at least 1.6 percent of the population in 1990, with larger undercounts in earlier censuses.
Getting people to pay the insurance premiums is another potential problem. While nearly everyone is eligible for Social Security, many domestic workers are not covered because their employers did not withhold Social Security taxes from their pay as required by law.
And strange as it may seem, the people who run social programs have found they must make aggressive efforts to induce people to sign up for benefits to which they are entitled, like food stamps and Medicaid. Millions of poor people, homeless people and immigrants do not avail themselves of care for which they are now eligible at community health centers.
 
Access to Insurance
 Administration officials say the requirement for universal coverage distinguishes Mr. Clinton's plan from others that seek merely to increase access to health care. Yet Mr. Clinton's plan and most of the other health care proposals pending in Congress fall short of universal coverage in one sense: They generally do not cover illegal aliens, of which the Census Bureau estimates that there are four million.
Mr. Clinton would require employers to pay at least 80 percent of health insurance premiums for their workers. Representative Jim Cooper, Democrat of Tennessee, has introduced a bill that would make insurance easily available to most people. But that bill, which has bipartisan support, would not require consumers to buy insurance or employers to pay for it and so would not guarantee universal coverage.
Mr. Cooper's bill would create large pools of consumers to buy insurance voluntarily, and he estimates that 80 percent of the uninsured would obtain coverage by this means within a few years. Under his bill, a Federal agency would study the remaining uninsured population and advise Congress how to achieve fuller coverage.
Thus, Mr. Cooper says, "our plan can achieve universal coverage on the same timetable as the President, by 1998, without an employer mandate." White House officials and Congressional supporters of the Clinton bill dispute that.
Nothing in the bill would prevent people from delaying the purchase of insurance until they needed care. But there would be a penalty for those who did: coverage of their existing medical problems could be denied for six months. Such people might then have to spend more of their own money on treatment.
 
Waiting for an Emergency
 Robert M. Ball, a former Commissioner of Social Security, says: "Universal coverage means that every legal resident of the United States would have protection against health care costs at all times, as in Canada or Britain. That is feasible. There is no reason why anybody should be left out at any time."
But Robert J. Myers, who served as chief actuary of the Social Security Administration from 1947 to 1970, predicted that some people would remain uninsured and "wait till a medical emergency occurs, then go to a hospital and get free care."
Anticipating this, the Clinton plan would establish procedures to enroll people at the precise moment they seek health care. As a penalty for their failure to obtain insurance earlier, the plan would have these people pay twice the amount of all the premiums they would have paid if they had enrolled when they were supposed to.
Hawaii has made a commitment to see that all of its 1.2 million residents have health insurance. To do so, it created the kind of requirement for employers to provide coverage that has been a point of bitter contention in the Clinton plan.
By most accounts, Hawaii's program has been a success. But the state's health director, Dr. John C. Lewin, says 3 percent of Hawaiians still lack coverage, and the Census Bureau estimated that 6.8 percent of Hawaiians were uninsured in 1990-92.
Mr. Clinton's plan requires consumers to get health insurance. It says, "Each eligible individual (other than a Medicare-eligible individual) must enroll in an applicable health plan for the individual and must pay any premium required." .
Moreover, the Clinton proposal says health plans may not cancel, limit or restrict coverage "for any reason, including nonpayment of premiums."
Obviously, Mr. Clinton assumes that most people want health insurance and would voluntarily sign up for it. But under his bill, the enforcement power of the Federal Government would be available if needed to make consumers and employers pay for coverage.
The President's plan says the Labor Secretary shall provide the regional insurance-buying pools with "such technical and other assistance as may promote the efficient collection" of premiums. Such assistance could include fines of up to $5,000 or three times the amount of the liability owed, whichever is greater.
 
Alternative Proposals
 Under a bill introduced by Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, every citizen and lawful permanent resident would have to obtain coverage by Jan. 1, 2005.
Another bill, sponsored by Senator Don Nickles, Republican from Oklahoma, offers tax credits to help consumers buy health insurance. "Under our plan," Mr. Nickles said, "everybody would have to have health insurance to cover expenses above $1,000." Consumers would lose the personal tax exemption, $2,350 for 1993, if they did not buy such insurance.
A third bill, by Representative Jim McDermott, Democrat of Washington, would enroll all people in a national health insurance program by 1995. The program would be designed and financed by the Government, and children would be automatically enrolled at birth. Mr. McDermott has proposed a variety of tax increases to pay for this "single-payer" scheme.
 
Social Security Comparison
 The Clinton plan would provide health insurance for the 38.9 million people who have no coverage. At the same time, millions of people who now get coverage through their employers would switch to new insurance bought through the regional cooperatives, which could be either state government agencies or private nonprofit organizations. Companies with more than 5,000 employees could operate their own health plans.
Such sweeping changes would be much different from the gradual process by which Social Security was expanded to cover nearly the entire population over three decades. The program was created in 1935, and in its early years, it did not cover agricultural workers, domestic workers or the self-employed.
"Our thinking back then," Mr. Myers said, "was that we wanted to get the system going, keep records and collect taxes, then extend coverage to other groups. In theory, everybody should be covered. But in practice, let's do what's doable. That was our thinking."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Coverage: Health Care Plans Compared"
 
CLINTON PLAN:
 White House's proposed legislation. Goal: Universal coverage by 1998.
 
Approach: All American citizens and legal residents would have to obtain a comprehensive health benefits package. Most people would get coverage through large insurance purchasing cooperatives called health alliances.
 
Financing: Businesses would required to pay at least 80 percent of premiums for their employees. Small companies, early retirees and people with incomes below certain levels would get Federal subsidies..
 
SINGLE-PAYER PLAN
 Sponsored by Represenetative Jim McDermott, Democrat of Washington, and Senator Paul Wellstone, Democrat of Minnesota. Goal: Universal coverage by 1995.
 
Approach: All American citizens and legal residents would be automatically enrolled in a national health insurance program established by the Federal Government and administered by the states.
 
Financing: Private insurance premiums would be replaced with a combination of payroll taxes on employers (4 percent for small companies and 8.4 percent for larger ones), a 2.1 percent tax on individuals' taxable income and new or steeper taxes on tobacco, handguns and ammunition.
 
COOPER PLAN:
 Sponsored by Representative Jim Cooper, Democrat of Tennessee. Goal: Universal access to health coverage. Sponsors say that with insurance more afforable, 80 percent of uninsured would voluntarily get coverage.
 
Approach: Relies on a voluntary program to cover all American citizens and legal residents through insurance reforms, the creation of insurance purchasing cooperatives and subsidies for the poor.
 
Financing: Would pay for subsidies by reducing Medicare and Medicaid spending. Would cap tax deductions that employers may take for contributions to employee health plans.
 
CHAFEE:
 Sponsored by Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island. Goal: Universal coverage by 2005.
 
Approach: All American citizens and legal residents would have to buy coverage through a qualified health plan. All employers would be required to offer their employees enrollment in a qualified health plan, but would not have to pay for it. Subsidies would be available for low-income individuals.
 
Financing: Would pay for subsidies by reducing Medicare and Medicaid spending. (pg. A11)

HEADLINE: North Koreans Agree to Survey Of Atomic Sites

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 15

 BODY:
Acting to avert a confrontation with the West, North Korea reversed itself today and told the International Atomic Energy Agency that it would permit a full inspection of seven sites that are thought to be part of a nuclear-weapons program.
The surprise announcement came less than a week before the agency's board is to meet in Vienna, where it was expected to declare that North Korea's refusal to allow inspections violated international accords. 
 United States officials had said that such a declaration would have sent the issue to the Security Council, where the possibility of economic sanctions had appeared increasingly likely.
 
Taking Edge Off Tension
 United States officials in Washington welcomed North Korea's decision but said the Administration would delay any steps to improve ties with North Korea until the inspectors complete their work. [Page A8.]
The decision seemed to defuse much of the tension that had built up over North Korea's refusal to permit inspections, particularly since the North had said repeatedly that sanctions would be regarded as an act of war.
While the announcement will solve the short-term impasse with the atomic energy agency, it falls far short of meeting all the West's demands.
The inspections, for example, would be limited to sites that North Korea has already declared part of its nuclear complex at Yongbyon, 60 miles north of Pyongyang, the capital. They would not cover two other sites that the United States suspects are waste dumps for weapons-grade plutonium.
In effect, North Korea agreed today to accept the first step in an inspection process that was ordered a year ago, when the Government abruptly said it would pull out of the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty because of what it said were unwarranted intrusions on its sovereignty. North Korea later "suspended" its withdrawal from the treaty but still refused to allow inspections.
 
Question of 'the Bomb' Remains
 Even if inspections are conducted at the seven sites, they almost certainly will not solve the most vexing question: whether North Korea has a nuclear bomb.
"If the intelligence agencies are right and they have built one or two, they are certainly not at Yongbyon," one senior United States intelligence official said recently.
In a statement today in Vienna, its headquarters, the International Atomic Energy Agency said the objective of its inspection would be "to verify that nuclear material in these facilities has not been diverted since earlier inspections."
The agency also said its team would reload cameras at the sites "to facilitate future verification." But it was unclear whether North Korea had agreed to anything beyond a one-time inspection.
The negotiations leading up to North Korea's decision today have been complicated and melodramatic, with reports of breakthroughs followed by reports of new impasses.
In January, for instance, the Clinton Administration said it had won agreement for an I.A.E.A. inspection of North Korea's nuclear sites, and it proclaimed the accord a major step forward that might lead to reciprocal measures, including cancellation of military exercises that North Korea deems threatening.
Later, however, the International Atomic Energy Agency said North Korea had refused to agree to the terms that the agency had laid out for a full inspection.
After a standoff that lasted for weeks, North Korea agreed today to inspection of the seven sites after all.
Some analysts said that, for all its heated threats, North Korea was afraid the Security Council would impose economic sanctions.
"I think they realized that their chances in the Security Council did not look very good," a United States official who has been deeply involved in the talks said today. "But this inspection will only set the base line. It will not solve the fundamental questions. We still have a long way to go."
 
Survey Could Take 3 Weeks
 Officials also said more information about North Korea's intentions could come from a visit to Pyongyang later this week by Representative Ronald V. Dellums, a California Democrat and chairman of the Armed Services Committee. Mr. Dellums is expected to meet with President Kim Il Sung, who rules North Korea like a dictator.
If North Korea finally allows inspections, officials at the International Atomic Energy Agency said, it would take at least three weeks for the team of six or seven inspectors to complete their survey.
A satisfactory report should clear the way for talks between North Korea and the United States over broader inspections and North Korea's return to the treaty, in return for economic and political incentives.
Inspectors last visited Yongbyon during the summer. Their access was sharply limited, and they have been barred from returning.
Since early January, after it reached what appeared to be a significant agreement with the United States, North Korea has angrily refused to go along with the conditions set by the atomic energy agency, which is an arm of the United Nations.
 
Strong Words From the North
 The Government repeatedly denounced the agency as a "lackey" of the United States. But today Yun Ho Jin, a North Korean diplomat in Vienna, delivered a letter to the agency declaring that his Government had accepted the agency's explanations about why it must conduct thorough inspections of all seven sites and replace batteries and film in surveillance cameras.
"There was no explanation," said David Kyd, a spokesman for the agency. "They simply agreed to all of the measures. They seemed to want to keep the process moving."
Officials speculated that today's announcement was timed to circumvent any talk of sanctions at next week's meeting of the agency's board.
The director general of the agency, Hans Blix, had been preparing to declare that the North had broken the "continuity" of inspections, language that would have forced the Security Council to take up the issue.
Such a move may yet be necessary. In the United States and among its Pacific allies, many officials have argued that North Korea was simply bluffing, holding the agency at bay, then allowing inspections at the last possible moment, but still not revealing its full hand.
Many believe the inspection announcement today may just be another step in that process, buying the North a few more weeks.
 
A Taste of the Carrot
 On the other hand President Kim, who is 81 and a canny survivor, may have decided that the economic opportunity of an opening toward the United States was too great to pass up. With the economy in shambles -- the gross national product has declined four years in a row -- Mr. Kim needs investment more than he needs bombs.
Assuming the inspection takes place without problems, the United States is likely to try to cajole the North into implementing its agreement with South Korea to keep the peninsula free of nuclear weapons. Washington has already said it would offer an assurance that it would not be the first to use nuclear weapons. But it is still unclear if the North would agree to inspections so rigorous that they would crimp its ability to extract plutonium.
One possible incentive to the North may be an offer from Washington to cancel this year's joint military exercise with South Korea, an exercise that the North regularly denounces as a "nuclear war preparation." Even without an inspection agreement, American and South Korean officials had planned a vastly scaled-down exercise in an effort not to provoke the North.
But it is unclear if the United States would go ahead with its planned deployment of Patriot missiles in South Korea. That deployment is to begin in March, but officials have hinted that it, too, might be reconsidered.

HEADLINE: The Yen's Rise Forces a Reassessment in Japan

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 15

 BODY:
Just days after Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa's firm stand against American trade demands met widespread approval at home, the damaging surge in the value of the yen has sent waves of anxiety through the business community and reversed sentiment about the wisdom of a confrontation with the United States.
Corporate executives and economists initially extolled the pluses of a more assertive Japan after trade talks with the United States collapsed last Friday. Mr. Hosokawa had rejected President Clinton's demand that Japan guarantee increased levels of imports, or targets, to insure reductions in Japan's yawning trade surplus. 
 But by Monday, after the yen had jumped more than 4 percent against the dollar, they were focusing on the pain the soaring yen is likely to inflict in the form of falling exports and an even weaker economy in the midst of a deep recession.
 
Prime Minister Criticized
 Many experts are now saying the Prime Minister should have prevented the sudden jump in the yen's value by countering with his own program for reviving the faltering economy and removing the blanket of regulations that hampers entry to foreigners. Such initiatives might have averted the sudden rise in trade tensions and the resurgent yen.
Since there was no agreement, traders and investors have pushed the value of the yen higher and the dollar lower because they assume that the Clinton Administration will favor this as an alternative means of pressuring the Japanese back to the bargaining table.
"I fully support Hosokawa's rejection of market targets," said Toshihiro Kiribuchi, the executive managing director of the Omron Corporation, a leading electronics manufacturer. "But at the same time I fully support the United States point of view on the general economic issues. Mr. Hosokawa should have come up with a counterproposal with a concrete schedule for removing regulation over the economy and for more stimulus."
Kazuo Nukazawa, the managing director of Keidanren, Japan's leading business lobbying organization, added: "Mr. Hosokawa is not much of an economist, but certainly his sense of urgency might be increased by what is happening with the yen. What we want is more expansionary measures and that they be taken as swiftly as possible."
The rise of the yen halted today, at least temporarily, after the Bank of Japan reportedly spent nearly $1 billion buying dollars and selling yen in an effort to halt the surge. In New York trading, 100 yen were worth 96.3 cents, down from 97.8 cents Monday. In the traditional way of expressing the exchange value, the dollar rose to 103.85 yen, up from 102.25 yen on Monday, a six-month low for the dollar and high for the yen and just off the record low for the dollar since World II.
But the one-day stabilization of the yen did not calm the stock market. The Nikkei index of 225 issues fell 484.65 points, or 2.5 percent, to 18,974.60 and is down more than 5 percent in the last two days.
[Stocks rebounded here somewhat on Wednesday. The Nikkei rose 77.51 points, or about four tenths of 1 percent, to 19,052.11.]
 A strong yen is a powerful but blunt weapon for the United States. It makes imported goods less expensive for Japanese consumers and raises the price of Japanese exports, thus crimping overseas sales of Japanese goods.
It can also force manufacturers to cut prices at home because of competition from cheap imports. That would tend to reduce Japan's trade surplus, but would also slow economic growth.
If President Clinton was consciously using exchange rates to pressure Japan into action -- something many people here suspect -- it appears to be working.
The front pages of all the big newspapers this afternoon carried articles prominently listing the latest yen exchange rate, with warnings of its negative impact on the already fragile economy.
Economists were predicting that if the yen remained at its current levels, it would deepen the two-year-old recession, increase unemployment and possibly put the stock market into a prolonged tailspin.
"If we continue to have a strong yen for the next few months, there's no recovery," Hirohiko Okumura, the chief economist at the Nomura Research Institute, said. "Even the strongest electronics companies cannot make money at these levels."
He said that while he had forecast economic growth this year of as much as 1 percent, a strong yen could turn that into a 1 percent decline, a big setback for the world's second- largest economy.

HEADLINE: Cabinet Officers Assail Balanced-Budget Bill

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15

 BODY:
Jabbing at every exposed political nerve it could find, the Clinton Administration told Congress today that a Federal balanced-budget amendment would imperil the national defense, increase crime, cheat veterans, squeeze the elderly and weaken the economy.
Analyzing how cuts would affect the economy and their departments, five Cabinet officers testified today against a proposed amendment that would require the Federal budget to be balanced, probably by the year 2001. The Senate plans to begin debating the measure next Tuesday, and neither side is sure how the vote will go. 
 The Cabinet officers appeared before Senator Robert C. Byrd, the West Virginia Democrat who heads the Appropriations Committee and is the amendment's staunchest enemy. He variously called the amendment "seductive," "simplistic," "this monstrosity" and "this nefarious proposal."
Senator Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois, who is the amendment's chief sponsor, sought to counter Mr. Byrd's display with a hearing of his own. He told the Judiciary Subcommittee on the Constitution, which he heads, that "no one can study the past 25 years of successive deficits without recognizing that there has been governmental abuse that must be halted."
 
Injection of Discipline
 Mr. Simon's leading witness was Paul E. Tsongas, the former Massachusetts Senator and Presidential contender, who said the amendment was a necessary "mechanism of discipline" to make Congress undertake the sacrifices required to balance the budget.
"This deficit is all too real, this debt all too crippling," Mr. Tsongas said. "Only a balanced budget amendment can inject the discipline to achieve this indispensable end."
A two-thirds vote, or 67 if all senators vote, is required to pass a Constitutional amendment. The House is expected to take the measure up later this year. If both chambers pass it with two-thirds majorities, then it would become part of the Constitution if approved within seven years by the legislatures of 38 states.
The Administration and Mr. Byrd are working to mobilize opposition to the proposal, which does not specify how the budget should be balanced. That gives different supporters the chance to offer different solutions, or none at all, which was what Senator Don Nickles, Republican of Oklahoma, offered today when Mr. Byrd asked him how he would eliminate the current fiscal year's deficit, now about $220 billion.
 
Grim Pictures
 On Monday at the White House, Administration officials told reporters of their opposition to the proposal. Today, the Administration took the battle to Capitol Hill, with Leon E. Panetta, director of the Office of Management and Budget, painting a grim picture of the uncertainties the amendment would thrust on the economy and four other Cabinet heads outlining probable cuts in their departments. Each assumed that their departments would have to share in spending cuts in proportion to how much they now spend.
Defense Secretary William J. Perry outlined more troop cuts, of 60,000 to 270,000, listed weapons that would have to be abandoned and said the amendment would inject "great uncertainty, and, I do not think it is hyperbole to say, chaos, into our defense planning."
Attorney General Janet Reno asserted that the amendment would undermine the Justice Department's ability to fight violence and that its passage would lead to "gutting the heart and soul of the Senate-passed crime bill."
She said that with such an amendment, prison spending would be reduced and violent offenders released to prevent crowding.
Jesse Brown, Secretary of Veterans Affairs, predicted that 20 Veterans Administration hospitals would be closed, burial in national cemeteries denied to 12,000 veterans a year, and the average annual compensation paid to veterans with service-related disabilities reduced to $4,968 from $5,602.
Donna E. Shalala, Secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services, warned that the amendment, which permits deficit spending but only with three-fifths votes in both houses, would force the deepest cuts in "safety net" programs when they were needed most, in a recession.
In a similar vein, Mr. Panetta said that by forbidding any lift to the economy with an infusion of Government spending during a recession, "we would be doing exactly the wrong thing."
Chiding the amendment's supporters for requiring a three-fifths majority to allow deficit spending, Mr. Panetta asked, "Why can't they get a majority to tell us how they would cut the budget?"

HEADLINE: Lawmaker Meets Again With Burmese Dissident

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 15

 BODY:
The American lawmaker who was allowed to meet om Monday with Daw Aung San Suu Kyi at her home in Myanmar said today that he was "cautiously optimistic" that the Burmese military Government would soon agree to negotiate with her.
The lawmaker, Representative Bill Richardson, Democrat of New Mexico, led the first delegation of foreign visitors permitted to see Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi since she was placed under house arrest in 1989 for her efforts to promote democracy in her country. 
 The delegation met with her for three hours on Monday, and Mr. Richardson had a second, two-and-a-half hour meeting with her today.
"I am cautiously optimistic that the proposal for a face-to-face discussion with Aung San Suu Kyi will be accepted," Mr. Richardson said in an interview after arriving here today from the Myanmar capital, Yangon, formerly known as Rangoon. "Aung San Suu Kyi is the key to a solution."
In the conversations with her visitors, Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi did not outline specific issues she would discuss in any direct meetings with the Government. But she suggested she would seek freedom for imprisoned supporters of the democracy movement she had led and would work toward the multiparty democratic system promised by the military when it declared the 1990 elections void.
While she was under detention, Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi's party, the National League for Democracy, won the election by a landslide, but the military government refused to accept the results. Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1991.
Representative Richardson said that while the Burmese military had made a "useful positive gesture" in allowing Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi to speak, "deeds must follow words."
"It does not substitute for significant discussions on political reconciliation, and it does not substitute for the unconditional release of Aung San Suu Kyi," he said.
 
Response to Clinton Letter
 Mr. Richardson said that during today's meeting, he received her response to a letter from President Clinton that he delivered on Monday.
The American Congressman also met twice on Monday with Lieut. Gen. Khin Nyunt, the head of Burmese military intelligence, and said that he had urged the general, who is regarded by many diplomats as the nation's new strongman, to deal with Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi directly.
While Mr. Richardson would not characterize the general's response to the proposal, American officials said they believed that General Khin Nyunt was leaning toward direct negotiations, but that he would not be able to commit himself until he had the approval of other junta members.
Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi (pronounced awng san sue chee) has had no direct contact with high-level Burmese Government officials. A lieutentant colonel who visits her occasionally has served as her liaison with the Government.
During her meeting with the delegation on Monday, Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi said she had always been willing to negotiate with the junta, which calls itself the State Law and Order Restoration Council, on all issues except the question of whether she would remain in Myanmar. The military has said she may go free if she promised to leave the country.
 
Congressman Awaits Response
 Representative Richardson, a member of the House Intelligence Committee who has been active in human rights issues, said today that he would return to Washington and would await a response from General Khin Nyunt.
He said he had concluded that Burmese concern about the Clinton Administration and its policies toward Myanmar was the reason officials had allowed an American-led delegation to be the first to see Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi.
In her remarks Monday, Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi expressed her thanks to the Clinton Administration, which has repeatedly called for her release, but she also said that she hoped to see from the United States a "more clear-cut policy in favor of the movement for democracy."
While the United States cut off all Government aid to Myanmar in 1988, it maintains trade links and limited diplomatic ties, despite the military leadership's abysmal human rights record. Several large American corporations do business in Myanmar.
 
Question of Sanctions
 Asked whether the United States and other nations should consider economic sanctions against Myanmar to protest its human rights policies, she said that foreign governments should consider whether their trade with Myanmar is "really helping the people or is it simply helping the Government to dig in its heels. This is the question to be asked."
Too many nations, she suggested, use economic carrots, and not sticks, to encourage improvements in Myanmar's human rights record. She asked her guests to remember that "you can stuff a mule to death with carrots."
While Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi appeared to be in generally good health despite her years of isolation, Western diplomats said that they were trying to determine, on the basis of her comments on Monday, whether she is receiving adequate medical care.
Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi said that her Burmese doctors had told her that she was suffering from spondylosis, a degenerative joint disease that results in a hardening and stiffening of the spinal column. "I can't sew any more because it gets at the shoulders," she said. "It's a bit of discomfort all the time."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
U.S. Urges 'Dialogue'
 WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (Special to The New York Times) -- The United States urged Myanmar's military leaders today to "build on this small step" of Representative Richardson's meeting by "beginning a dialogue with Aung San Suu Kyi and moving toward genuine democratic reform."
In a statement, the Administration added: "The President regards the continued detention of Aung San Suu Kyi and all other prisoners of conscience in Burma as unacceptable and renews his call for their immediate and unconditional release."
The White House also released a copy of a letter from President Clinton that Mr. Richardson delivered to Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi on Monday in which Mr. Clinton praised the Burmese for her courage and expressed concern about her welfare.

Viacom's Victory
Viacom edged out QVC Network in the five-month battle for Paramount Communications, with a winning $9.7 billion bid. The victory makes Sumner Redstone, the chairman of Viacom, even more powerful in the entertainment business. [Page A1.] 
 The merger leaves the fates of top Paramount studio executives in doubt, prompting much speculation in Hollywood. [D5.]
An extra $1 billion was all that stood between Barry Diller, QVC's chairman, and a conquest of Paramount. But Mr. Diller drew a line, deciding a chance at victory was not worth the risk. [D5.]
 
International
The United States announced it was drawing up a list of Japanese companies that would be punished in the American market if Japan did not open its cellular phone market to Motorola. The move seemed intended to touch off fear of a trade war in hopes of pressing Tokyo into negotiating on American terms. [A1.]
 Japanese executives and economists have shifted their focus from supporting Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa's firm stand against U.S. trade demands to becoming increasingly worried about the soaring yen. [D1.]
In retrospect, Motorola was bound to be thwarted in its drive to penetrate the Tokyo cellular phone market because the Japanese company entrusted with marketing its products was already building a mobile phone system using rival technology by N.T.T. [D4.]

HEADLINE: U.S. Says North Korean Decision Is Welcome

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15

 BODY:
American officials said today that they welcomed North Korea's decision to allow international inspectors to visit its nuclear sites, but said the United States would wait until the inspectors gave Pyongyang a clean bill before improving ties.
Michael McCurry, the State Department spokesman, said that in response to Pyongyang's move, the United States had taken the modest action of restarting informal, low-level talks today in New York with North Korea. 
 He said that only after the inspections were completed and North Korea began talks with South Korea about denuclearizing the Korean peninsula would the United States give Pyongyang the two things it has asked for: suspending military exercises with the South and beginning high-level talks aimed at improving economic ties.
 
Paving the Way for Talks
 "We look forward to these inspections as soon as possible," Mr. McCurry said at the daily State Department briefing. "Satisfactory completion of the inspection at the earliest possible date and resumption of the North-South dialogue on denuclearization will pave the way for the next round of U.S.-North Korea talks."
American officials said that as a result of the announcement today, they had put on hold their preparations to persuade the United Nations Security Council to impose economic sanctions on North Korea. The Clinton Administration repeatedly threatened to push for such sanctions unless the board of the International Atomic Energy Agency, which meets next Monday in Vienna, could certify that North Korea had not diverted atomic material.
Administration officials said they would still seek sanctions if the international inspectors found that North Korea had diverted nuclear material from its atomic energy program to a suspected nuclear weapons program.
North Korea's decision, after months of refusing to allow inspections, came as a surprise to the Administration.
"The North Koreans saw they could follow two different roads," a State Department official said. "One road would lead them into being an outlaw nation, while the other leads them back into the community of nations."
Now that North Korea has agreed to allow inspectors to visit seven declared nuclear sites, the Clinton Administration said it would push, at any new high-level round of talks, for inspections at two other sites where American intelligence officials suspected improper diversion of nuclear material.
American officials said that the announcement today was an important step toward getting the inspections back on track, but they acknowledged that North Korea had still not agreed to the regular, ad hoc inspections called for under the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. Several officials vowed that they would continue to push for such inspections.

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW YORK;
A Subwaycentric Lens on History

BYLINE: By David Gonzalez

 BODY:
"SEE Spot run" may have been the first words read by lots of children, but not by Paul Fritz.
"Express," "via" and "local" hold that place of honor in his life. 
 "My parents didn't drive, so we went everywhere by subway," explained the 39-year-old Brooklynite. "I could read a subway map before anything else."
A buff was born.
He eventually outdid most buffs, trading the vicarious adventures of studying and riding trains for the real life of a subway motorman. He also improved upon his earliest reading matter, sketching out over the last 11 years an intricate map of the New York City subway system at the height of its complexity in 1937 when three separate systems competed for commuters.
Of course, some New Yorkers might quibble and say the system is never more complex than when they are swimming through the crowds at the Times Square Station during a soggy winter rush hour, frantically looking to make a transfer. But his map details elevated lines, stations and spurs that were razed or closed long ago in the wake of the city's consolidation of systems.
"I'm thinking from the perspective of the historian, not the straphanger," he said of his map, which he designed for researching the system's evolution. Thinking back over his creation, he calls it the "greatest map ever made," but then corrects himself, lest he be accused of bragging. Instead, he points out its accurate geographical perspective, with islands that include one offshore terminal of a totally different nature.
"Mine is the only subway map to include Potter's Field."
Maybe it's best not to have his map hanging in a subway car.
The world of dark subway tunnels and clacking elevated lines held a special lure for Mr. Fritz as far back as he could remember, which in his case is an IRT ride home to Brooklyn when he was 2 years old. He came to associate what most New Yorkers thought of as a mundane means of transportation with nothing less than power, and the mysteries of being a grownup -- like his father, an economist who took the train to work each morning.
"The train was a forbidding, adult environment," he said. "The straps were too high for me to hold. Everything about it was for grownup people."
Forbidden to ride alone, he soon began to draw subway scenes. In his room he could have a train in front of him whenever he wanted.
By then trips became an end in themselves, like when his family, which had then moved to Jackson Heights (on the Flushing IRT line), would visit the Bronx Zoo. The real attraction for him was seeing the gigantic, curved trestles near West Farms Square on the White Plains IRT line. With a smile, he recalled how that Bronx scene was the genuine IRT.
"I felt cheated because I lived on the Flushing line, because that wasn't the real IRT," he said. "It used different cars. It didn't go up to Harlem or the Bronx. To me, the IRT had to go uptown, to where the BMT didn't go. There was something wimpy about the BMT."
But life on the Flushing line was still better than what awaited him in his teen-age years, when his family moved to Great Neck, L.I. There were people there, he said, who had never been on a subway car. And they were proud of it.
"I felt like an oddball," he said. "To me, a person who's never been on the subway is someone who's never opened their eyes."
That's the truth.
After stints teaching public school and driving a cab, Mr. Fritz gave in to his hobby and took a job with the Transit Authority in 1982. His schooling -- a college degree in writing -- nonetheless shows. He may be one of the few transit workers to pepper his speech with words like "anomie" (what motivates graffiti writers) and "milieu" (for the underground world of trains and tracks).
With access to the yards, tracks and tunnels he had only glimpsed from passing trains, he began to work on his idea for the map. Memo pad in hand, he rode the front of trains, sketching out the curves of current lines. Visits to libraries, with their own maps and photos, helped him flesh out his project, and he even took to exploring some abandoned tunnels to insure that no detail escaped his attention.
The finished project shows it. The old Myrtle Avenue line to downtown Brooklyn and Manhattan is on it, as well as the Bronx Zoo and Bronx Park IRT spurs that once took visitors directly to their destinations. Different colors show the various train lines, as well as indicating whether they were underground or not.
He's now thinking of doing more drawings of old-time subway scenes, evoking the same kind of period detail that made subway cars interesting before they become more standardized. To make his point, he dashed off a quick sketch of an old R-1 subway car -- the kind that had soft, incandescent lights and rattan seats.
For him, it's the system's history that appeals to him -- like the late 1950's when the subway cars and stations still had some character.
But he admits there's a bit of the 1960's that appeals to him, too.
"In the blackout of 1965, I was envious of the people who were stuck on the tracks and could walk on the tracks," he said. "I really envied the people who were stuck in the river tubes and had to walk distances in the tunnels."
