HEADLINE: VIACOM'S VICTORY;
Rival Bidder Diller Says: 'It's History'

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
When did Barry Diller finally let go of the dream he had been nursing for so long to merge his company with Paramount Communications and oust an old rival while he was at it? In an interview, a prickly Mr. Diller would not say. "I don't want to get into any of that," he said from QVC Network Inc.'s offices in West Chester, Pa. "It's history."
But Brian L. Roberts, the president of the Comcast Corporation and a partner of Mr. Diller's in his five-month quest to take over Paramount Communications, said the fateful decision came shortly before Feb. 1, when final bids were due. 
 Mr. Diller's advisers had concluded that victory was within their grasp if they simply promised to pay an extra $1 billion to Paramount's shareholders if QVC's stock tumbled after the deal -- matching Viacom's bravado.
But even though victory would mean settling an old score for Mr. Diller -- he had quit Paramount in 1984 after falling out with its chairman, Martin S. Davis -- Mr. Diller was all business.
 
Some 'What Ifs'
 As Mr. Roberts recalled, "Barry told everybody -- and we didn't quarrel -- 'It may work out. But what if the United States starts a war and stocks go down? What if interest rates go up? What if Clinton starts a trade war? You'd owe $1 billion you didn't have.' "
The stream of doubts did not surprise Mr. Roberts. "In the end, Barry didn't want to spend all his waking hours worrying about financings that come due in six months," Mr. Roberts said. "He wanted to spend his days worrying about which new shows to put on television and which movies to make."
Diane von Furstenberg, a designer who is an investor in QVC and is featured on it, had similar recollections of Mr. Diller's resolve: "By the time he didn't get it, he didn't want it anymore. He drew the line and that was it."
As a veteran programmer, Mr. Diller's reluctance to take a big financial risk may stem from the years he spent trying to build the Fox television network for Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation under a crushing debt load. "Murdoch went right to the edge and Barry told me, 'I never want to get there again,' " Mr. Roberts said.
When he left Fox two years ago, he said he wanted to be his own boss, an odyssey that led him to QVC and ultimately into his unsuccessful fight for Paramount.
In a world where appearance is everything, Hollywood's image makers went to work yesterday on a furious campaign to persuade the world that the home shopping executive was not tarnished by the loss.
Herbert Allen, his investment banker, argued that Mr. Diller should get credit not only for driving up the bidding but also for creating many of the assets at Paramount years ago that Sumner M. Redstone, the rival head of Viacom, ultimately wanted so badly.
 
Losers Aren't Weepers
 Ms. Von Furstenberg went further, arguing that Mr. Diller's many backers were actually "excited by the prospect" that Mr. Diller was now free to pursue other alliances. "There's a lot of opportunities out there, so I wouldn't worry," she said.
Like politicians who argue that being the also-ran does not have to hurt a career, the logic of Mr. Diller's supporters was essentially that losers do not have to be weepers -- so long as they become household names from the experience.
"Here, in Hollywood," said Laurence Mark, a Hollywood producer, "it has only heightened his profile and heightened the profile of his company."
Mr. Diller's first order of business, friends and analysts agree, is to hunker down at QVC and preside over his company's coming introduction of Q2, a new, more upscale shopping channel.
The debut, scheduled for this May, is crucial, since Mr. Diller's ability to finance acquisitions depends heavily on QVC's stock price, which rose yesterday by $1.75, to $50.25, in Nasdaq trading. Mr. Diller could also get his hands on a $1.2 billion war chest without too much trouble simply by leveraging QVC's $200 million in cash flow, according to Craig Bibb, a Paine Webber analyst.
Protecting QVC's position in the home-shopping arena may also mean approaching Home Shopping Network, its main competitor, to talk about dusting off the $1.35 billion merger that the two companies temporarily abandoned when Mr. Diller's interest in Paramount grew serious.
Bankers and analysts get wide-eyed thinking about the possibility of Mr. Diller making a run at any number of giant media companies from big networks like CBS and NBC to hooking up with Seagrams through its mutual bankers at Allen & Company to buy Time Warner.
Others are less charitable. They say Mr. Diller made tactical blunders in the way he pursued his deal from sloppily bidding against himself at one point to losing a minor timing advantage by waiting five days to start a hostile offer he had made.
Mr. Diller will have none of it, arguing that none of those decisions cost him the victory. "The mistake we may have made is that we decided not to pay more," he said. "God knows, that might be the giant mistake of all time. Time will tell."

HEADLINE: Assisting The Needy Amid Guns

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY

 BODY:
Bernard Hanson, an art historian who lives in New Haven, believes in gun control so strongly that he has considered putting bumper stickers on his pickup truck calling for the repeal of the Second Amendment.
"But I'm afraid I'd get my window bashed or something," said Mr. Hanson, who calls New Haven "the northern branch of the South Bronx" because of the crime and guns that have invaded even his cloistered neighborhood of 19th-century houses and walled yards. 
 When Mr. Hanson learned in December that a Manhattan carpet merchant, Fernando Mateo, had launched a campaign to stem the tide of gun-related violence -- by offering toy-store gift certificates in exchange for guns -- he was so moved that he wanted to do something in Mr. Mateo's honor.
"It meant a lot to me that this was a private citizen who felt strongly enough to do something," said Mr. Hanson, who decided to send $100 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, his very first contribution, because of Mr. Mateo's efforts.
Mr. Hanson is one of several people who have contributed to the Neediest Cases Fund in honor of Mr. Mateo, whose idea helped the police in the 34th Precinct in upper Manhattan bring in more than 1,500 guns in December and January.
By giving to the fund, which supports seven of the city's largest social-service agencies, the contributors bolstered programs that provide food, shelter and medical care to tens of thousands of the poorest New Yorkers.
The Times pays the overhead of the campaign, which is in its 82d year, so that every dollar is given directly to the agencies to help people.
But as the appeal enters its final two weeks, the ability of the fund to continue providing help is in danger because contributions are lagging about $90,000 behind where they were last year at this time.
Individual contributors are now keeping pace with the amount they gave last year: 11,624 donors have given $3,192,722, or about $1,000 more than last year. But donations from estates and trusts, which fluctuate depending on interest rates, have decreased.

HEADLINE: The Trade Frustrations of Motorola

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 15

 BODY:
When the United States and Japan agreed to open a big part of Japan's cellular telephone market to Motorola Inc. in 1989, Robert A. Mosbacher, the Commerce Secretary at the time, hailed the pact as "a model for future negotiations."
But rather than a model of success, the cellular telephone agreement has become an example of what American trade negotiators have long found frustrating about dealing with Japan: first, when one barrier seems to be swept away, another obstacle seems to arise to take its place; second, agreements often seem to fall apart when it comes time actually to put them into effect. 
 Now, citing a lack of market access for Motorola, President Clinton has decided to put sanctions on Japan. And, in retrospect, it is clear the cellular agreement was not as strong as Washington believed.
 
A Crucial Market
 A big flaw from the American perspective is that Motorola's penetration of the market in the crucial Tokyo-Nagoya corridor was left in the hands of a cellular phone service company that had little incentive to push Motorola products.
"No one liked it, but it was take it or leave it," Robert M. Orr Jr., director of government affairs for Motorola's Japanese subsidiary, said of the arrangement. Mr. Orr, who was not with Motorola in 1989, said that in retrospect, "It doesn't look like a good agreement."
The cellular phone service company, the Nippon Idou Tsushin Corporation, known as IDO, was building a mobile phone system using a rival technology developed by N.T.T., the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation. It agreed, under considerable prodding from Japan's Government, to build a separate system using Motorola technology.
But IDO could not easily afford to build two systems, so it concentrated on the one using N.T.T. technology. As a result, as of last month it had 400 base stations for the N.T.T.-compatible system compared with 110 for the Motorola system. The N.T.T.-compatible phones can be used in 94 percent of the service area compared with 61 percent for the Motorola phones.
Given this disparity, it is little wonder that more than 310,000 customers have chosen the N.T.T.-compatible phones and only about 10,000 the Motorola phones. It is this lack of sales that Washington says violates the "comparable market access" that Japan promised.
Yoshio Utsumi, director general for international affairs at the Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications, said that "comparable market access" meant only that Motorola would get equivalent radio frequencies. How many Motorola phones are actually used is strictly a matter between Motorola and IDO, he said.
Mr. Orr of Motorola disagreed, saying that since Japan arranged the shotgun marriage between Motorola and IDO, the Government was responsible for the results.
In 1987, the United States and Japan reached an agreement that would allow Motorola to sell its system, with the Japanese deciding to allow one competitor for N.T.T. in each region.
The DDI Corporation, a maverick discount long-distance company that decided to use Motorola's equipment, won the franchises for Osaka and much of Japan. But IDO won the high-density Tokyo-Nagoya corridor, which is home for most Japanese businesses and most potential cellular phone users; IDO decided to use the N.T.T. technology.
The matter seemed to be settled. But Motorola was not completely happy -- DDI customers in Osaka could not use their Motorola phones in Tokyo or Nagoya.
 
A Compromise
 The 1989 agreement called for granting frequencies for a Motorola system in the Tokyo-Nagoya region. But rather than let DDI provide the service in the Tokyo-Nagoya area, which would have meant a third competitor in the market, the telecommunications ministry persuaded IDO to offer a Motorola-based service.
IDO is building 80 base stations for the Motorola system, to be completed by April, and another 100 are scheduled by April 1996. That will put coverage of the Motorola system at 93 percent of the service area, about what the N.T.T. system has.
Still, Mr. Orr of Motorola called the plan "too little too late."

HEADLINE: Calm in Currency Markets Bolsters Stocks

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
After the White House moved to calm the turbulent currency markets, stock traders strongly bid up most of the main stock indicators in heavy trading.
With bond and currency markets more stable, equity investors continued to pour funds into economically sensitive stocks like Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, Allied Signal and Goodyear Tire and Rubber. 
 "A little more reality has set into the currency markets" compared with Monday's trading, said Kevin J. Lawrie, a foreign exchange manager at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. "The fundamentals, like a recovering economy, favor the dollar, so people are a little less keen on dollar weakness."
But John K. Nelson, director of global foreign exchange at Barclays Bank, remained cautious. "Until the Clinton Administration says forcefully that it will not politicize the dollar, the dollar will remain under pressure," with possible effects on the stock market, he said.
 
Dow Industrials Up 24.21
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 24.21 points, to 3,928.27, and the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 2.29 points, to 472.52. The smaller-stock Nasdaq composite index rose 4.67 points, to 790.12. The American Stock Exchange market value index declined slightly, down 0.07 point, to 474.84.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 1.10 points, to 262.36, on volume of 306.8 million shares. Advancing stocks led decliners by 1,198 to 882.
Stock and bond traders had feared that turmoil in the currency markets, roiled by worsening trade relations between the United States and Japan, would spill over into stocks and bonds.
But the Treasury Department reiterated late Monday night, around noon on Tuesday Tokyo time, Secretary Lloyd Bentsen's policy that markets, not governments, should dictate foreign exchange rates. The announcement helped ease fears that the Clinton Administration was deliberately talking down the dollar.
Also, the Bank of Japan yesterday stepped in decisively, spending as much as $2 billion to bolster the dollar, currency traders said. The action helped keep the dollar from plunging below 100 yen, although the dollar traded as low as 101.9 yen in overnight trading. It settled yesterday at 103.85 yen to the dollar, up 1.6 yen.
 
Economic Reports Ignored
 The news in yesterday's economic reports was expected, so the markets ignored it. The Federal Reserve Board reported that industrial production rose five-tenths of a percent in January, better than the consensus estimate of four-tenths of a percent. January factory use came in as expected, at 83.1 percent.
Six Dow component stocks rose 1 point or more, including Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, up 2 5/8, to 108 1/2; Allied Signal, up 1 3/4, to 79 3/4, and Goodyear Tire and Rubber, up 1 1/2, to 47 1/2.
American depository receipts of Telefonica de Espana were the most actively traded stock on the New York Stock Exchange after the company sold more A.D.R.'s. They rose 1/8, to 44, on a volume of 9.1 million A.D.R.'s. One Telefonica A.D.R. equals three ordinary shares.
Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine's A.D.R.'s were the second-most-active stock on the Big Board after a public sale of 9.5 million new A.D.R.'s. They rose 1 1/8, to 36 3/4, on a volume of 4.65 million A.D.R.'s. One A.D.R. represents half of an ordinary share of the French oil and gas company.
As widely expected, the winner in the battle for Paramount Communications saw its share prices fall and the loser saw its price rise. Shares of QVC Network, the loser, rose 1 3/4, to 50 1/4. Class B shares of the winner, Viacom fell 1 7/8, to 28, while class A shares fell 3/4, to 34 1/8. Blockbuster Entertainment, Viacom's prospective merger partner, saw its shares rise 3/8, to 25 1/4.

HEADLINE: An Apron for a Squeegee

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that squeegee men should go out and get jobs in restaurants instead of trying to wash car windshields.
"There are plenty of jobs available," he told an interviewer on WBAI radio. "A person who's a squeegee operator could work in a restaurant." He added, "Maybe the hours are a little longer and then you've got to pay taxes and there are a whole bunch of other things that are involved, but you really shouldn't fuel the impression that the people who are doing squeegees just really don't have a job." 
 Mr. Giuliani first raised the squeegee workers as an issue during his campaign for mayor, saying they menaced drivers and reduced the quality of life in the city. And since taking office, Mr. Giuliani's Police Commissioner, William J. Bratton, has made clear that he expects officers to deal not just with major crimes but panhandlers, squeegee workers and even truants.
An eight-week police department study of squeegee men, based on a survey of 41 of them, showed that police can easily drive them away from the entrances to bridges and tunnels through aggressive patrolling.
The study also concluded that the squeegee users "are of a population that is largely beset with alcohol and drug abuse, economic marginality and unemployment." Many, it said, "appear to be unemployable save some heroic efforts that go beyond any rehabilitation technologies." And for about half, "arrests for serious criminality" are a problem.
Mr. Giuliani, however, said he "knew of situations in which people have turned down jobs in restaurants because they felt they had more flexibility" with their squeegees. And he said his administration expects "more of people."
"Don't stand on a corner squeegeeing," he said. "Go to a restaurant. Get a job at a restaurant. There are plenty of restaurants in this city that will employ people at wage levels that make sense, that offer some degree of a career.
"I know people who own restaurants that started by washing dishes. I've washed dishes in restaurants. It's an honorable, decent, terrific thing to do, a lot of self-fulfillment that you're working 10, 12 hours a day and you kind of like working steadily and moving toward the possibility of moving up, becoming a waiter."

HEADLINE: U.S. Hoping to Use Fears of Trade War To Pressure Japan

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15

 BODY:
The initiation today of formal United States trade sanctions against Japan for protecting its cellular phone market touched off a new wave of anxiety about a trade war -- just the reaction the Clinton Administration appears to be trying to generate to get Japan to return to the bargaining table on American terms.
At a news conference attended, to the Administration's delight, by television networks from around the world, the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, announced that his office would publish within 30 days a list of the Japanese companies that would be punished in the American market, unless Japan fully opens its cellular phone market to Motorola Inc. 
 Mr. Kantor's news conference, attended by more than 100 journalists, underscored the immense international interest in the trade rift between the world's two largest economies. The attention fit into what appears to be the Administration's strategy: to create as much uncertainty and anxiety in Japan as possible about Washington's next moves, in the hope that this will drive up the Japanese yen and put pressure on Tokyo to return to the negotiations on American terms, before any more sanctions need be applied.
The uncertainty has already driven up the value of the yen against the dollar by about 6 percent since Thursday. That potentially makes all Japanese exports 6 percent more expensive -- which is the most onerous sanction of all because it is the equivalent of a 6 percent tariff on everything Japan sells in the United States. This, in turn, adds to recessionary pressures in the Japanese economy and eats away at some of the stimulus package the Japanese Government announced last week.
The Clinton team would like to avoid a tit-for-tat trade war with Japan. Such a conflict could sour economic relations, hurt American consumers, complicate political cooperation with Tokyo on crucial issues, like Korea and Russia, and possibly undercut the Government of Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa, who Mr. Clinton basically believes wants to overhaul and open Japan's economy over the long run.
The trick for the Clinton Administration is to squeeze Japan into accepting the American negotiating framework without doing irreparable damage to the relationship. Hence its current strategy, which might be called constructive uncertainty.
 
The Currency Factor
 "I think that the Administration has concluded, correctly, that time works in their favor because of the impact of the higher yen on the Japanese economy," said Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International. "That higher yen reduces the competitiveness of Japanese exports, boosts their imports and squeezes profits. Therefore, I think Washington can afford to wait, and let the yen do their talking -- without having to take any new sanctions."
The danger, Mr. Hormats added, is that if this anxiety and uncertainty last too long, tensions could build, there could be a nationalistic reaction from Japan, and things could get out of hand -- possibilities that are causing the Administration to hope the Japanese will act quickly.
Indeed, the Treasury Department issued a statement Monday denying that the United States was intervening in the markets to drive up the yen. But the Treasury does not have to intervene. The surge is a result of speculators anticipating that the United States may take such a move in the future as part of a trade war.
In any case, the net effect on Japan is the same. That explains reports today that the Japanese central bank was busily buying dollars and selling yen to push down the yen's value against the dollar.
From an American point of view, this all suggests that the strategy is taking hold. White House officials are clearly going out of their way to give Tokyo time to draw its own conclusions from these events. They pointedly note that the President's advisers are still putting together a menu of sanctions that Mr. Clinton could use against Japan.
They also note that the list will not be on the President's desk before the end of this week, at the earliest. Mr. Clinton will then want to take his time and study the options before he makes up his mind about which, if any, to choose, the officials said.
Some or all of the sanctions presumably would be aimed at Japan's telecommunications industry since the case involves American accusations that Motorola is being discriminated against in Japan's cellular telephone market. American officials are supporting Motorola's complaint that it has been effectively shut out of the huge and lucrative Tokyo cellular market because of business arrangements forced on it by Japanese officials and because the Japanese have deliberately favored cellular technologies that differ from Motorola's.
When Administration officials say they want the Japanese to return to bargaining on American terms, they mean that they want them to accept not only the principle of opening their relatively closed markets -- particularly in insurance, autos, medical equipment and telecommunications -- but also to accept numerical indicators for measuring whether Japan is keeping its promises.
For instance, in autos, the United States would like Japan to accept as one measure of whether it is opening its markets a regular accounting of how many Japanese car dealers offer foreign models.
Japanese officials are afraid that what Washington calls numerical indicators will be not just yardsticks to measure Japanese auto imports, but also targets that Japan will be held to, accompanied by punishments for not reaching the goal. That is what happened with an agreement on semiconductors.
The crux of the matter is that the two sides no longer trust each other. And if the talks are to resume, under whatever pressures, a level of trust will have to be built -- so that Japan can agree to indicators that it is sure will not be held up as market targets, and so that the United States can have indicators it considers reliable in determining whether Japan is really opening its markets.
So far, American officials say, there have been no feelers from Tokyo about returning to bargaining, but, they add, it is still very early.

GRAPHIC: Photos Mr. Kantor, the United States trade representative, held a cellular telephone as he talked of trade sanctions against Japan. (pg. D4)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Government Securities Are Mixed

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Prices of government securities were mixed yesterday, as investors and dealers remained worried about a weaker dollar against the yen.
The price of the Treasury's 30-year bond fell 1/16 yesterday. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, rose to 6.45 percent, a tick higher than 6.44 percent on Monday. The prices of most of the intermediate maturities rose, while shorter maturities were unchanged. 
 The dollar plunged against the yen on Monday after tough trade talk by the Clinton Administration sent tremors through the global currency markets, but the dollar made a comeback against the yen yesterday. The bond market's chief concern is that a weaker dollar against the yen could encourage Japanese investors to sell dollar-denominated securities.
According to MMS International, Treasury data compiled through the end of the third quarter of 1993 show Japanese investors bought $10 billion in United States Government securities.
The yen's strength against the dollar is also viewed as inflationary because it makes Japanese imports more expensive in the United States. That, in turn, gives American manufacturers more leeway in raising prices at home, analysts said.
Matthew Alexy, government trading strategist at CS First Boston, said the danger of Japanese investors selling dollar-denominated securities looked less ominous even though the market remained concerned.
"Most people are coming to the consensus that it would be hard for a strong yen to be sustained over a period of time," Mr. Alexy said. "This is not a change in fundamental outlook in the world currency market. It is more about yen strength, than the dollar weakness."
A country's currency is a reflection of its economic strength, he noted, and "presently, our economy is further along than theirs."
"Trading was firm," said David A. Ader, a managing analyst at the Technical Data division of Thomson Financial Services. "But like the half glass of water, its performance depended on how you looked at it," he said. "Is it half full? Or is it half empty?" He said it was remarkable that trading had stayed in a narrow range while going through a series of significant events, including an interest rate increase by the Federal Reserve, the government's record quarterly borrowing, the Producer Price Index and the rise of the yen. "Despite all that, the market is still holding to its tight range," Mr Ader said, "with the yield of the 30-year bond having moved about 15 basis points." A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Mr. Ader said recent trading had been dominated by professional traders who are only jockeying for position. Investors who moved to the sidelines weeks ago are waiting for Wall Street to define the market's trend.
The Government reported yesterday that industrial production climbed in January for the eighth consecutive month despite the limiting effects of severe winter weather in the East and by the California earthquake. Overall capacity rose to 83.1 percent.
 
Corporate Bonds
 In the corporate debt market, a $250 million sale of 10-year notes by Colombia marked the first time a Latin American country had sold investment-grade debt in the United States market.
The offering may be a sign that Latin American economies have reversed their misfortunes of the 1980's, when many were heavily leveraged.
David L. Roberts, an analyst with the Duff & Phelps Credit Rating Company, said Colombia was virtually the only Latin American country to meet all its scheduled debt payments in the 1980's. He said the successful sale of this issue would bring other Latin American countries into the United States market.
Traders outside the underwriting group, which was led by Merrill Lynch, said the issue was well received and quickly sold. The issue was given a 7.25 percent coupon and priced at 99.196, to yield 7.365 percent, or about 148 basis points more than a Treasury issue with a like maturity.
The noncallable note is rated Ba-1 by Moody's Investors Service, BBB- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation and BBB by Duff & Phelps.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises Against Yen, But Fall Is Seen Resuming

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar rebounded against the Japanese yen yesterday after plunging to a six-month low on Monday amid fears of a possible trade war between the United States and Japan.
"There is some sentiment that it was a little overdone," Hillel Waxman, a vice president at Bank Leumi Trust Company of New York, said of the dollar selloff on Monday. 
 The dollar crashed to an intraday low of 101.20 yen on Monday and ended trading in New York at 102.25 yen. It recovered yesterday, rising to 103.85 yen, as traders took profits on the soaring yen. But many dealers believe the dollar still is set for a test of the 100-yen level.
 
 
Support From Bank of Japan
 The dollar apparently received considerable support yesterday from the Bank of Japan, which reportedly spent nearly $1 billion buying dollars and selling yen in an effort to halt the Japanese currrency's surge.
Dealers said the currency markets were jittery ahead of an afternoon statement by the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, on American retaliation against Japan for violating its promise on opening its cellular telephone market.
But the statement, when it came, did little to alleviate worries that the United States might still use the exchange rate as a lever to exact trade concessions from Japan. Mr. Kantor said only that the White House would announce proposed retaliatory measures against Japan in 30 days.
"People were looking for the Administration to come out with something concrete," said Peter Carruthers, an analyst at Credit Suisse. In the absence of firm talk of sanctions, traders believe the United States will resort to talking the dollar lower against the yen, he said.
A lower dollar would cut the cost of American goods in Japan and make Japanese goods in the United States more expensive.
The dollar also received support from comments by a a Federal Reserve governor, Edward W. Kelley Jr., who said American inflation remained too high and must be brought down. The remarks encouraged dealers to buy dollars against other currencies on the premise that the Fed might raise rates again soon. Higher American interest rates make dollar-based assets relatively more attractive than foreign investments.
The dollar finished at 1.7283 German marks in New York trading, up from 1.7240 on Monday. The British pound fell to $1.4755 in New York, from $1.4865 on Monday.
Meanwhile, gold prices slipped, with gold for April delivery falling 10 cents, to $385.80 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange in New York.

HEADLINE: Industrial Output Up In January

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15

 BODY:
The nation's industrial output climbed for the eighth consecutive month in January despite severe weather, the Federal Reserve Board said today.
Factories ran at their highest operating rates in four and a half years last month, the Fed said. Total industrial production in January rose by five-tenths of 1 percent, lower than a revised gain of nine-tenths of 1 percent in December but enough to keep going a string of monthly increases that began in mid-1993. 
 "These are really solid numbers despite the cold and show the underlying momentum in economic growth carrying into early 1994 from early 1993," said David Jones, an economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Company in New York.
 
 
Steady Monthly Increases
 The economy surged in late 1992 but then lost strength in early 1993. But steady monthly rises in industrial production from last June through January strongly suggest the pattern will not be repeated this year.
In January, factories ran at 83.1 percent of their maximum capacity, up from 82.9 percent in December and the highest rate since 83.2 percent in August 1989.
Mr. Jones said the capacity number suggested that price pressures would gradually accelerate in coming months as companies seek higher profits. Raw materials will become more expensive, and businesses must start hiring soon instead of relying on overtime as they strain to meet demand.
"I think businesses are eager to test the markets on prices," Mr. Jones said, "They've gone about as far as they can on every variety of cost-cutting."
Industry would have produced goods at an even faster clip last month if the weather had been better.
The Fed said a series of crippling East Coast storms in January, coupled with the devastating California earthquake, held growth in output at manufacturing plants at two-tenths of a percent, compared with an average monthly advance of nine-tenths of a percent in the fourth quarter of 1993. .
"Steel, appliances and motor vehicles and parts were among the industries with the most significant disruptions," the Fed said. Many auto makers shut down assembly lines for a day or more because employees could not get to work.
But production increased at mines, and output soared at gas- and electricity-producing industries to meet strong residential demand.
The National Association of Manufacturers said a boom in computers and new production equipment added to the buoyancy in industrial output.
A separate Federal Reserve System survey showed rising loan demand from companies of all sizes in January.
The Fed survey of 77 American and foreign-owned banks reported a significant increase in companies and individuals seeking loans since November.

HEADLINE: Inflated Worries?;
Fed Is on the Case, but the Markets Give Hints of a Message Misread

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
Inflation, Wall Street would have us believe, is not good for brokers, bond traders and other living things. Why, then, did blue-chip shares take their biggest one-day drop in two years on news that the Federal Reserve was nudging up interest rates as a pre-emptive strike against the dread condition? And why, two weeks later, despite repeated assurances from the economics establishment that inflation is nowhere in sight, do professional investors wait with bated breath for the dribs and drabs of price data released periodically by Washington?
One answer is that after three years of benign neglect of prices and another year of words without deeds, even the delicate squeeze on credit signaled by the Fed was bound to shock. "The move was a surprise in its timing" if not its direction, concluded Lesley Daniels Webster, a securities trader and economist at the Union Bank of Switzerland. 
 Another answer is that subtle messages can be misinterpreted easily. In spite of copious evidence that inflation is under control, the very fact that times have looked so good on Wall Street for so long may be bringing out the pessimists. "Perhaps the bond traders said, 'Gee, maybe the inflation threat is worse than we thought,' " Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch, speculated.
The other possibility -- by far the most important to Americans who don't make a living trading securities -- is that the Fed is breaking the bad news gently. If that is indeed the case, said David Hale, an economist at the Kemper Financial Group, "this was only the first step in a continuing process" of tightening money and credit.
The Federal Reserve can influence interest rates on everything from A.T.& T.'s multibillion-dollar debt to Joe Sixpack's mortgage in a variety of ways. The way it chose this time was the most delicate and most common: a change in the Federal funds rate (the rate big banks pay to borrow one day at a time) brought about by the sale or purchase of Government securities from the public.
College sophomores are taught that the value of corporate shares is largely a product of expected future earnings to which the owners are entitled -- an expectation that might go up or down on news of higher interest rates. But day-to-day changes in stock prices are apparently dominated by a combination of psychology and the supply of loose savings looking for a profitable home. And from this perspective the Fed's move was unambiguously bad news.
Mr. Steinberg points out that the grand surge in stock prices over the last few years has been powered by savers -- mostly pension and mutual funds -- who were unwilling to settle for the 3 or 4 percent interest from money market funds and insured bank deposits. Hence an increase in interest rates, especially one that might presage more increases, made bank deposits a little more attractive and stocks a little less.
The impact on bond prices is more of a puzzle. Those who lend their money for 20 or 30 years in return for a fixed semiannual payment have every reason to remain vigilant of future inflation. There is hardly a greater nightmare for investors, after all, than being stuck earning, say, 6 percent interest for decades when prices are escalating at 15 percent. Why then, Mr. Steinberg asks, didn't the bond market say "thank you" when the Fed reminded Wall Street that it was not asleep at the inflation switch?
Ms. Daniels Webster points to the sort of day-to-day factors that influenced the stock market. The Fed's announcement, she notes, came just a week before the auction of some $40 billion in bonds. And any surprise, any news from the Fed that makes the plausible range of future interest rates less certain, is likely to make bond buyers more cautious in the short run.
"It's John Maynard Keynes's old story," said Robert Shiller, an economist at Yale who specializes in the psychology of markets. "The price of securities is what people think other people think they should be." (Ponder that one at the risk of a headache.)
All this might suggest that however great the immediate shock, the Fed's action and the securities' markets reaction was nothing more than the sort of "midcourse correction" that economists, not to mention journalists, pontificate about when they have nothing much to say. But there is the more daunting possibility that inflation is a clearer and more present danger than the consensus soothsayers have been forecasting.
On the one hand, Mr. Hale pointed out, there is little objective evidence that inflation is a significant threat. "We still have a weak world economy," he noted, one in which Americans' rising demand for, say, autos, can be met easily with imports. Equally important, the remarkable 6 percent growth rate of the last quarter of 1993 was accomplished without a surge in hiring or pressure on wages -- a fact that Mr. Hale interprets as evidence that the economy's underlying capacity to produce more goods with less capital and labor is greater than believed in recent years.
 
Some Disquieting Signs
 On the other, Mr. Hale detects disquieting signs in the prices of a handful of industrial commodities and increased investor interest in stocks like mining companies that could serve as a hedge against inflation. And at least in some minds, January's four-tenths of a percent uptick in the underlying prices that businesses charge other businesses carries the same message: Consumer prices are almost certain to grow more rapidly, suggesting that yesterday's 3 percent inflation may become tomorrow's 5 percent inflation.
Mr. Hale said he thought the Fed would lean more firmly against the wind if the economy continued to grow faster than the 2.5 to 3 percent consensus view of growth in long-term productive capacity. The quarter-point increase in interest rates will be followed by more of same that, he said, could raise the cost of borrowing by a full percentage point by the end of the year.
Predicting the behavior of the Federal Reserve is almost as rash an exercise as predicting the behavior of the economy. Still, many Fed watchers see the Fed's move as "the beginning of the end of cheap money," as Barron's magazine recently put it. Though producer prices in January remained moderate, many economists predict that at some point they will kick up a bit in response to strong demand -- and that the Fed will ratchet up rates still further.
That would be bad news or good news, depending on whose shoes fit. Mortgage and car payments would indeed go up, and businesses that borrow heavily would feel the pinch a bit. But it would mean higher bank rates for those living on savings. More important, it would reinforce the self-fulfilling sense that strong economic growth is here to stay, that the long period of three steps forward and two steps back that cost millions of Americans (including George Bush) their jobs, is finally over.

HEADLINE: Demand Up For Loans

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15

 BODY:
Loan demand rose and banks were more willing to lend in January as the economy improved, according to a Federal Reserve survey released today.
"The survey results again showed an easing of terms and standards on loans to businesses and households by a significant proportion of respondents," said the Fed, which conducted a similar survey in November. "A significant number of respondents reported an increase in credit demand over the past three months." 
 The survey of senior loan officers at 59 United States banks and 18 branches of foreign banks found that demand for commercial and industrial loans was up sharply from November. All sizes of companies were seeking credit, the Fed said.
In response, banks eased their qualifications for commercial and industrial loans, although standards for commercial real estate loans were unchanged from November. Consumer loans also were easier to get.
Bankers were more willing to make business loans mainly because of the brighter economic outlook and growing competition from other banks. Weak demand in their home countries made a few foreign banks more eager to lend in the United States.

HEADLINE: A Classic Chardonnay Returns to New York

BYLINE: By HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

 BODY:
THE chardonnay of Hanzell Vineyards, one of the most influential producers in California's wine-making history, is staging a comeback in the New York region.
The 37-year-old Sonoma County boutique winery, famed for powerful chardonnays that age as long and as well as the best white Burgundies, is aggressively placing its delicious 1991 chardonnay in stores and restaurants. 
 "I haven't seen Hanzell for years," said Michael Aaron, president of Sherry-Lehmann, the Manhattan wine store. "It's the granddaddy of them all, but it has become a forgotten vineyard."
Bob Sessions, Hanzell's wine maker and general manager since 1973, said that the winery, resting on its laurels, paid little attention to changes in the New York market and let the brand virtually vanish here.
In the affluent 80's, Hanzell chardonnay that was not sold to mailing-list customers was rationed nationwide to shops and restaurants and was hard to find. The 90's economic crunch, making sales harder, forced Hanzell to join a sales consortium with four other small producers, and it took on a new distributor.
Hanzell, which produced its first commercial vintage in 1957, is generally credited with introducing modern chardonnay-making techniques in California. Its founder, James D. Zellerbach, popularized the use of small oak barrels for aging wines. He was also the first California producer to use temperature-controlled stainless steel tanks to ferment chardonnay grapes and to use nitrogen, a preservative, when bottling his wines.
His first wine maker, Ralph Bradford Webb, carried out seminal experiments with secondary fermentation (technically called malolactic fermentation), which adds depth and smooth texture to wine.
 "Today, most chardonnay making in California is Burgundian, with heavy use of barrel-fermentation and aging in new barrels," said Mr. Sessions, who joined Hanzell in 1973 and has barely modified its style. Mr. Sessions uses a modified Burgundian approach: only 10 percent of the grapes are barrel fermented, although everything is barrel aged for at least a year. But he works with a lighter hand than many colleagues.
"Our emphasis is in bringing the chardonnay fruit into the wine rather than having a heavy barrel presence," he said. "We do have a wood presence, but it is in the background."
That was plain in a tasting of the 1966, '71, '74, '78, '81, '85, '90 and '91 chardonnays last week. A defining theme shone through all of them: rich, mouth-filling fruitiness; subtle flavors; smoothness; balance, long aftertaste -- in short, elegance. (Always made from very ripe grapes, these whites have high, but not intrusive, alcohol levels: 14.5 percent in the 1991.)
"I've not tasted California chardonnays that have aged so gracefully," said Daniel Johnnes, the wine director at the Montrachet restaurant in Manhattan, who sampled the series. "I can't get over how fresh the old ones are."
He put the '91 on the wine list at the restaurant at $55 a bottle.
Mr. Sessions said, "I like to drink my chardonnays between 8 and 15 years after the vintage." At a minimum, he added, consumers should uncork them four to six years after the vintage. The jury is still out on the ageability of many of today's California chardonnays, because many wineries are too young to have established a record.
The Hanzell winery is an architectural gem. It was built by the late Mr. Zellerbach, president of Crown Zellerbach, the giant forest products company, and Ambassador to Italy in the Eisenhower Administration. He was a devotee of the great Montrachet wines from Burgundy's Cote d'Or; the facade of his winery replicates the face of a building at the historic Clos de Vougeot vineyard in Burgundy.
With new plantings, the estate, now owned by a young Englishman, projects an output of 2,000 cases of chardonnay annually, beginning with this year's harvest.
Because of high production costs, Hanzell chardonnays have always been expensive. The New York distributor, Lauber Imports, has priced the '91 at $32 a bottle in stores; in restaurants, with their markups, it sells for even more.
In Manhattan, Crossroads is discounting the '91 chardonnay at $26. The wine will be around $30 at Sherry-Lehmann and Ambassador Wines and Spirits, as well as at Liquorama Wine Cellars in Hyde Park, N.Y.; Home Liquors in Verona, N.J., and Shoppers Discount Liquors in Madison, N.J.

HEADLINE: Forecast Warns Of Inflation Clouds

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "The Fed Goes for Overkill" (Op-Ed, Feb. 8), James K. Galbraith maintains there is no justification for the quarter-point boost in short-term interest rates announced by Alan Greenspan, Federal Reserve Board chairman, "to forestall an inflationary threat that all agree has not appeared." I do not agree. 
 Professor Galbraith is looking in the rear-view mirror. Past movements in inflation are not a reliable guide to imminent cyclical turns in inflation. Far more reliable is a series of leading inflation indicators that have individually and collectively had a stellar record in predicting cyclical turning points in inflation.
For example, in January commodity price inflation rose sharply; the percentage of purchasing managers reporting higher prices jumped from 51 percent to 60 percent; the percentage of these same managers reporting slower deliveries -- a sign of tightening supply lines -- also rose significantly, and the ratio of employment to population headed upward.
In addition, the percentage of those in business who are expecting higher selling prices rose in the last quarter. Also, import prices, which were declining in the early part of last year, are now rising, and so as well is the growth rate of total Federal and non-Federal debt.
These indicators are all components of the leading inflation index, which was developed by Columbia University's Center for International Business Cycle Research. This index, which has had an extraordinarily reliable record in forecasting upturns and downturns in inflation, rose sharply last month, and it is growing at its fastest pace in eight years.
Therefore, it is fallacious for Professor Galbraith to maintain that there is no justification for the Fed's minuscule rise in interest rates. There are early warning signs of a cyclical upswing in inflation.
Indeed, if the tentative signal given by our leading inflation index is confirmed by subsequent data, we can expect inflation to start rising later this year.
 
GEOFFREY H. MOORE
Director, Center for Intl. Business
Cycle Research, Columbia University
New York, Feb. 9, 1994

HEADLINE: Let's Have a Light-Rail Link for the Entire Midtown Core

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The Regional Plan Association was delighted by "To Test a Trolley," your Feb. 7 editorial endorsement of a light-rail line along Manhattan's 42d Street. As you note, the proposed trolley would connect major destinations from the United Nations to the Javits Convention Center and would be "faster, cheaper, cleaner" than current transportation options. 
 We agree that midtown Manhattan needs improved transportation if it is to continue to serve as the center of our region's enormous economy. We too strongly advocate creation of the proposed trolley line. But the current proposal contains the potential for an even greater vision for the center of Manhattan and the region.
Instead of terminating at the Convention Center, the trolley could run down the waterfront along the planned Hudson River Esplanade, turn back into Manhattan and travel to Herald Square, where it would turn up Broadway toward Columbus Circle and Lincoln Center.
This route would connect Pennsylvania Station, Herald Square, Times Square, Columbus Circle and Lincoln Center to the major tourist sites and destinations on 42d Street. It would unify the core of Manhattan, physically and visually integrating pedestrian and surface transit circulation through a unifying civic design. Additionally, it would reduce traffic on Broadway and would also ease gridlock at Herald and Times Squares.
The proposal also makes great sense for commuters. It would better connect Grand Central, the Port Authority, Pennsylvania Station and PATH. It would also accommodate an increase in the number of New Jersey commuters using ferries to get to the west side of Manhattan.
The 42d Street light-rail proposal opens the door to improvements for the entire region. It should be approved now, so we can begin creating a stronger and more confident midtown as the center of a stronger region.
 
H. CLAUDE SHOSTAL
President, Regional Plan Assn.
New York, Feb. 8, 1994

HEADLINE: REPORT TO CLINTON SEES VAST EXTENT OF HOMELESSNESS

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16

 BODY:
A draft of the Administration's plan to end homelessness says the problem is "far larger than commonly thought" and calls for spending large, though unspecified, new sums on housing, mental health and tax credit programs.
The plan was ordered last spring by President Clinton and drafted by an interagency group headed by three Cabinet Secretaries. It represents a departure from a 12-year standoff between advocates for the homeless and Government officials about the scope and cause of homelessness. 
 If the draft is embraced by President Clinton, it would mark the first time the Government has called homelessness a large-scale problem that demands a large Federal response.
In what advocates for homeless people called an effort to minimize the scope of the problem, Republican Administrations had said that about 600,000 Americans were homeless on any given night, with the majority suffering from drugs, drink or mental illness. The Administration's report, by contrast, endorses recent estimates that as many as seven million Americans were homeless at some point in the late 1980's.
 
Chronic and Complex
 And while the report agrees that drugs and mental illness are common among the homeless, it also argues that poverty, racism and past budget cuts are pushing many families into the ranks of the dispossessed.
"Homelessness has become a structural problem in America: chronic, continuous, large scale, complex," said Henry G. Cisneros, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development and chairman of the group drafting the plan.
The vice chairmen are Donna E. Shalala, Secretary of Health and Human Services, and Jesse Brown, Secretary of Veterans Affairs. Mr. Cisneros agreed to discuss the plan today after an official from another agency provided a copy of the draft report to The New York Times.
The report is under review by the Office of Management and Budget and other White House officials, who may revise it at a meeting on Thursday before passing it on to the President.
Administration officials conducted extensive consultations with local governments, academic experts and advocacy groups, many of whom are giving the draft high marks for its analysis of the problem.
"It doesn't just talk about mental illness and substance abuse, it also talks about housing and poverty and racism," said Fred Karnas, director of the National Coalition for the Homeless. "It really does say what we've been trying to say for a long time."
The draft, titled "Priority: Home! The Federal Plan to End Homelessness," does not specify the amount of new spending needed to solve the problem. But it said the Department of Housing and Urban Development would spend an additional $40 billion a year if its budget had kept pace with inflation since 1980. The department spends $25 billion a year.
"We should undertake an aggressive housing development program," the report said.
The report begs a question at the heart of the ambitious Clinton agenda: where will the money come from?
 
Middle-Class Subsidy
 This task force wants to increase spending on housing and programs to prevent homelessness. But the group drafting Mr. Clinton's welfare plan recently suggested cuts in some of the same programs, to provide new programs for people on welfare.
Mr. Cisneros, who is not involved in drafting the welfare plan, said he would oppose such cuts in housing assistance. "We will make that clear, that we shouldn't be working at cross purposes," he said.
The plan for dealing with homelessness raises a politically sensitive issue in noting that prosperous homeowners receive far more in housing subsidies than poor people do. The vehicle for the middle-class subsidy is the deduction of interest on home mortgages, which the plan said cost the Federal Treasury $41 billion last year.
Of that amount, the report said, 85 percent went to the most affluent quarter of American taxpayers, who earn more than $50,000 a year. The homelessness plan does not call for ending those subsidies, but it does argue that the Government is misdirecting its resources.
 
People at Risk
 The Clinton report says the emptying of mental hospitals and the rise of crack abuse have contributed to homelessness. But it also talks about the decline in public assistance payments, which leave many women on welfare unable to afford rents, and the decline in wages for working Americans without high school educations.
"It's remarkable, in contrast to the Reagan and Bush years, in its recognition of the scope and complexity of the homeless problem," said Martha Burt, an analyst with the Urban Institute.
The plan, which was largely written by Andrew M. Cuomo, an assistant housing secretary, differentiates between two pools of people at risk of homelessness. The smaller but more visible pool, it says, are the addicts or mentally ill, many of whom inhabit public places.
The larger, but often hidden group, it says, are those suffering from chronic poverty, who can be plunged into homelessness by a sudden crisis, like a fight with a family member.
As a result, the plan recommends "increasing H.U.D.'s housing assistance budget to make up for past budget cuts." It also suggests including housing costs when figuring the tax credits alloted to low-income workers.
That potentially expensive provision, a back-door way of expanding housing assistance, has not been reviewed by the White House budget office.
The plan also calls for a sweeping reorganization of the main Federal spending program for homeless people, the McKinney Act. It calls for services to homeless people to be delivered by nonprofit groups, rather than Federal or local governments.
And it recommends expanding programs for the mentally ill, including aggressive efforts at "outreach efforts" to get disturbed people into treatment.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Homeless people taking refuge from the cold yesterday in New York, near the United Nations. (Carrie Boretz for The New York Times) (pg. A20)

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1087 words

HEADLINE: U.S. Plans to Delay Work Permits For Immigrants Who Seek Asylum

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16

 BODY:
Officials of the Immigration and Naturalization Service say they plan to charge people seeking political asylum a $130 fee and to delay issuing work permits for 150 days to try to to deter new applicants and cut the backlog of asylum claims.
The fees would make the United States the only nation in the world to charge an application fee for people who contend that they are fleeing persecution in their homelands, according to the United Nations High Commissioner on Refugees. 
 The Deputy Immigration Commissioner, Chris Sale, who described the proposed changes, said current asylum procedures were "encouraging people to abuse the system."
Existing procedures generally make it easy for immigrants to apply for asylum but place them in a legal no-man's-land awaiting hearings. Ms. Sale said the long delays in the system were also "damaging the bona fide candidates" for protection under the asylum laws.
Ms. Sale said that a work permit was a prize sought by fraudulent asylum-seekers and that delaying the permit would deter the fraud. Immigration officials say they expect word of the fees and the work-permit delays to go out on a global grapevine, slowing the flood of new asylum applicants.
Without a work permit, asylum applicants who wish to live within the law must depend on a fragile network of church groups, family or friends, since they are not entitled to welfare or any other Government assistance.
The filing fees would help pay for a proposed doubling of the corps of 150 asylum officers. The fledgling asylum corps now faces a backlog of 364,000 asylum applications. The backlog has been growing at a rate of 10,000 a month. The immigration service said that last year 18,110 claims were denied and 5,105 were approved.
Advocates of immigrants' rights applauded the agency's effort to increase the asylum corps and ease the officers' administrative burdens. But they said filing fees and restrictions on work permits were the wrong ways to combat fraud and would unfairly penalize tens of thousands of legitimate asylum-seekers.
"To wait six months for a work permit -- how will they survive?" asked Jeanne Butterfield of the American Immigration Lawyers Association.
Critics who seek a far more restrictive asylum policy derided the proposed measures as mere tinkering.
 
Right to Political Asylum
 "So long as you permit anyone to invoke the asylum process simply by getting to the United States, any administrative change is doomed to failure," said Dan Stein of the Federation for American Immigration Reform, which supports legislation pending in Congress that would summarily reject most asylum applicants now arriving at airports or border stations.
The right to political asylum is guaranteed under international law and treaties signed by the United States. Under Federal law, political asylum can be granted to an alien who can prove that he or she has been the victim of persecution or has "a well-founded fear" of persecution on the basis of race, religion, political belief or membership in a particular organization.
Last year, 150,386 people from 154 nations sought political asylum in the United States. Most came from places like Guatemala, El Salvador, the former Yugoslavia, the former Soviet Union, China, Cuba, Haiti and Liberia, nations not noted for their respect for human rights.
Tens of thousands of the applicants were really fleeing persecution, but tens of thousands clearly sought to abuse the asylum system, immigration officials say.
Under the law, most were allowed into the United States immediately, physically on free soil, but legally without a country. By invoking a claim of asylum, they were generally free to enter; most could receive a work permit within 90 days, immigration officials and lawyers say. But because of the backup in the asylum system, more than half had no foreseeable hope that their claims would be resolved.
 
Cases of Fraud
 Many applicants could use their work permits to buy phony driver's licenses, invent identities and disappear into the underground economy. Those caught at an airport with phony travel documents and no credible claim for asylum are generally detained and deported; in such cases the airline they flew in on often bore the cost of their return.
The American asylum system was altered three years ago to do away with cold-war procedures that granted protection almost exclusively to those fleeing Communism. The backlog of asylum applications that the Clinton Administration inherited included tens of thousands of people whom Federal judges found had been denied due process in the 1980's.
But the new system received little money from Congress. The asylum corps, far smaller than its counterparts in Australia, Britain, France, Germany, Holland, Norway, Sweden or Switzerland, survives on fees raised by other immigration programs.
Its top officers say it cannot cope with the growing numbers of legitimate and illegitimate asylum-seekers; nor can it readily distinguish the victims of political terror from the potential terrorist.
"The system in the past year and a half has just collapsed under its own weight," said Carol Wolchok, director of the American Bar Association's center for immigration law. She said the immigration service needed millions of dollars to increase, train and equip the asylum corps.
A working corps would insure a quick, full hearing for all asylum applicants, she said, adding that this would be both a deterrent to fraud and the fairest way to deal with genuine asylum applicants, she said.
"Once it's in place, there will be a dramatic drop in false claims," she said. "The system would be used by the people it's intended for."
The new filing fees and work-permit strictures proposed by the immigration service are to be published soon in the Federal Register, the digest of proposed Government rules, and could take effect as early as Oct. 1. It is unclear under what procedures the agency might waive a filing fee or grant a work permit more speedily.
If Ms. Sale is correct, the new rules would deter thousands of fraudulent asylum seekers and lighten asylum officers' burdens. But if proponents of stricter laws are right, they will do little to control false claims. And if immigrants' advocates are correct, they could force asylum applicants, who cannot receive welfare or other Government assistance, to work illegally or go hungry while they wait for an overburdened system to notify them that their day for a hearing has arrived.

HEADLINE: SAUDI AIR TO BUY $6 BILLION IN JETS BUILT IN THE U.S.

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16

 BODY:
After intense lobbying by President Clinton and his top advisers, the Administration announced today that Saudi Arabia had decided to replace its fleet of commercial jets with American planes. The $6 billion sale should provide jobs for tens of thousands of Americans.
Announcing the decision at the White House with Saudi Arabia's Ambassador, Prince Bandar bin Sultan, by his side, President Clinton said the sale was an example of how his Administration intended to campaign for contracts for United States businesses as ferociously as European and Asian governments have done for theirs. 
 The yearlong competition for the contract for some 50 planes for Saudia Airlines was one of the biggest global business contests in a decade, pitting the Boeing Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation against the European consortium Airbus Industrie.
 
'A Gold Medal'
 The Europeans had urged Saudi Arabia to split the deal at least 50-50, but under heavy pressure from the United States, King Fahd threw all the business Washington's way.
Mr. Clinton, who had lobbied King Fahd for months with phone calls and letters, sounded today like a victorious commander just back from the trade wars. Evoking the Olympics, Mr. Clinton declared the agreement "a gold medal win for America's businesses and workers."
What won the Saudis over, American officials said, was a combination of financing provided by the Export-Import Bank and Washington's position as Saudi Arabia's principal arms supplier. Riyadh thus has an interest in maintaining the health of the United States aerospace industry.
Indeed, the $6 billion contract will temporarily resuscitate the aerospace industry. [Business Day, page D1.]
 
The Ties That Sell
 For Saudi Arabia, which is flanked by two dangerous foes, Iran and Iraq, the deal is like buying insurance: It strengthens the economic bond between Riyadh and Washington and improves the chances that the Clinton Administration would come to the kingdom's defense, just as the Bush Administration built a allied coalition against Iraq in the gulf war.
Prince Bandar alluded to this, saying Saudi Arabia felt a responsibility to be "a strategic asset and not a strategic liability" for the United States. Thus, he said, Riyadh is ready to share the burden of maintaining the quality of the United States aerospace industry.
Mr. Clinton said the Export-Import Bank, a Government institution that helps to finance United States exports, was prepared to guarantee financing for most of the total cost of the planes. This, he said, will support "tens of thousands of American jobs in Washington, California, Kansas, Missouri, Utah, Arkansas and several other states." The Administration estimates that every $1 billion in exports creates or maintains about 20,000 jobs.
 
A Big Guarantee
 It is not clear how much of the loan guarantees Saudi Arabia and their United States suppliers will use. The bank is ready to guarantee up to $6.2 billion of the final price, which may include extras like service contracts. If the Saudis and the two companies take the full amount, it will be the biggest loan guarantee ever by the bank.
The bank stepped in last July when it became apparent that Airbus Industrie was offering government-backed financing from its members -- Spain, France, Britain and Germany.
The bank guarantees repayment of commercial loans that Boeing, McDonnell Douglas and Saudi Arabia might need to complete the contract. This guarantee lowers the interest rates commercial banks would normally charge. There is virtually no cost to the American taxpayer unless Saudi Arabia should default, which is unlikely.
 
A Shift in Emphasis
 Saudi Arabia has had some economic problems, however, brought on by a drop in oil exports because of a worldwide glut, a fall in oil prices and years of heavy spending that has eroded its cash reserves.
Though other Administrations have lobbied foreign governments on behalf of big exporters, the focus was usually on arms sales. With the arms trade shrinking and exports now playing a more vital role in the United States economy, the Administration has taken a higher profile in such efforts.
Saudi Arabia has invited Boeing and McDonnell Douglas officials to Riyadh on March 20 to negotiate the final details of which planes are wanted and at which price. United States officials say they expect the Saudis to split their business evenly, buying about $3 billion worth of 747's from Boeing and $3 billion worth of the 300-passenger MD-11's and smaller MD-80's and MD-90's from McDonnell Douglas. Boeing is based in Seattle, McDonnell Douglas in Long Beach, Calif.
 
A Chat in the Oval Office
 Given Saudi Arabia's cash-flow problems, delivery of the jets could be stretched out over the rest of the decade. The contracts will also benefit the Pratt & Whitney division of the United Technologies Corporation in Connecticut and the General Electric Company in Ohio, which build engines for the planes.
The deal began to come together in July when Prince Bandar was brought to the Oval Office to hear a personal sales pitch from the President. Mr. Clinton, aides said, told the Ambassador that the deal would be critical in helping both the aerospace industry and the United States economy.
A month later, Mr. Clinton telephoned King Fahd and made the same pitch.
In August, King Fahd tentatively promised Mr. Clinton that he would give the United States his business, and news to that effect leaked out. But it was not confirmed by Riyadh, and it turned out to be only the beginning.
 
What the King Wanted
 King Fahd first wanted a commitment from the Export-Import Bank, which he soon received. Then, the King asked for time to work through some of Saudi Arabia's financial problems and to deal with the Europeans.
It was not until Prime Minister Edouard Balladur of France visited Riyadh in December, on a sales trip of his own, that King Fahd finally told him that Airbus Industrie would get nothing. United States officials believe the Saudis were miffed at efforts by France to improve ties with Iraq.
But the Saudis still would not complete the deal until Washington worked out an agreement to reschedule $9.2 billion in payments due for Saudi arms purchases from five United States companies. The Saudis said falling oil prices had forced them to slash annual spending by 20 percent and they needed to stretch out their payments, primarily for 72 F-15 fighter jets, which are made by McDonnell Douglas. That deal was completed two weeks ago.
The chairmen of the two companies, Frank A. Shrontz of Boeing and John F. McDonnell of McDonnell Douglas, also attended today's ceremony. In a bit of understatement about the pressure behind the scenes, Mr. Shrontz said, "I'd like to thank you and your Administration, Mr. President, for helping to communicate to our customers the importance of this transaction."

HEADLINE: With New Republican Allies, Cuomo Pushes Medicaid Plan

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 16

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo renewed his push today for a complex plan to ease the large and growing costs of Medicaid on New York City and county governments and offered to sweeten the deal with more money sooner from the state.
Mr. Cuomo said an improving economy would give the state unexpected revenues, allowing it to give New York City and the 57 other county governments a total of $110 million in the state's fiscal year, which begins on April 1. That would be a small fraction of the $3.4 billion that those governments are expected to spend on Medicaid in the coming fiscal year. 
 Mr. Cuomo said that two-thirds of the $110 million, or about $73 million, would go to New York City, which is looking for $265 million in state aid to help close a projected gap of $2.3 billion in its budget for the fiscal year that begins on July 1.
 
Rising Burden on Counties
 New York is one of the few states that require local governments to pay a share of the cost of Medicaid, the federally mandated health insurance program for the poor. The program's rising cost has become a huge financial burden on New York City and on many county governments, particularly during the recent economic downturn.
The broad strokes of the Cuomo plan, which the Governor has tried and failed before to get through the Legislature, call for the state to take over the local share of Medicaid over the next seven years while also taking some of the revenue produced by local income or sales taxes.
While they would have to give up some taxing power, local officials, including Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York City, generally favor the deal because most forecasts suggest that Medicaid costs will continue to climb faster than the revenues from taxes, so they will get more than they give up. But if that turns out to be wrong, the Governor's plan calls for the state to assume all the risk by promising never to take more tax revenue from local governments than it sends them in Medicaid relief.
In addition, the trading of taxes for Medicaid takeover would not begin for four years, so in the first three years the localities would gain help from the state at no cost.
Despite the considerable local support, the Republicans who control the State Senate have repeatedly blocked Mr. Cuomo's plan. But the situation has changed in two ways this year: The Governor has attracted the support of a group of influential local Republicans, led by Mr. Giuliani, and he proposed today for the first time to put up state money in the first year of the plan, sweetening the deal for localities.
The announcement by the Governor, a Democrat, was a significant tactical victory for the Mayor, a Republican, who had lobbied Mr. Cuomo aggressively to include the money in his budget for the 1995 fiscal year. It set the stage for a major test of Mr. Giuliani's influence with his fellow Republicans in the Senate, who had opposed Mr. Cuomo's earlier proposals. Mr. Giuliani's aides predicted today that it would be far more difficult for the Senate to reject a Medicaid takeover now that Mr. Cuomo essentially had put money up front to begin paying for it.
"The fact that there's money in now makes for a completely new chapter," said Robert M. Harding, Mr. Giuliani's lobbyist in Albany. "It automatically makes it legitimate for discussion."
It is far from certain today that the Legislature will agree with Mr. Cuomo's call to spend the new money on a state Medicaid takeover, rather than on other popular election-year programs like aid to schools, tax cuts, anti-crime efforts and jobs programs.
 
Cuomo Changes Course
 Leaders of both the Democratic-controlled Assembly and the Republican-majority Senate refused to make commitments, saying only that they would consider a Medicaid takeover plan in coming budget negotiations along with other proposals.
The Governor's announcement reversed the course he set in his Jan. 18 executive budget proposal. That plan did not include money to finance a Medicaid takeover plan in the next fiscal year.
Mr. Cuomo has proposed a state Medicaid takeover every year since 1991. But under his past proposals, New York City and the county governments would have benefited financially only starting in the second year of a seven-year plan. What changed today is that they would profit in the first year, providing immediate budget relief for Mr. Giuliani and the state's county executives.
In a year when Mr. Cuomo is running for a fourth four-year term, the change was seen in Albany as a nod to local government leaders who have blamed Mr. Cuomo for forcing them to increase property taxes by cutting unrestricted state aid to cities, counties, villages and towns. Some legislators and lobbyists said the decision also seemed to be a direct appeal by Mr. Cuomo to Mr. Giuliani's supporters, including the moderate Republicans and Independents he may need to win in November.
 
Dinkins Got Less Help
 "I think he feels pressure so he's putting it out there," said the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, Democrat of Manhattan.o
But the Governor's announcement left some aides to former Mayor David N. Dinkins wondering why Mr. Dinkins did not receive the same financial help from his fellow Democrat, especially in the 1993 election year. "We were arguing vociferously for it from the day we got in office," said Norman Steisel, the former First Deputy Mayor.
Mr. Cuomo said at a news conference today that there was only one difference: "We have more money this year."
Mr. Cuomo argues that there are sensible reasons for what may seem a complex maneuver, whose financial benefit to localities could be achieved far more simply if the state just wrote a check to each one.
 
State Taxes Called Fairer
 But that would not give the state control of the $10 billion Medicaid program, which Mr. Cuomo argues is necessary to control costs truly. In structuring his takeover this way, Mr. Cuomo would get control of Medicaid but not have to bear the entire cost from current state revenue.
Mr. Cuomo also argues that the state's tax base, broader and more reliant on the progressive income tax, is fairer than the property taxes most localities use to support Medicaid.
Under Mr. Cuomo's seven-year plan, the state and local governments would work to reduce Medicaid costs during the first three years, largely by increasing the use of managed care programs by Medicaid patients. During that period the state also would begin to pay for local administrative costs for the Medicaid programs. The $110 million would be part of that.
In the last four years, the state would gradually begin to pick up the actual local share of Medicaid payments to health-care providers, while begining to collect local tax revenue from New York City and the counties.
