HEADLINE: Storming the Snow In a Family Humvee;
Gulf War Car Wins Civilian Sales

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LITTLE FALLS, N.J., Feb. 15

 BODY:
It may be nearly as wide as a semitrailer truck, as heavy as two ordinary cars and as expensive as a modest home in some parts of the country. But in a car culture in love with four-wheel-drive vehicles, and in a winter that has often defeated conventional automobiles, it has been embraced by a devoted few as the thing to drive.
"I have five cars in my family," said Audray Baker of Flemington, N.J., "but this winter, it's the only one that can get up my driveway." 
 Mrs. Baker is one of a small but growing group of drivers who own Hummers, the big-shouldered, civilian version of the military's High Mobility Multipurpose Wheeled Vehicle -- the darling of the Persian Gulf war. At $50,000 apiece, seven feet wide and weighing three tons, Hummers -- the civilian version has been available for 18 months -- seat only four people and may strike some as laughably expensive and wildly impractical.
This winter, as the ice has followed the snow, time after time, Hummers have also gained a reputation as one car that will not get stuck, as well as being a sports-utility vehicle -- the fastest-growing segment of the car market -- that the neighbors are unlikely to have.
Which would help explain why Bob Greces, president of the Princeton Motorsport dealership in Lawrenceville, N.J., who normally sells just one Hummer per month, has sold six this month alone. Mr. Greces's two Hummer agencies -- the other is in Lyndhurst, N.J. -- are part of a chain of three outlets in the New York region for Hummers; the other is in Fairfield, Conn.
 
Winter Is Great for Sales
 "I would expect sales to be picking up anyway, now that the vehicle is getting established," Mr. Greces said, "but the weather this winter has just been terrific for sales."
Over all, AM General has sold about 1,000 Hummers since their introduction in the fall of 1992. Of those, 162 were sold nationwide by 36 dealers just last month, said Susan Carney, a spokeswoman for the manufacturer. AM General was originally part of the American Motors Company, which was in turn a descendant of the Willys Company, builder of the original World War II Army jeep. In addition to the Hummer, AM General builds heavy trucks for the military.
The United States military has been using the trucks, which they call Humvees, for nine years. It was during the gulf war that the blunt, desert-colored Humvees were in nearly every picture, introducing them to the country's automotive consciousness.
The war and its remembered glory got Joseph P. Gutilla on the telephone to the manufacturer as soon as production of the civilian version was announced. He wasn't fast enough to beat Arnold Schwarzenegger, however; the actor was at the top of the list for the first one. But Mr. Gutilla, who owns a trucking firm here, did manage to buy one of the first Hummers that year, and then traded it in for a new, red one this winter.
"I've been through a bunch of four-wheel-drive vehicles," Mr. Gutilla said, "but when I saw these things on TV during the gulf war, and being a vet myself, they made an impression on me. They're like the American spirit, and when people see them, it gives them that feeling again. It's nothing like driving a Range Rover."
To begin with, the Hummer on close inspection is nearly all wheels and motor. To achieve its 16-inch ground clearance under the chassis, the manufacturers have moved the engine and transmission into the passenger compartment. That leaves room for four bucket seats at each corner of the interior, with the engine and transmission housing extending front to back, rather like a refrigerator laid between the seats.
Sharing the inside of a car with a big hump for the motor and transmission was hardly a problem for the military, which likes its machine guns and anti-tank weapons mounted high enough for a clear line of fire anyway. For Mrs. Baker, however, there was some trepidation about buying when she realized that the vehicle's roomy outward appearance camouflaged very limited interior passenger room. Still, her four grown sons prevailed on her to consider a Hummer as a replacement for the family Isuzu Trooper.
 
Growls but Likes Puppies
 "At first I was surprised, because you expect something that wide to have loads of room to seat people," she said. "I thought, 'This is going to be a problem.' But I found you can still stuff groceries and bags and puppies in there."
The Hummer's diesel engine growls but is not obtrusive. And with automatic transmissions, power steering and brakes, along with such modern necessities as air conditioning and stereo sound systems, the Hummer is, except for its width, like any other car to drive. Among its several unusual features is a central tire inflation system that allows the driver to lower tire pressure for driving on sand, and then to re-inflate the tires while driving.
"It feels very safe to me," said Mrs. Baker, who commutes daily to a nighttime nursing job in her Hummer.
In fact, Mr. Gutilla pointed out, in last week's snowstorm the only problem he had in his Hummer was getting around stuck cars. The problem was easily solved. He had only to mount an old truck tire in front of his Hummer, and help the others get on their way.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Hummers, at $50,000 apiece, are the civilian version of the military's High Mobility Multipurpose Wheeled Vehicle -- the darling of the Persian Gulf war. (Norman Y. Lono for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Saudi Sale Should Brighten Aircraft Makers' Dark Days

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 16

 BODY:
Saudi Arabia's decision today to purchase $6 billion in commercial aircraft from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation and the Boeing Company will temporarily revive an industry facing one of its worst downturns.
The deal is expected to increase sluggish production at McDonnell Douglas and Boeing, the country's two biggest plane builders, and to preserve thousands of jobs at the companies and their subcontractors. 
 But the deal is not expected to dramatically improve the broad economies of the Seattle or Los Angeles-Long Beach areas, where the two manufacturers have big plants.
McDonnell and Boeing won the contract over the European consortium Airbus Industrie, amid heavy lobbying by the Clinton Administration. President Clinton announced the deal in Washington today, saying it would sustain jobs for tens of thousands of Americans.
Company officials and economists said that it was too early to know if the aircraft order would create new jobs, but that at a minimum, it would let McDonnell Douglas and Boeing avoid near-term layoffs.
Specifics of the sale were not released and were expected to be negotiated at a meeting next month among Boeing, McDonnell and Saudi officials to determine the number and type of planes to be bought.
American trade officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that the Saudis were likely to buy 50 to 60 aircraft and that 60 percent of the $6 billion was expected to go to McDonnell Douglas.
While officials of the companies declined to say what the Saudi sale would mean to the companies' overall finances, some analysts predicted that it would increase their revenues about 10 percent a year over a two- to three-year delivery period.
The Saudi deal is likely to mean more to St. Louis-based McDonnell Douglas, the nation's largest military supplier, whose commercial aircraft division has been struggling. McDonnell's commercial jet unit, based in Long Beach, has had few new orders for planes in recent years. Its manufacturing costs are high, and it does not have the money to develop jets.
Many aircraft-industry analysts have questioned whether McDonnell Douglas can sustain production with so few orders, and some industry experts have predicted that the company will quit the commercial aircraft business sometime this decade -- an assertion McDonnell dismisses.
McDonnell Douglas officials said today that the Saudi order would stabilize employment at its commercial division and throughout its network of suppliers. The company has reduced its commercial aircraft work force to 11,000 employees from a peak of 42,000 in 1990.
 
Two Approving Views
 Don Hanson, a McDonnell spokesman, said the Saudi deal was a "very important milestone because it will help to fill a lot of gaps in production lines in the years ahead."
An analyst for Paine Webber, Jack Modzelewski, also applauded the deal. "This deal was critical for McDonnell Douglas's survival," he said. "They have no new products in development, no partnership as of yet, and very few orders. They are on a life-support system."
Economists said that while the Saudi deal might not have an immediate effect on the Southern California economy, they expected it to stem the loss of jobs in the long term, particularly because many Boeing and McDonnell subcontractors are situated in the region. For example, Rohr Industries, which makes the pylons for McDonnell's MD-11, is based in San Diego, and the Northrop Corporation, based in Los Angeles, makes the fuselage for the Boeing 747.
Lynn Reaser, chief economist for First Interstate Bank, said that "because we are still on a downward trend in terms of defense cuts, the net effect of the Saudi deal will be to help balance things out -- to offset some of the job losses and economic losses that are coming."
Commercial aircraft jobs have dropped 40 percent in Los Angeles County, to 74,000 now from a peak of 126,000 jobs in 1987. The manufacturers are getting scant help from passenger airlines, most of which are ordering few jets these days.
Shares of McDonnell Douglas closed today at $118.875, up $1.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. Boeing's shares finished the day at $46.50, up $2.125.
Larry Clarkson, Boeing's vice president for planning and international development, said he expected the Saudis to order several Boeing 747 jets, but did not know if they would also buy the 777 or other new models.
In Seattle, economists said that the Saudi deal might end Boeing's layoffs, which have kept the region in an economic rut. Last year, Boeing reduced its work force to 87,160 employees from 98,325 in 1992. The company has said it plans another 7,000 layoffs this year. Boeing officials did not know if the new order would reduce the planned layoffs.

HEADLINE: Drug Makers, Happy, Still Fear Bureaucracy

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Feb. 16

 BODY:
Officials of American pharmaceutical companies active in Russia today welcomed the pact with the United States on marketing drugs as a way to ease the delays and expenses of obtaining sales approvals from the Russian Government.
But some business people who have run the gantlet of the Health Ministry expressed skepticism that the agreement could cut through a bureaucracy hampered by a lack of computers and the stampede of applicants seeking entry into the Russian market. 
 "I think it is a healthy step, because until now it has been very, very hard to understand the registration system," said Sergei A. Tsvetkov, a partner in Sarmite U.S.A., which holds distribution rights here for Rugby Laboratories Inc., a manufacturer of generic drugs in Rockville Centre, L.I. "There is not one room where they will tell you how to do it, whom to approach first, in short, 'Where's Papa?' Someone still will be keeping the people who have lined up in order."
If the agreement works, Eli Lilly & Company should quickly win approval to market five pharmaceuticals in Russia, the medical director for the company in Moscow, Aleksei V. Sergeyev, said. The drugs include glucagon, which has been used to treat diabetics in the United States for 20 years and has a close analog in use here.
But Mr. Sergeyev said, "We all have doubts as to whether it will really be implemented because we all have experience working here in Russian circumstances."
 
From One to Two Years
 Registering a drug with the Health Ministry has usually taken American companies one to two years, depending on whether the ministry orders clinical trials and on how many connections a company has. At least three committees in the ministry have had roles in awarding quality certificates and sales licenses. Clinical trials, which have to include a minimum of 50 patients, can cost $200 to $1,000 a patient.
Under the new system, companies applying to register drugs that the United States Food and Drug Administration has approved have just to file the proper documents with the Health Ministry. The ministry will continue to monitor the quality of the medicines.
Mr. Sergeyev said the agreement could also help Russian concerns, which would could cooperate with American businesses to produce pharmaceuticals. Like other sectors of the Russian economy, the pharmaceutical industry has been hit hard by the collapse of centralized control of production and the privatization of some factories.
Pharmacies have to pay hard currency to buy drugs previously available from republics like Lithuania and Ukraine and East European countries like Bulgaria, East Germany and Hungary. "Prices have risen 1,000, 1,500 times over the last few years," said Lina D. Kochalayeva, director of a 24-hour pharmacy on Peace Prospect in Moscow. "Still, we can offer a much richer assortment today." In part that is because many foreign companies recognize the market's importance.
Distributors of generic drugs said the accord could help their sales and would help bring down prices. "Now if you have a good product and good prices, you can get into the market," said Natasha F. Kuznetsova, a vice president of Mypharm, a distributor. "It will be the F.D.A., and not some bureaucrat, giving the green light."

HEADLINE: Russia Allows Sale of Drugs Made in U.S.

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16

 BODY:
The Administration announced today that Russia had agreed to allow the sale of virtually all drugs made in the United States and approved by the Food and Drug Administration.
The agreement, which takes effect immediately, was described by the F.D.A. as the first in which any nation has formally agreed to rely so heavily on another nation to insure that drugs sold are safe and effective. 
 Any prescription or nonprescription drug made in the United States and approved by the F.D.A. will be assured of approval within 90 days in Russia. Pharmaceutical companies are simply required to give the Health Ministry documentation of the approval.
 
Ready to Apply and Ship
 Dr. Mary K. Pendergast, the deputy F.D.A. commissioner who led the negotiations with the Russians over the last year, said that important medicines like antibiotics, insulin and drugs to combat high blood pressure were in extremely short supply in Russia and that American companies were ready to apply soon to ship those drugs.
The agreement is also expected to be a boon for American drug companies that have faced obstacles entering the Russian market, particularly if Russia can stabilize its economy.
Russia buys $300 million to $400 million in foreign drugs annually in a poorly supplied and chaotic marketplace, the F.D.A. said, and American drugs account for $7 million of that total. Countries like France and Italy each have total drug markets of about $12 billion annually, the industry says. The United States market is $58 billion annually.
 
'A Big Market'
 Richard R. Saul, assistant vice president for Europe at the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association here, said the market in Russia had been very unstable and frustrating for years.
"It is very hard going," Mr. Saul added. "But potentially it could be large. Companies view this as a very long-term investment, and the prize in the end is a share of a big market."
Under the previous system in Russia, companies had to submit data in Russian on all chemical, animal and human tests, duplicate the human experiments inside Russia and submit the entire package to the Ministry of Health and Medical Industry. The process was expensive and took years, and the outcomes were unpredictable. Of thousands of drugs approved by the Food and Drug Administration, 40 have been approved for sale in Russia.
But beginning today, Ms. Pendergast said, the Health Ministry has agreed to approve American-made and F.D.A.-approved drugs within 90 days of the submission of a basic description of the drug and its action, a copy of the official approval letter and the latest Federal inspection reports from the manufacturer.
 
Unresolved Liability Questions
 The F.D.A. is trying to devise a way to inform the Russians by computer about safety problems that arise involving drugs it has approved. Ms. Pendergast said that Russia had little civil, property or contract law and that questions about liability had not been resolved.
Vice President Al Gore said the agreement was a breakthrough in "our efforts to open new doors and forge new partnerships that recognize how the world has changed."
Dr. Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, said in an interview: "The public-health dimension of this cannot be stressed enough. We have enormous respect for the Russian scientists and we hope to help them help the Russian people."
American drug companies were elated because the agreement gives them a potential advantage in Russia and because it is a strong shot in the competition for world markets.
Gerald Mossinghoff, president of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, which represents large drug companies in Washington, said that this was the first time that one nation had accepted the regulatory approval of another, but that European nations would soon be doing so among themselves. The rules would be established in the European Union under which a drug approved by one nation would be assumed to be approved by other members, unless there were special circumstances.
 
Consistency in Testing
 The F.D.A. has set up an international conference on "harmonization," trying to assure that studies of animals and humans by drug companies can be used to have drugs approved in more than one country. Now, for example, one country may require a two-year study of a drug's effects in beagles and a rodent study with 2,000 animals, while another country requires a seven-year dog study and work with 500 rodents.
The United States and Japan are also working to establish common requirements. "The ultimate goal," Mr. Mossinghoff said, "is that we would accept each other's drug approvals. But Russia is right there today, and that is a big step."
The accord with Russia was executed by an eight-page memorandum of understanding signed by the Food and Drug Commissioner, Dr. David Kessler, in Washington on Jan. 28 and signed by the Russian Health Minister, Eduard A. Nechayev, on Tuesday.
The agreement covers all drugs and biological products, but not homeopathic medicines or medical devices. It states that for drugs and biological products, "The Russian Federation participants will accept F.D.A.'s decisions and regulations on premarket approval, licensing, monographs and related matters, as well as F.D.A.'s product-quality standards and enforcement of manufacturing controls and other requirements."
 
Influence in Other Countries
 If a company provides the documentation to Russia, "the Russian Federation participants will not require, as a condition of importation, the conduct of any additional clinical or analytical review or testing."
F.D.A. approval carries great weight for health ministries around the world. Many nations, especially in the third world, use the approvals as informal guides about the safety and effectiveness of drugs.
The Food and Drug Administration has approved 2,500 prescription drugs, of which 200 account for 80 to 90 percent of total sales, said Jeff Warren of the manufacturers' group.
Also covered by the agreement are thousands of over-the-counter products like cold remedies and hemorrhoidal compounds. About $13 billion of thosedrugs are sold in this country each year. The provision that the drugs and products be manufactured in the United States restricts the agreement to the plants that the F.D.A. regularly inspects.
 
Possible Additional Accord
 The agreement also states that the F.D.A. and the Russian ministry will sign a memorandum in six months to cover medical devices and some food additives. Many devices are virtually unregulated in the United States, making an agreement on acceptance more difficult to reach, as the agency cannot vouch for their safety and effectiveness.
The obstacles for American drug companies to selling drugs in Russia over the years have been large. In the Soviet Union the Government tightly limited access, and most drugs were manufactured by Eastern bloc countries and a few favored sources, including India and Japan.
In the post-Soviet era some countries that have been selling to the region for years have been able to obtain drug approvals from the Russians more easily than others. The new agreement will shift that balance and may give American products a significant advantage.
But more important obstacles to sales are the chaotic state of the economy, the lack of money and the problems in distributing and selling products in Russia.
"It will be at least 10 years, if things go well, before all this will be sorted out," said Mr. Saul, of the manufacturers' group. "But it is a great chance."

HEADLINE: Arafat Must Ask Who's a Friend, Who's an Enemy

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TUNIS, Feb. 16

 BODY:
Dogged by enemies who have vowed to gun him down, a financial crisis so severe he can no longer pay salaries and difficulties in his talks with Israel, Yasir Arafat says he is struggling to keep the rancorous P.L.O. from disintegrating even before it takes control of the Gaza Strip and the West Bank town of Jericho.
"The Israeli Government is not in a hurry to implement this agreement," he said in an interview today, "but this is a dangerous policy that could backfire." 
 The 65-year-old guerrilla leader, his eyes watery and red with fatigue, said he has lurched from one disappointment to another since signing the Palestinian accord with Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin in September. The agreement was to have led to Israel's withdrawal from the Gaza Strip and the West Bank town of Jericho by Dec. 13, but the withdrawal is still being negotiated with the Palestine Liberation Organization.
 
Blaming Washington
 Mr. Arafat spoke about his difficulties as he sat, well after midnight, in his office in Tunis, slumped forward in a gray swivel chair. Most of Tunis, where he has his headquarters on a quiet, tree-lined street, had gone to bed.
Mr. Arafat, who spoke in both English and Arabic, said he could not understand why so much had turned so sour on the eve of triumph. "The only thing that has not been a surprise," he said during the hourlong interview, "is the 18-hour days."
The P.L.O. chairman pinned much of the blame for the delay on what he said was the passivity of the Clinton Administration.
"We asked the Americans to play a positive role," he said. "We asked them not to leave us alone with the Israelis. But the Americans have not intervened to make sure that what was signed in Washington, under the auspices of President Clinton, is implemented. The Americans have intervened in the negotiations for the Syrians, the Lebanese and the Jordanians. They have intervened for everyone except the Palestinians."
Mr. Arafat, a pistol strapped to his right hip and a compact black machine-gun tucked behind his desk, said Prime Minister Rabin was correct when he cautioned that negotiations were at least a month away from being concluded.
"The size of the security force and the police force are still one of the problems which have not been settled," he said. "The size of the Jericho area has not been settled. We have not determined the size of the security zones around the Jewish settlements or the differences between the bridges that cross the Jordan River and the border crossing with Egypt at Rafa. There are problems concerning the administration, security and the liaison bureaus."
 
Guns, Guns Everywhere
 But what seemed to bother Mr. Arafat most was the struggle to keep the Palestinian movement from tearing itself apart. He referred repeatedly to weapons that he said are pouring into the Gaza Strip and the West Bank, blaming the Israelis for not halting the arms traffic. The arms, coupled with the delay in carrying out the agreement, could push the occupied territories into anarchy, he said.
"This weapons trade is being carried out under the auspices of some Israeli officers in the West Bank and Gaza Strip," he said. "This is part of a wicked plan. Once the Israelis withdraw, these weapons will not be used against the Israelis, but against whom? It could lead to another Afghanistan among the Palestinians. This is a very serious game."
Israeli officials have denied any involvement in arms trafficking.
Mr. Arafat dismissed the harsh criticism of the P.L.O. peace accord by Syria and Libya, saying, "Only the Palestinians and the Israelis shall have the power to damage the agreement."
But he also said the P.L.O. was in trouble, racked by dissent and by a serious lack of money. The hundreds of millions of dollars the P.L.O. chairman once spent lavishly to cement alliances, maintain offices in European and Arab capitals and keep dissidents mollified have dried up.
 
$50 Million Would Help
 The financial crisis became serious when the Persian Gulf states ended their huge contributions because of Mr. Arafat's sympathy for Iraq during the gulf war. Disastrous investments, including banana groves in Somalia and chicken farms, compounded the losses.
Mr. Arafat said he now pleads for money just to keep operating, adding that Saudi Arabia, after a recent reconciliation, had promised $100 million but that no money had arrived. Western donors have also promised hundreds of millions of dollars once the self-rule begins, but for now the P.L.O. is broke.
"If I could just get $50 million, it would solve so many of my problems," he said, gesturing with a pale hand.
Mr. Arafat several times recalled the loss of important lieutenants: Khalil Wazir, known as Abu Jihad, was killed in 1988 by agents believed to be from Israeli intelligence; Salah Khalaf, known as Abu Iyad, was killed in 1991 by gunmen believed to be in the service of the Palestinian terrorist Abu Nidal.
 
Mourning '11 Martyrs'
 When Mr. Arafat was told last October that another aide, Assad Saftawi, had been assassinated in the Gaza Strip, the third associate killed since the peace accord was signed, he shut himself in his suite at Le Crillon Hotel in Paris and wept, according to those who were with him.
"In this march I have lost my nearest and greatest brothers and leaders," he said, "and I am still paying a price. There are so many we have lost, 11 martyrs so far."
The threat of assassination is never far from the minds of his security detail, who hovered in the room and stood outside the door of his sparsely furnished office, which is filled with huge color pictures of Jerusalem. Black-uniformed troops, under the glare of floodlights, patrolled in front of the modest stucco house where Mr. Arafat lives and works.
"What we fear most is not these dissident groups," said one aide, "but some crazy Palestinian with a gun."

HEADLINE: VIETNAM'S EXODUS IS DECLARED OVER

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam, Feb. 16

 BODY:
The era of "boat people" from Vietnam has been declared over, and Vietnamese fleeing their country will no longer be entitled to at least temporary asylum as political refugees.
"A chapter is coming to an end in Indochina and Southeast Asia," Sadako Ogata, United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, said earlier in the week at the conclusion of a special meeting at the United Nations refugee organization's Geneva headquarters. 
 Less than two weeks since the United States lifted its trade embargo on Vietnam, the refugee group's steering committee ruled that from now on, Vietnamese who flee would no longer be automatically entitled to consideration for a grant of asylum as political refugees but would be treated as asylum-seekers from any other nation. This means that if the country where the migrants land rules that they are not refugees from persecution they can be sent home immediately.
"The conference stated that the international community will not and cannot pay indefinitely to provide free food, free housing and free medical care for these people," the High Commissioner's office announced.
 
Special Status for 'Boat People'
 Until now, "boat people" were generally given special treatment, with a right to at least temporary asylum until their cases could be studied.
"The Vietnamese cannot be treated any differently from other groups of asylum-seekers," Mrs. Ogata said. She cited "generally positive trends" of development in Vietnam.
Since 1986, when aid from the Soviet Union began dwindling, Hanoi has encouraged the establishment of a market economy and opened its doors to participation by foreign investors and businessmen. The lifting of the American economic embargo on Feb. 4 is expected to bring a more rapid rise in living standards in a country where the average citizen earns little more than $200 a year.
Only about 60,000 "boat people" remain in camps in Asia, and most of them have been determined to be economic migrants rather than refugees. They will be returned to Vietnam, even against their will. The High Commissioner's office reported that last month, 2,844 Vietnamese were voluntarily repatriated. Since the refugees are given no alternative, the use of the word "voluntary" has been a subject of protest by humanitarian organizations.
Only 55 persons fled by small boats in 1992. The number rose to 777 last year. They fled mainly to Japan, prompted by rumors here that Tokyo would either allow them to work there or return them with large cash payments. Most of the refugees of the last decade have been North Vietnamese, with no connection to the former South Vietnamese Government or its American backers, and have had relatively safe passages from the region of the port city of Haiphong along the Chinese coast to Hong Kong.
 
Mass Exodus in 1970's
 At its height, from the fall of South Vietnam in 1975 to the early 1980's, the stream of "boat people" was a dramatic flight of hundreds of thousands of South Vietnamese ready to throw their lives and that of their children on the mercy of the South China Sea, mainly in fishing boats not built to withstand such rigors. How many of them perished cannot be known.
After China invaded northern Vietnam in 1979, the Vietnamese authorities singled out the ethnic Chinese minority for particular pressure to emigrate. They loaded ancient freighters with thousands of ethnic Chinese, who had to pay in gold for their forced flight, and sent them onto the sea. The arrival of such ships led to extended disputes between Western and Southeast Asian countries before the passengers were granted temporary asylum, usually in Malaysia.
Nearly 800,000 refugees from Vietnam reached safety, mainly in Malaysia, Thailand and Hong Kong. Many did so after watching fellow refugees die from hunger, thirst or exposure. Many others were killed, raped, robbed, brutally beaten and subjected to indignities by fishermen, mainly Thai, who found preying on refugees more rewarding than their normal occupation. Others lost their lives when hostile security forces drove them from their shores or towed them back onto the open sea.
 
Most Came to U.S.
 The great majority of the "boat people" found refuge in the United States. After flying out 135,000 Vietnamese in the final days of the Saigon Government, the United States accepted almost no further refugees from its former allies in Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos, until press reports of their plight in 1977 caused the Administration of President Jimmy Carter to open immigration quotas for them. At the peak of admission to the United States, 168,000 refugees a year entered.
Under international pressure, Vietnam agreed in 1979 to the "Orderly Departure Program," which made possible legal emigration, usually to reunite divided families. Nearly 500,000 Vietnamese have emigrated under the program since 1980, more than 350,000 of them to the United States.
The American total includes two groups admitted to the United States under agreements between the two countries. They are people who say they are the offspring of Americans who served in South Vietnam before 1975 and Vietnamese women, and their relatives, and former officers and officials of the Saigon Government who were confined in rugged and isolated areas termed "re-education camps," as well as their families.

HEADLINE: HOSOKAWA CLINGS TO REFORM IMAGE

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 16

 BODY:
As the Japanese have grown increasingly torn by the confrontation over trade with the United States, Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa is defending his stand by depicting it as just one of the sweeping changes that he has sought to bring to the scandal-ridden political system. He has cast the battle as part of his campaign to bring fundamental reform to Japan.
But for many Japanese who have grown disillusioned by the continuing strife within Mr. Hosokawa's governing coalition and signs that he is more of a conservative at heart than a reformer, a series of trials in a stark courtroom less than a mile from the parliament may say more about where the real push for change is coming from. 
 More than 36 prefectural governors, mayors and construction executives are facing charges of corruption over public construction. The prosecutors have made clear, however, that they are not attacking isolated venality, but the collusive heart of the way that Japan has worked for 40 years.
The effects of the trials on the actions of Mr. Hosokawa have been considerable, because the disclosures of corruption helped him to push through changes aimed at curbing the influence of cash contributions from industrial to political leaders and parties.
 
Recantation of Confessions
 But despite some clear moves toward change, even many supporters of Mr. Hosokawa say they have been disappointed at the way that he has struck compromises with the conservative Government bureaucrats or the power brokers of the Liberal Democratic Party, which ruled Japan for decades until Mr. Hosokawa ousted them last year. The party has been heavily implicated in the corruption trials, which are under way in Tokyo District Court.
However the trials on the 41 indictments turn out -- several defendants have pleaded not guilty, saying earlier confessions had been coerced -- there is little doubt that they played an instrumental role in ending the 38-year rule of the Liberal Democrats last summer. In fact, it is dawning on some here that the real force for fundamental change here may be not the vision of the Prime Minister or the will of Parliament, but the prosecutor's office.
 
'To Clean Out the Sewers'
 "Our role," an important prosecutor in the case, Yusuke Yoshinaga, said, "is to clean out the sewers."
There have been influence-peddling scandals in Japan before, of course, and some have brought down governments. The scandal today is different, because it involves the construction industry. Contractors have been central to the ways of politics in a country that has been called a "doken kokka," a phrase that could be translated roughly as a nation built around the construction industry.
Among the largest single expenditures made every year by the national and local governments is construction -- for a total of $350 billion last year. The largest single contributors to politicians are construction companies. Many of the Government contracts are let through bid rigging, a practice known as dango, that the Government acknowledges is widespread.
The chief Cabinet secretary, Masayoshi Takemura, who had been Governor of Shiga, recalled once that the pressure to accept cash for contracts was unrelenting. "Once they set their sights on you, they use every trick in the book," Mr. Takemura said of the construction companies. "Anyone might eventually give in to temptation."
"Other countries have some kind of bid rigging at times, but in Japan dango is part of the industry's structure," said Yoshitsugu Kanemoto, a professor of economics at Tokyo University.
 
Politicians as Steerers
 Kunio Maeda, a former construction executive and now a professor at Fuji University, has estimated that Government construction costs in Japan are 30 to 40 percent higher than in the United States because of the bid rigging. Much of that extra money, of course, is paid to the politicians who steer contracts.
Those practices have led to suits and threats of sanctions by United States negotiators seeking to gain access to the construction markets for American companies.
The first close peek into how the system works was on March 6, 1993, with a raid by prosecutors on the home and office of Shin Kanemaru, a former deputy prime minister and Liberal Democratic kingmaker. The Government found millions of dollars of gold bars, cash and bearer bonds.
Mr. Kanemaru was charged with tax evasion, and the prosecutors said most of the money was from construction companies. The public was outraged. Finally most politicians began to realize that they courted disaster if they did not support a campaign to stamp out the corruption.
The prosecutors then raided the offices of 18 construction companies, taking a total 4,600 cardboard boxes filled with documents. That led to the first indictment, on June 29, of Toru Ishii, Mayor of the northern city of Sendai.
Perhaps the most shocking arrests were of executives of the Kajima Corporation, the most influential company in the industry because of its tight links with the bureaucracy and politics. Seven top executives, including the president, are former Construction Ministry bureaucrats, and the children of several former top executives have married into politically influential families.

HEADLINE: Cold Curbs A Rebound In Housing

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16

 BODY:
Hampered by the nation's third-coldest January in a century, builders slowed the pace at which they broke ground for homes by 17.6 percent, matching the biggest decline in 10 years, the Commerce Department reported today.
The Northeast was the hardest hit, with housing starts diving 32.8 percent to a pace below that of January 1993. 
 But economists and housing analysts expressed no alarm, citing what they consider an unsustainably robust December -- revised still higher today -- as well as the earthquake in California and severe winter weather that extended well into the South.
 
Expectations Unchanged
 "This isn't that hard to deal with," David F. Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders, said of today's figures. He said his association's February survey of builders' sentiment found 54 percent expecting "good or better" conditions in the next six months, a reading virtually unchanged from January.
Permits for future construction fell 7.9 percent, less than half the plunge for starts. Both sets of figures are adjusted for normal seasonal variations but these by definition do not capture exceptional developments.
"January numbers have proven to be notoriously fickle over the years," said Robert D. Barr, deputy chief economist for the United States Chamber of Commerce. In addition to the effects of severe weather, the January figures suggest the economy is "taking a breather" following a sizzling fourth quarter, he said.
 
December Starts Revised
 The January starts were 1,294,000 at an annual pace, fewer than what analysts had predicted, but the percentage drop was exaggerated by a revision that carried December starts to 1,571,000, the fastest pace since January 1989.
December was only the second month in the last 13 years in which starts of single-family homes exceeded surpassed a rate of 1.3 million.
Starts of single-family homes dropped 15 percent in January, to a rate of 1,147,000. Apartment house construction was even weaker, with dwellings in buildings of five or more units plunging 38.4 percent, to a rate of 125,000.
The 32.8 percent drop in Northeastern starts, to an annual pace of just 90,000, compared with a 22.9 percent drop in the Midwest, to a 262,000 pace, and with a 15.6 percent drop in the South, to a rate of 65,000. The Southern region, which extends up to Delaware and Maryland, had a considerable amount of bad weather.
 
West Virtually Unchanged
 Groundbreaking in the West was virtually unchanged last month at a rate of 377,000 dwellings a year but analysts said there surely would have been a gain had it not been for the California earthquake.
But the housing rebound since late last summer is likely to at least hold its gains when better weather arrives, various analysts said.
"I don't see a slackening" in underlying activity, said Robert Davis, chief economist for the Savings and Community Bankers of America, a trade group representing mortgage lenders.
Building permits were issued at a rate of 1,360,000 last month: 587,000 in the South, 356,000 in the West, 315,000 in the Midwest and 102,000 in the Northeast. This was a decline for all regions but the West, with permits falling most in the Northeast, where a 42 percent plunge resulted in the lowest pace since March 1993.
Although permits are often regarded as forecasting home building activity in coming months, Mr. Seiders and other industry professionals have found it an indicator with little predictive value.
 
Faster Than a Year Ago
 Despite last month's big drop in groundbreaking, the pace exceeded that of January 1993 by 10.6 percent, the Commerce Department's survey also showed.
Actual housing starts -- with no seasonal adjustment or annualization -- were 77,100 last month, 9.4 percent ahead of January 1993. Only 4,900 of these were in the Northeast.
Having raised his forecast in early January, just before the industry's annual convention, Mr. Seiders predicts starts for 1994 will total 1.43 million, with single-family homes up 9 percent and the multifamily category up 11 percent from its depressed state.
The December advance, a jump now put at 11.7 percent, benefited from a rise in interest rates that while relatively modest, jolted many buyers into action. This is a typical response when rates stop declining and consumers suddenly decide that they risk missing favorable terms if they don't act.
Except for a same-size drop in January 1991, last month's tumble was the biggest since starts dropped 26.4 percent in March 1984.

HEADLINE: Stocks Edge Up on Currency Reassurance

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Stock traders nudged up shares across the board yesterday, as the Clinton Administration continued to reassure the currency markets that it was not politicizing the dollar and bond markets were relatively calm. The best movers were economically sensitive stocks like United Technologies and Alcoa.
Still, bears were turning ever more bearish. Harrison Roth, a senior options strategist at Cowen & Company, derided the notion that the stock market would get to or near the 4,000 level on the Dow because the market was awash in money. Last year, individual and other investors poured a record $128 billion into stock mutual funds. 
 "The perceived wisdom is that equities is the only game in town, but the fact of the matter is there's more than one town," Mr. Roth said. He cited record dollar inflows into bond funds as well as foreign equity funds, especially those in emerging markets like Mexico and Southeast Asia.
Anthony F. Dwyer, chief market strategist for Sherwood Securities Inc., said: "This is the perfect time to be a contrarian, when everyone is putting money into stocks. Pretty soon the buying power of this market is going to run out, probably by the end of the first quarter."
 
Utilities Average Down
 Indeed, yesterday the Dow Jones utilities average, an avidly scrutinized market barometer, declined 2.70 points, to 212.76. When the average, comprising a group of power companies including Pacific Gas and Electric, declines, it is said to signal higher interest rates, which would hurt stocks. Utilities, rich in dividends, act like stocks but also somewhat like fixed-income bonds, analysts say, making utilities useful as an indicator.
The Dow industrials rose 9 points, to 3,937.27, and the broader Standard & Poor's 500 rose 0.27 point, to 472.79. The Nasdaq composite index rose 2.50 points, to 792.62 and the American Stock Exchange market value index rose 0.48 point, to 475.32.
The New York Stock Exchange Composite Index rose 0.19 point, to 262.55, on volume of 295.5 million shares. Advancers exceeded decliners by 1,183 to 965.
The economic news of the day was generally ignored because traders expect January and February economic data to be distorted by the severe winter in the Northeast and the ruinous California earthquake.
The Commerce Department reported that January housing starts plunged to an annual rate of 1.29 million units, far worse than the expected 1.38 million units. There was some encouraging news. January building permits, running at an annual rate of 1.36 million, fell less sharply than those of housing starts, indicating more robust building later this year.
Boeing and McDonnell Douglas, hurt by a slump in demand for jets, got a $6 billion order yesterday from Saudi Arabia, which had been actively courted by the United States.
Details of the accord were not released but are likely to favor the far larger Boeing, whose stock rose $2.50, to $46.625 a share, in active trading. McDonnell Douglas's stock rose $1.875, to $118.875. The stock of United Technologies, a major aerospace contractor, also benefited, rising $2.625, to $71 a share. United Technologies accounted for 5.9 points of the 9-point gain in the Dow.
Intel was the most active stock, with volume of 8.2 million shares, in over-the-counter trading. The microchip maker's share price rose $2, to $67, in part because of traders' expectations that a recovering economy would lift its sales of advanced microprocessors.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Mixed Ahead of Price Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Bond trading was subdued and prices mixed yesterday as dealers and investors sat on their hands ahead of today's report on January consumer prices.
A report that showed a sharp 17.6 drop in January housing starts lifted prices in early trading, but most market participants had already suspected that severe winter weather would take its toll on home building for the month. 
 An upward revision in the December number showed growth in that area continuing. Analysts say that once the weather improves it is likely the economy will see a spurt in housing starts again.
The Treasury's 30-year bond traded at 97 13/32 to yield 6.45 percent, unchanged from the previous day. The shorter maturities were unchanged, while the intermediate maturities were mixed.
 
 
Consumer Price Index
 The market stayed focused on today's Consumer Price Index. Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities, said bond trading ahead of the index's release "was about as exciting as going into work on a weekend."
The consensus of analysts' estimates of the index calls for a gain of three-tenths of a percent over all, and a gain of three-tenths of a percent in the core inflation report.
Traders said it was possible the figure could be lower because of a new method of calculating inflation. Many economists have already lowered their Consumer Price Index forecast because of the new method.
In any case, the Federal Reserve is likely to be cautious in interpreting the economic data because of weather-related distortions.
Analysts say the threat of a near-term interest rate increase by the Fed is minimal. Some market watchers suspect a tightening may come around the next meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's policy-making panel, on March 22.
In an interview yesterday, a Federal Reserve governor, Edward W. Kelley Jr., told reporters that he expected the Fed's most recent tightening on Feb. 4 would ultimately curtail inflationary expectations and hold down interest rates.
"If the bond market feels that the Fed is dragging its feet, bond yields will rise further," Mr. Fine of Chase Securities said. "The only way yields are dropping further is if the economy makes a U-turn."
 
 
Currency Market
 The market has also been following the currency market. The breakdown of trade talks between the United States and Japan caused the dollar to plunge against the yen on Monday before regaining some stability.
Analysts at MMS International, however, said they believed that the potential for a substantial trade confrontation between the United States and Japan was minimal despite concerns in the currency market about an impending trade war between the two. Among the reasons they list: a Japanese Government that is primarily focused on domestic issues; the current Government coalition is too weak to make significant changes in trade law, and a confrontation would probably prove nearly as costly to the United States as to Japan.
The Federal Government yesterday set the terms for next week's auction of two-year and five-year notes, cutting the size of the five-year auction back to $11 billion, after increasing it by $1 billion, to $12 billion, in January because of the bond call. The two-year auction was left at $17 billion.
In when-issued trading, the two-year note was being offered at a price to yield 4.47 percent, and the five-year note at a price to yield 5.38 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Eases in Expectation Of Action by German Bank

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar eased against most European currencies yesterday on expectations that the Bundesbank, the German central bank, will hold interest rates steady at its meeting today.
But the dollar remained stable against the Japanese yen after a round of aggressive dollar purchases by the Bank of Japan. Tokyo is trying to stem the soaring yen after trade talks with Washington failed. 
 In New York, the dollar dropped to 1.7237 German marks, from 1.7283 on Tuesday. It also ended at 103.80 yen, down slightly from 103.85 yen.
Meanwhile, gold prices also slipped. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, the April gold contract, which is the most active, settled at $385.30 an ounce, down 20 cents.
Many analysts believe that the Bundesbank may be loath to ease credit until current wage negotiations with a huge engineering union are completed and the outlook for inflation becomes more clear.
They also pointed to the Bundesbank's February report, which said the central bank would continue to consider rate cuts but must act to maintain confidence in the mark.
Lower German interest rates would make mark-based assets relatively less attractive than foreign investments, including those denominated in dollars.
 
Dollar Steadies Against Yen
 The dollar remained relatively stable against the yen, primarily as a result of purchases by the Bank of Japan. Dealers said many traders were still scrambling to buy back dollars sold in a hurry after the trade meeting between the United States and Japan leaders ended last Friday without an agreement.
"People are still short dollars looking for more bad news on trade," Christopher Wilson, a senior dealer at Union Bank in Los Angeles, said. "Most are interested in seeing tomorrow's December trade deficit figures."
Dealers said the trade gap between Japan and the United States would drive the dollar's direction against the yen. If the gap widens, dealers are likely to sell dollars on the idea the White House might push for a stronger yen to help trim the deficit.
The Clinton Administration has repeatedly denied that it wants a strong yen, but dealers remain skeptical.
Meanwhile, the British pound was unchanged in New York at $1.4755 yesterday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Tuesday's quotes, included: 1.4537 Swiss francs, down from 1.4550; 5.8675 French francs, down from 5.8850.

HEADLINE: Broadway Pays Big Dividends, Study Says

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
The Broadway theater contributes $2.3 billion a year to the economy of New York City, or about a fourth of the total economic impact of all of the city's cultural activities, according to a study by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to be released today. The report is the first comprehensive analysis of Broadway's economic impact by an independent authority.
Port Authority researchers said that during the 1992 season Broadway shows attracted 1.7 million tourists and 782,000 suburbanites, who spent more than $266 million on restaurants and $242 million on hotels and more than $35 million on taxicabs. 
 About 25,000 jobs are linked to the economy of Broadway, ranging from stagehands and theatrical suppliers to hotel and restaurant workers, the report said, and the business that Broadway generates yields $142 million annually in state and local income taxes, hotel occupancy taxes and sales taxes from visitors' patronage in restaurants and retail stores.
"These are considerable figures, when you consider that there are only a few dozen theaters," said Catherine Lanier, a Port Authority consultant who did the analysis and wrote the report for the agency's Office of Economic and Policy Analysis.
 
Impact of Films and TV
 Theater is not, however, the city's most rubust entertainment industry. The Port Authority puts the economic impact of film and television production in New York City at $2.6 billion.
The release of the report, which draws its conclusions from the 1992 theater season and does not include figures from 1993, comes when half of Broadway's 35 theaters are dark, the result of a generally bleak fall season in which a number of shows closed quickly. January and February, traditionally slow months, have been hit hard by the weather, and attendance is down even at perennial sell-outs like "The Phantom of the Opera." Six plays, six musicals and at least two solo shows are scheduled for the spring season.
Ms. Lanier said that the report was conducted independently of public-policy considerations, defending it as an accurate portrait of economic activity involving the theater. "It's a conservative study," she said, "since we're focusing on those who came to New York specifically for the theater."
Nonetheless, the report is likely to strengthen the perception of the theater's importance to the city economy at a time when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's aides have placed a new emphasis on the economic value of cultural institutions. Some of the sponsors of the report may use the findings to lobby for greater public and private support for theater-related activities.
 
A Draw for New Money
 A major finding of the report is that theater draws new money into the New York region, "from everywhere from France to Ohio, and that's important to economic health," said Ms. Lanier.
She contrasted the theater economy "with industries that pass money around in the same region," like dry cleaners or local restaurants, "which recirculate money without adding money to the region."
"You can't have regional growth based on that kind of economy," she said.
The report is a sequel to a Port Authority study released last October, sponsored by the agency along with the Alliance for the Arts, the New York City Partnership and the Partnership for New Jersey. That report, which did not analyze specific data about Broadway, estimated that the total economic impact of the arts and cultural activities was $9.2 billion in New York City, including television and motion-picture production, and the effect of cultural institutions like museums, art galleries and auction houses.
 
The Role of Tourists
 The new study was based in part on an analysis of the production and operating budgets of 22 Broadway plays and musicals during the 1991-92 season. Additional findings on tourism were based on some 3,200 questionnaires returned by theatergoers during the 1991-92 season.
Of the tourists surveyed by the Port Authority, slightly more than half said that attending cultural activities was the main purpose of their trip, and three-quarters of that group said they had come expressly to see Broadway shows. The authority estimated this audience to be about 1.7 million people, who spent $686 million in the city in addition to the purchase of theater tickets.
Road productions of Broadway shows also added to the city's economy, the report said. The direct annual expenditures by Broadway producers for shows in New York, both commercial and nonprofit, were $311 million (including payments for labor, sets, equipment rental, transportation, advertising and theater rentals). An additional $127 million was spent in New York City to mount touring productions, and benefited the city through profits, royalties and salaries, "money that stayed in our region's economy," said Ms. Lanier. "Such productions ultimately were paid for by people out of town."
The effect of Broadway spending "ripples through the economy," said Ms. Lanier, "as firms doing business with production companies make purchases from additional businesses, and as employees spend their wages and salaries."

HEADLINE: HOUSE PROUD

BYLINE: By WILLIAM L. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
INDOOR/OUTDOOR living, though dear to the heart of most suburban homeowners, rarely gets its due as a design issue.
The standard suburban architectural formula for connecting the two realms: knock a hole in the wall, add a picture window or sliding doors and hope for the best. It's like hooking up nature as though it were cable television. But the standard stuff seldom delivers on its promises -- great views, freedom of access -- or adds anything imaginative to either side of the setup. 
 Robert Kahn, a New York architect whose recent projects include the interior redesign of the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center last year, struck a delicate balance between indoors and outdoors when he built a small house in St. Louis for his parents, Jane and Dr. Lawrence Kahn. The house has a roomlike garden at the center embraced on three sides by actual rooms. Opening on one side is the living room, whose view is centered on the garden. The living room and the garden operate as halves of the same space, connected like interior salons by french doors.
In season, one wanders freely from one end of the space to the other as though the two areas were one large room, used for gardening, reading and entertaining. Off-season, the french doors partition the space decoratively. The passageway between the areas feels natural -- not window or door in a wall, but part archway, trellis and picturesque landscape view.
Mr. Kahn was addressing a greater issue at the time -- the empty nest. With their children grown and gone, his parents wanted a smaller, more manageable house. The Kahns are gardeners, so a condominium apartment was out of the question. They bought a small lot in an older suburb of St. Louis -- "a classic city lot, 60 feet by 120 feet," Dr. Kahn said -- and hired their son to design a house that would give them the two things they wanted in retirement: privacy and a place to garden, neither of which seemed possible on a sixth of an acre.
"They're no fools," Mr. Kahn said of his parents. "They waited until I had done a few houses to hire me."
Mr. Kahn faced a bit of friendly competition -- his parents' fond memory of their previous house, designed with a student of Frank Lloyd Wright's. It employed "a classic Prairie house concept -- indoor/outdoor, a band of windows all around," Dr. Kahn said, adding that with the new house, he and Mrs. Kahn wanted a garden and, again, a lot of light.
Mr. Kahn designed a complete inverse of a small suburban house. Rather than creating a box divided into rooms that look out across narrow yards to immediate neighbors, he built a series of long rooms and halls that form a "U." The "U" shape embraces the 30-by-40-foot garden on three sides. The combination living/ dining room is to the west, the kitchen is to the south and the master bedroom and carport are to the east. A latticed fence and planted bamboo screen the north side.
The plan allows for complete privacy, despite large exposures of glass. And every room has a view of the garden -- a neat double play.
"The house looks in on itself, like a Roman courtyard house," Mr. Kahn said. "If one goes to Pompeii, there's one house after another, which is in many ways a suburban problem. What's pleasant is that the house is centered on a space of open air."
Nowhere is the Kahns' open communication with their garden more apparent, or more mutually beneficial, than in their living room, because of Mr. Kahn's careful approach to a common solution: french doors. In fact, the doors are part of a larger frame that includes eight clerestory windows above the doors, creating a hybrid of door and window in the wall.
"The idea was to open up the wall as much as possible," Mr. Kahn said. "But the problem with an enormous exposure is that you feel like everything is always exposed. A framed view is much more interesting than having all the view all the time. It's not how much you look at the outdoors; it's how you look at the outdoors."
Mr. Kahn used four independently framed and individually opening french doors that effectively remove the wall. The doors -- 6 feet 8 inches by 2 feet 10 inches -- are made of 1 3/4-inch-thick Ponderosa pine with 1/2-inch thermal glass panels. Unlike sliding glass doors, they look and act like a secure wall when closed, in addition to being handsome.
"The doors are very large and heavy," Dr. Kahn said. "The hardware is all commercial grade -- big hinges, locks. Those things give a good feeling of strength of construction."
The door frames were left unstained. "The fact that they're natural has a lot to do with the fact that you connect them to the outdoors," Mr. Kahn said. The eight clerestory windows are an equally important element of the frame. The window panels are compositions of glass, crafted by Kenneth Von Roenn, a Louisville architect and glass designer who is a friend of Mr. Kahn's from their student days at Yale University. Each panel employs both clear and sand-blasted glass laminated with squares of dichroic glass that refract the daylight like prisms, throwing "marvelous colors on the wall as the sun goes down," Dr. Kahn said, and dappling the living room with leafy color and light as though it were part of the garden. At night, the glass border becomes a kind of illuminated frieze.
The garden itself is densely planted with miniatures: small spruces, hollies and Korean lilacs. Two tall crimson maples intimately dominate the space like a small French public square, providing an awning for the garden and shading the living room from summer sun and heat. A fountain with a lion's-head spout sits in the garden, creating roomlike ambiance with sound.
The overall result is both practical and poetic: an easily maintained garden within an arm's length of any part of the house; a manageable house with an urbane, private, parklike setting, and a good landscape picture hung in every room.
In the Kahns' living room, the four french doors give the appearance of a four-panel folding screen, with a natural view -- a nice allusion to classical representations of a garden. "I'm lucky," Mr. Kahn said. "I have parents who appreciate art and architecture. Maybe that's why I'm interested in it. This house wasn't an uphill battle."
 
Specs
 THE big secret to the french doors? "We designed them so that they'd open and close," Robert Kahn said.
Funny, but not a joke. It's said about doors on good cars: they feel heavy, snug and secure when one closes them. They have a good fit, right down to the sound. Exterior doors on houses are as important, especially in hard winter weather. Mr. Kahn used weatherstripping made of neoprene, a synthetic rubber, instead of more common metal strips, at the top, on the hingeless side and in a groove at the bottom of each door.
"One of the places in a project where I don't think it's good to economize is on hardware," Mr. Kahn said. "Quality of hinges -- and how many -- handles, etc. Those things don't cost that much more." Mr. Kahn often favors commercial-grade hardware for its quality of construction and durability. "Doors are things you can be sure people are going to use every day," he added. "Economizing on how thick a door is or how well made -- it is not a good savings."
For garden doors, ease of use seemed particularly important. "If doors work beautifully, satisfyingly, you're going to use them more," Mr. Kahn said.
The estimated cost of the living room's four french doors and eight clerestory windows, without Kenneth Von Roenn's custom art glass, is $6,500 (a wall without any openings would have cost about $1,000). The doors were custom made, but Mr. Kahn said that standard good-quality french doors could have been used. WILLIAM L. HAMILTON

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Labor Talks to Start. Labor Talks to Start.

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Fourteen months after they thought they were starting negotiations for a new labor agreement, representatives of the Players Association and major league club owners will meet March 7 to begin negotiations for a new labor agreement.
Richard Ravitch, the owners' chief labor executive, and Donald Fehr, head of the players' union, said yesterday that they would meet in Tampa, Fla., a familiar site for negotiating sessions during spring training. Fehr likes to hold talks near training camps so players can attend them. 
 Negotiations appeared to begin last year with two sessions in January, a month after the owners voted to reopen the collective bargaining agreement. But the talks were suspended while Ravitch tried to get the owners to agree to share more of their local revenue among themselves. Now that Ravitch has achieved that goal, he will resume working toward a new labor agreement.
Although the owners will seek the players' agreement to a salary cap, Ravitch will most likely not go to the Tampa meeting with a proposal in hand. He declined to comment on what his agenda would be, but he is expected to discuss the owners' recent approval of a new revenue-sharing plan and how they have linked it to a salary cap.
 
A General Discussion
 Rather than present a specific proposal for what the owners call revenue participation, Ravitch will likely discuss caps generally, explain the owners' economic need for one and invite the players to offer their thoughts on what a cap should be like.
But the players will likely respond that they have rejected a cap in the past and plan to continue to reject it unless the owners can show a legitimate need for what would be a major change in the way they are paid.
Although the owners' adoption of the revenue-sharing plan was contingent upon the players' acceptance of a salary cap, the players contend that the owners can share their revenues without help from the players. The union further argues that the creation of a ceiling on payrolls would simply return to the wealthier clubs the money they would give to the poor clubs under the revenue-sharing plan.
The Tampa meeting will come less than a week after Ravitch meets with the owners in Scottsdale, Ariz. The owners will hold their regular quarterly meetings there from Feb. 28 to March 2. At Ravitch's session with them, he and the owners will discuss and establish their strategy for the negotiations.
 
A Committee's Fate
 The owners are also expected to decide at that meeting the current status of the Player Relations Committee, which has been the clubs' labor arm. Under the restructuring report outlining the commissioner's duties, the committee is eliminated and labor relations placed under the commissioner.
But the owners do not plan to hire a commissioner until they have a new collective bargaining agreement. That leaves the relations committee in an ambiguous state.
But the restructuring report also calls for the creation of a commissioner's standing committee on player relations so that Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, and the executive council may appoint owners to that new committee. They would likely be the same owners, or at least mostly the same owners, who are on the existing committee.
Meanwhile, another committee is planning a meeting of sorts for Florida during spring training. The Senate Judiciary Committee has said it will hold a hearing on baseball's exemption from antitrust laws during this Congressional session, and the tentative plan is to have it in Tampa, possibly on March 21. The hearing may focus on the powers of the commissioner.
Nancy Coffey, an aide to Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee's Subcommittee on Antitrust, acknowledged that the hearing will likely be in Florida. But she added that the site and the date haven't been definitely set.

HEADLINE: Back From the Brink Again

 BODY:
Ending yet another bout of brinkmanship, North Korea acceded on Tuesday to international inspections of its declared nuclear sites. That is a hard-earned victory for U.S. diplomats who are trying to persuade the North to give up any ambition to build bombs.
North Korea agreed to let inspectors into all seven of its declared sites. They can conduct repeated visits if necessary, but only to assure that nuclear safeguards are intact -- to verify that no nuclear material has been diverted to bomb-making in the year since their last visit and to check seals and replace film in cameras designed to inhibit diversions in the future. 
 Once the inspectors are reassured and talks between North and South Korea resume, the stage will be set for a new round of tough talks between Washington and Pyongyang to bring the North into full compliance with the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. The Clinton Administration needs to prepare a package of incentives to get North Korea to comply, starting with cancellation of this year's Team Spirit military exercises, conducted jointly with South Korea.
The North's response comes none too soon. The board of governors of the International Atomic Energy Agency, which oversees nuclear inspections, is scheduled to meet Monday. If it were unable to certify Pyongyang's compliance with nuclear safeguards, it would refer the matter to the United Nations Security Council, which has the authority to impose economic sanctions.
The North views sanctions as an attempt to strangle it. Imposing them would almost surely derail diplomatic efforts to gain unimpeded access to all its nuclear sites and would increase the risk of instability, if not war, on the Korean Peninsula. For these reasons the North's neighbors, China, Japan and South Korea, have been reluctant to impose a tight embargo.
The Clinton Administration was wise to cut a diplomatic deal instead. Its strategy is working so far. But the hardest bargaining lies ahead. It rightly wants North Korea to allow more thorough regular inspections of all its declared nuclear sites, to keep it from turning nuclear material into bombs.
It is especially important to resume regular inspections by summer, when North Korea will have to shut down its reactor and replace the fuel rods. At that time, inspectors will be able to weigh and assay the nuclear material to find out whether any of it was diverted in the past, and if so, how many bombs' worth.
Special inspections of suspected North Korean nuclear waste sites might also be necessary for that purpose. Those too would have to be negotiated.
The Clinton Administration should be prepared to pay a reasonable price to gain such access -- by meeting the North's demands for improved relations, giving security assurances, providing reactors that are less proliferation-prone, and offering trade and aid. Diplomacy will cost a lot less than confrontation, and it just might get what the world wants -- a nuclear-free Korea.

HEADLINE: Hard Times, Not Fraud, Explain Loan Defaults

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your "Looting Student Aid" series (front page, Feb. 2-4) points out the impossible task for the Department of Education to monitor more than 7,000 higher education institutions adequately with limited staff and an inadequate information system. We compliment you for recognizing this. 
 Unfortunately, Congress has not seen fit to allocate funds so that the department can do the job of assessing the administrative and financial capability of the colleges, universities, professional and trade schools that make up the world's leading higher education community.
As head of a privately owned education organization with some 14,000 students in major United States cities and in Europe, and about 1,800 staff and faculty members who own a substantial part of the company, I am very familiar with the strengths and weaknesses of the Federal student aid programs. A fundamental problem with student aid is that our political leadership has yet to make the decision that our citizens are our most important natural resource -- the one resource we won't run out of -- and that we need to invest in the productivity of our citizens, which will have a direct impact on our future. This includes investing in students through the aid programs.
The central point about student loan defaults is that we are making loans to poor people. The Federal education scholarship program -- the Federal Pell Grant -- has not kept pace with inflation, so that today it is worth less than half what it was worth in the 1970's. It should be no surprise that with student loan volume way up, the dollar volume of student loan defaults has grown accordingly. The real dollar loan default rates have fluctuated over a narrow range for 15 years.
Every study we have done indicates that the tendency to default has everything to do with whether or not the student has the financial means to complete a chosen academic program, and whether or not there is a state grant program to supplement Federal Pell grants.
Yes, there have been instances of fraud, many of them before 1992, when Congress made significant changes in the Higher Education Act, which governs Federal student aid. But has the Government ever quantified the magnitude of losses to the student aid funds as a result of fraud, as opposed to the result of low-income students borrowing money in a difficult job climate? Or as the result of the Federal Government's failure to provide adequate oversight? It's time to start dealing with the real problems in the Federal student aid programs.
 
ROBERT B. KNUTSON
Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
Education Management Corporation
Pittsburgh, Feb. 7, 1994

HEADLINE: Hard Times, Not Fraud, Explain Loan Defaults;
Heroic Jordan College

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your Feb. 4 article on the default rates in Federal student loan programs unfairly portrays Jordan College. You state only that Jordan is not accredited -- true but misleading. You should also have noted that the college has been granted conditional accreditation by the North Central Association of Colleges and Schools. Jordan is well on its way toward formal accreditation. 
 This conditional status is treated the same as fully accredited status by the Department of Education in determining an institution's eligibility for student aid.
One of the themes in your series was that a reason for the Department of Education's problem is pressure from politicians not to act against schools with high default rates in their own states, using my fight for Jordan as an example. As I told your reporter, I have favored closing fly-by-night schools that hurt students and taxpayers with substandard educations. Yes, even in my own state.
Jordan is well respected by educators and has earned strong support of such independent groups as the Association of Independent Colleges. For reasons I don't understand, your reporter declined to talk to the association director after assuring he would.
Jordan is not a school bilking its students while its officers live high on the hog. It is a nonprofit institution, whose officers and trustees have accepted low wages and put personal assets on the block to support the institution financially.
Jordan's student population has a higher percentage of economically disadvantaged and minority students than some historically black colleges and universities. It seeks out students who have had little or no opportunity, including a large percentage of single mothers. It helps people who otherwise would not get an education, that other schools don't reach.
Because of the heroic way Jordan College lives up to its mission, the college continues to have my strong support.
 
CARL LEVIN
U.S. Senator from Michigan
Washington, Feb. 10, 1994
