SECTION: Section A; Page 23; Column 2; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 715 words

HEADLINE: Liberate Cuba. Liberate Us. Lift the Embargo, Now.;
Give Castro A Carrot

BYLINE: By Andrew Zimbalist; Andrew Zimbalist is professor of economics at Smith College.

DATELINE: NORTHAMPTON, Mass.

 BODY:
As the Clinton Administration lifts the trade embargo against Vietnam and considers easing travel restrictions to Cuba, Libya, Iran and Iraq, its economic embargo against Cuba is being increasingly criticized. Yesterday, the United Nations released a report concluding that far from encouraging political or economic reform, the embargo is doing the opposite.
Indeed, it is widely recognized that the policy not only flagrantly violates international law, which proscribes trade sanctions based on political ideology, but also is counterproductive. Two months ago in Mexico, Vice President Al Gore defended the North American Free Trade Agreement by arguing that more open trade would promote the development of democratic institutions in Mexico. The same argument applied in the former Soviet bloc, China and Vietnam, and would apply, if given a chance, in Cuba. 
 President Clinton isn't fooling anyone when he says that the reason for Cuba's market-oriented reforms in recent years is economic pressure from the U.S. embargo. Cuba has been opening its economy gradually since 1989 because it has no choice.
As a small island country with limited natural resources, it must trade to survive, and to trade it must adapt to the rules of the world marketplace. Cuban reforms like encouraging foreign investment and allowing small private enterprise are gaining momentum and will continue to do so with or without the embargo. Ending the embargo, however, would accelerate Cuba's economic transition, as it would encourage openness and improve the chance for peaceful change.
The alternative will either be prolonged agony for ordinary Cubans or a political explosion accompanied by instability and potentially a large-scale immigration problem for Florida.
It is no accident that recent reports from the Inter-American Dialogue, the Rand Corporation, the 20th Century Fund, the Army War College and the Center for International Policy, among others, all advocate the dismantling of the embargo. Each report endorses a step-by-step loosening of the embargo in return for piecemeal concessions by President Castro, leading to the grand finale, a Nicaraguan-style presidential election.
There are many reasons why this quid pro quo gradualism is ill-conceived, but two stand out. Once the U.S. takes its first significant step -- lifting travel restrictions or allowing trade or investment in medical products -- Mr. Clinton will have burned his bridges with the ultra-conservative Cuban American National Foundation. Virtually the only reason that the embargo is still in place is the political clout of this well-financed organization. Once Mr. Clinton alienated it, the political constraint on a rational policy toward Cuba would disappear.
More importantly, as the Administration made its first clear move toward normalization, foreign capital from Europe, Canada, Latin America and Asia would pour into Cuba, as investors moved to exploit opportunities that would come with the prospective opening of the U.S. market.
Over the last three years, Cuba has received $500 million in foreign capital through 112 joint ventures in tourism, mining, agriculture, and manufacturing.
Yet the present value of U.S. properties nationalized from 1959 to 1961 in Cuba, when far fewer opportunities for profitable investment existed, is more than $5 billion. With 11 million people, a disciplined and well-trained labor force and proximity to the U.S. market, Cuba offers additional billions of dollars in prospective investments. A gradual lifting of the embargo would preserve the existing advantage of overseas companies and give them a jump-start on exploiting these new opportunities while U.S. capital continued to have its hands tied.
It makes political and economic sense simply to lift the embargo all at once. The U.S. can retain leverage through carrots instead of sticks: setting a higher sugar import quota, offering economic aid or most-favored-nation trade status, negotiating frozen Cuban assets or waiving compensation for nationalized properties.
How can President Clinton call for democracy in Cuba when his own policy is determined by a handful of reactionary exiles? This is Mr. Clinton's chance to manifest clarity and courage in his foreign policy.

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS;
Pressure Grows on Croatian Army Troops to Get Out of Bosnia, Too

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ZAGREB, Croatia, Feb. 17

 BODY:
United Nations observers said today that Croatia appeared to have made little effort to withdraw its regular army troops from Bosnia and Herzegovina despite a sharp warning two weeks ago to start pulling them out or run the risk of economic sanctions.
A senior official at the headquarters of the United Nations Protection Force for the Former Yugoslavia said that rather than withdrawing, regular army troops might be masking their presence by removing their insignia from vehicles and uniforms. 
 While international attention has focused on the threat of air strikes against the guns of Serbian forces besieging Sarajevo, the reports by United Nations observers based here may be the first step toward a much tougher stance toward Croatia.
Up to now, Croatia has had relatively good relations with the United States and the 12 members of the European Union, especially Germany. But there has been growing criticism of Zagreb's links to the most extreme factions of the Bosnian Croats, who continue to wage a fierce battle for control of Mostar, in southwestern Bosnia.
 
8 Army Units Reported
 United Nations observers estimate that Croatia has sent 5,000 troops across the border to aid their ethnic brethren in central Bosnia, where the Muslim-led Bosnian Army has made some gains in the last six weeks. The Bosnian Government puts the figure much higher, upwards of 20,000 troops.
A United Nations official here, speaking on condition of anonymity, said observers had identified soldiers from eight regular Croatian Army units operating in Bosnia. The troops are not part of full Croatian brigades or under the direct control of Croatian command posts, he said.
On Feb. 3, the Security Council sharply condemned the presence of regular Croatian troops in Bosnia and requested a report by the Secretary General on "progress toward the complete and full withdrawal" of the Croatian forces from Bosnia.
Depending on that report, the United Nations could begin to take steps against Croatia, including economic sanctions like those imposed in 1992 against the Serb-dominated Yugoslav federation.
 
Half an Admission
 Although Croatia has said it has sent only "volunteers" to fight on the side of Bosnian Croats, Foreign Minister Mate Granic offered last weekend to withdraw troops from border areas near Mostar in exchange for United Nations guarantees of safety for Croatian civilians caught in central Bosnia.
United Nations observers said earlier this month that they had seen a Croatian convoy, including more than a dozen trucks and weapons like mortars and antiaircraft guns, crossing the border from southern Bosnia into Croatia. But they said they did not consider this a sign that the Croats had initiated a significant movement of troops.
[In a letter sent Thursday to the Security Council, Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali reported that "there may still be 5,000" regular Croatian Army troops in Bosnia. He also said Croatia had failed to present proposals for monitoring the withdrawal of forces from Bosnia.]
The United States has been especially critical of Croatia's military involvement in Bosnia. The Ambassador, Peter W. Galbraith, said at a forum tonight in Zagreb that Croatia has undermined the sympathy it had drawn as a victim of Serbian aggression in 1991.
 
The Serbs in Croatia
 "How can Croatia expect the international community to support its demand for Serb withdrawal from Croatia when its army is in the sovereign state of Bosnia and Herzegovina?" Mr. Galbraith asked. "How can Croatia expect the international community to expend vast resources to uphold Croatia's frontiers when it seeks to violate those of another country?"
About 30 percent of Croatia is still occupied by Serbian troops as a result of the fighting that broke out between the Yugoslav Army and Croatia after the federation broke up in 1991.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
A Plea From Belgrade
 Arguing that sanctions were threatening the "very existence" of ordinary people, Yugoslavia's Prime Minister appealed yesterday to the Clinton Administration to take the pressure off Belgrade.
Even if international sanctions were lifted this year and the economy grew 4 percent a year, Yugoslavia would not regain its previous level of production until 2012, the Prime Minister, Radoje Kontic, said in an address to the Council on Foreign Relations in Manhattan.
The United Nations imposed the sanctions in May 1992 in retaliation for Belgrade's aid to the Serbian nationalists' forces campaign in Bosnia.
Mr. Kontic said Yugoslavia, which now includes only Serbia and Montenegro, had lost about $25 billion in output as a result of the embargo, and expects to lose $15 billion more this year.
He said the sanctions had produced "a sharp social stratification into a small group of rich war profiteers and smugglers and a vast population whose very existence is threatened." Mr. Kontic also said the embargo had strengthened the hand of political extremists and racketeers.
Mr. Kontic called on the Clinton Administration to become more involved in persuading Bosnia's Muslim-led Government to accept the peace plan put forward by the European Union and international mediators.

HEADLINE: Mayoral Aides and Yankees Meet to Discuss Stadium Plan

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR

 BODY:
After the first face-to-face meeting between officials of the Giuliani administration and the New York Yankees, the team expressed optimism about the city's plans to keep the franchise at Yankee Stadium beyond the end of its lease in 2002.
"It went very well," said David Sussman, the team's general counsel. "It was very informative, but it'll still very formative." 
 The city's latest package of inducements to persuade the team to stay in the Bronx includes plans to renovate Yankee Stadium, restoring much of the ball park's 1923 look; adding scores of new luxury suites; improving the Major Deegan Expressway and other roadways, as well as building a garage for several thousand more cars, a Metro-North Commter Railroad station, and a retail arcade or major regional shopping mall.
The three Yankees officials who met at City Hall with Deputy Mayor John Dyson did not include George M. Steinbrenner 3d, the principal owner, who will make the final decision on staying in the Bronx or moving.
"Some parts of their plan were definite, others were just concepts," Mr. Sussman said. "Now they're looking to see what the Yankees and George want." Mr. Steinbrenner, a vice president of the United States Olympic Committee, returned yesterday from Norway, where he was attending the Winter Olympics.
Mr. Dyson refused to estimate the cost of renovating Yankee Stadium and its environs, although estimates from other city officials are from $250 million to $300 million.
"We don't know what it will cost," Mr. Dyson said. "It'll be a lot of money but worth every nickel."
The cost will be borne in unequal parts, by the city, state and perhaps the Federal Government, for road reconstruction.
Despite a huge budget deficit facing the city and the possibility of municipal layoffs, Mr. Dyson said the city can justify spending to keep the Yankees in the Bronx as part of an economic development effort to revive the downtown Bronx.
"The money for this would be spent four or five years into the future," Mr. Dyson said. "The city will be straightenend out and we'll be able to handle the borrowing."
"Five or six" private developers have been approached "to find out if some of our ideas are feasible and would they invest in them," Mr. Dyson said.
As he left City Hall yesterday, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who did not attend the meeting, said: "The city and the Yankees have to meet and talk and understand exactly what the issues are. The bottom line is the Yankees are very important to the city and the city is very important to the Yankees."
Asked what he would do if the Yankees left New York City, Mr. Giuliani said, "It would be very embarrassing to see a grown mayor cry."
City officials believe their chances of keeping the Yankees in New York have been enhanced by statements from Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey that the state would not make a deal to build a stadium for the Yankees if it required using taxpayer money. She recently refused to proceed with a plan to build an arena for the Philadelphia 76ers in Camden because she felt taxpayers would incur a liability.
"I don't think we'll be in a competitive battle with New Jersey," Mr. Dyson said. "We're in a competitive battle with ourselves, rather than worry about what the competition is doing."
In part because of the perceived threat posed by New Jersey's Sports and Exposition Authority, the race to keep the Yankees in their 71-year-old home heated up last summer. City and state officials started to respond regularly to Mr. Steinbrenner's desires to generate more revenues from luxury suites and for improved parking, security, roadway access and sanitation.
In addition to presenting ways to renovate "The House That Ruth Built," Gov. Mario M. Cuomo at one point suggested building a $530 million stadium and garage complex south of the Jacobs Javits Convention Center on Manhattan's West Side.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
 Steven Hoffenberg, the Manhattan bill collector, was charged with securities fraud and obstruction of justice. The Federal complaint said he had defrauded thousands of investors across the country of $450 million. [Page A1.] 
 Chemical Bank mistakenly deducted about $15 million from more than 100,000 accounts in one day, causing consternation among customers. It was one of the biggest computer errors in banking history. [A1.]
A Federal indictment accuses General Electric, De Beers and two European businessmen of conspiring to raise and fix prices in the half-billion-dollar global market for industrial diamonds. [D1.]
Lotus Development is reportedly close to a deal with A.T.& T. to set up a network based on Lotus's popular Notes software. The reports, by an analyst and a trade publication, encouraged investors, who drove up shares of Lotus more than 10 percent. [D1.]
Miles will buy a 28 percent stake in Schein Pharmaceutical for $310 million in an effort to enter the generic drug market. [D3.]
R. H. Macy plans to ask for a four-month extension to the time it has to propose a bankruptcy reorganization plan. The retailer, which had previously sought a six-month extension, is seeking to avert a showdown with its senior creditors. [D3.]
Figgie International said it had taken steps to stem a cash squeeze. It is also in talks on a long-term financing package. [D3.]
I.B.M. is withdrawing the Ambra line of personal computers from Europe because the price gap between the no-frills Ambra and its other brands had narrowed. [D3.]
 
The Economy
Consumer prices were unchanged in January. The Government's report on inflation was better than expected. But a survey by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia showed a rise in regional producer prices, which unnerved the financial markets. [D1.]
Bond investors saw the Philadelphia Fed survey as confirming their inflation fears, and prices tumbled. The yield on the 30-year Treasury jumped to 6.54 percent, the highest since August. [D1.]
Metropolitan New York has become the leading marketplace in the global economy at the same time that mass production has mostly disappeared from the region. [A1.]
The F.A.A. authorized commercial airlines to begin using a satellite-based navigation system for landing in bad weather. [A16.]
 
International
The Japanese Government will seek to open markets in sectors of the economy in which it has the most control. Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa's strategy is aimed at showing enough progress to avert a trade war with the United States. [D1.]
The United States had its largest trade deficit ever with Japan last year. Over all, however, the American trade gap shrank in December as exports continued their five-month climb. [D4.]
Germany's central bank lowered a key interest rate by half a percentage point. The move suggested a more self-assured and international approach by the Bundesbank. [D2.]
 
Markets
The stock market took its cue from bonds, sending prices lower. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 14.63 points. [D4.]
The dollar edged up against the mark after Germany's central bank cut a key interest rate. Gold prices fell. [D11.]
Corn and soybean prices fell sharply as United States corn exports continued to decline. Oil prices recovered slightly. [D11.]

 Momentum has helped shares of Flightsafety International to soar. And while the training company has a bright outlook, investors may have gotten ahead of themselves. Market Place. [D4.]

HEADLINE: Inflation Nervousness Sends Stocks Sliding

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The inflation news was so startlingly good yesterday that bond traders did not believe it. So bond prices tumbled and, after some hesitation, so did stock prices.
A wide range of blue-chip stocks that have benefited in the recent rally dropped in price, including I.B.M., Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, Philip Morris and General Motors. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 14.63 points, to 3,922.64; the broader Standard & Poor's 500 fell 2.45, to 470.34, and the Nasdaq composite index dropped 2.38, to 790.24.
Trading was heavy at 340 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange, whose composite index fell 1.17 points, to 261.38. Declining stocks led advancing stocks by 1,251 to 882. The American Stock Exchange market value index also fell 0.86 point, to 474.46.
 
Rebound Is Expected
 But analysts expect a recovery in both the bond and stock markets today, when there are no economic statistics scheduled for release.
"If the bond market is any good on Friday," said Frederic I. Leiner, bond market strategist for Continental Bank in Chicago, "it'll dig itself out of this hole quickly, in maybe one or two trading sessions, and probably lift the stock market."
Don Hays, the stock investment strategist for Wheat First Butcher Singer in Richmond, said yesterday's fall was good for stocks because it would make for a more solid advance later. "The Dow should rally 18 points Friday, even if the bond market doesn't rally," he said. "It's a real bruised market after the Fed raised interest rates. It's healing, but it's still tender."
Yesterday, before the stock market opened at 9:30 A.M., the Labor Department reported that the prices consumers pay for goods and services were unchanged in January, the first time the Consumer Price Index failed to climb in five and a half years.
Government economists explained that if they had retained a previous method of calculation, the Consumer Price Index would have risen three-tenths of a percent, which is what Wall Street had expected.
 
Another View on Prices
 By 10 A.M., however, the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia released its February Business Outlook Survey, indicating that manufacturing was strong and prices were rising. Later in the morning, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the chairwoman of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers, said in a television briefing at the White House that the United States economy probably grew faster in the final three months of last year than was previously estimated.
Both reports fed bond traders' anxiety about inflation. After falling briefly, the yield on the closely watched long bond, a key indicator of inflation concerns, surged to a six-and-a-half-month high.
That quickly fed stock traders' anxiety about inflation, ending three consecutive rising sessions for the Dow industrials, the S.& P. 500 and the Nasdaq composite index. Shortly after 1 P.M., the Dow began falling in earnest.
Telephone, financial services, automobile and computer stocks were all off sharply and helped drag down the S.& P. 500.
In the 30-stock Dow industrials, five components made the biggest contribution to the fall: I.B.M., which dropped 1 7/8, to 52 3/4; Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, which dropped 1 1/2, to 108; Philip Morris, which fell 1 1/4, to 58; General Motors, slipping 1 1/8, to 59 7/8, and Procter & Gamble, declining 1 1/8, to 58.25.
There was no discernible news about the companies, besides worries over inflation, to account for the price drops.
The United States Surgical Corporation was the most active stock on any exchange at 10.7 million shares after it lost an important patent case Wednesday and then warned of a worse-than-expected quarterly loss. It fell 3, to 18 1/2 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Lotus Development was the second-most-active stock on any exchange at 8.2 million shares. The computer software company rose 6 1/2, to 66 1/2, after an analyst recommendation and a trade press report that Lotus was talking with A.T.& T. to jointly develop sophisticated computer-messaging equipment for corporate users.

HEADLINE: Greece Closes Macedonia's Main Trade Route

BYLINE: Special to The New York TimesAP

DATELINE: ATHENS, Feb. 17

 BODY:
Greece forged ahead in its fight with Macedonia today, closing the former Yugoslav republic's main trade route and drawing angry protests from other members of the European Union.
European Union officials criticized Greece for acting without consulting other nations in the organization, which agreed last year to cooperate in developing a common foreign policy. 
 Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou, furious over Western diplomatic recognition of Macedonia, on Wednesday ordered that the northern port of Salonika be closed to all goods bound for landlocked Macedonia except for food and medicine.
Greece contends that Macedonia's name and national symbols are historically Greek and thus imply a desire to control the northern Greek province that is also called Macedonia. Greece is trying to press its neighbor to change its name and guarantee that it will not make claims on Greek territory.
"We want this crisis to be an opportunity to solve the problem," said Foreign Under Secretary George Papandreou, the Prime Minister's son.
Macedonia, which denies having designs on Greek land, accused Greece of "taking advantage of our position as a landlocked country."
Greek officials at the border said goods moving to and from Macedonia were being blocked. Port officials in Salonika, about 43 miles south of the border, said ships had stopped loading and unloading Macedonian shipments.
Most of Macedonia's foreign trade moves through Salonika, including about two-thirds of its oil. Officials in Macedonia said they had oil reserves for about two months, and reports from Skopje, the capital, said long lines were already forming at gasoline stations.
The embargo is likely to increase friction in the 12-nation European Union, in which Greece currently holds the six-month rotating presidency.
"It is not good for European construction," said Bruno Dethomas, a spokesman for the Union's Commission, its executive agency in Brussels. "We will ask for clarifications."
Foreign Minister Helveg Petersen of Denmark called the embargo "seriously alarming" He said he would raise the issue at an European Union meeting on Monday. "I must suggest the Greek Government regain its composure and withdraw its decisions regarding Macedonia -- especially the one about economic measures," Mr. Petersen said in New York.
A spokesman for the union's External Affairs Commissioner, Hans van den Broek, said the issue also would be discussed Friday at a previously scheduled meeting between the Greek, Belgian and German Foreign Ministers and Mr. van den Broek.

HEADLINE: U.S. Indicts G.E. and De Beers in Diamond Pricing

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17

 BODY:
A Federal grand jury indicted the General Electric Company, De Beers Centenary A.G. and two European businessmen today on a single count of conspiring to raise and fix prices in the half-billion-dollar-a-year worldwide industrial diamond industry.
The two companies control about four-fifths of the international market for industrial diamonds, which are mainly produced synthetically from carbon under extremely high pressure and temperature, and which are embedded in saws and drills for use in cutting stone and concrete. 
 The indictment, by a grand jury in Columbus, Ohio, accuses the companies of having used the two European businessmen to exchange list prices in order to raise prices early in 1992. It is one of the biggest cases that the Justice Department has ever filed charging an international violation of United States antitrust law.
Anne K. Bingaman, Assistant Attorney General in charge of the department's antitrust division, said the Government "will not tolerate anticompetitive acts by two firms who dominate their worldwide markets, or sophisticated schemes that are used to fix prices and to disguise criminal activity."
"The division will actively prosecute such international cartels," she said.
General Electric denied wrongdoing, arguing that the case was based on recently recanted allegations by a dismissed executive.
"The Government has no direct evidence or testimony of price-fixing," it said in a statement.
The executive referred to is Edward J. Russell, a former General Electric vice president who ran the company's industrial diamond division. He sued G.E. nearly two years ago for wrongful dismissal, saying he lost his job for objecting to price-fixing in the industrial diamond market.
But Mr. Russell dropped his suit and signed an affidavit on Wednesday stating that he had no knowledge of any wrongdoing. In return, General Electric agreed to grant him the medical and life insurance benefits it gives to retired executives and paid part of his legal bills, said Joyce Hergenhan, a spokeswoman for the company.
"This is an effort by the Government," Ms. Hergenhan added, "to salvage its two years and millions of dollars by filing a case that has no merit."
A Justice Department spokeswoman, Gina M. Talamona, called Mr. Russell's suit "a separate matter." Mr. Russell did not return calls today to his home in Dublin, Ohio.
Calls to De Beers Centenary, at its headquarters in Lucerne, Switzerland, were not answered. The company has ownership links with De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd., the South African corporation best known for its dominance in the natural diamond industry.
The two indicted businessmen could not be reached for comment. One of them is Peter Frenz, a German citizen and the managing director of the European operations of General Electric's industrial diamond business. The other is Philippe Liotier, a French citizen and the former chief executive of Diamant Boart S.A., a Brussels-based tool manufacturer that buys industrial diamonds from General Electric and De Beers. The Justice Department said Mr. Liotier was also a former director of a company with ownership links to De Beers.
In Columbia, S.C., an official of Diamant Boart America, said, "We really can't comment because of the ongoing investigation."
In the past, De Beers Centenary has denied any wrongdoing in the industrial diamond market.
 
Possible Penalties
 Companies found guilty of violating the antitrust law involved in this case are subject to fines up to $10 million, or twice any gain from a crime or twice the cost to the victims, whichever is greater. Individuals are subject to fines up to $350,000 and as long as three years in prison.
Ms. Hergenhan, the G.E. spokeswoman, said the industrial diamond division accounted for less than one-half of 1 percent of the company's sales last year.
The indictment was announced at midafternoon today, while United States financial markets were still open, but well after the closing of South African and European exchanges. In Nasdaq trading, the American depository receipts of De Beers Consolidated Mines closed down 87.5 cents, at $23.625. General Electric shares closed at $109.125, up 37.5 cents, on the Big Board.
No estimate of General Electric's or De Beers' allegedly illegal gains were given in the indictment, and Ms. Talamona of the Justice Department declined to provide estimates.
G.E. said in a statement that differences between the prices of its industrial diamonds and De Beers' products had increased during the months after the alleged price fixing. Before early 1992, 64 percent of saw diamond sales involved products with the same list price, while almost no sales have been at the same list prices since then, the company said.
As imports and exports account for a growing part of the United States economy, the Justice Department has expressed more and more interest in pursuing international antitrust cases. The department in 1992 ended a self-imposed restriction against filing cases.
Speaking of today's indictment, James R. Loftis 3d, an antitrust lawyer at Collier, Shannon, Rill & Scott here, said, "This signals no fear going against large companies in complicated international settings."

HEADLINE: Serious Subway Crimes Continued Falling in 1993, Transit Police Say

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Serious crime reported in the subways fell by 11.2 percent last year, and has declined by more than one-third since 1990, the transit police announced yesterday. But the police and various officials, including Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, predicted that few New Yorkers would believe it.
Felonies reported to the police, including homicides, rapes and attempted rapes, robberies, serious assaults, burglaries and grand larcenies, fell to 11,763, from 13,250 in 1992. The figure equals about 32 felonies a day, down from 50 a day in 1990. 
 "Confrontational crime, the kind our customers fear the most, is now at its best level since 1979," said Peter E. Stangl, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the parent body of the agency that runs the subways and buses.
There were more arrests for carrying weapons and drugs, but that is good news, the police said, because most of those suspects were caught jumping turnstiles. Catching them at the entrances, said the Chief of the transit police, Michael F. O'Connor, means they are stopped "before proceeding to begin felonious conduct."
Chief O'Connor and others attributed the decline to an increase in officers, to 4,300 now from 3,800 in 1990, and $40 million in 1991, mostly for overtime, training, better radios, cars and emergency vehicles, and a computerized mug-shot system.
Alan F. Kiepper, the president of the Transit Authority, said that ridership was up by more than 3 percent last year and by more than 5 percent since the low point in July 1992, and that reduced crime was a factor. "If crime had kept going up, people wouldn't have come back," he said. Another reason, he said, was an improving economy.
The Governor, after praising the transit police at the news conference where the figures were announced, said "most people will rebel" at the idea that the subways are getting safer. "It sure don't feel that way out on the streets, and in life generally," he said. But he said reported robberies, by far the largest category, were down by 4,000 over three years. "That's 4,000 people who were not robbed, or it might be less than 4,000 people who were not robbed more than once," he said.
Mr. Cuomo spoke for 10 minutes on the need for gun control and life terms without parole for people convicted of three serious felonies. "If you are convicted three times of a violent crime, it is because you have probably committed 50 or 100 violent crimes," he said.
 
Better Feelings About Service
 Mr. Cuomo's reading of public feeling about the subway parallels the findings of an annual survey taken last May by the M.T.A. The telephone survey of 1,200 city residents, representing a cross-section of people who make at least four one-way trips a week by some mode of transportation, determined that attitudes about personal security on the subways had been about the same since 1991. People felt a little safer at night last year than in previous years, but less safe during the day on weekends.
But according to the survey, they also felt better about overall subway service, cleanliness and lighting in the stations and other factors that affect feelings of security, like the presence of homeless people and panhandlers in stations and cars.
A less scientific sample drawn from subway platforms yesterday afternoon showed skepticism and some cautious optimism.
"I don't believe it," said Johnnie Walker, a 65-year-old machine presser who commutes from his home on West 148th Street to his job near Times Square. "It looks like the same old thing is happening."
Philip Bares, 42, a real-estate broker who uses the No. 1 and No. 9 trains from Chelsea to take his daughter to preschool near Columbia University, said: "I guess it's good. It's positive. I feel reasonably comfortable."
"I've been riding the subway for 16 years, and I can say they've become cleaner over the last 3 to 4 years," he said. "Even the acoustics in some of the stations have improved."
Whatever the public perception of crime, the numbers come at a good time for the transit police. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has proposed merging it with the Housing Authority's and the city's police. The transportation authority opposes the merger, and Chief O'Connor said yesterday: "Why fix what's not broken? We're an effective department."

HEADLINE: Year's Trade Deficit Widened; December's Shrank

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17

 BODY:
The American trade deficit shrank in December, but the United States still posted its largest deficit ever with Japan last year and its biggest overall trade deficit since 1988, the Commerce Department announced today.
The shrinkage of both deficits in December came as American exports continued their five-month climb. As a result, Wall Street economists generally welcomed today's announcement as a sign that foreign demand for American goods remained strong and that American economic growth in the fourth quarter might have been even greater than the Commerce Department's initial estimate of 5.9 percent. 
 But the focus was more on the annual deficit with Japan, which is likely to provide fresh ammunition for the Clinton Administration's trade battles with Tokyo. The deficit with Japan widened last year to $59.32 billion, the biggest bilateral trade gap that the United States has ever accumulated with a foreign country. The Japanese economy has been in a deep recession that has curbed Japanese demand for imported goods, while the expanding American economy has left businesses and individuals here more willing to buy cars, clothing and other products from abroad.
 
Fifth-Largest Deficit
 The nation's overall merchandise trade deficit broadened last year to $115.77 billion, the largest since 1988 and the fifth largest ever. The largest American trade deficit, in 1987, was $152.12 billion.
The December trade deficit was $7.41 billion, down from a revised November level of $9.68 billion. Economists attributed the decline partly to a surge in aircraft exports that may not be repeated soon.
"I think that we will be back to somewhere in the $9 to $10 billion range," for monthly trade deficits in the first quarter of this year, Stephen S. Roach, the chief economist at Morgan Stanley, said.
President Clinton said in a radio interview from the White House this morning that in trade talks with Japan, "We're going to try to pursue a much more aggressive policy now, which will actually open markets."
Top officials from a half-dozen Federal agencies met here Wednesday night to begin drafting a list of retaliatory measures that the United States might take against Japan following the failure of talks last week between President Clinton and Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa.
"We are reviewing our unilateral options, and we will undoubtedly be taking one or more steps in the short and medium term," possibly next week, said a senior Administration official who requested anonymity.
One likely option for American action against Japan, the official said, would be for President Clinton to reinstate a section of American trade law, known as Super 301, that sets a fast timetable for opening certain foreign markets and mandates sanctions if it is not met.
But a more controversial step mentioned by President Clinton last year -- raising tariffs on imported minivans and sport utility vehicles from the 2.5 percent rate charged on passenger cars to the 25 percent rate charged on light trucks -- is not being actively considered as a near-term option, the official added.
In today's radio interview on the "Imus in the Morning" program, broadcast on WFAN in New York, President Clinton criticized Japanese trade policies at length, saying: "They simply cannot continue to pursue the policy that they pursued when they were a poor country growing rich -- they're now a rich country, and they can't, you know, export to the rest of the world and keep their own markets closed. And I think they know that. And, you know, we're going to work hard and try some different things to push that market open."
The United States exported goods worth $42.23 billion in December, a record, and imported goods worth $49.63 billion. For all of 1993, American exports were $464.77 billion and imports totaled $580.54 billion.
The Commerce Department also revised upward today its estimate of exports in November, the previous record, to $40.24 billion. Stephen L. Cooney Jr., a trade analyst at the National Association of Manufacturers, said that rising American exports in recent months reflected a bottoming out of recessions in several Western European nations, led by Britain, and continued demand from Southeast Asian nations like Thailand that have been little affected by the recent economic sluggishness in the industrialized world.
Today's figures covered trade only in physical goods, like cars or television sets. Beginning with the trade figures for January 1994, the Commerce Department will begin calculating an overall monthly trade balance in goods and services, as well as the merchandise trade balance.

HEADLINE: Japan Looking for Ways To Avert U.S. Trade War

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 17

 BODY:
Under growing pressure to prevent the outbreak of a damaging trade war with the United States, Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa of Japan seems to be hoping that progress, even modest progress, in opening markets will end President Clinton's threats of a trade war.
That strategy became clear today as Mr. Hosokawa asked his top trade bureaucrats to bring him a plan in the next several days for opening markets in sectors of the Japanese economy in which the Government has the most control. He is also dropping hints of returning to the bargaining table. 
 The developments came as the United States reported a record trade deficit with Japan for 1993 and its biggest overall trade deficit since 1988, even though, the Commerce Department announced, the nation's trade deficit shrank in December. [Page D4.]
 
Business Is Screaming
 But while the Prime Minister appeared to be taking the initiative, the proposals his Government is considering -- from new Government procurement rules to drives to import more and new measures to deregulate the Japanese economy -- appear cobbled together from old proposals that the Clinton Administration has already rejected as insufficient.
"Hosokawa is in a very, very tight spot," one of his senior policy advisers said tonight. "He is destitute of a good policy, business is beginning to scream, and he's got to come up with something pretty fast."
The chief Cabinet secretary, Masayoshi Takemura, said that the Prime Minister and his advisers "agreed that the ball is in Japan's court." Mr. Takemura suggested that Mr. Hosokawa may soon send another "special envoy" to Washington, much as he did before last week's meeting, to explain to President Clinton what he is doing. Finance ministers from the Group of Seven industrialized nations meet on Feb. 26 in Frankfurt, and the presumption is that Japan would like to have the outlines of a plan ready by then.
The effort to come up with a plan, however, marked a shift in Japan's strategy, fueling a sense that the broad initial support for Mr. Hosokawa's tough response to President Clinton last week is eroding, as the cost to Japanese business mounts.
The yen's sudden lift, along with Mr. Clinton's comments Wednesday that he would be reviewing a series of options for further retaliatory steps, has begun to rattle confidence. One evening newscast here said that Mr. Hosokawa "must be slowly realizing now what his decisions have cost."
If the 5 percent increase in the value of the yen since the trade talks broke down last week is sustained, it would undo Japan's domestic economic stimulus package and could deepen the recession. Corporate profits would be squeezed even further.
That is exactly the pressure that Mr. Clinton's economic team has been trying to bring since Tuesday, when the United States initiated sanctions against Japan in a cellular telephone dispute and sat back as the yen soared. But American officials said it was still too early to declare that their strategy was producing results.
Oddly, perhaps, Mr. Hosokawa is turning for his new alternatives to the very men whom Washington views as the source of the problem: Japan's elite bureaucrats. Neither the Prime Minister nor his staff has much grasp of the intricacies of the trade issues involved, meaning that the policy is still being controlled by the conservative bureaucracy that has opposed the kind of large-scale market changes Mr. Clinton wants. Moreover, Mr. Hosokawa has little choice: The bureaucrats can so easily subvert any plan that is put into effect -- especially deregulation plans -- that he must make them a central part of the decision-making process.
 
Bureaucrat Disappointed
 Today one of those top bureaucrats, Koichiro Matsuura, the deputy minister for foreign affairs, expressed disappointment that Mr. Clinton did not accept an offer the Japanese made to him last week: to resolve several issues "on which we were very close" and produce a compromise in which some market openings would be announced and others deferred for later talks. But Mr. Clinton's team refused to accept any deal that did not include specific pledges for measurable progress in reducing the trade deficit.
In a revealing moment, Mr. Matsuura said that he still saw an enormous gulf between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Hosokawa's views about the depth of the trade problem.
The problem for Prime Minister Hosokawa is that he lacks the power to bring about the kind of market openings Washington wants. He can only tinker around the edges of the economy.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS: New Fears Emerge Amid Low Inflation;
Bond Prices Dive After Early Rally; Yields Up Sharply

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Bond traders, looking for bad news on inflation, found it yesterday, despite the Government's report that January consumer prices were unchanged.
As a result bond prices fell and the yield on the 30-year bond jumped to 6.54 percent, its highest level since August. 
 Traders said prices of Treasury securities surged in early trading after the Consumer Price Index showed inflation was not growing, easing investor fears of another increase in interest rates by the Federal Reserve.
 
Another Survey Consulted
 But the rally faded as quickly as it started, as hints of inflation reappeared in another Government report, the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia's February Business Outlook Survey. A jump in oil prices added to the reversal.
While long-term interest rates are now the highest since early August, analysts said they did not see them moving as high as 7 percent as long as economic growth does not surge. But the selloff yesterday did indicate to others that there is little chance of the yield falling to 6 percent until traders and investors are assured that inflation will remain in check.
"What the bond market is telling us, is that it remains fearful of potential new inflation," said Joseph V. Battipaglia, managing director of Sterling Advisors, a division of Gruntal & Company. "And since the outlook is clouded about what happens next in the economy, the easy answer for investors is to sell."
Mr. Battipaglia said he believed this period of volatility would not have dire consequences. "I think the market is probably establishing a new level of equilibrium, with the yield on the 30-year bond, I think, trading between 6.25 percent and 6.75 percent."
Louis Crandall, chief economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates, said he was surprised by the market's selloff yesterday. He said he was always concerned when markets sold on bad news and ignored good news. He said he saw the yield on the long bond in the second quarter at least lower than yesterday.
Mr. Crandall said he did not rely too much on the price index from the Philadelphia Fed because it covered only the early part of February and might have been affected by last week's crippling East Coast storm, which could have contributed to the rise in material prices.
"The last time the market reacted the same way was in early February when the Purchasing Managers Index also showed sharp price gains," Mr. Crandall said. "Investors' reaction to the data today perhaps was as much a response to the memory of the P.M.I., than to the number."
The price of the 30-year bond fell a point and 4/32 as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, jumped from 6.45 percent on Wednesday. The price of the 10-year note also fell sharply with the yield ending at 5.98 percent, up from 5.88 percent. The yield on the two-year note was 4.47 percent, up from 4.40 percent.
Since the Fed raised short-term interest in early February, traders and investors had been trying to divine whether long-term rates would continue to rise or stabilize on the belief that the Fed would keep inflation in check. But because many analysts now think that the rally of 1993 is over, there is a tendency to pay more attention to bad news.
Another concern is whether the trade dispute with Japan will push up consumer prices here. "The Japanese are a very important reason for why we have low inflation," Mr. Battipaglia said. "Their products are very much a part of the consumer-buying pattern and any increase in tariffs or lower trade limits raises prices."
 
Trade Deficit Shrinks
 Other favorable news yesterday included the December merchandise trade data, which showed that the trade deficit shrank to $7.41 billion from a revised $9.68 billion, mostly because of surging exports.
On the Consumer Price Index, the market consensus was for an increase of three-tenths of a percent in January. But when it turned out to be unchanged, many traders and investors concluded that any additional move by the Fed to raise short-term rates could be delayed.
Traders said the early morning rally was fueled solely by the index, which appeared positive throughout. The core rate, excluding food and energy, rose a modest one-tenth of a percent. This was below the two-tenths of a percent increase in December, which itself was revised downward from the previously reported gain of three-tenths of a percent.
Some economists said they did not think the unchanged consumer index would effect the Fed's monetary policy. This is because the January data was, in part, the result of a new method of calculating seasonal adjustment factors that sought to get rid of the sharp -- and usually misleading -- jumps in prices over the last several years in the reports for January, February, March and April.
As a result, investors turned to the inflation data in the Philadelphia survey for signs of how price trends were moving in February. Analysts at MMS International said the Philadelphia data on overall business conditions appeared to be distorted by the weather, as inventories surged and delivery time rose, while shipments and employment fell, all consistent with the impact of severe winter weather.
But it was the rise of the price index in the Philadelphia report thatdrew concern and cut short the rally set off by the Consumer Price Index.
In when-issued trading yesterday the two-year note to be auctioned next week was being offered at a price to yield 4.54 percent, while a five-year note, was offered at a price to yield 5.49 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Selective German Rate Cut Sends the Dollar Up a Little

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar gained slightly against the mark yesterday after the German central bank reduced a benchmark interest rate but signaled that money-market rates would only fall slowly.
The Bundesbank said it would cut the discount rate, the rate charged for loans to commercial banks, by half a percentage point, to 5.25 percent. Lower German interest rates make investments denominated in marks less attractive than those in other currencies, notably dollars. 
 But dealers viewed the rate cut with little enthusiasm, some asserting they had already expected the central bank to continue its policy of gradually easing borrowing. In addition, the bank said it would keep its other benchmark rate, the Lombard, unchanged at 6.75 percent. That is the central bank's rate for lending emergency funds to banks, and it acts as a ceiling on the money market.
In New York, the dollar settled at 1.7265 marks, up from 1.7237 on Wednesday.
"The Bundesbank is trying to reassure the markets that interest rates are coming down in Germany at some point," said Avinash Persaud, currency analyst at J. P. Morgan in London. "But it couldn't deliver them today because it's still very concerned about money-supply growth and wage negotiations."
Gold prices fell yesterday. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, the April contract, which is the most active, settled at $384.30 an ounce.
 
U.S. Bond Prices Decline
 The dollar got little help from a Treasury market selloff that sharply increased yields on long-term bonds and thus depressed their prices. The bond prices fell even though the Labor Department said consumer prices had been unchanged in January.
The dollar edged higher against the Japanese yen. But dealers said the market was very quiet as the market awaited news on trade from United States and Japanese officials. In New York, the doillar settled at 104.35 yen, up from 103.80 yen on Wednesday. The British pound was at $1.4775 in New York, up from $1.4755 on Wednesday's. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Wednesday, included: 1.4575 Swiss francs, up from 1.4537; 5.8665 French francs, down from 5.8675; $1.3377 (Canadian), down from $1.3508 (Canadian), and 1,674 Italian lire, down from 1,678.

HEADLINE: From France, Depardieu as God And Other Joys

BYLINE: By CARYN JAMES

 BODY:
MANY in the French film industry think Gerard Depardieu is God, but only Jean-Luc Godard has dared to take the idea literally. In "Helas Pour Moi" ("Woe Is Me"), the actor plays an ordinary man named Simon whose body is briefly inhabited by God, or so it seems when God's gravelly voice comes out of Simon's mouth, speaking "thine" and "thou," to the astonishment of his wife.
No road company of "The Odd Couple" could have come up with a less likely pair than these two men. The cerebral and often inaccessible Mr. Godard, a master of the French New Wave of the 1960's, has been under a critical and commercial cloud for two decades. Mr. Depardieu is so popular and lucrative a property that a recent story in Variety practically suggested that the French film business might collapse without him. But in "Helas Pour Moi," they inspire each other's best tendencies. Beautifully photographed beside a Swiss lake, the film has a poetry and emotion rarely associated with Mr. Godard. Mr. Depardieu's performance is surprisingly restrained and resonant. 
 The tirades about French film that erupted during the recent GATT talks have mercifully faded away. (To refresh your memory, both sides sounded like little boys squaring off in the playground: "No fair! You're trying to kill us!" the French screamed at Hollywood. "Are not! And your movies stink anyway!" Hollywood yelled back.) "Helas Pour Moi" hints that reports of French film's demise were wildly exaggerated. And there is plenty more evidence in a provocative, exciting series hiding behind a drab, uninviting title: "Cahiers du Cinema Selects Recent French Films."
The series of a dozen films, most made within the last year and being shown in this country for the first time, begins today at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center and runs through March 1. It is the third annual installment of the program, chosen by the Film Society of Lincoln Center along with editors of the French journal Cahiers du Cinema.
Even in France, Cahiers has far less influence than it did 30 years ago, when its best critics turned to film making and created the personal, fluent style of the New Wave. But the journal still champions films that reveal a director's distinctive vision and signature.
Though this year's series includes several names from the Cahiers pantheon, the program is not bathed in nostalgia. Eric Rohmer's "Tale of Winter," Claude Chabrol's documentary "The Eye of Vichy" and the Godard film present those directors in top form. And a documentary by Serge Toubiana and Michel Pascal, "Francois Truffaut: Stolen Portraits," is a surprising view of the much-loved director as his family and colleagues saw him.
 
Teen-Age Werther
 One of the most charming films will be shown on Sunday and Monday. Jacques Doillon's "Young Werther" is more lighthearted and engaging than its title and plot make it sound. Ismael, the film's endearing 15-year-old hero, is not the suicidal Werther character based on Goethe's novel; his friend, Guillaume, is. Early on, Ismael and his friends learn of Guillaume's suicide and spend the rest of the film talking about life, love and death, and trying to track down the young woman who might have broken their friend's heart and left him in despair. "Young Werther" is most affecting in the way it gives adult weight to its unmistakably teen-age characters.
"Helas Pour Moi," showing today, Sunday and Monday, is not as easy to slip into, but its rewards are profound. Mr. Godard's sometimes fragmented narrative is broken by chapter titles and words on the screen. Townspeople tell what they know of Simon's possibly miraculous transformation, as if they were a Greek chorus. It helps to know that the story was inspired in part by the Greek legend of Amphitryon, whose body Zeus borrowed to seduce the man's wife. Mr. Godard's rigorous film mirrors the complexity of his themes: the process of storytelling; rediscovering traditions; the possibility of believing in God. All these ideas are eloquently embodied in Mr. Depardieu's sorrowful Simon. "Helas Pour Moi" will also be shown at the Joseph Papp Public Theater from March 18 to 31.
Mr. Chabrol's "Eye of Vichy" is an engrossing look at French propaganda films and newsreels made for the collaborationist government of Marshall Petain during World War II. As the narrator notes at the start, the film depicts France "not as it was, but as Petain and the collaborators wanted it to be seen." The film could have used more context. How many French people saw these films? What Allied or Resistance works might have counterbalanced them? But this firsthand evidence of what was put forth as happy news -- unemployed French find jobs in Germany and Petain is beloved by children all over France -- is still chilling.
"Francois Truffaut: Stolen Portraits" plays off the title of Truffaut's own "Stolen Kisses." As a film it is merely competent, but as a glimpse at the director it is fascinating. More a professional view than a personal one, it nonetheless has moments of wrenching personal tenderness. Here is Mr. Depardieu again (maybe he is a one-man industry) reading a despairing letter Truffaut wrote while he was in a juvenile detention home.
 
A Rohmer Substitution
 A new Rohmer film, "The Tree, the Mayor and the Mediatheque," was originally scheduled for the series, but at the last minute legal tangles kept it away. No one should complain about its substitute, though. Mr. Rohmer's charming and wise "Tale of Winter" is the story of a young woman who is misplaced by her lover. She gives him a wrong address, goes home to have his child and blithely assumes that one day he will turn up again. Meanwhile, she gets on with her life. Romantic and wry at once, "A Tale of Winter" suggests that while the French film industry is far from dead, it does not have an easy time in the United States. This film was shown at the 1992 New York Film Festival and is only now about to be released commercially, sometime in the spring.
Fifteen years ago, when it cost far less to distribute a film and there were more art houses around the country, many of the films in this series would automatically have had theatrical releases here. That they have struggled to be seen raises a crucial question: have action movies and juvenile comedies forced them out of the marketplace, or are they simply not very good? The answer, of course, is a little of both.
Not every French film is a gem. The series includes all three features by Leos Carax, a favorite of the New York Film Festival. "Les Amants du Pont Neuf," about two straggly lovers (Juliette Binoche and Denis Lavant) who live under a bridge and find themselves soul mates during the French bicentennial celebration, is nearly unwatchable. But the overwhelming majority of films on the program deserve an audience. This enticing series should help them find it. Whether anyone finds God in Gerard Depardieu is quite another story.
 
Cahiers Films And Times
 "Cahiers du Cinema Selects Recent French Films," a retrospective of films that have been cited for excellence by the French film journal, will be shown through March 1 at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center, 165 West 65th Street. Admission to each screening is $7. Information: (212) 875-5600. Here is the schedule.

HEADLINE: Bring Back the Wise Men

BYLINE: By Jimmy Carter; Jimmy Carter, the former President, is chairman of the Carter Center.

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
Ever since Japan became one of our most important trade partners and competitors, differences in national policies and priorities have threatened to degenerate into a counterproductive trade war. The current standoff is the most threatening in recent years and could have extremely serious consequences.
Such disputes are hardly unexpected, given the integration of Japan's Government and private sectors and its extreme dependence on exports. There is little doubt that Japan, a relatively closed society, has alliances among corporations that would violate American antitrust laws as well as safeguarded paths of product delivery from raw-material suppliers through manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers to consumers. 
 National laws and customs perpetuate these arrangements, making penetration of the market very difficult for foreigners unless they find a way to become part of the system.
In fairness to the Japanese, our laws almost completely exclude foreign imports that compete with vulnerable or politically powerful American industries or farm producers. Then, too, until recently most of our manufacturers depended on our enormous domestic market for sales, with relatively little emphasis an exports.
With a few notable exceptions, our consumer goods are not designed to accommodate the exceptional preferences of foreign consumers: How many Japanese cars would Americans buy if all their steering wheels were on the right side?
Still, there are situations and products that require attention at the highest level in Washington to enhance equitable access to markets, protect domestic employment and prevent the dumping of foreign goods here at or below production cost.
These factors are exacerbated by domestic political pressures, with leaders of both nations striving to avoid blame for economic problems and to gain credit for spirited actions and words against economic competitors. Fiery language, threats and step-by-step sanctions can escalate almost beyond control.
There is a proven alternative to counterproductive sanctions, public condemnations and arguments. In the late 1970's, a U.S.-Japan Economic Relations Group meet regularly and privately to address the multiple trade problems that inevitably arose.
The Prime Minister appointed four Japanese and I chose four Americans. Soon known as "wise men," all were respected senior statesmen knowledgeable about life and politics in both countries. The co-chairman were former ambassadors Robert Ingersoll and Nobuhiko Ushiba. With them were A.W. Clausen, Hugh Patrick, Edson Spencer, Akio Morita, Shuzo Muramato and Kiichi Seeki. They had no authority and only advised the President, Prime Minister and special trade representatives.
Controversial issues -- like those involving the quantity of imported shoes, TV sets and cars -- were referred to them. For example, Japan quietly accepted a proposal that it limit the number of cars exported to America and begin a program of producing Japanese cars here. Another resolved crisis related to allegations that the Japanese were dumping certain kinds of steel products on the American market at prices below those demanded in Japan.
The wise men's suggestions (almost always unanimous) were shared with top national leaders, who were still free to become personally involved or to initiate a public debate. The system worked remarkably well. Developing problems could be addressed almost immediately before they became controversies, and the result of actions taken could be assessed quickly. There was almost total freedom of communication, confidentiality was preserved and the need for face-saving and political rhetoric were minimized.
The President and Special Trade Representative were provided with sound and well-balanced advice on which to make decisions. Among private business and financial leaders in both countries, knowledge that the wise men had considered an issue and made a joint recommendation carried great weight and helped remove the stigma of politicization.
The wise men were disbanded soon after Ronald Reagan was inaugurated. The same system can work again and be initiated almost immediately. It would pay rich dividends.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Mr. Cuomo's Medicaid Cure

 BODY:
For years, Gov. Mario Cuomo has proposed having New York State take over the share paid by local governments for Medicaid -- the program of medical insurance for the poor. But never did he take the next step of budgeting money to pay for the worthy plan. That changed this week when the Governor proposed spending $110 million next year as a first installment of a phased Medicaid takeover.
Release of the money is contingent on Albany passing a multi-year takeover plan. In the past the Republican-led Senate has balked. But the election of a Republican Mayor in New York City, and dozens of Republican county executives around the state clamoring for Medicaid relief, might wilt that opposition. That makes Mr. Cuomo's decision to push his plan forward not only good public policy but also astute election-year campaigning. 
 Once a plan is passed, New York City will learn how much of the $110 million it will collect. But a rough guess is that the city would gain about $75 million over the next 13 months, and -- if the state puts up comparable money in its next budget -- perhaps $130 million before July 1995. That matches the figure its Mayor, Rudolph Giuliani, penciled in the city budget to balance next year's books.
New York is one of the few states that makes local governments pick up part of the tab for Medicaid, and it sticks those governments with the highest costs of any state. Next year New York City will spend about $2.5 billion on the program. It ought to pay nothing. The nation's poor should be a national responsibility, with Washington paying the entire tab. Short of that unlikely outcome, the state should pay Medicaid bills for all its poor citizens.
What Governor Cuomo proposes falls short of a full state assumption of the costs. He would slowly have the state take over Medicaid. But in return, counties would turn over to Albany a small fraction of their sales tax revenue, and New York City would turn over some of its personal income tax revenue. In the first couple of years the swap would be nearly even. But if Medicaid costs continue to explode, the city and counties would eventually come out ahead.
When the Governor presented his 1995 budget in January, he put up no money for a takeover. But Mayor Giuliani lobbied hard. And recent projections show that the state will, because of economic recovery, take in more tax revenue next year than originally estimated. Mr. Cuomo proposes using most of this to finance the initial cost.
Local governments face the danger that, with national health reform on the horizon, Medicaid costs will slow down while the taxes they gave away keep rising, so the swap might cost them money. But Mr. Cuomo proposes a "hold harmless" clause to guarantee that the city and counties would never turn over more tax revenue to the state than they would have spent on Medicaid.
However, there is a possible catch. Suburban executives are backing the Governor's initiative because they too are promised Medicaid budget relief. But everyone can't win. If New York City and other high-poverty regions come out ahead, then suburban taxpayers would presumably foot the bill through higher statewide taxes. Suburban leaders may be betting that the takeover will be financed not by taxes but by spending cuts -- in social programs that the better-off suburbs do not much use. If that happens, the "hold harmless" clause won't entirely work: The city would pay for part of its Medicaid relief by losing other state money.
Thus the Governor's plan poses some risk. But spending cuts for New York City are unlikely to exceed Medicaid relief, so the risk is worth taking. The city is spending nearly one-third of its revenues on the poor. That is unsustainable. The Governor proposes significant relief.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Political Crime

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
At the urging of President Clinton and many other politicians of both parties, the United States is about to embark on a remarkable new social program. It is to house, feed and provide geriatric support services for elderly Americans who have led worthless, harmful lives.
That will be one result of "three strikes, you're out," the much-touted proposal to put criminals away for life after a third violent felony. It would make state and Federal prisons hold increasing numbers of men past the age of violence, living on into their 80's and 90's. 
 If the Federal Government and the states considering the idea go ahead with it, the cost will be enormous. Philip Heymann, who has just left the job of Deputy Attorney General, estimates that it will cost between $600,000 and $700,000 to keep one person in prison for life after age 50, when the statistics show that criminal careers run down.
Mr. Heymann, speaking out after he returned to private life, said what most students of the crime problem privately believe: The three-strikes proposal and much else in the crime bill passed by the Senate will do little if anything to reduce violent crime.
"It's feeling good by appearing to be tough," Mr. Heymann said on ABC's "Nightline." Ted Koppel, who is usually so wise an interviewer, sneered at Mr. Heymann as "a lousy politician." Telling the truth about the phoniness of much crime legislation risks sneers, and that is why few have the courage to do it.
Politicians produce tough-looking remedies for crime because that is what voters want. The public is right to be angry and fearful about crime. Though statistics do not show a recent rise in violence, people are aware of drive-by shootings, the murder of children and other random horrors. They want to be tough: longer sentences, more prisons, boot camps. But the question is whether that kind of toughness will reduce violence.
The United States has more prisoners per capita than any other country: 455 per 100,000. That is 10 times the rate in Japan. There are almost one million Americans in prison today, three times the number in 1990.
The number of prisoners is so large, and growing so rapidly, for two main reasons. This country imposes penal sentences for minor drug offenses. And in recent years Congress and some states have imposed mandatory minimum sentences, without parole, for a number of crimes.
We tend to think of people who are sent to prison as depraved and brutal. Many, probably most, are in fact nonviolent offenders. About 20 percent of Federal prisoners are drug offenders with no prior record, no violence and no connection with any big drug operation.
Consider the case of Joel Proyect, a lawyer in upstate New York, former president of the Sullivan County Bar Association. He grew marijuana plants at his place in the country. He was not a dealer, not a seller, just a user of pot. He is now serving a mandatory minimum sentence of five years in Federal prison.
Joel Proyect was wrong to violate the law. But can it conceivably benefit our society to keep him in prison for five years for growing marijuana plants? And there are many thousands like him.
This country needs to reduce its prison population. It needs to get away from mandatory minimum sentences. Janet Reno knew that and said so before she became Attorney General. But the Clinton White House, determined to make the President look tough on crime, has evidently muzzled her.
The Senate crime bill would cost upwards of $22 billion. That kind of money would make a difference in a serious effort to deter violent crime, but the Senate bill is not that. It is a rag-bag of politicians' gestures, such as turning local offenses into Federal crimes, that will do nothing except waste money and frustrate citizens concerned about crime.
The saddest thing about the political posturing over crime is that it turns us back toward remedies proved useless: more prisons, longer fixed sentences and the like. The politicians, from President Clinton down, are determined not to let a new thought on drug policy or the causes of crime enter our failed system.
A headline in The Economist of London put it exactly: "Three strikes, you're hoodwinked."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Medical Prices Outrun The Rate of Inflation

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Today we hear that sweeping national health care reform may not be necessary because competition has broken the back of health care inflation. While medical care prices were increasing at 9.1 percent in 1990, they had fallen to 7.2 percent by the end of 1992 and to about 5.9 percent by the end of 1993.
Exactly 10 years ago, the Reagan Administration proudly announced that it had "broken the back of the health care inflation monster that has plagued us for more than two decades." That inflation rate had fallen from 10.8 percent in 1981 to 6.3 percent in 1984. But then, as now, most of the decline reflected the decline in overall inflation. Today, medical prices are rising 2.4 times faster than general inflation, considerably higher than in 1990. 
 The high rate at which the prices and use of medical services erode corporate profits and cut into state and Federal budgets for crime control, education and investments in economic growth certainly looks like a crisis. Spiraling prices also contribute to the personal crisis of people no longer sure their health insurance company will cover their medical bills. Thus, when leading Republicans dismiss the grave concerns of the Clintons as "a brazen campaign of fear-mongering" about a nonexistent crisis, they mislead the public.
After more than a decade of the most intense competition in medical care, both prices and overall expenditures rose proportionately faster during the 1980's than in the 70's.
Costs are not slowing now either, but competition is making a lot of money for a lot of people. Containing costs in the long run, now as in 1983, will greatly depend on the limits that are put on the total budget for spending. Sad to say, I suspect the United States will have no serious controls on total health care budgets 10 years from now.
 
DONALD W. LIGHT
Prof. of Comparative Health Systems
U. of Medicine & Dentistry of N.J.
Princeton, N.J., Feb. 11, 1994

HEADLINE: In Haiti, Oil Embargo Increases Suffering

 BODY:
To the Editor:
We recently returned from a medical mission in rural Haiti, where we observed rapidly deteriorating living conditions as a result of the United States-led United Nations oil embargo. Most of us are veterans of previous medical missions in rural Haiti; some of us have returned annually for more than a decade. 
 We observed a drastic reduction in medical and preventative health services provided to rural Haitians. Compared with January 1993, attendance at rural illness clinics is down 70 percent, surgical cases at regional hospitals are down 75 percent, and the number of immunizations and family planning services dispensed has similarly declined.
Public transportation (in rural Haiti on the back of dangerously overcrowded pickup trucks called "taptaps") has declined nearly 85 percent, and the cost has increased 500 percent, beyond the reach of most Haitians. Thus, poor rural Haitians cannot receive badly needed health care. Their health, already the worst in the Western Hemisphere, will certainly decline further as the embargo continues. The oil embargo is a de facto embargo on medical and preventative health care for rural Haiti.
Similarly, we observed decreased availability of food and an apparent increase in malnutrition. Although food is not specifically embargoed, the main sources of nutrition for rural Haitians (beans and rice) are imported and must be transported to the highlands. With transportation less available and more expensive, the price of rice and beans in the marketplace has more than doubled.
We noticed an increase in the number of children with the orange hair, thin limbs and swollen abdomens characteristic of malnutrition. This burden is added to a high rate of serious childhood malnutrition (some 25 percent) in rural Haitian children. The oil embargo is a de facto food embargo for rural Haiti.
The deliberate promotion of malnutrition and disease in Haiti is morally unacceptable to us. We believe most Americans would agree if they saw the new suffering the embargo has caused. Although the best way for our Government to proceed is not yet apparent, we are certain the oil embargo further victimizes the Haitian people. The oil embargo should be lifted. Now.
 
WILLIAM COCH, M.D.
HENRY MACLER JR., M.D.
KEN VAN DINE, M.D.
Andover, N.Y., Feb. 7, 1994
The letter was also signed by nine other medical mission members.
