HEADLINE: Burmese Lighten Policy on Dissident

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 18

 BODY:
In what diplomats described as a significant step toward possible freedom for Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Government-controlled newspapers in Myanmar published a long transcript of remarks today in which an American Congressman described the Burmese opposition leader as "a woman of passion and commitment" who "stands for the best ideals of democracy."
Diplomats said it was the first time since she was placed under house arrest in 1989 that words of praise for Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi had been allowed to appear in any official Myanmar Government publication. 
 The remarks were made at a news conference in Bangkok on Wednesday by Representative Bill Richardson, a New Mexico Democrat who this week led the first delegation of foreign visitors outside her family to see Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi since her detention. Mr. Richardson's comments were printed in full today in both the Burmese and English-language editions of The New Light of Myanmar, the principal Government newspaper.
 
'Dumbfounded and Delighted'
 A Western diplomat in Myanmar said he was "dumbfounded and delighted" to see that in the paper.
"I think they're laying the ground work for some sort of negotiations between Khin Nyunt and Aung San Suu Kyi," the diplomat said, referring to Lieut. Gen. Khin Nyunt, the head of Burmese military intelligence and the man considered by many to be Myanmar's new strongman. "It would be astounding if they would use their official mouthpiece to put out this much praise for the negotiating process and for Suu Kyi if they didn't intend to negotiate."
In the comments printed today in Myanmar, Representative Richardson described Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi as "a woman of towering intellectual ability and strength of conscience."
"She is a woman of passion and commitment," Mr. Richardson said. "She is a woman who stands for the best ideals of democracy. U.S. policy with Burma will improve only if Aung San Suu Kyi is released without condition as well as other political prisoners, and a genuine democratization effort takes place. Aung San Suu Kyi should be let free."
 
Announcement on Radio
 The Burmese junta clearly wanted to draw the public's attention to Representative Richardson's remarks since the Burmese state radio ran an announcement Thursday night alerting Burmese that the transcript would appear in the newspapers this morning.
During his visit to Myanmar, Representative Richardson met twice with Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi (pronounced awng san sue chee) at her family compound, which has served as her prison for nearly five years, and twice with General Khin Nyunt.
"The most productive effort that I can undertake is to get Aung San Suu Kyi and General Khin Nyunt together for talks," he said in other remarks also republished today. "Let me stress that I also believe that Lieut. Gen. Khin Nyunt is a pragmatic individual who is sincere about wanting to resolve the divisions in his country."
Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi has already agreed to the talks. General Khin Nyunt has not made a reply, although diplomats in Yangon, the capital formerly known as Rangoon, said today that the decision to publish such highly complimentary remarks about the democracy leader in the tightly controlled Burmese press meant that negotiations could now be only a matter of time.
 
A Sign of Policy Change
 "It sounds like they are serious," said another Western resident of Yangon. "It's the kind of thing we want to see. This is the first time we've ever had anything like this in the papers. I think this is as significant a litmus test for a change in the Government's policy than the actual meeting" between Mr. Richardson and Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi.
Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi is the daughter of a national hero, Aung San. In 1990, despite her detention, her opposition party won a landslide victory in national elections called by the military. The junta then refused to honor the results and arrested many of Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi's followers.
She won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1991 for her nonviolent campaign to bring democracy to her homeland.
Diplomats offer a variety of opinions why the junta has apparently decided to ease the restrictions on Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi. Many say that the junta's leaders have come to the belief that Myanmar will never break out of decades of economic stagnation unless the issue of her detention is resolved.

HEADLINE: At I.R.S.'s Parking Garage, Cars Zip Around a New Tax

SERIES: The Fine Print: A periodic look behind the law.

BYLINE: By By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18

 BODY:
If anyone knows how to take advantage of wrinkles in the tax rules, it is the bean counters at the Internal Revenue Service. So it should come as no surprise that they have figured out how the top officials at the agency can avoid paying hundreds of dollars in extra taxes this year to cover the value of parking free in the I.R.S. garage.
To do so, the agency had to violate principles it laid down eight years ago on how the value of taxable fringe benefits should be calculated. It wrote a one-year grace period into the enforcement rules of a new law and then figured the worth of I.R.S. parking in such a favorable way that the executives who use it owe no additional taxes. 
 Taking their cue from the tax authorities, the payroll managers at most other departments and agencies here are telling their officials that they too do not have to pay additional taxes this April on their free parking spaces.
Congress is in something of a dither, uncertain what to do. So the Architect of the Capitol, George M. White, has retained Arthur Andersen & Company, the accounting firm, to conduct a study and report next month on the worth of the free parking spaces available to all members of Congress and thousands of their staff members.
At issue is an obscure provision of a 1992 energy policy law that requires workers who receive free or subsidized parking from their employers to pay income taxes on the value above $155 a month, beginning with their 1993 tax returns.
The purpose of the provision, according to its sponsor, Representative Robert T. Matsui, a Democrat from California, is to raise a small amount of revenue and at the same time conserve energy and reduce pollution by discouraging commuters from driving to work.
 
Surprise for Officials
 The tax change was never debated or voted on separately in Congress, and few people in or out of the Government knew of its existence. It apparently never occurred to those who did know about it that Government officials might be affected, even though commercial parking rates in Washington are among the highest in the country and subsidized parking is much more prevalent here than it is in other big cities.
Then, between last Christmas and New Year's Day, more than a year after the law was enacted, the tax agency issued a ruling on how the value of parking should be calculated.
This regulation is important because without official guidance, many people have no idea how to figure what their subsidized parking is worth. When an employer pays a commercial lot for the space workers use, then the value is reasonably clear. But when the employer owns the building and allows employees to park there at no cost, as is often the case in the Government, then the value is in doubt.
The new rules specified that beginning with 1994 taxes, the value should be determined by what the I.R.S. called the fair market value, or the price a taxpayer would have paid for the parking space in a commercial transaction at the same location or one nearby. It is up to employers to tell their workers what they owe and to include the sum on W-2 forms, the forms that show how much income was earned each year and how much tax was withheld.
The tax agency left little wiggle room: the monthly rate must be applied if the space is available all month, even if the employee uses it only part of the time. If several employees commute together, one of them must be designated the "prime member" of the car pool and bear the tax consequences. If someone is driven to work in a limousine, as are some Cabinet officers and Congressional leaders, taxes are still due on the value of space where the limousine parks.
 
Yardstick for Fringe Benefits
 This follows the general I.R.S. regulation, in effect since 1986, on the proper way to assess the value of employer-paid fringe benefits. That regulation states: "The fair market value of a fringe benefit is the amount that an individual would have to pay for the particular fringe benefit in an arm's-length transaction. . . . An employee's subjective perception of the value of a fringe benefit is not relevant."
But the regulation on parking issued last December contained what in tax jargon is known as a transition rule and what others might call a one-year escape hatch. For 1993 taxes, the ones due this April 15, employers can apply any "reasonable good faith" method of calculating what the parking they provide their employees is worth. In the case of the Government, the rules left it up to each department and agency to determine the value of the parking it provides for its workers.
Lawyers and consultants who advise clients on the taxation of fringe benefits say that private employers in the few large cities in the country where parking runs higher than $155 a month are scrambling to take advantage of the escape clause.
At the tax agency's headquarters on Constitution Avenue, 79 officials enjoy free, indoor, reserved parking. They are given to the highest ranking officials, handicapped workers and some who work nights.
For taxes due this year, the agency has decided not to follow in the case of its own employees what it has proclaimed in the 1986 regulation to be the proper way to calculate the value of parking or any other fringe benefit. Instead, said Frank Keith, an agency spokesman, the agency figured the worth of parking spaces on the basis of the rent the agency pays the General Services Administration, the Government's landlord.
 
Justification of Move
 In a telephone interview, Mr. Keith described the process this way: "We are assessed a fee of $6.93 per square foot for our parking garage. We multiplied that by the square footage of the parking spaces and determined that it came to less than $155 a month. This particular method we used for evaluation, a good faith method, is a method any taxpayer could have used."
Maybe so. But it is not an arm's-length transaction.
The Justice Department, which enforces the laws, the General Accounting Office, which audits the Government's books, and many other departments and agencies followed the lead of the I.R.S. and used a similar method to figure the worth of parking last year to their employees.
A spot check of commercial parking lots near Capitol Hill and in downtown Washington, where most of the Cabinet Departments are situated, shows that indoor, reserved spaces cost about $300 a month. Outdoor spaces and unreserved spaces indoors generally run less than $155, below the threshold of the new law.
In any event, the rules mean that beginning with income earned in 1994, all Senators and Representatives, most Cabinet officers and thousands of other executive branch officials and Congressional aides who park indoors in spaces reserved for them will owe taxes on at least an additional $1,740 ($300 minus $155, or $145, times 12 months). Those in the 36 percent tax bracket will owe an additional $626 in taxes on April 15, 1995.
The White House and the Treasury Department do not have indoor garages, so parking there probably falls beneath the threshold. (In a true arm's-length transaction, based on, say, what a parking space might go for at auction, the outdoor spots on West Executive Avenue next to the White House, where the really important people park, are probably worth thousands of dollars a month. But that is beside the point. Surely no one will ever be required to make that calculation.)
Asked about this the day after an ice storm last week, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the chairwoman of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers, said, "You see me scraping the ice last night, and you tell me this is worth more than $155."

HEADLINE: Oregon Starts to Extend Health Care

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 17

 BODY:
A woman stood up and asked, If someone makes absolutely no money, how could she possibly prove that her income was below the Federal poverty line to qualify for free medical insurance.
A man wanted to know if the cost of an operation that is not covered by insurance could be covered if the condition is discovered during a surgical procedure that does qualify for reimbursement. 
 "What about periodontal costs?" an older man called out.
The questions continued for an hour one night last week as two state administrators explained Oregon's new health care plan at a center for the elderly in Tigard, a suburb south of here. Many people listened with worried expressions.
 
Questions on Ability to Pay
 After years of dispute, Oregon is finally beginning to carry out an ambitious plan to extend health coverage to all residents, and the people at the Tigard Senior Center were some of the intended beneficiaries. In the first step, which took effect on Feb. 1, Oregon became the first state to extend Medicaid coverage, care paid for by the state and Federal governments, to most residents below the poverty line.
But serious questions are already being raised about the state's ability to pay for the new services and its political will to extend insurance to all.
The next step toward universal coverage is to require all employers to contribute toward health insurance, but that has been resisted by small-business owners, and the mandate has been put off until 1998.
Oregon's original idea was to help pay for the expanded coverage of poor people by eliminating payments for treatments deemed low in benefit, a step toward rationing that drew widespread criticism. In the end, only the most marginal of medical services were eliminated, saving little money, and the State Legislature had to come up with $65 million at a time of acute financial strain.
 
Difficult Decisions Ahead
 In coming years, unless it is bailed out by a new national health program, the state will either have to approve large additional outlays for health coverage or take the politically explosive step of scaling back the treatments it covers under Medicaid, denying medically useful care.
The five-year experiment guarantees coverage to all Oregonians whose income is under the Federal poverty level but too high to qualify for the existing Medicaid program. The estimated Federal poverty level for a family of four in 1993 was an annual income of $14,764.
The focus of most questions in Tigard last week was the list of covered services. The administrators' answers allayed enough anxieties to cause a near stampede when the audience was invited to fill out application forms.
"This is wonderful," said Janet Wieneke, 36, an unemployed radiation therapist. "Now, I've got no insurance and it's real scary. With every ache or pain, you think this is it. I could lose everything I own."
State officials estimate that as many as 120,000 of the 479,000 Oregonians without health coverage could qualify for the expanded Medicaid program. Applicants need to meet the poverty-line requirement for only a month to qualify for six months of coverage.
In formulating the Oregon plan, which provides a choice among 22 health maintenance organizations, a state panel produced a list of 696 health conditions and treatments, ranking them on a cost-benefit basis. After public hearings and negotiations with Washington, the state agreed to cover the first 565.
 
Extent of Coverage
 The plan provides general medical and dental coverage, with no stipulations for pre-existing conditions, and covers the entire cost of prescriptions. The conditions excluded from coverage are those that are not deemed to be serious enough to require treatment, like common colds, flu, mild food poisoning, sprains, cosmetic procedures and experimental treatments for diseases in advanced stages.
The program was approved for the 17 months through June 30, 1995, with financing of $20 million from the state's general fund and a gradual increase on cigarette taxes that is expected to produce $45 million.
But with the new plan scheduled to absorb all those who remain under the standard Medicaid plan by Jan. 1, 1995, and with benefits expanding to include mental health and chemical dependency treatment, officials are predicting that costs could rise to as much as $200 million over the next two-year period. With the cigarette tax increase expiring, it remains unclear where the money would come from in a state that prides itself on having no sales tax.
The entire Oregon plan could be folded into whatever national program is adopted by the Federal Government. "Which would be fine with me," said John Kitzhaber, a former state legislator who helped draw up the state's plan.
Mr. Kitzhaber, a Democratic candidate for governor, said the plan that went into effect two weeks ago differed from his original concept in one major area: the timing of the requirement that all employers offer health insurance. The original plan would have required employers to cover all workers by July 1993. For companies with 25 employees and more, the deadline was pushed back to July 1995, then to March 31, 1997. Companies with fewer than 25 workers were given until Jan. 1, 1998, to comply.
 
Concern on Rationing
 Advocates for the poor are concerned that the delay, combined with the possibility that health care costs will continue to rise in the short term, will force the state to begin cutting back on medical services that are covered, causing the dreaded rationing.
"Because Oregon has done nothing to control costs, there is only one way they will respond: move the benefit line," said Ellen Pinney, the executive director of the Oregon Health Action Campaign. But when the Federal Government approved the Medicaid experiment last year, it banned a reduction in services for two years, and required Federal permission for three years after that. What will happen if the state cannot come up with the required money is unclear.
In the past two weeks, the response to the plan around the state has been overwhelming, health officials say. Calls to an information number have far exceeded early projections of 5,000 a month, said Hersh Crawford, the assistant director of the state's medical assistance program. "The reality has been, we're getting 3,500 to 4,000 a day," he said.
Many of the 200 community meetings, like the one in Tigard, have attracted as many as 150 people at a time.
For people like John Oliphant, 26, an unemployed former marine who is now studying criminal justice at a local community college, the plan offers new hope. After his wife, Rae, was involved in an automobile accident, he said he called the health plan's information line and was told that her medical bills would be covered. He came to the Tigard center to enroll.
"When I called, they told me I would qualify, but I'm still a little skeptical," Mr. Oliphant said. "I know this is helpful. But I'll feel a lot better when my wife goes to the doctor and it's all paid for."

HEADLINE: Stocks Slip Nervously Following Bonds' Lead

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
In a second straight session of falling prices, the stock market followed the unnerved bond market yesterday, as prices dropped on the leading stock exchanges in moderate trading before the long holiday weekend.
Now, both stock and bond traders will turn their uneasy gaze to Congressional testimony on Tuesday by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve. Mr. Greenspan is sure to startle both markets by what he says, or fails to say, about future increases in interest rates. 
 Three weeks ago, when Mr. Greenspan testified, he clearly signaled a rise in interest rates to fight a potential resurgence of inflation. His testimony preceded by mere days a quarter-point rise in a key short-term rate that touched off a 96-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average.
 
 
Most Dow Stocks Drop
 The stock market has not been the same since. Traders yesterday bid down 27 of the 30 component stocks of the Dow industrial average and 313 of the components of the Standard & Poor's 500.
The Dow dropped 35.18 points, to 3,887.46, the S.& P. 500 fell 2.65 points, to 467.69, and the Nasdaq composite index declined 1.39 points, to 788.85.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 1.51 points, to 259.87, on volume of 290 million shares. Declining stocks outnumbered those that rose by 1,411 to 706. The American Stock Exchange market value index fell 3.51 points, to 470.95.
David Shulman, chief equity strategist for Salomon Brothers Inc., said the stock and bond markets were moving on more than a morbid fascination with inflation and interest rates. Recent economic data like housing starts and auto sales, despite having been distorted by severe winter weather and the Los Angeles earthquake, have been strongly positive, he noted.
The economy is bound to accelerate as the weather improves, Mr. Shulman said, and that could possibly hurt stocks. "If the economic recovery moves from Wall Street to Main Street," he said, "then people will move from buying stocks to buying cars and houses and refrigerators. The financial market will get less of that pool of funds."
 
 
Another Decline Predicted
 William E. Raftery, a market technician for Smith Barney Shearson, said he would not be surprised if the Dow dropped to 3,750 soon, perhaps as early as next week. "A hundred points or more is nothing on a Dow close to 4,000," Mr. Raftery said. "You have got to think big numbers these days."
Yesterday, stock traders took their cue from bond traders fearful of a surge in inflation that for the moment has not become evident. When corporate borrowing costs rise, as when interest rates go up, stock prices of corporations often fall.
The fever chart of the bond traders was clear yesterday. The yield on the benchmark 30-year bond generally reflects the bond market's outlook on interest rates. The yield has soared nearly 17 basis points in the last three sessions alone to close yesterday at 6.62 percent, the highest level in six and a half months. The 30-year bond's price, which declines as the yield rises, fell 11/32 , to 957/32 .
 
 
Utilities Also Falter
 The Dow Jones utilities average also seemed to reflect traders' inflation concerns. It declined for a sixth consecutive session, falling 3.56 points, to 208.54. Because stocks of electric power companies pay such high dividends, some market analysts regard them as a hybrid of stocks and bonds and a potential indicator of the future direction of both markets. A decline in the utilities average is said to signal higher interest rates.
Novell was the most active stock of the day, with 7.3 million shares traded. The maker of computer networking software rose 1 1/8, to 23 7/8, on reports that it could reap more than $100 million from new license fees for Unix computer software.
Ventritex, a maker of heart-treatment devices, was the second-most-active stock, with trading volume of 6.8 million shares. Its shares fell 10 1/4, to 26 3/4. Analysts downgraded the stock, citing questions about the company's compliance with a Food and Drug Administration inquiry.
In Japan, stocks traded slightly higher yesterday. The Nikkei index of 225 issues rose 28.21 points, or about a tenth of a percent, to 18,959.60.

HEADLINE: The Degrees Of Separation;
Seniors Prepare for the Real World

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STORRS, Conn.

 BODY:
As the college class of 1994 approaches graduation, it is that nervous time when parents who have not nagged once in four long years find themselves blurting out, "Have you found a job?"
Jeremy Palmer, an engineering student at the University of Connecticut here, is one who, somewhat to his surprise, does have a job, at General Electric. Before his successful internship at G.E. during the semester break, he said, "I had almost been locked into graduate school." 
 But to Mr. Palmer and his classmates, who entered college at the start of a recession and are leaving in what economists are saying is the first foothold of a recovery, landing a first job out in the real world is not what it used to be.
As college career officers across the country sound their final alarm this month, they are telling seniors that the job market is improving, even in the Northeast, where the recession hit hard. But after four years of cutbacks and reorganization and, plainly put, mass dismissals at the great names of American industry and finance, students know the market has changed, perhaps for their lifetime.
It may always have been a jungle out there, but they sense they are stepping back into the kind of workplace jungle that Upton Sinclair would recognize, one where loyalty is a luxury and security a dangerous illusion.
"People have been warning us, especially our parents, that you need to have an escape plan," Mr. Palmer said. "What I mean is, that once you're over 40, companies are likely to weed you out. You have to be prepared to start your own business or change careers."
With nearly 3,000 seniors graduating with degrees in liberal arts, business, engineering and health, the University of Connecticut offers a wide window into the changing job market and the evolving expectations of employers and their potential employees.
Career officers at the university say they know the job market is finally improving because more employers are coming to them. At the peak, in the late 1980's, 400 employers a year came to campus to interview seniors. At the nadir, in 1992, 150 did. This year, the number should pass 200, said Gene Policelli, assistant director of the Department of Career Programs.
As important, he said, as many as 100 companies with job openings call his department each month, asking for the resumes of qualified students.
"What I suspect, with this class, is that there is less frenzy about landing a job," Mr. Policelli said. "Not less anxiety, less frenzy. No one's surprised by what's out there."
For most students, February is a month for basketball fever, with both the men's and women's teams ranked in the Top 10 nationally this year. But for seniors, it is the month when career officers offer workshops on preparing resumes, interviewing, searching and networking. Mock interviews are conducted. Students start submitting their resumes for the real interviews.
 
Sit Down Front
 "Could I ask of you a favor?" Mr. Policelli said to 25 students gathered in a lecture hall one afternoon, none seated within 10 rows of where he stood. "All of you who would like jobs, please sit down in the front."
Seconds later, everyone rearranged, he continued, "What I really want to do today is psych you up to give you some hope that there is hope, and to put the fear of God in you that it won't happen unless you get out there."
The message that Mr. Policelli and his colleagues deliver is double-edged. "The whole concept of employment has changed," he warned. "Downsizing is real. That tremendous work force we had is not coming back."
But even companies that are dismissing thousands of older, experienced, higher-paid employees, he said, still need entry-level workers, especially those with the skills to step right in and do the work piling up on vacated desks.
"Maybe instead of hiring 10, they'll hire 3," he said. "So it's more competitive, but they're hiring."
Even getting a campus interview is competitive, he said. Most recruiters talk to only a dozen students; many companies want to see only students with grade-point averages above 3.0.
"This bothers us," he said, confiding that the university does not screen out students with averages below an employer's cut-off point. ""We've done some research, and we've found there's absolutely no correlation between a high G.P.A. and success on the job."
"Yes!" someone in the rear said softly but firmly.
"There's your hope," Mr. Policelli said.
Afterward, students talked about their plans. Lisa Diamond of Newington had built up her resume with a double major in psychology and journalism, an internship with the State Alcohol and Drug Abuse Commission and, last semester, had worked full time at a law firm. Back on campus, she finally had time to think about life after graduation.
"I just want a job with benefits," she said.
Padrick Power of West Hartford was hearing contrary advice: adults were steering him toward sales, classmates toward teaching. His father had advised him not to worry about his philosophy major: "He told me, 'You're going to have to change careers anyway. Not jobs. Careers.' "
The recession, he said, had always been a concern. "It's been like a burden, an atmosphere of fear about the economy. Now you see companies laying people off and then hiring others, and you have to ask, are they really interested in me? Do they have any loyalty?"
John Totten of Coventry and Chris Alexopoulos of Storrs, both aspiring sports broadcasters, had been occupied with stints on the campus radio station, internships at a Hartford television station, and part-time jobs. They were prepared for the worst: leaving Connecticut.
"I'd go to Walla Walla if I could do radio there," Mr. Totten said. "But I'm in a position where I definitely have to have something in May. And I have to help my family. I can't just go home and take a year off."
Career officers say the seniors have realistic expectations. They understand why they are employable, fresh out of college, when their parents and other adults are losing jobs they might once have aspired to. They understand why more employers want to put them right to work, rather than invest in training them.
So they are not so surprised when a company like International Business Machines, once a symbol of careerlong employment, now comes to campus offering what it calls "term employment": a three-year contract.
"Students are doing better than older people in dealing with revisions to the implied social contract between employers and employees," said Raymond Palmer, a consultant with the career center at the School of Business Administration.
Many students are doing well. Health-service graduates and computer-science engineers are in demand. So are accounting majors like Cathy Jarrett of Stamford, who accepted a position as an auditor with KPMG Peat Marwick last October.
"Most of us are going Big Six," she said of her accounting classmates.
Many are undertaking the search with the sense of adventure that graduating seniors have always had. "I played football for four years, so I'm just starting now," said Gary Bailey, a communications-science major from Norwalk, who stopped by the career library to look up tips on interviewing. "I'm on pins and needles, trying to get my life in order."
In the United Technologies Building, a group of mechanical-engineering students agreed that with the three largest recruiters of University of Connecticut engineers laying off employees -- Electric Boat, Pratt & Whitney and Sikorsky Aircraft -- they were prepared to look out of state.
"I don't think Connecticut is really a great place for industry, so I'm looking elsewhere," said Richard Glatt of Glastonbury.
Tim Mercier of Glastonbury said, "I'd be more willing to take a job that paid $5,000 less in return for knowing I could be there 10 or 15 years without having to worry."
 
Help With the Master's
 Jeremy Palmer said he hoped General Electric would help pay for him to pursue his master's degree. Jeff Staniunas of Manchester hoped to find a job in Connecticut "and then network my way out to Arizona."
Pratt & Whitney, where he had had a semester-long job arranged through the university, wanted to interview him, Mr. Staniunas said, but he was unsure. "Who's to say we won't be laid off in three years?"
Mr. Policelli says he is not surprised to see students leave Connecticut. Other parts of the country have jobs. But while he watches students adapt to the changing marketplace, he also wonders how their new, lower expectations will ultimately benefit the economy.
This is a generation that grew up leery of marriage and intimacy because of the divorces they saw all around them. Now, he said, its members are being encouraged to look warily on relationships with employers.
"What can they offer a company?" he said. "Two or three years, I tell them. Because that's all the company is going to offer them.
"Yes, I do worry. Where is their anchor?"

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Closes With Losses After an Early Rally Falters

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most European currencies yesterday amid disappointment that it failed to sustain a rally after the German central bank cut an important interest rate.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.7133 marks, down from 1.7265 marks on Thursday. 
 The Bundesbank said on Thursday that it was cutting its discount rate by half a percentage point, to 5.25 percent. Other European central banks also trimmed rates.
But interest rates in the United States moved higher yesterday as bond prices fell amid new fears of inflation.
Lower interest rates in other countries tend to make investments there less attractive, and the dollar initially rallied after the European rate cuts. But the dollar then failed to make much headway.
That dampened many players' expectations for a much higher dollar in coming months, prompting many to scale back their holdings of dollars.
The dollar's huge selloff at the beginning of the week against the Japanese yen also helped cast a shadow over the dollar.
"With the dollar down on the yen, it drags everything down with it," said Frank Pusateri, vice president at Bank of Boston.
The dollar did manage to post a minor gain against the yen in trading yesterday after Japanese officials said they planned steps to make markets more open to American exports. In New York, the dollar rose to 104.61 yen, up from 104.25 yen.
The British pound rose to $1.4825 in late New York trading, from $1.4775 on Thursday.
Gold prices fell. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, the most active gold futures contract for April delivery dropped $2.70, to $381.60 an ounce.
Other late dollar rates, compared with Thursday's quotes, included: 1.4425 Swiss francs, down from 1.4575; 5.8238 French francs, down from 5.8665; 1.3427 Canadian dollars, up from 1.3377, and 1,666 Italian lire, down from 1,674.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Copper Eases but Still Ends The Week Nearly 2 Higher

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Copper prices retreated yesterday but still posted nearly a 2-cent-a-pound rise for the week as many analysts predicted an increase in copper demand from expanding global economies.
Crude oil prices edged lower, while heating oil, gasoline and natural gas prices firmed. 
 Profit taking was prevalent in many commodity markets, which will not reopen until Tuesday because of the long holiday weekend.
At the Commodity Exchange in New York, the March copper contract fell 2.05 cents, to 86 cents a pound. Bernard Savaiko, an analyst at Paine Webber, said the contract's failure to breach the 88-cent level had led to selling. "From there, prices eroded as stocks and bonds declined sharply amid fears of higher interest rates," he said.
The market posted a 10-month high of 90.3 cents a pound on Feb. 2, having only gradually recovered from a low of 72 cents set in October.
"The price I feel we need to achieve before we truly break the psychology of a six-year downtrend is 95 cents," Richard Hirsch of Sharps Pixley Brokers said at an American Metal Market copper forum this week. He based the outlook for higher prices on a continuation of the economic recovery in the United States and a quicker-than-expected economic bounce in Europe, perhaps led by Germany.
Charles Bradford of UBS Securities said that copper prices were likely to average around 85 cents a pound this year but rise to 95 cents next year. "In a recovery, you get substantial growth in consumption," he said.
But Leanne Baker of Salomon Brothers forecast a fall in copper prices because of expanded copper mining. "Supply on an annual basis should rise by about 5 percent in the second half of 1994," she said, predicting a copper surplus of 200,000 metric tons by the end of the year.
 In oil trading, Peter Beutel, an energy analyst at Cameron Hanover, said many investors had taken profits on previously established spread trades by buying back heating oil contracts and selling off gasoline contracts.
At the New York Mercantile Exchange, March crude lost 2 cents, to $14.21 a barrel; March heating oil added 0.51 cent, to 45.75 cents a gallon; March gasoline gained 0.17 cent, to 43.23 cents a gallon, and March natural gas jumped 3.3 cents, to $2.418 for 1,000 cubic feet.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Unwitting Hostages To Currency Risks

BYLINE: By Leslie Eaton

 BODY:
BETTING on currency moves is too risky, too hazardous, too akin to gambling for any investor short of George Soros, right?
Maybe, but that hasn't stopped millions of Americans from placing big wagers on currencies -- usually without knowing what they're betting on or, in some cases, without knowing that they are making a bet at all. These investments may come back to haunt them if, as many pundits predict, the dollar strengthens this year. 
 Given the kind of volatility investors saw last week, when the dollar plunged 4 percent against the Japanese yen on Monday before rebounding a bit, you might expect currency moves to have caught the attention even of people who think the Thai baht has something to do with baseball. Unfortunately, last week's action may have reassured, rather than alarmed, investors.
The reason: The dollar dropped. And while that made Tokyo a tougher place for American tourists to afford, it increased the dollar value of their investments in Japan.
With currencies as with stocks, nobody complains about volatility that's in her favor. And it's been years since the dollar slammed investors and helped travelers; the dollar peaked against most currencies back in 1985.
Though Europe's 1992 currency crisis certainly pounded investors in short-term global bond funds -- so much so that these funds barely exist anymore -- that was two years ago. "Memories have gotten so short," said Robert Markman, president of a Minneapolis investment advisory firm that bears his name. In 1990, 1991 and 1992 "people got killed in overseas markets," he said. "Now we've had one good year and they've had a financial lobotomy."
But many Americans have been investing overseas for less than a year, pouring billions of greenbacks into all kinds of international investments, sometimes without knowing it. Lots of mutual funds that on the surface look like red, white and blue funds turn out, on close inspection, to have big bucks at work overseas. For example, Fidelity Capital Appreciation Fund has about 40 percent of its $1.4 billion in assets invested abroad.
Then there are foreign investments that trade on stock exchanges in the United States: closed-end country funds and American depository receipts, which are basically foreign companies' stocks. Because these securities look like domestic issues, and trade in dollars, neophyte investors may not have thought much about the fact that the underlying investments may be denominated in ringgits or Deutsche marks or pesos.
The biggest foreign investments, however, have come through American mutual funds that specialize in overseas stocks. Last year, Americans put $26.3 billion into international funds, more than in the previous 10 years put together, and five times 1992's level
"Currency can be a powerful force, to be ignored at your peril," said Simon H. Davies, investment director of Gartmore Capital Management Ltd. in London. Mr. Davies, who last year began managing an international mutual fund for the Colonial Group of Boston, said he was surprised to discover how few of his competitors hedge currency risk -- a situation he expects will change if he's right about the dollar rising later this year.
In fact, investors counting on professional money managers to protect them from currency risk may be in for a nasty surprise. Most mutual funds reserve the right to hedge their currency exposure, but many have little or no intention of doing so.
Even reading a fund's annual report may not tell you much, because disclosure about derivatives and currencies is weak, as even Federal regulators concede. The Securities and Exchange Commission's staff has discussed forcing international funds to disclose how much of their returns come from currency, but that trial balloon has never floated far.
Morningstar, the Chicago fund-tracking firm, does try to figure out whether funds are using currency hedges or not, but it's not easy, Jim Coursey, an analyst, reported. A few funds, most notably those run by G. T. Capital Management, are almost always hedging their currency exposure and qualify as active hedgers. A larger number, like those in Franklin Resources' Templeton division, never hedge. But "the vast majority fall into the category of occasional hedgers, which is squishy and noninformative," Mr. Coursey said.
Of course, hedging currencies can be expensive and is by no means foolproof. "I don't have a lot of confidence in real active currency management," said Kenneth Gregory, an investment adviser and editor of the No-Load Fund Analyst newsletter in Orinda, Calif. "Even the smart guys are wrong a lot."
Furthermore, he noted, just because 10 percent of a portfolio is invested overseas, that doesn't mean it has 10 percent exposure to currency fluctuations. Some currencies, including many in Southeast Asia, are linked to the dollar, and foreign companies that export goods might do better if the dollar rises.
Still, Mr. Gregory said, over the last year he has increased his use of mutual funds that try to reduce their exposure to currency fluctuations.
Over the long run, currency fluctuations may be a wash, he said. "But the short run," he added, "can be pretty long sometimes: three or four or five years."

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Maas Gaining Cash, Losing a Career

BYLINE: By Murray Chass

 BODY:
On the surface, the raise Kevin Maas won by losing in salary arbitration seems absurd. Maas went to bat for the Yankees only 177 times last season and batted .205, but he emerged from his hearing with a $170,000 raise, even though the Yankees' last offer before they submitted that figure represented a $30,000 pay cut.
That's what salary arbitration has done to clubs. It has made them economic wimps. For all of their complaining about players' salaries, the clubs approach the arbitration process with cowardice. Of the 80 players who exchanged salary figures with their clubs for this year's potential hearings, only two faced pay cuts. 
 Clubs are afraid to argue for cuts because they don't think arbitrators will grant them, but by not attempting to gain cuts, clubs are telling arbitrators that lower salaries are not part of the arbitration game.
So Maas will earn more money, and for possibly less work for the Yankees. That's the other side of the Kevin Maas story.
"It's a classic case of wasting an asset," Craig Fenech, the player's agent, said yesterday. "While that's unfortunate for the Yankees, it's tragic for Kevin. He's 29 years old. He has to get out and play or he won't have a career."
Maas has tried to have a career. About the only thing he hasn't done is picket outside Yankee Stadium carrying a sign saying, "Free Kevin Maas."
For more than a year, he has begged the Yankees to trade him or release him or sell him to a Japanese team. A couple of months ago he placed a series of telephone calls to George Steinbrenner, a man who shows such compassion for the underdog that he gave Tonya Harding $20,000 for training expenses. Maas wanted to make his case directly to his employer and ask him not to tender him a contract for the 1994 season, thus making him a free agent.
"We wanted to appeal to him as a human being to let him go," Fenech said. "He's 29. They're frittering away his career. He's never said play me. He's said if you have no use for me, trade me."
Steinbrenner never called back. After ignoring numerous messages, he had Tim McCleary, the Yankees' assistant general manager, make the call. The answer, of course, was no, just as it had been earlier, when Fenech, at Maas's request, asked Gene Michael, the general manager, to sell him to a Japanese team.
"What, are you crazy?" Fenech quoted Michael as responding. "What's the matter with you?"
Michael defended his decision not to let Maas walk away.
"We're not going to let a player go just because he wants to go," Michael said. "If we can get something for him, we'll let him go. I told Hensley Meulens the same thing. He just wanted me to let him go. We have a lot of money invested in these guys. If I let guys go just because they want to be let go, I'd be fired."
So Maas remains trapped in an impossible situation. The Yankees have absolutely no use for him -- Don Mattingly is their first baseman, Danny Tartabull the designated hitter -- and his trade value has plummeted to the used resin bag level, but they stubbornly refuse to liberate him.
Rumors surfaced recently that the Mets, in the market for a first baseman, were interested in Maas, but there's no way the Yankees would send him to Shea Stadium. Fenech believes the Yankees would send Maas to Columbus before they would put him on the subway to Queens, although he speculated that a $425,000 salary would be an expensive minor league salary.
A decade ago, though, the Yankees kept Butch Hobson at Columbus under house arrest for three years at $400,000 a year rather than release him and let him try to earn a major league job elsewhere.
Maas is caught in a baseball version of Catch 22. He has played professionally for eight years, but even after his ninth season, he will not have accumulated enough time to be a free agent either as a minor leaguer or a major leaguer. He needs nearly all of the next three seasons to gain major league free agency, or at least one day in the minors in each of two more seasons to qualify for minor league free agency.
His playing time with the Yankees has decreased each of the last two seasons, and Fenech said, "He would need a train wreck to play this year." Furthermore, the Yankees have a new left-handed hitter, Sam Horn, who could serve the part-time role Maas has played the past couple of seasons.
"I'm not asking the Yankees to get nothing for Kevin," Fenech said. "All I'm saying is give the kid a chance, before he's too old, to find out what kind of player he can be. When given a chance to perform, he performs well. We have never said he should be playing for the New York Yankees. What we have said is if you can't use him, let him go. The saddest part is no one gives a damn."
Meanwhile, the Yankees have given Maas a pay raise, which in their supposedly downtrodden financial straits is inexplicable.
"He's arbitration eligible," Michael said, trying to explain the raise. "The salary scale changes then and we acknowledge that. We admit that."
Fenech offered a different view.
"After three years, a player earns the right to be compensated if he's going to be warehoused," he said. "There's a terrible cost involved for Kevin, but there's compensation for that."

HEADLINE: REDESIGN PLANNED FOR CITY HOSPITAL SERVING BROOKLYN

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE

 BODY:
Two weeks after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani declared a moratorium on the billion-dollar reconstruction of Kings County Hospital, his administration and state officials say they plan a thorough redesign of the project in order to produce a smaller, more efficient institution.
The call for a redesign of the city's largest public hospital, coming after a decade generally acknowledged to have been wasted on delay, mismanagement and poor planning, is certain to postpone the long-awaited project in East Flatbush even further. 
 Political and neighborhood leaders in central Brooklyn, who have pleaded for a new hospital through more than three decades and five different mayors and who sharply criticized Mr. Giuliani when he imposed the moratorium, say the new delay is unconscionable.
"It's outrageous that they've spent all this money to have an expert design it, and now they say it won't meet the needs of the next century," said Waldaba Stewart, an economist living in Crown Heights who is a member of the Kings County Hospital Community Advisory Board. "How long is it going to take for them to come up with the right hospital?" So far, $43.6 million has been spent on planning and design.
 
A Design Too Old?
 But the swift changes transforming the country's health care system have already eclipsed the mid-1980's design for a sprawling, 1,200-bed campus that New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation has struggled for years to build, state and city health officials say.
Whatever hospital finally emerges will have fewer beds and be more tightly focused on primary care, with emphasis on prevention and outpatient treatment, rather than expensive specialties, they say.
"The project was not headed in the right direction," said Dr. Bruce Siegel, who began work this week as the new president of the hospitals agency, appointed by Mr. Giuliani. "All over America hospitals are redesigning to cut out expensive inpatient beds and expand their primary-care networks. It's not a good idea to just bulldoze ahead with a 15-year-old project that may not be what Brooklyn needs in the year 2000."
 
Mayor Concurs
 Karen Crowe, a spokeswoman for Mr. Giuliani, said the Mayor concurred with Dr. Siegel's desire to steer the project toward more primary care for the community. She said the two men would meet soon to discuss the precise size of the new hospital.
Residents and political leaders in central Brooklyn said they were suspicious of the administration's intentions in redesigning the project, expressing concern that the current moratorium is a prelude to simply killing the project in a largely black neighborhood that supported Mr. Giuliani's opponent. But Giuliani administration officials insisted they plan to build a replacement hospital with a minimum of delay.
There have been numerous master plans and designs for a replacement of the 62-year-old hospital, but the current plan, completed in 1986, calls for a 1.4-million-square-foot medical center with 1,220 beds and a full complement of specialized medical units, like a burn center and a radiation therapy clinic. The size of the new hospital was determined at a time when the existing building was so desperately overcrowded with patients that its ancient wards were jammed with makeshift beds and emergency cases could barely fit into overstuffed elevators.
But hospital records show that the occupancy rate of Kings County Hospital has steadily declined in the last five years from more than 100 percent to 75.4 percent in 1993, a trend matched by surrounding medical centers. Hospital officials say the construction throughout central Brooklyn of several primary-care centers, which practice preventive medicine and treat illnesses before they require hospitalization, has reduced the demand at Kings County, as have limits on Federal payments that result in shorter patient stays.
"What's happening at Kings County is part of a nationwide trend," said Robert D. Gumbs, executive director of the Health Systems Agency of New York City, which coordinates planning of new hospital operations in the city for the state. "Occupancy has dropped because of things like outpatient surgery and a better ability to manage H.I.V. and substance abuse. You don't need these mammoth structures anymore; the hospital will wind up being less important as the focal point of health care delivery."
As the Kings County Hospital plans are re-evaluated, Mr. Gumbs said, his agency would require the new hospital to have "significantly fewer" inpatient beds. He did not specify how many, but other city and state officials predicted that the new plan would include somewhere between 600 and 800 beds.
"There are a lot of people who think the optimal-size hospital is under 600 beds," said Dr. Siegel. "I want to look at this in the perspective of what is the size that the people of Brooklyn need. What does the community need?"
 
Duplication Cited
 A top official with the State Health Department said the moratorium was also an appropriate time to trim a large number of planned specialized units that are duplicated at the State University of New York's Health Sciences Center at Brooklyn, a 300-bed teaching hospital directly across Clarkson Avenue from Kings County. Edward J. Dowling, associate director of the Health Department's Division of Health Facility Planning, said there was no need to have two complete medical laboratories, radiation therapy units and obstetrics and pediatric units on both sides of the same street.
"This may be an opportunity to look at the scope of the project," said Mr. Dowling, who has been a critic of the project's size for many years. "I think there are several things that could be changed without adding another 10 years to planning it. And you don't want to walk away from the $119 million they've already spent."
Despite the concerns of some Brooklyn residents, Dr. Siegel said a replacement hospital for Kings County would definitely be built, and he predicted that the additional delays would be minor in comparison with the delays in the current project, which is about four years behind its original schedule.
Sidique A. Wai, president of the New York City Health Crisis Coalition, an umbrella organization of 15 community groups that has pressed for the new hospital, said he believed the neighborhood would not object to shifting the hospital's focus toward more primary care, but he insisted that the city provide a firm date when new construction would begin.
 
Councilman Objects
 Enoch Williams, a Brooklyn Councilman who is chairman of the Council's Health Committee, objected to the decision to reduce the hospital's size, saying residents of the area have the right to the same kind of full-service medical center that wealthier neighborhoods now enjoy.
"Those primary-care clinics are no panacea," said Mr. Williams. "We have a lot of health needs in central Brooklyn, and for them all of a sudden to turn everything around on this hospital just doesn't make sense. We can't stand any more stops on this."
Health and Hospitals officials say they have begun preliminary discussions with the state Dormitory Authority over whether that state agency might construct the new hospital and then turn it over to the city. Such a move, combined with the reduced scale of the hospital, could mean fewer construction jobs and fewer of the minority contractors that political leaders have requested, but Dr. Siegel said the agency's new highest priority was making the project manageable.
"I understand the symbolism of the project, and I understand the employment concerns," said Dr. Siegel. "But you have to remember that this is a health care project, and it should be designed to provide health care first and foremost."

HEADLINE: Russia's Sarajevo Gambit

 BODY:
Russia, after days of pouting over feeling shoved aside by NATO in Sarajevo, has now dramatically and unilaterally rewritten the script by cutting a deal with Bosnian Serbs and moving Russian troops into place around the besieged Bosnian capital.
Taken by surprise, Washington has little immediate choice but to accept Moscow's fait accompli. But it must not back off from its own principles and policies merely to let Boris Yeltsin please Russian nationalists who want to shift Moscow's policy in the Balkans toward a more partisan and confrontational path. 
 Acting independently of America and other Western powers, Moscow worked out its own arrangement Thursday with Bosnian Serb leaders. It provides for withdrawal of Serbian artillery from the Sarajevo area in exchange for the deployment of Russian troops there under a U.N. flag.
Russia's abrupt move could work out well for everyone if it simply represents a face-saving way for the Serbs to pull back their big guns. Besides saving Sarajevan lives, that would spare NATO from having to follow through on a risky bombing campaign, and would ease the growing pressure on Moscow from Russian nationalists.
But, unsettlingly, Russia now insists that its deal "negates" last week's NATO ultimatum, which threatened air strikes unless Serbian artillery surrounding Sarajevo was either pulled back or placed under U.N. control by tomorrow night. Moscow also wants Sarajevo placed under direct U.N. administration. But that would wrongly erode the authority of the Bosnian Government, effectively putting it out of business.
President Clinton and other NATO leaders must make three things clear at once: Any Russian troops deployed around Sarajevo should be under unambiguous United Nations command. The 10-day deadline on withdrawing or surrendering control over Serbian artillery still stands. And the West will not coerce the Bosnian Government into peace arrangements it reasonably resists.
Still unknown is where Mr. Yeltsin has struck the balance between trying to head off Russian nationalists and actually accommodating their demands. In the eyes of the nationalists, and probably of most Russians, the Bosnian Serbs are ethnic and religious brethren. Yet the Bosnian Serbs' leaders and their patrons in Belgrade are the declared political enemies of Russian reform and reformers like Mr. Yeltsin.
Is Mr. Yeltsin's dramatic gesture meant to protect the brotherly Serbs in their continued war of aggression against Bosnia, or to maneuver them into accepting a face-saving way out? The answer will only be known as events play out on the ground over the next few days.
In the best case, a concerted push by the U.S., Europe and Russia could help achieve a fair peace, which cannot be confined to Sarajevo but must encompass all of Bosnia. Such a peace would bring an end to attacks on civilians. It would leave the Government side with a workable economic base and maritime access to the outside world. And it would provide territorial arrangements allowing the secure passage of people and goods between all Government-controlled cities.
Saving Bosnia requires more than surrounding an isolated Sarajevo with Russian soldiers whose impartiality cannot be taken for granted -- unless they are under direct U.N. command.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
SEGA ENTERPRISES FORECASTS DROP IN PROFITS

BYLINE: Reuters 

 BODY:
Sega Enterprises Ltd., the Japanese video game maker that eclipsed its archrival, the Nintendo Company, in the United States market last year, yesterday forecast its first drop in profits in 12 years. It cited the soaring yen and the recession in Europe, as well as intensified competition. The company has been spending heavily to develop theme parks, advanced computer game machines and electronic toys. Such investments come with a cost, however, and Sega said its profits were likely to fall to 42.5 billion yen, or $408 million, in the year ending March 31, down nearly 23 percent from 55 billion yen, or $529 million, the previous year. It had previously forecast profits of 57.5 billion yen, or $552 million.

HEADLINE: Landfill Methane Doesn't Always Make Money

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "How Cities Make Money" (Op-Ed, Feb. 10) Gar Alperovitz, president of the National Center for Economic Alternatives, suggests that a methane recovery system at a landfill may be a "moneymaking venture" for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York City to undertake. 
 Such a system has been in place at the Fresh Kills Landfill in Staten Island since 1982, where it has produced gas high in British Thermal Units, which is sold to Brooklyn Union Gas. New York City is issuing a request to develop additional sections of the landfill for methane gas recovery and processing.
Landfill gas recovery with energy processing can be a very successful undertaking for local governments that own the landfills and companies that own power production and gas collection facilities.
The Methane Recovery From Landfill Yearbook, my organization's soon-to-be released biennial study, documents that about 225 landfills throughout the country are either operating or developing methane recovery and processing facilities.
However, this moneymaking idea is not as simple as merely putting it on a list would suggest. The profits from processing landfill gas derive, in part, from a favorable regulatory environment, which insures that the energy produced can be sold at a high enough rate to recover investment costs. With many utilities now buying electricity at low rates, landfill gas-to-energy may not necessarily be a "moneymaking venture."
Nevertheless, if the economic conditions are favorable, then the installation of a landfill gas recovery and processing plant will become a revenue producer for the landfill's owner.
 
EILEEN BRETTLER BERENYI
New York, Feb. 10, 1994
 
The writer is president of Governmental Advisory Associates Inc., solid waste management consultants.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

SECTION: Section 1; Page 18; Column 5; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Equivalency Test Offers a Second Chance

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I read with great interest "High School Equivalency Guarantees Second-Class Status" (letter, Jan. 31) by Steven Cameron and James Heckman, who are with the University of Chicago's Harris School of Public Policy. They were responding to "High School Equivalency Test Poses a New Question: Will Taking It Matter?" (Education page, Jan. 5), which debated the value of the General Education Development test, a test used by the 50 states as a way for dropouts to earn a high school diploma. 
 My concern is that Mr. Cameron and Mr. Heckman have presented a distorted view of what G.E.D. tests can and cannot do, and that their research will inevitably be used to reduce or eliminate the funds for many programs.
The G.E.D. tests are tools for measuring what a graduating high school senior is supposed to know about mathematics, science, social studies, writing, literature and the arts. The tests are not supposed to guarantee economic or professional success.
No credential, no matter how prestigious, can do that, not even a college degree. The G.E.D. merely gives high school dropouts, regardless of race and class, a second chance to document what they have learned from school and from life.
Afterward, it is up to the individuals to decide which goals they should realistically pursue, given their own intellectual abilities and interests.
Mr. Cameron and Mr. Heckman suggest that earning a G.E.D. guarantees a person second-class status. To the contrary, the high-school equivalency certificate gives many Americans a second chance at gaining the skills that will put them on the path toward a more satisfying life. Why risk taking that away?
I speak as a G.E.D. graduate myself who happens to be a tenured member of the faculty at Princeton University. I do not consider myself, or the nearly half-million other Americans who earn their high school equivalency each year by passing the G.E.D. tests as second-class citizens.
For purely economic reasons, I left school after completing the eighth grade. My G.E.D. helped prepare me for the junior college where I earned a business degree, and later for the private four-year college where I was graduated magna cum laude.
Each year, approximately 25 percent of high school students leave school before graduating. Now that the Clinton Administration is proposing more than $600 million in budget cuts to Federal education programs, including $37.7 million used to pay for drop-out prevention programs, the G.E.D. alternative will undoubtedly become more important than ever.
Until someone can propose some real alternatives, why should we waste human capital by not providing second chances to this segment of our population?
 
CAROL M. SWAIN
Assoc. Prof., Politics & Public Affairs
Woodrow Wilson School, Princeton U.
New York, Feb. 9, 1994

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: North Korea's Master Hand

BYLINE: By Michael Shapiro; Michael Shapiro, assistant professor of journalism at Columbia, is author of "The Shadow in the Sun: A Korean Year of Love and Sorrow."

 BODY:
In the end, North Korea did not blink. Despite reports this week of its capitulation in the face of economic sanctions, Pyongyang has emerged the victor in its confrontation with the United States over inspections of seven sites where it may or may not be producing nuclear weapons.
The crisis on the Korean peninsula has been defused, but only temporarily. North Korea has agreed to comply with terms to which, in fact, it had already agreed in 1985. Meanwhile, there is the strong suspicion that the evidence of weapons production can be found elsewhere, dumped in two nuclear waste sites the North Koreans insist remain off-limits, in the name of national sovereignty. And of course there is the legitimate fear that the inspections will come too late, that North Korea already has its bomb. 
 After months of negotiations, the West has succeeded only in buying time. And that is the truest measure of Pyongyang's victory. Because the agreement necessitates further talks, North Korea has insured that it will not be pushed off to the periphery of America's attention.
For the North Koreans, this crisis is not about war. It is about being treated as an equal by its most hated foe, the United States.
The moment the crisis ends, the moment Pyongyang assumes what in the West would be regarded as a reasonable position, is the moment North Korea recedes in significance and becomes just another small and impoverished country pleading with potential investors to visit.
Kim Il Sung, the dictator who has ruled North Korea for 48 years, has staked his claim to legitimacy on the idea that one day the world will finally come to its senses and recognize the long overlooked greatness of the Korean people. It is an appealing message to a people whose 5,000-year history is one of being marginalized by the powerful nations that surround it.
Mr. Kim also tells North Koreans that America lies in wait, ready to invade. So the country keeps its million-man army on alert. And it begins producing nuclear weapons -- or makes the world think it is producing nuclear weapons.
North Korea has committed savage terrorist acts like killing half the South Korean Cabinet in 1983 and blowing up a South Korean airliner in 1987, killing 115 people. But the world eventually turns away.
The threat of nuclear weapons, however, is another matter entirely. It is North Korea's most effective threat because it is sustainable.
All through the negotiations during the past year, through the apparent agreements and broken promises, there lingered the danger of what might be. And because Kim Il Sung has built up a reputation as a man crazy and determined enough to risk war, he cannot be taken lightly.
Pyongyang has made it clear that, in addition to seeing the end of the joint United States-South Korean "Team Spirit" war games, it wants to sit across the table from the Americans -- not in tandem with their despised brothers to the South and not with the United Nations. The North Koreans dream of joint ventures with American companies and of economic cooperation with our Government. One day the two countries might even talk of formalizing their relationship, of exchanging diplomats, just as equals do.
North Korea has the U.S. in a bind. If we call Kim Il Sung's bluff and heighten the pressure on Pyongyang, we risk the very real possibility of war on the Korean peninsula, where 35,000 American troops are stationed.
That path is unacceptable, which leaves us with no choice but to keep talking, giving North Korea the recognition it so badly wants. It is, to say the least, an unsatisfying resolution, as is always the case in bargaining with an enemy who has everything to gain and makes it clear that he believes he has nothing to lose.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Keynes Would Be Horrified

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The headline for Arthur Schlesinger Jr.'s review of the second volume of Robert Skidelsky's biography, "John Maynard Keynes" (Jan. 23), was "The Economist of the Century." A more appropriate title would have been "The Economist of the Depression." 
 In "The General Theory of Employment, Interest, and Money," Keynes gave a prescription for dealing with an economic depression like the one that afflicted the United States during the 1930's: under those conditions, the Government should stimulate the economy through deficit spending. However, he also stated that as soon as the economy recovered, the Government should generate surpluses to repay the debt. This caveat has been ignored by virtually all politicians and by many economists.
The United States Government has incurred deficits in 54 of the past 60 years. The Federal debt totals $4.5 trillion and is growing at the rate of about $1 billion a day. Keynes would be horrified at the irresponsible policies that have been rationalized on the basis of his theories for dealing with the Depression of the 30's. Under current circumstances, Keynes would undoubtedly give top priority to policies that would balance the budget and start repaying the Federal debt.
 
ERNEST J. OPPENHEIMER
New York

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter
