LENGTH: 3098 words

HEADLINE: Mark Plaatjes

BYLINE: By Jere Longman; Jere Longman is a sports reporter for The New York Times.

 BODY:
December in Johannesburg, a place that gives a whole new meaning to white Christmas. The Plaatjes family gathers in a wide circle around the dining-room table, three dozen relatives holding hands, as grace is said before the homecoming meal. Mark Plaatjes, the youngest of five sons, has returned to the home he reluctantly left six years ago to escape apartheid and gain the chance to compete against the world's best runners.
In recent months, he has become both an American citizen and the world champion marathon runner. But apartheid never lets its victims off easily, and Plaatjes is reminded again of how much he has given up to pursue his dreams. 
 A vast welcoming meal of braised meat, curried chicken and a bean casserole has been prepared, along with cakes and ice cream for dessert. In the middle of dinner, a family news conference breaks out as Mark is peppered with questions about his victory in August at the world track-and-field championships in Stuttgart, Germany. At 5 foot 8, 117 pounds, he is built with a marathoner's muscular economy. He wears a trim beard and cinches his belt around a narrow waist; even at 32, he seems like a boy not yet grown into his clothes. His is a body built for distance, but his eyes are urgent, sprinter's eyes.
In an excited voice, Mark relives, mile by mile, that humid race in Stuttgart. For 12 years, since he won his first marathon, he worked toward that day, uncertain whether he could build a first-class career given the second-class existence prescribed by apartheid. As a South African, Mark was banned by international sanctions from competing against athletes from other countries. Even after he gained political asylum in the United States, he did not receive citizenship in time for the 1992 summer Olympics. It wasn't until the 1993 world championships that he ran head to head against the finest international marathoners instead of names and faces in a running magazine.
After 17 miles of that 26.2-mile race, Mark found himself in sixth place. At 21 1/2 miles, he had taken a secure grip on second place, but he was still 90 seconds behind a Namibian runner named Lucketz Swartbooi. Realizing he would win a medal, Mark was content to hold his position. Then Swartbooi began to fade. A half-mile from the finish, Mark caught him. "He had lost his last four marathons this way -- in the last mile; I felt sorry for him," Mark says. "I hesitated, but I knew I had to do it. He is only 27. He has a lot of time ahead of him. I didn't even look at him when I passed by."
At the finish line, there was confusion about whether Mark had to run another lap. Photographs circulated around the world showed him with his arms outstretched, his weary face not exalting in victory but anguished as he asked race officials: "Where is the finish line? Where is the finish line?"
Finally, someone told him to stop running. He crossed the line in 2:13:57, a relatively slow time, but fast enough on this day to be world champion. He won a Mercedes-Benz, and at his next marathon, in Korea in March, he will be able to command a handsome appearance fee (typically more than $100,000).
"You want to do something at the finish line, but I didn't know where it was," Mark says. "Still, it was a feeling I can't describe. I felt like I had legitimized myself as a runner. Very few people in life get a shot at their dream. I got a shot. I did it."
IN AN ADJACENT ROOM, RALPH Plaatjes lies on a sofa, wearing a T-shirt and athletic shorts, wrapped in a blanket, listening to his younger brother describe the race. His own voice trails off into a phlegmy cough, and he laughs and says: "I've never had a problem with smoking. Only the doctors have had a problem with me smoking."
Cancer has left him bedridden again. The disease that began in his spine has now invaded his lungs and liver. In 1990, doctors gave him six weeks to live, but six weeks have become three years, and Ralph has not yet succumbed. He still works as a builder when he feels fit, and, at 52, even with his body depleted, he remains thick and stout.
Victory at the world championships was as much a dream for Ralph as for Mark. Ralph had been more like a father than a brother, rearing Mark, pushing him to succeed in school and in running, proud of his brother but hard on him too. When Mark began running, Ralph would follow behind on a bicycle or in a car, hold up a brick and say, "Run faster, you bastard, or I'll hit you with this." To build up Mark's legs, Ralph made him train in heavy boots, carrying a backpack half filled with sand. He and his wife, Johanna, spent their money to enter Mark in races, to buy him shoes that cost up to $150 for an adequate pair. They paid the air fare to his distant races and, habitually late, scrambled to get him to local competitions on time.
"I learned how to run fast because we were always five minutes late getting to a race," Mark would joke. "I had to be fast just to catch up to everybody else."
By now, Ralph's stucco home in the Yeozille section of Johannesburg has become a museum of Mark's accomplishments, one entire wall of the living room given over to a display of trophies, photographs and a bronzed running shoe. Mark's medals fill up a travel bag like a treasure of doubloons. Ralph has his good days and bad days, five bad ones to every two good ones, he says, and there was one rough stretch in November where he didn't know if he would make it until the homecoming.
Earlier in the evening, tears welled in his eyes when Mark walked into the bedroom after a 14-hour flight from New York, trailing his wife, Shirley, and their three daughters, Gene, 9, Luz, 5, and Camille, 15 months. Mark leaned over to hug his brother, and Ralph pulled him close and said: "I'm so glad to see you. I didn't know if I would be around much longer." But this was the only sentimental moment Ralph allowed himself. He is not a man who expresses affection easily. The talk turned to the world championships, and Ralph's words came like fingers stabbing into Mark's chest. "I told you so," he said to his younger brother. "I just don't know what took you so long."
"You know how it is," Ralph is saying now, struggling to a sitting position on the sofa. "I'm never satisfied. If he wins, I always find fault. I don't want him to know how pleased I am. But he knows."
At age 3, Mark left his parents' home in the Johannesburg township of Coronationville. Twelve people, sometimes as many as 16, were crowded into three bedrooms, the only heat coming from a coal stove. So Mark went to live with his brother, Ralph, and Ralph's wife, Johanna.
In a country where everyone was tagged with a racial fingerprint -- a label that once determined where you could live and work and attend school, whom you could marry, whether you could swim at the beach and walk on the sidewalk -- the Plaatjes family was classified as "colored," or mixed race. Mark's maternal grandfather was Portuguese. Under the grand, failed scheme of racial separation, coloreds had marginally more privileges than blacks but never the equality of whites. Ralph and Johanna refused to accept such limited aspirations for Mark. Instead of a carpenter or a welder or an upholsterer -- his appointed stations as a colored -- he would become a doctor.
"You are as good as anybody," Ralph and Johanna told him repeatedly.
Mark ran his first race as a senior in high school in 1978. A friend dared him to run the 3,000-meter event at a meet, and he did, circling the cinder track in a pair of Converse high-top basketball sneakers and winning. Three months later, he became the national colored high-school champion. Ralph pushed him toward longer distances in this marathon-crazed country.
At age 17, Mark ran his first long-distance race, a 31-mile trek between Johannesburg and Pretoria. Early in training for the race, Ralph took Mark 18 miles from home, stopped the car and said, "Get out and run back." Mark had never run more than three or four miles in one workout, but Ralph would hear none of his protestations, yelling out of the window, "Run faster, or I'll bump you." Mark made it home, but says, "I couldn't walk for two days." Eventually, he worked up to 26 or 27 miles in training. On marathon day, his toenails came off with his shoes at the finish line, and he was not allowed to use the toilet facilities because he was not white. Still, Mark won the junior division and organizers presented him with a medal, a warm-up suit and a new pair of waffle-soled Nike running shoes.
When Mark's high school didn't offer biology, chemistry and physics, Ralph and Johanna found one that did. When the university admissions quota for coloreds was filled, they drove to Pretoria, the capital, and cajoled an education minister into providing Mark with the more difficult whites-only exams, which he easily passed -- gaining a place in an "open" university, one that admits a limited number of nonwhite students. He would become the only 1 of 10 Plaatjes children to attend college. Eventually, he was admitted to medical school at the University of the Witswatersrand in Johannesburg.
"We forced our way," Johanna Plaatjes says. "We wanted to show we could do the same as whites. His life was not going to stagnate. He wasn't going to live in a shell. He's a bird. Let him fly."
But a South African athlete could not easily spread his wings. From 1964 until 1992, South Africa was barred from the Olympics as part of international sanctions. For the final 17 years of isolation, the country's athletic borders were sealed. No South African runners could run on the outside; no foreigners could run inside. There were rare exceptions. Zola Budd, for example, received hurried citizenship and ran for England at the 1984 Olympics, where she collided with the American, Mary Decker, in that infamous barefoot tangle.
Inside South Africa, runners faced a more complicated -- and far more threatening -- political tangle. Anti-apartheid groups like the South African Council on Sport and the South African Non-Racial Olympic Committee campaigned aggressively against "normal sport in an abnormal society." This meant asking athletes to boycott white-sanctioned events, including national championships, and to refuse to wear the green-and-gold colors of the national team. Mark could not abide by this. These groups were asking him to sacrifice his one great talent. A banned writer could smuggle his books to the outside. Nelson Mandela could spend 27 years in prison and, once released, still seek the presidency. But a runner's career ends once his legs are exhausted. So Plaatjes kept running, seeking to find liberation in his own personal achievement.
"What better way was there to show the authorities up, to show that you were just as good as anybody," Mark says. "That's all racism is, ignorance. If you show people what they don't know, they will change. I invited white people home, to show them that we slept in beds, not on rocks, that we ate the same food they did. You don't solve conflict by turning the other way. You look people in the face."
By 1987, Plaatjes had won two South African marthon championships and three national cross-country titles. He had run 2:08:58 -- then the 16th fastest marathon time in history. Of course, his every achievement was a shining light refracted through the prism of apartheid.
To many whites, Plaatjes was proof that apartheid was not so restrictive. To many nonwhites, he was a traitor. "Directly or indirectly, knowingly or unknowingly, consciously or unconsciously, he was an agent of apartheid," says Sam Ramsay, president of the South African Olympic Committee. "The message he sent was that he was an Uncle Tom."
Strangers approached Plaatjes in grocery stores or drove past and called him "a sellout," because he competed with whites. His mother, Louise, and his wife, Shirley, received anonymous phone calls at home and at work: "You'll find him dead on the doorstep." And: "You'll get another call to tell you where to pick up the body." Two of his friends died mysteriously while running. Mark himself was pushed out of the way of a swerving car while jogging with another marathoner. He was threatened with "necklacing," the grisly ritual during which a gasoline-soaked tire is placed on a victim's shoulders and set afire.
On the surface, Mark had a comfortable life. He was a medical-school student and an accomplished runner with an endorsement contract from a shoe company that provided him with free use of a car and a monthly stipend. He wrote a weekly newspaper column, made guest television appearances and built, along with Ralph, a house with a pool. But apartheid made him an incomplete citizen, left him a pariah in his own country.
Plaatjes also soured on medical school, leaving after three years to study physical therapy. "I didn't like the teaching methods," he says. "They prescribed drugs based on which companies put money into the program."
WHAT FINALLY DROVE him to leave South Africa was his daughter Gene. She was 3 and had begun to ask questions for which he had no comfortable answers. "How do you explain to a 3-year-old that she can't go to an amusement park because of the color of her skin?" he says. "Young children are so innocent. Gene would go up to white children, and the parents would reprimand her for talking to them or touching them. I didn't want her to grow up feeling inferior."
In January 1988, Mark, Shirley and Gene flew to Chicago, carrying two suitcases on what was planned as a monthlong vacation. They had no winter clothes and no idea that they wouldn't be returning home. Through a South African connection, the Plaatjes had come to visit Glenn Latimer, who runs a school for the disabled in suburban Chicago. Latimer needed a physical therapist. After much wrenching discussion, the Plaatjes decided he would take the job and apply for political asylum (which was quickly granted). Back in South Africa, his family was shocked.
"I was so close to the boy, it was like losing your right arm," Ralph says. "I was disappointed that he didn't inform me before he made up his mind. But I know now it was the right decision. He wouldn't be what he is if he stayed here."
Mark was an ocean away now, eventually setting up a physical therapy practice in Boulder, Colo., but Ralph continued to push him relentlessly. As a reminder of the old days, Ralph mailed a brick to Mark with this admonishment: "Run faster, or I'm coming."
"Ralph was the guy that always drove me, told me I could be the best in the world," Mark says. "If I finished second in a race, he said I should have finished first. If I won, he said I should have run faster. Even in school, he pushed and pushed. It wasn't an option; I was going to college. He made me do everything well. There was no excuse not to."
A different person -- perhaps most people -- would resent Ralph's relentless pressure. But Mark never did. "It was a natural acceptance that he knew what was right for me. I had to do it.
"I can see now there were some negatives. I wouldn't do it that way if my son were running. I would give a little more positive feedback. But his methods worked with me. You couldn't ask for a better motivator than him."
Still, it was three years before Mark won his first important marathon in the United States. The most discouraging time was the summer of 1992. South Africa was allowed back in the Olympics after an absence of three decades, but Mark was stateless, not having yet received his American citizenship. He watched on television. The South Africans had invited him to compete at their Olympic trials, but he declined. "I couldn't do it," Mark says. "We had made a commitment to the United States."
His citizenship finally came on July 24, 1993. Three weeks later, he ran in the world championships in Stuttgart. The marathon was not carried live on television in South Africa, so Ralph went to sleep on Aug. 14 not knowing the results. He awakened before dawn, switched on his radio and began channel-surfing. For two hours, he heard nothing about the order of finish. Finally, at 6 in the morning, word came from the BBC. Mark had won. A stream of congratulatory calls came, and Ralph feigned ignorance with each caller. Tell me again, he would say. Mark won? Where? You don't mean it. And he savored each retelling as if he were hearing the news for the first time.
"This was one of my dreams, that he would be the tops," Ralph says. "He had potential, so I was hard on him. I wouldn't take second best. When he won, I gave myself a hug."
A WEEK INTO MARK'S homecoming visit, Ralph suffers a setback, and Mark takes him for chemotherapy. "I feel so helpless," Ralph's wife, Johanna, says. After dinner, Mark sits at the dining-room table, head down, rubbing his eyes. The doctors have said there is nothing more that science can do. Mark is further distressed that two of his other brothers are drinking again, risking the loss of their jobs and families. That is one reason he left, he says, to get away from a country that tells black men they are less than zero and sends them to find their worth in a bottle. Mark is hearing whispers, too, about how he lives in splendor in the United States while his brothers live here in squalor. "If they only knew that I spend half my money on all my family," he says.
Could he ever move back, now that apartheid is imploding and elections are coming in April? Probably not, he says. He wants to re-enter medical school in Boulder, and he wants to win the 1996 Olympic marathon in Atlanta, an American finishing in a stadium full of Americans. "I feel a little guilty that I wasn't here for the changes," Mark says. "I really miss my friends and family. But the quality of life in America is so much better. The freedoms that Americans take for granted are the freedoms that people in other countries die for."
A few days later, Ralph begins coughing up blood. He misses a wedding for one of his nieces, and he spends Christmas in the hospital. By the middle of January, though, he is home and feeling fit enough to complete an addition to his house. Mark is leaving soon, returning to his physical-therapy practice. He is thinking about taking Ralph with him. Just in case something can be done.
"I may go," Ralph says, his voice strong over the phone. "My determination to make Mark a champion, that's the same determination I've got to overcome this. I'll fight it to the last. Maybe I need Mark standing there with that brick, telling me I must get fitter."

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL VIEW;
A Blunder, A Backlash, Now What?

BYLINE: By Edward Rothstein 

 BODY:
THE AMERICAN SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA League probably did not expect the outrage that greeted its report "Americanizing the American Orchestra" last summer. After all, the call for multicultural programming, including jazz and music from other cultures, is now commonplace in the visual arts and in educational curricula. The recommendations that orchestras reach out for new audiences by programming pop, using video and hiring interior decorators are no different from what has already been done in the entertainment business. Even the call for orchestras to hire consultants to begin "diversity sensitivity training" is just an attempt to catch up to other institutions. But the outrage was significant. And the league, shaken by widespread objections, is trying to figure out where it went wrong.
Recently some of the league's most important members have been registering their objections as well. Their resolution criticizing the report was presented to the league and obtained by the New York Times. These managers of some of the largest American orchestras objected to the way the report was prepared and released, and they argued that some of its conclusions were "seriously flawed." 
 The problem, they felt, was that the report did not recognize that orchestras have a very specialized function: to perform a particular repertory from a specific tradition. Instead of focusing on ways to educate a wider spectrum of listeners about that repertory, the report often seemed to be throwing in the towel. The league's report did not serve its constituents -- the orchestras, the audiences and musicians -- but a group of administrators and observers with a different agenda. The bigger challenge is that that agenda still carries great weight in a changing cultural and political climate.
This was apparent during a recent conversation in Los Angeles with Shelton Stanfill, who was named president of the Los Angeles Music Center last month. The music center is the West Coast counterpart of Lincoln Center. It has four resident companies: the Los Angeles Philharmonic, the Center Theater Group, the Los Angeles Music Center Opera and the Los Angeles Master Chorale. Its education division, one of the largest in the country, presents more than 12,000 in-school workshops and performances.
Like Lincoln Center, the music center will have a hand in programming, particularly when the Philharmonic moves to the new Walt Disney Concert Hall in the fall of 1997. Mr. Stanfill, formerly president of the Wolf Trap Foundation in Virginia, does not minimize the center's problems. The economy of southern California, he said, is being "restructured" (with hard times coming for the arts), and the demographics have changed; artworks of the Western tradition are being challenged by those of other communities.
In fact, Los Angeles, with its large Hispanic, black and Asian-American populations, provides a new version of the American melting pot in which whites will be an ethnic minority by the end of the century. The music center already has an "advancement committee" made up of about 30 representatives of the city's cultural and ethnic communities to guide outreach programs and provide what Mr. Stanfill calls a touchstone on "where we are, where we are going."
Last month, the opera company presented the first American performance of Manuel Penella's 1916 zarzuela, "El Gato Montes," in Spanish. The production was supported by a three-year grant from AT&T to help bring Hispanic audiences into the opera house. An irony of such an outreach project is that this zarzuela, with its verismo style, is nearly as alien to Mexican communities in Los Angeles as is an Italian view of bohemians on Paris's left bank. The 1990 Los Angeles Festival, directed by Peter Sellars, took a more radical approach to multicultural programming, presenting music, dance and drama from cultures on the Pacific Rim rather than centering on the European tradition.
Political shifts in the status of traditional arts institutions have been more evident in other cities. St. Louis gave financing priority to its zoo over its orchestra. In Houston, a coalition of ethnic arts leaders persuaded the arts council to decrease the money allotted to organizations like the Houston Grand Opera. Can Los Angeles be far behind?
"I don't have a sense of where this place will be 10 years from now," Mr. Stanfill said of the music center. "The changes are so dramatic in demographics and economics."
The changes, of course, can lead to such welcome discoveries as the Penella work and to expanded knowledge about the remarkable musical traditions of the world. Certainly, too, the confluence of cultures has been a distinguishing characteristic of the Western artistic tradition, which has also, in turn, found devoted audiences in other cultures.
But crudely applied pressures can lead to such meretricious pandering as the opera "Frida," which attracted so much self-congratulatory attention in Houston. They can lead to policies allocating concert pieces and orchestra chairs according to some artificially imposed demographic hierarchy. They can lead to arguments that esthetic distinctions are meaningless. They can also lead to the misguided recommendations of the league report.
There is a large audience that will object to such policies, as the league learned. Meanwhile, the issues behind the report -- issues now being raised in arts centers around the country -- have yet to be seriously addressed.

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Is It Time To Buy A Co-op?

SERIES: The first of two articles.

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS 

 BODY:
AFTER suffering nearly four years of widespread financial instability, a credit famine and tumbling values, the co-op apartment market in New York City may now offer some of the most affordable housing in the entire metropolitan region.
Though not all buildings were affected, co-ops in general became difficult to sell in recent years. Studio and one-bedroom apartments, especially those with shaky financial underpinnings, were particularly hard-hit. In the last year, median prices for all co-ops in Manhattan fell by 9.8 percent, according to the Real Estate Board of New York, with the prices of units of one bedroom or less falling by 12.1 percent. 
 As a result co-ops may now offer unusual opportunities, and they are often in prime locations -- an outcome of the avalanche of conversions in the 80's that produced many more co-ops than condominiums.
Folded into this reversal of fortune is a window of opportunity for anyone with limited means who is new to the co-op market. Exceptional chances also exist for tenants already in these buildings who may have declined earlier chances to purchase their apartments, but now find their homes being offered to them at significantly lower prices.
"There are some incredible deals out there," said Diane Papsidero, a loan officer with Washington Mortgage Financing Group of Jersey City, mortgage bankers that specialize in financing underlying mortgages in co-op buildings.
"It really is a good time to buy because the situation is certainly not going to get any worse and it's already getting better," said Stuart Saft, a partner with Wolf, Haldenstein Adler Freeman & Herz, who is chairman of the Council of New York Cooperatives.
The fear that the co-op itself might slide into bankruptcy, wiping out the buyer's equity, afflicted hundreds of prospective buyers and owners from 1989 through 1992. Many financially strapped sponsors stopped paying their share of a building's maintenance costs, causing a financial crisis during which some bills could not be met.
Brokers and others in the real estate industry around the city suggest that this has now ended.
"You're hard-pressed to find a building that's not worked out its problems with the sponsor," said James Goldstick, sales manager at Mark Greenberg Real Estate of Manhattan, a company that manages and markets some 60 co-op buildings throughout the city.
A result, he says, is that income from maintenance fees is more likely to be covering expenses. There is less danger of having to pay supplementary maintenance charges or special assessments to cover shortfalls.
The problem of getting financing, either to buy or sell a unit, is also receding as banks return to co-op lending. A key element in the banks' return was the announcement several months ago by the Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae), which buys residential mortgages and tends to set policy for the industry, of liberalized guidelines for co-op lending in New York City. Though this new program was slow to get off the ground it is now starting to make hundreds of buildings previously deemed unfit for financing eligible for loans.
The more liberal rules have also encouraged new lenders to come aboard, such as the National Co-op Bank, which started making co-op share loans in New York for the first time only in January.
The National Co-op Bank will now finance buyers in buildings where only 51 percent of the units have been sold, compared with the former industry minimum of around 70 percent.
"It's going be much easier to buy and sell in the future," said Dorothy Babson, National Co-op's manager for share loans.
The upshot is that dozens of unsold or occupied units that were frozen for years in legal limbo while their status was being clarified are increasingly being acquired by owner-occupiers, allowing even the worst of the buildings to reclaim financial respectability.
In December, for instance, Mark Zborovsky, president of Mark Zborovsky & Company, a real estate brokerage dealing mainly with investors, arranged for the sale of 476 of these "frozen" units in 14 buildings in four of the five boroughs. They had been repossessed by a banking institution following sponsor defaults. He sold them as a package to an investor who is now offering them individually to the general public -- to outsiders if the unit is vacant or to the tenant in possession if the unit is already occupied.
An improved proportion of owner-occupied units has also enabled more of the troubled buildings to refinance their underlying mortgages, noted Ms. Papsidero, the mortgage banker. At today's low rates, this should also control maintenance costs -- another concern keeping buyers away.
The icing on the cake is the fire-sale prices. According to Barbara Corcoran, president of the Corcoran Group, a real estate concern that regularly charts values, a one-bedroom co-op apartment in a postwar building on the Upper East Side or West Side of Manhattan that might have cost $275,000 in 1988 now sells for around $160,000. And there are more than 2,000 such units to choose from, she said.
BY contrast, a condominium of equal size and amenities that would have sold for $375,000 in 1988 has dropped only to $275,000. Moreover, only around 600 are on the market. And there's not even that much difference in carrying costs -- around $750 a month for the co-op compared with $570 for the condominium.
Prices are even cheaper in co-op buildings that suffered serious financial distress because of a defaulting sponsor or a preponderance of unsold units.
In boroughs outside Manhattan, studios and one-bedroom units in such buildings still fetch only around $30,000, says James Samson, a partner with Bangser Klein Rocca & Blum, a Manhattan law firm that represents some 80 co-op boards. And that can make them cheaper than rentals.
Insiders -- nonpurchasing tenants already in possession -- can grab an even sweeter deal. At a 40-unit co-op on West 111th Street in Morningside Heights, one tenant, who declined to allow his name to be published, just bought his one-bedroom apartment for $14,552. In 1984, when the building was first converted to a co-op, he was offered the same unit for $96,300.
One reason for these exceptional insider prices, say lawyers, is the desire by a growing number of defaulting sponsors, as well as the lenders and co-op boards that have repossessed the units, to let some occupied units be acquired by insiders at nominal cost. This way, the percentage of owner-occupied apartments required by lenders before financing for all the others is permitted can be reached more rapidly, making the remaining units more marketable and thus more valuable.
Yet a further plus is a new move by the New York State Insurance Department to make title insurance available to the co-op buyer, much as it has always been for buyers of condominiums and detached houses.
"It makes you feel that much safer," said Mindy H. Stern, a lawyer with Shoeman, Marsh & Updike of Manhattan, who is involved in explaining the new insurance program to other co-op lawyers.
But issues in the transformation still require buyers -- whether they are insiders or outsiders -- to proceed with caution.
Next week: Questions that should be raised before buying, and the remaining drawbacks and pitfalls.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 5; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Briarcliff Manor;
Sweeping Vistas and Subdivided Estates

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN 

 BODY:
FROM the top of Scarborough Ridge, sweeping views of the Hudson River take in the broad expanse of Haverstraw Bay to the north and the skyscrapers of Manhattan 23 miles to the south.
That vista -- without the skyscrapers -- attracted Sint Sinck Indians, Dutch and English farmers and 19th-century estate owners with names like Vanderbilt and Webb. Modern-day landowners have included Brooke Astor and, until about 10 years ago, Queen Elizabeth of England. 
 Today, most of Briarcliff Manor's large properties have been converted into smaller lots in a village that won a county planning award in 1985 for its adaptive reuse of estates. Beechwood, the former riverfront estate of Frank A. Vanderlip, a banking executive, is now a homeowners' association whose members read in the mansion's library, swim in its pool and stroll beneath its copper beech trees.
Up on the ridge, the Renaissance Revival mansion designed by Stanford White for Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt's granddaughter Margaret and her husband, Elliott Shepard, is now the clubhouse for the Sleepy Hollow Country Club. The Ridgecrest section, bordering the club, is one of the most sought-after sections of the village.
"The view of the Hudson is drop-dead," said Elizabeth M. Biggar, manager of the Prudential-Carolyn A. Dwyer agency in Briarcliff Manor. Ridge lots are half an acre to an acre, but homes with good views sell for around $1 million, she said.
The ridge divides Briarcliff Manor from Scarborough, a hamlet with its own post office, railroad station and identity. When railroad officials tried to hang a sign reading "Briarcliff West" in the Scarborough station early in the century, it was promptly thrown in the river by the residents.
East of the ridge, Briarcliff Manor owes its special identity to its founder, Walter Law, a carpet manufacturer whose influence over the village proved so great that in an article in 1902, The New York Times called him "one of the few American millionaires to own villages of their own."
Arriving in 1890, Law bought up most of the small farms dotting the area. By 1900, his Briarcliff Farms employed virtually everyone in the area and supplied much of the metropolitan area with high-quality milk, American Beauty roses and bottled water. His employee population made the area eligible to become a village and in 1902 Law applied to the state for and got a village charter for Briarcliff Manor. He became one of the new village's first trustees; his son, Henry, was Mayor from 1918 to 1936.
One business venture made Briarcliff Manor internationally famous. Through the first third of the century, the Briarcliff Lodge, Law's resort hotel, which had 150 rooms when it opened in 1902, played host to a glittering clientele and served as a country getaway for such prominent New Yorkers as J. Pierpont Morgan, F. W. Woolworth and Jimmy Walker and the actresses Mary Pickford and Tallulah Bankhead. When it closed in 1936 it had about 200 rooms.
Guests took golf lessons from Gene Sarazen and tennis lessons from Bill Tilden and swam in a pool that Johnny Weismuller and Gertrude Ederle used for their olympic trials in 1924. Two years later, the Winter Olympic trials were held at the lodge using snow brought in by train from Canada.
Today, plans for the lodge, which became the main administrative building of King's College, have divided the village. An organization seeking to buy the lodge and the surrounding 52-acre campus in the center of the village to build an Irish-American cultural and sports center, Tara Circle, has generated intense opposition among residents concerned about environmental impacts. Should the plan be turned down, the property could revert to residential sites.
IN the village as a whole, approved plans for 299 attached one-family homes and 136 free-standing one-family homes have been gathering dust during the sluggish economy, but village officials say there is increased interest in development. "The phones are starting to ring," said Anthony Turiano, the assessor.
Residents worry about a sudden development boom, but Lynn M. McCrum, village manager for 22 years, said the village had established careful land-use policies.
"Briarcliff has changed very little since I arrived," Mr. McCrum said. "I take that as a compliment."
While the total of town, village, county and school taxes is relatively high, Mr. McCrum said, so is home-buyer interest in Briarcliff Manor. "We are just in such a good location," he said. Briarcliff Manor is 15 minutes northeast of White Plains, served by two railroad stations and intersected by the Taconic Parkway and Routes 9 and 9A. It lies in two towns, Ossining and Mount Pleasant.
Because land is expensive, with lots ranging from $250,000 to $350,000 an acre, there is little moderately priced housing, Mr. McCrum said. Voters have approved a bond issue to pay for a $2.67 million water filtration system and later this year a referendum will be held on building a new library.
Among the housing plans that have been approved are those for Briar Vista, which is to have 14 custom-built one-family homes on one-acre sites, and for the Unicorn at Sleepy Hollow, which is to have 30 homes in the same general area. All are expected to sell for about $600,000. Active work on infrastructure improvements, including the extension of existing streets, began in the fall.
The site is next to the Estates at Rosecliff, a nine-year-old planned community where 84 of what eventually will be 116 three- and four-bedroom one-family homes have been built on a 152-acre wooded estate once owned by Edward Walker Harden, who went from financial editor of The Chicago Tribune to a millionaire investment banker. With homeownership -- prices range from $449,000 for a three-bedroom house to $570,000 for a four-bedroom -- comes the use of Harden's Italianate mansion, pool and gardens.
MOST homes in Briarcliff Manor are one-family although three mostly two-bedroom condominium complexes have been built in the last decade. There is one three-story rental apartment complex, Briar House, with 66 two- and three-bedroom units, including some duplexes.
Agents say finding a home in Briarcliff Manor is extremely difficult. Inventories are at their lowest level in recent memory, said Eileen O'C. Weber, an agent with Houlihan Lawrence and the unofficial village historian.
"Clients are waiting in line for people to move," Mrs. Weber said. "There's such a demand to move to Briarcliff, but the houses people want we don't have."
Two- and three-bedroom starter homes in the Old Village and Crossroads area near the elementary school sell for $200,000 to $300,000 but are rarely available, say Mrs. Weber and Mrs. Biggar.
More expensive homes are found on Linden Circle overlooking the Hudson River in Scarborough, on plots laid out by the firm of Frederick Law Olmsted. At Chilmark, the 250-acre former estate of V. Everit Macy, a Standard Oil heir, the Macy family planned the estate's transition to one-family homes whose owners, as an association, jointly own a swimming pool and tennis courts.
About a third of the village's children, including most Scarborough residents and all those in Chilmark, attend Ossining public schools. Real estate agents say the two systems are equal, but buyer preferences for the Briarcliff Manor schools have inflated prices for homes in the district, they say.
The Ossining School District is comparatively large, with 3,383 students in its three elementary schools and its middle and high school. Ossining High School, selected as one of the state's 10 best in 1985, sends 80 percent of its graduates to college. The high school, which graduated 211 students last year, has a fully licensed student-operated radio station and offers college-level courses sponsored by Syracuse University.
The Ann M. Dorner Middle School, named a Federal Blue Ribbon School of Excellence in 1989, has special honors programs in mathematics and science starting in Grade 6 and foreign language study in Grade 7.
AN unusual feature of Ossining's educational program is the Ossining Plan, which lets students progress through the grades as a cohesive group. Developed in response to the district's large multicultural population and with the community's endorsement, the plan keeps all students in a particular grade at the same school, encouraging a wide ethnic and racial mix.
The Briarcliff School district has 1,000 students in the k-6 Todd Elementary School and the combined Briarcliff Middle and High School.
The 88 members of Briarcliff High's Class of '93 had the highest SAT scores in 20 years and produced two National Merit finalists. Ninety percent went on to higher education. There are four National Merit finalists among this year's high school seniors. Briarcliff High School was the first in Westchester County to require and seniors to contribute 120 hours of community service before graduation.
Briarcliff Manor residents have a wealth of recreational opportunities in the village, including 167 acres of parkland plus biking and hiking on Old Croton Aqueduct Trail and the County Bike Trail. Two stables provide horses to ride on the grounds of the nearby 801-acre Rockefeller State Preserve.
The village's five parks have 10 tennis courts and three paddleball courts. The village pool at Law Memorial Park is open to all residents. Last year the fees were $200 for residents and $400 for school district residents who do not live in Briarcliff Manor.
Three small retail areas provide a typical assortment of laundries, grocery, hardware and liquor stores and pharmacies. On North State Road, Giardino's restaurant offers Italian specialities and fresh fish dishes.

 MAD MOTORING: In 1905, village fathers, distressed by automobiles careening through their community, posted an 8-mile-an-hour speed limit, along with a warning to"speed demons who might have longing for higher and terrific risks." Three years later, the village sponsored the Briarcliff Automobile International Road Race. Twenty-two drivers -- watched by a crowd 300,000, many of whom had come by train -- rattled over 33 miles of dirt road competing for the Briarcliff Trophy and $10,000 donated by Walter W. Law. Louis Strang, in an Isotta-Fraschini, won, covering 256 miles in 5 hours 15 minutes.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Brokers Swing Onto Information Superhighways

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
WITHIN the last six months Connecticut's residential real estate industry has developed five information superhighways capable of carrying highly detailed multiple listings throughout several counties and past state lines at the touch of a computer keyboard.
Computerized multiple listings have existed for a decade, and are available at most real estate offices by town. But they are relatively primitive compared to the new regional systems, which offer minutely detailed information and color pictures of homes in dozens of communities. 
 Originating in Norwalk, Hartford and New London, some of the new systems are fully operative and others soon will be.
In spite of the expensive equipment required and the cost of membership in two, three or more services, an increasing number of agencies and real estate boards around the state are buying into the regional services. Otherwise, they fear they will find themselves "on the exit ramp," as Lisa Governale, spokeswoman for the Connecticut Board of Realtors, put it.
But a pattern of geographical overlap and duplication of information is growing, along with problems arising from incompatibility among existing software and hardware leased over long terms.
And the proliferation of regional listing services is heading toward an informational traffic jam that the Connecticut Association of Realtors hopes to clear by 1996 with "a statewide system that provides our 13,000 members with greater access to listings and customers," said Gerald Kunde, the association's executive vice president. "And it could negotiate better terms with technology vendors on a volume basis."
Following a review of a study due in March, the association's board will vote in April on whether to create such a system.
Last November, in a move toward a nationwide multiple listing service, the National Association of Realtors in Chicago created a Federation of Real Estate Markets. Earlier this month, it allocated $1.9 million to incorporate it, hire personnel and buy equipment.
"Through the Federation," said Almon R. Smith, executive vice president of the board, "regional multiple-listing services will be able to interconnect with other regions next door or across the country."
This, he said, will "level the playing field for small and large realtors by negotiating for technology on a nationwide basis."
What is also occurring is the merging and downscaling of traditional real estate offices, just as other businesses have done in the recession. A laptop computer accompanying a broker from home to car to client is widely seen as the future, and it's here.
"There are areas of the country where realtors are using CD-Rom with portable hand-held equipment that can download all the information in a computer through any telephone connection," said Mr. Smith.
FAIRFIELD 1, a nonprofit corporation established with $500,000 from its four founder agencies -- William Pitt, William Raveis, Prudential Connecticut, and Coldwell Banker Schlott real estate companies -- is the first of Connecticut's regional multiple-listing services to offer such extensive information and training.
Its headquarters in Merritt 7, a Norwalk business park, opened last month, with a membership of 122 realty offices and 1,800 agents in Fairfield and Litchfield Counties.
Annual operating expenses, covered by membership fees, are estimated at around $1.3 million a year. Excess revenues would be distributed back to the members.
Its computer system, operating 24 hours a day, seven days a week, was supplied by PRC of McLean, Va., a division of Black & Decker. PRC also keeps a troubleshooter on site, ready to assist any office or agent with computer problems, and it provides instructors to train Fairfield members.
Nearly 4,000 properties can be called up on the screen in color, singly or up to 16 houses at once, interiors and exteriors, anywhere in the region. Textual information includes minutely detailed descriptions of rooms, basements, attics, landscaping, appliances, storage, roof, siding, utilities, taxes, estimated mortgage payments, fuel and air-conditioning.
Data on schools, demographics, architects, plumbers, mortgage lenders, contractors and town services will be added soon. Color printouts are immediately available to the customer and for advertising purposes.
"People trying to find a house sometimes worked with five or six agents in different towns over days or weeks," said Bett McCarthy, chief operating officer of Fairfield 1. "Now they can do it in an hour or two."
Competing with Fairfield 1 is the Realtors MLS of Greater Fairfield County, organized by 13 boards of realtors in Fairfield and Litchfield Counties and based at 116 East Avenue in Norwalk. "We have 600 offices and 4,850 agents" as members, said Donald Hull, the organization's chief executive, "but very few of the 16,000 listings are in the system as yet."
An effort to merge the two competitors, thus avoiding duplication, failed when it was discovered that Realtors MLS technology vendor, Moore Data Systems, provides a similar service but is not compatible with Fairfield 1's PRC system. "Nothing can happen until the contracts expire in five years," said Mr. Hull.
MEANWHILE, brokers such as Harriet Haffner, in business for 30 years in Norwalk and head of a firm bearing her name, joined both systems while retaining her membership in the multiple-listing service of the Norwalk Board of Realtors .
"I didn't feel that I could service my clients unless I had access to every piece of merchandise available," she said. "Listings are available to me in 23 towns, most of which I will never get to because I can't learn enough about 23 towns to avoid getting lost, nor can I speak intelligently about 23 school systems. Agents in other towns won't try to sell houses here for the same reason."
This, she said, "turned out to be a lot more expensive than I thought."
"My software was not applicable, so I had to buy software, and I had to update my computer equipment. My agents were distressed when they had to join both MLS's in order to stay competitive. It's been angst for everybody."
Regional multiple-listing service costs vary widely according to the level of service and numbers of subscribers. Charges for listings can range from $5 to $20, dues from $100 a year to $100 a quarter. Books showing all available listings are available at $50 a quarter, but "they are out of date by the time they are delivered twice a month," said Ms. McCarthy.
New London's Regional Multiple Listing Service uses Boris Systems of East Lansing, Mich., as its technology provider, while the United Regional Multiple Listing Service across the middle of the state, and the Hartford Regional Multiple Listing Service both use Realtron, of Pembroke, Mass. At least half a dozen other companies service individual boards and brokerages throughout Connecticut.
The Greenwich, Darien and New Milford Boards of Realtors have not joined any regional service although many real estate companies in those towns have.
"We think there will be a statewide realtors' MLS within two years, so we are going to wait," said Mary Beth Hackenberg, executive officer of the New Milford board.
David Ogilvie and Associates of Greenwich is another holdout, as is Susan Hughes, a broker with the firm and president of System One, a 600-member cooperative of smaller realtors in Connecticut and Westchester. "I see this really as a war among major computer companies trying to be the vendor for all of Connecticut," she said.

HEADLINE: Streetscapes/The American Radiator Building;
A 1924 Precursor of Art Deco

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
THE American Radiator Building, at 40 West 40th Street, is now just extra inventory in a recession-bloated sea of empty space. But it was once a dazzling new idea that promised to remake the city.
The owner of the striking black-and-gold, 23-story mid-block office tower, which has been vacant for four years, is getting restless and expects this spring either to convert the building to residential use or to sell it to a developer for the same purpose. 
 The man who designed the building, Raymond Hood, rocketed to prominence in 1922 when he won the international competition for The Chicago Tribune's new office tower. The young architect had been scraping by on small things, like radiator covers for the American Radiator Company, but after the competition he got many offers, including one from American Radiator for an office building facing Bryant Park on a block that until then was characterized by brownstones and turn-of-the-century clubs.
Hood embraced both the esthetic and business sides of architecture and was proud that the Radiator building steelwork was completed only seven months after the design. The building opened in 1924 and embodied several departures from existing practice.
In basic form it is a free-standing tower, a type diametrically opposed to the notion that buildings should have some shoulder-to-shoulder harmony.
Although free-standing towers have restricted floor areas because they are not built to the lot line, they can be treated architecturally all the way around and provide good natural light.
Hood also disliked the typical office building facade, where the regular dark glass reflections of the windows contrasted with the light masonry skin, making most buildings look like a "waffle stood on end," as he put it.
So he called for the American Radiator Building to be built of black brick (a product that proved very difficult to obtain) and topped it with gold-colored masonry units, which supposedly recalled the black iron and glowing embers of furnaces of the day.
The basic feeling of the tower is neo-Gothic and the exquisite bronze and marble entry is explicitly so. But the general ornament is abstract and clearly moving toward Art Deco, which would become important a year or two later.
Special floodlighting made the building "one of the sights of the city" at night, said the magazine American Architect, adding that "it has attracted and held the attention of thousands who ordinarily give little heed to street architecture."
In the basement, with its crypt-like low arched ceilings, were boiler and furnace showrooms. Upstairs were offices, including one for Hood, who went on to design the Daily News, McGraw-Hill and Rockefeller Center buildings, all landmarks of Art Deco modernism.
At the American Radiator Building, the fact that 90 percent of the space was within 25 feet of a window cut both ways. While it provided excellent light, it also meant that elevators ate up much of the interior space, something that Hood sought to mitigate with automatic leveling and push-button car gates to increase their operating efficiency.
In the tower, the far side of the building is never far away, and gives the sense of a flood of light. From it there are close views of other midblock towers of the same period and the idea of a city of medium-sized, independent office spires seems very reasonable, even if a bit quaint.
But the efficiency of building to fill the zoning envelope offered a greater logic, and the free-standing tower later appeared only on a huge scale, like the Empire State and Chrysler Buildings.
Hood combined a practical bent with a free spirit and was not loath to admit a style of life that included an appreciation of liquor at a time of Prohibition. He also testified as a witness for the defense in the 1927 obscenity case of the play "Sex," which was written by and starred Mae West (who was fined $500 and sentenced to 10 days in jail).
The Landmarks Preservation Commission designated the Radiator building a landmark in 1974. American Radiator eventually became the American Standard Company, which in 1988 sold the building to a Japanese company, Clio Biz, just as a buying binge by Japanese peaked in New York.
Clio Biz announced at the time that it would convert the property to a 200-room hotel and build additional space on adjacent low-rise sites.
The typical floor area is so small, about 5,600 square feet, that it would be more profitable for residential than for office use in the midtown area.
A conversion is still the idea, says Daniel Stewart, a spokesman for Clio Biz, which he identifies as a real estate holding company controlled by a Japanese national who lives in both New York and Japan. Mr. Stewart says that there are now "promising" negotiations with a developer who would follow through with a residential condominium with hotel amenities.
If those talks fail, he says, "we'll do it ourselves."

HEADLINE: THE GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:

CELEBRATING O'KEEFFE
One of America's legendary 20th-century artists will be celebrated in an exhibition titled "Of, For and By Georgia O'Keeffe," opening Friday at the Whitney Museum of American Art in Stamford, and running through April 20.
In addition to a display of her paintings and drawings, the show explores a broader view of her life with photographs of her and of subjects which were characteristic of her by famous photographers, including Alfred Stieglitz, Arnold Newman, Todd Webb and Eliot Porter. 
 As an indication of her influence on other artists, a selection of sculptures by Mary Callery and Juan Hamilton, two friends of O'Keeffe's, are also on view.
The museum, located on the ground floor of the Champion International Building on Atlantic Street at Tresser Boulevard, is open free of charge Tuesday through Saturday from 11 to 5. Free gallery talks are given on Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday at 12:30 and free parking is available in the Champion garage on Tresser Boulevard. The number for more information is 358-7652.
 
TALES OF CITY LIFE
 "Griot New York," a full-length ballet that borrows its narrative format from the West African Griot, or tribal storyteller, relates in music and dance a variety of tales about city life. It will be performed next weekend at The Bushnell, 166 Capitol Avenue in Hartford, by the 15 members of the Garth Fagan Dance Company and a seven-piece ensemble of musicians.
The score is the first to be composed for a ballet by the noted trumpeter Wynton Marsalis. The choreography is by Mr. Fagan and the scenery was designed by the sculptor Martin Puryear.
During its 23 years of existence, the Fagan company has acquired a distinctive style, melding modern dance, classical ballet, jazz and Afro-Caribbean movement. "Griot New York" gives the dancers an opportunity to display all of those stylistic components in such segments as "High Rise Riff," satirizing life among the yuppies; "Bayou Baroque," a love duet, and "The Disenfranchised," about big city homelessness.
Since it was first performed at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in 1991, the piece has been seen in a dozen American cities and in Vienna. Performances will be at 8 P.M. Friday and Saturday; 2:30 P.M. Sunday. Tickets, priced from $5.50 to $33.50, may be ordered by calling 246-6807.
 
CITIES OF THE FUTURE
 "The Future of the American City," a symposium questioning whether or not the cities can be saved, will take place in New Haven on Saturday from 9 to 5 in the auditorium of the Yale Law School, 127 Wall Street.
Following talks by Anthony Downs, senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, and others, four panel discussions will address the issues of economic and social factors, government and policy, urban design and urban life, and New Haven case studies.
A group of experts in the fields of architecture, urban planning, business and management, design, the environment, economic development and transportation has been assembled for the panels from Rutgers, Columbia and Yale Universities, the Ford Foundation, the Connecticut Department of Economic Development and the Connecticut Department of Transportation, as well as individual architects, developers and housing officials.
The fee is $30 in advance, $35 at the door and $10 for students with ID. Reservations may be made by calling 772-2788 and registration will begin at 8:15 A.M.
 
BRUCKNER REVISITED
 "Bruckner for People Who Think They Don't Like Bruckner," a symposium and two concerts, subtitled "Rarely Heard Works by Anton Bruckner" and sub-subtitled "Bruckner and the Nazis Re-examined" is to be held on Monday and Tuesday at Connecticut College in New London.
According to organizers of the event, a conference of this magnitude on Bruckner has not yet taken place in America because of the hostility toward his music generated by the Third Reich's lionizing of him, along with Richard Strauss, as a Teutonic musical icon. Strauss received his reprieve at a 1992 conference at Bard College in New York State.
Monday's concert at 8:30 P.M. includes Bruckner's Third Symphony arranged for two pianos and five of his songs performed by the baritone Richard Lalli. On Tuesday at 8 P.M. the program will consist of Bruckner's Seventh Symphony arranged for chamber orchestra, and a selection of choral works. Tickets are $7 per concert, or $5 for students.
Symposium sessions held both days cost $20 a day or $10 for students, including concert admission. Participants include Leon Botstein, president of Bard College; Christoff Wolff, dean of the Harvard Graduate School; Paul Hawkshaw, associate dean of the Yale School of Music; and faculty members from Oberlin College Conservatory, the University of Berlin, University of Hamburg, Duke University, the Bruckner Institute at Linz, the University of Liverpool, Alexander University of Nurnberg, and numerous other institutions here and abroad.
Registration for the entire conference costs $60, $30 for students. The number is 439-2787 for tickets or to obtain more information.
 
CAREERS IN BUILDING
 Each year the Southern Connecticut chapter of the National Association of Women in Construction sponsors a Block Kids competition, wherein children from first through sixth grade are given one hour to create a structure using 100 building blocks. This year's event will take place on Saturday from 3 to 5 P.M. at the Eli Whitney Museum, 915 Whitney Avenue in Hamden.
The purpose of the Block Kids contests is to heighten interest of boys and girls and their parents in the opportunities available for careers in construction. Winners will receive savings bonds, gift certificates, T-shirts and other prizes.
The National Association of Women in Construction has 9,000 members in the United States and Canada. For more information, or to enter the free competition, the number is 777-1833.
 
RESEARCHING ROOTS
 Finding one's roots through the computer and other resources is the subject of a seventh annual one-day genealogical seminar to be held by the Historical Society of Greenwich, the Stamford Historical Society and the Connecticut Ancestry Society. It is scheduled on Saturday from 9 to 4 at Christ Church Parish Hall, 254 East Putnam Avenue in Greenwich.
Thomas J. Kemp, the keynote speaker and director of special collections at the University of Southern Florida Library, is a former head librarian at Turn-of-River Library in Stamford. He will present two talks: "Technology Moves Forward Into the Past" and "Little Known Biographical Sources."
Craig R. Scott, editor and publisher of his own genealogical quarterly, will talk about researching records and conquering intimidation at the vast National Archives, and Kevin Mathewson, senior librarian of cataloguing at the New York Public Library, will discuss underused map resources.
New CD-ROM disks for genealogical research will be demonstrated by Robert W. Green of the Connecticut Ancestry Society, and a representative of Jonathan Sheppard Books, which specializes in out-of-print genealogies and local history will have some examples on hand.
Registration costs $45 and includes a morning snack and lunch. The number is 329-1183 for more information or to sign up.
 
BEETHOVEN BONANZA
 A double dose of Beethoven will be offered in Westport this week by the Friends of Music, in a lecture-demonstration by the Ad Hoc String Quartet on Wednesday at 8 P.M. at the Public Library, Bernhard Plaza, and a concert by the Talich Quartet from Prague on Saturday at 8:30 P.M. in the Unitarian Church, 10 Lyons Plain Road.
Joan Turner, violinist, will lead the discussion and demonstration of Beethoven chamber works on Wednesday, abetted by Herbert Steiner, violinist; Catherine Dobbs, violist, and Anne Rorich, cellist. Admission will be free.
Tickets for the Saturday concert are $15, or $10 for elderly people and students. The number is 227-3345 for reservations or more information. ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Strategists Aren't Writing Japan Off Yet

BYLINE: By James Sterngold

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
IF the recent collision between Japan and the United States over trade wiped out a bystander this week, it was the Japanese stock market. The trans-Pacific war of nerves put what had been one of the hottest markets in the world on the skids.
With the yen soaring in value, the prospects for corporate profits looking grimmer and the fear of American trade sanctions spreading, the Nikkei index of 225 stocks lost a little more than 5 percent of its value, closing Friday at 18,959.60. More than that, it made the market a hostage to the yen, which appears likely to remain strong for now. 
 Is the great bull run of 1994 already over?
The surprising answer from a number of market analysts is: don't bet on it. Some investors have been discouraged, of course, but many experts believe the news from Japan is likely to get better, not worse.
"I haven't changed my view," said Jeff Bahrenburg, the senior strategist here with Merrill Lynch Japan. "We still have a slight overweighting on Japan."
Added Geoffrey Barker, the head of research here with Baring Securities: "We haven't broken out of the uptrend in the market that we've seen since December. We had a correction, that's for sure, but we're still in the range."
The market has dropped 7.6 percent since hitting its recent peak about 10 days ago. But it has still gained more than 10 percent in the last two months.
In addition, foreign investors remain strong buyers, analysts said.
Foreigners made net purchases of a little more than a trillion yen worth of Japanese shares last year, according to the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the equivalent of almost $10 billion. Then in January, foreigners snapped up another $9 billion, the second-highest monthly total on record.
No one denies that there are serious problems in Japan. The economy is in a two-year-old recession, and the Government has offered fairly tepid measures to get it out of its rut. Corporations still have to do some deep cost-cutting to return to profitability.
And now there is the trade mess. The Administration has threatened to slap sanctions on Japan because of a dispute over the cellular phone market. Japan has suggested that it may retaliate if Washington acts. And the yen has shot up, squeezing exporters and their already strained bottom lines.
The real fear is that a prolonged rise in the yen could counter the $140 billion Government program to breathe new life into the economy.
"If the yen stays where it's at, it wipes out any positive impact of the stimulus package," said Mineko Sasaki-Smith, an economist here with Morgan Stanley Japan.
But barring the emergence of worse problems, most analysts seem to think Japan is near an economic turn and the stock market is anticipating the improvement.
For instance, Ms. Sasaki-Smith said she was expecting a quick reduction in the Bank of Japan's discount rate, perhaps in a week.
And Mr. Barker said, "This market wants to go up, and it will if there are more signs of a compromise on trade."
He and others argue that American pressure will speed up, if only slightly, Japan's push for greater economic deregulation. And that would help the market a great deal.
"The point is that the pressure will be good for Japan in the end," Mr. Bahrenburg said. "It will accelerate the changes already under way to opening things up."
Mr. Bahrenburg may be one of the more optimistic analysts. He said one cause for hope was the fact that corporate balance sheets had gotten so bad that only a small pickup in business could have a pronounced effect.
He said he had calculated that a 2 percent increase in sales and a reduction in fixed costs of just half a percent would lift pretax profits about 45 percent for most companies.
"That's a very big jump," he said. "The reason is that the bottom line is now so depressed. That's why I say that the long-term story is very positive."
He is so optimistic, in fact, that he has picked some long-ignored stocks for his model portfolio. He said he liked consumer goods companies like Sony, Toyota, Sharp and Jusco, a big retailer.
Mr. Bahrenburg said he was also recommending some capital goods stocks, like Canon, Tokyo Electron and Makino Milling. As it happens, corporations have been slashing their capital-spending budgets, so this is a bold move.
Mr. Barker said that the market as a whole was unlikely to show sharp improvement in the short term. But he said there were plenty of good opportunities for those willing to explore promising niches.
For instance, Mr. Barker said he was expecting some improvement in consumer spending. Thus, he likes Toyo Wharf and Warehouse and the Kamigumi Company, a port transportation and warehousing company. These are not exactly cutting-edge companies, but Mr. Barker said they appeared likely to enjoy some pickup in growth.
Even John Baldwin, the strategist here with Jardine Fleming Securities and a bear on the market, said he saw some good buys.
He said smaller companies in particular may prosper. "This is a good environment for an active fund manager," Mr. Baldwin said. "There are lots of little niches that will be profitable, even if there is not any growth in the index."
He said he liked Nichiei, which offers financing to mostly smaller companies, and Yamakawa, an auto parts producer.
