HEADLINE: The Graying Factory

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
AT the age of 61, when many assembly line workers have retired to Florida or Arizona to pass their time playing cards or golf, James Langell rises almost every morning at 4:30 to prepare for his day at the Chrysler Corporation's Jefferson North plant here, where workers are scrambling to keep dealers stocked with the hot-selling Jeep Grand Cherokee.
Fifty-six times an hour, nine and a half hours a day, six days a week -- including Saturdays -- he installs the rear windshield washer hose and attaches front and rear bumpers, using a special screw gun that makes it easy on his arms and back to tighten screws. He has less than 90 seconds to do it and if he loses his rhythm he falls behind. 
 Hoses and bumpers. Hoses and bumpers. With seniority that comes with 30 years on assembly lines, Mr. Langell has a job that is not as taxing on his legs, arms and back as others. "At least I don't have to bend or get inside the cars. Those jobs are terrible," he said. Still it is tiring and monotonous, and the mandatory overtime as well as the pressure to churn out the cars -- without defects -- makes it even tougher.
"You work 10 hours a day, six days a week, and when you get up on Monday at 5 A.M., you're still tired," said Luther Cooksey, who during his nearly 28 years on the line has injured his back and suffered strains and cuts. Now, to avoid hamstring muscle pulls, he wears special pants favored by basketball players. "Time to move on and give a young man this job."
But where have all the young workers gone? In America's manufacturing heartland, ranging from aluminum factories to tire plants, there are precious few of the 90's version of the muscular long-hairs who populated plants 20 years ago. They declined in number along with newly-hired female workers after repeated layoffs in the 80's that pared thousands of people, mostly with little seniority. In industries like steel and rubber, and almost any place where layoffs, restructurings and union contracts have been the rule, only the oldest workers have survived.
 
Transforming a Work Force
 Now workers and management alike are trying to transform this old and tired work force into one of the most competitive and productive in the world. Onto their backs, biceps and brains have fallen the demands of increasing productivity, the work-smarter, work-faster ethos that has fueled a remarkable recovery not only on Detroit's assembly lines but in the manufacturing cities and towns across America.
"The traditional way of improving productivity has been to speed up the line, but you can't do that with older workers," said Harley Shaiken, who teaches industrial relations at the University of California at Berkeley. As workers in basic industries age, Mr. Shaiken said, "you have skill and experience, which can be positive factors if you know how to harness them." But "you can't rely on 22-year-olds working at the limit to dig you out of a hole."
One of the most stunning economic achievements the last decade has been the turnaround in manufacturing productivity growth -- the ultimate accelerator of profitability and pay. During the high-inflation, low-growth 1970's, America's factory productivity, though still the highest in the world, stalled. A decade later, after layoffs, plant closings and billions invested in technology, the nation's factories boasted the fastest rate of productivity growth among wealthy nations -- including Japan.
Here at the Jeep plant the average age is 52, the oldest in the auto industry and about six years higher than that of the average auto worker. Yet Chrysler is churning out the same 250,000 vehicles per year here as it did at the plant that Jefferson North replaced -- with only 2,500 workers to the old plant's 5,000. All told, Jefferson North, which opened in 1991, can assemble one and a half times as many vehicles per square foot as the leaky 84-year-old facility it replaced.
Engineers designed the Grand Cherokee for easier assembly than previous models. But much additional productivity was expected from harder, smarter efforts from individuals, as Detroit adopted Japan's lean production techniques. That expectation created new physical and mental burdens.
"There's not really enough time or space to do your job," said one worker. "You make one little mistake, you are in a hole," because the next vehicle arrives as the other one moves away.
TOYOTA MOTOR COMPANY executives, before joining the General Motors Corporation in a joint venture in California some years ago, were worried that G.M. workers were too old and set in their work habits to adjust to the greater physical and mental demands of Toyota's manufacturing system. The venture largely has been a success, although some workers have complained about the fast pace and demands of work. In Japan, the average auto worker is 34.
To make sure workers don't collapse under the strain, Detroit auto makers have been compelled to rethink the deployment of an aging work force. At the old Jefferson plant Chrysler paid hundreds of extra workers whose only duties were to tidy up, fix mistakes and fill in for tired or absent workers.
No more. To keep cost down and quality up, workers today must be productive nearly every moment. That means they must do their own cleaning up. And increasingly, they must contribute ideas for efficiency, as well as physical effort.
Adjusting to a faster pace and additional responsibilities poses a particular challenge for older workers. So auto makers have instituted extensive training in problem-solving and teamwork; and they have installed ergonomic equipment to ease the physical strain.
The Jefferson North Assembly plant is the most modern in the American auto industry. Overhead conveyors tilt vehicle bodies at an angle so that workers standing underneath can easily make assemblies without straining. The entire plant "is designed to make jobs less physically demanding," said Jim Puckett, a 49-year-old millwright who has been in the plant for 30 years.
Mr. Cooksey, who is 46, uses a mechanically articulating arm to help him swing a 50-pound metal sheet that becomes the floor of a Grand Cherokee. The air guns that drive screws for Mr. Langell and a mitt worn by Keith Hence, a 44-year-old assembler who has worked at Chrysler 25 years, are specially designed to reduce the stress that causes painful wrist and arm injuries like carpal tunnel syndrome. Almost all line workers stand on special matting designed to reduce stress on backs and legs.
WHEN it built the plant, Chrysler constructed a small gym so that workers could stay fit. Now, employees can sometimes be seen power walking around the perimeter of the shop floor.
Manufacturers in other industries have used training and ergonomic design to improve productivity and reduce physical stress for a graying work force. For example, tire makers have designed a machine that raises tires onto a conveyor, eliminating the traditional task of lifting tires that weighed up to 110 pounds each.
At the Aluminum Company of America's plant in Davenport, Iowa, where the average age of workers is 47, "strains and sprains" were becoming a chronic problem until the company asked all 2,500 workers four years ago to attend a "back class." The classes continue and the result has been that injuries declined.
At USX Corporation's Braddock, Pa., steelworks, the company spent as much as $60,000 per worker to train men in their 50's in the operation of a high-tech continuous caster that makes steel more efficiently.
An even bigger payoff for training and ergonomics may arrive when a young generation of workers are hired on to replace those about to retire. Slowly, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation have begun to hire in small numbers, reflecting the rebound in car sales.
"This is an unprecedented chance to redefine what an auto worker will be," said Sean McAlinden, a labor economist at the University of Michigan. "There's a lot of thinking about what kind of skills an auto maker must have. The union wants this too, because it knows companies don't throw away skilled workers."
Russ Eckel, an industrial sociologist based in Boston, said older, more experienced workers "know a lot about design, and today companies are willing to listen to them and spend money on their ideas."
Historically, meeting production quotas took priority over quality, ease of effort or safety. So workers sometimes injured themselves struggling with defective parts or machines that didn't work properly. "First line supervisors are starting to listen when a team suggests changes," Mr. Eckel said.
In an unusual gesture, Chrysler invited workers to critique the Grand Cherokee before it went into production. Of 650 suggestions to improve manufacturability, 170 were accepted, including one, for example, to lengthen the connector on a bundle of wires, which simplified installation.
In practice, though, older workers can turn quickly cynical if they are encouraged to participate and their ideas aren't acted upon. They "get disgusted if they believe no one cares what they think," said Ron P. Mattice, 51, who leads a work team at the Chrysler plant.
Sometimes worker suggestions are flops. Said one worker, "They spent $15,000 to move a conveyor after the workers said it would improve things. Now the team wants it back the way it was." At the old Jefferson Avenue plant, a building that Jefferson North workers recall bittersweetly, workers didn't have to think, only sweat. A person with 20 or 25 years seniority exercised rights under the labor agreement to a respite from hard physical exertion. Older workers were entitled to a clipboard or the keys to a forklift -- a softer jobs away from the assembly line.
Safee Akbar, 67, with 51 years of seniority does indeed have such a job: He operates the computer that tracks parts deliveries and drives a forklift. Seniority rights remain in force, but the soft jobs today are few.
Instead, workers must master subjects like statistical process control, a technique of gathering and analyzing data that helps predict quality glitches and machine breakdowns. Trouble is, the education skills of many older workers have grown rusty. So they first must relearn basic math and reading, in addition to computer skills.
"The majority of workers have high school diplomas but that doesn't always mean you had a high school education," added Larry Morgan, a training manager for the United Automobile Workers union.
Big demand for the Grand Cherokee has increased the hours of overtime assigned to workers, consequently squeezing time available for training and discussion of quality-improvement ideas.
Constant overtime, rather than the intensity of the tasks or the pace, may have a negative impact on quality, as well as worker's attitudes toward their jobs. "Overtime followed by slack times are part of being an auto worker, but those jumps are what could be taking a toll on the 52-year-olds," said Robert Cole, a professor of business administration at the University of California at Berkeley.
Chrysler prefers to schedule overtime rather than to hire more workers, the alternative favored by the union and the workers. From the employers' perspective, new workers mean additional benefit costs. From the union's perspective, new members pay dues and reverse the membership losses. "The idea is not to hire too many workers, so we don't have to lay off people in the future," explained Jim Strasbaugh, a former Chrysler plant manager.
But Mr. Mattice argues that "people need more time off. The money is good but we need time to enjoy it." He owns a vacation home in northern Michigan and a speedboat. Most weeks Jefferson North is operating two shifts, 18 hours a day, every day except Sunday.
IN response to complaints about overtime, Chrysler recently instituted a special shutdown early on Friday so day shift workers could go to the bank. And in a few weeks, Chrysler will begin hiring temporary workers at the plant to fill in for hourly workers who say they are tired and want to take three-day weekends.
At the old plant any worker who needed a break could call in sick and bring a doctor's note. Some doctors on the east side of Detroit were known as quite willing to write excuses for auto workers. Absenteeism is no longer tolerated; besides, those still working are among the most dedicated. The only way out is retirement, which is possible on a full pension after 30 years of service.
Mr. Langell, whose first job on the line was stapling fender liners for 1954 Chrysler New York Yorkers and Imperials, made $55,000 last year and could retire now on a monthly check of $1,900 but has decided against it for awhile. "My wife died, this is all I have," he said.
Mr. Cooksey has 18 months to go and plans to retire immediately. "A lot of people just want to get out of here," Mr. Mattice said. "I go within the year. I've been very fortunate never to have any bad injuries, only a broken toe and a chipped tooth." By the year 2000, Mr. McAlinden predicts, most of the older workers will be retired and the face of Chrysler's work force will be suddenly and dramatically younger.
"The new guys will be facing a completely different environment than the one we've known," said Mr. McAlinden. "The people on the line know things must change, they're just asking for a chance to work their way out of it."
 
 
 
PRIDE GOETH BEFORE A RECALL
 THE Jeep Grand Cherokee, a hot-selling sport utility vehicle and the pride of the Jefferson North Assembly plant, has been recalled four times in the last year for safety defects.
Quality problems also have dogged Chrysler's L/H sedans and the recently introduced Neon subcompact. Nevertheless, the models have helped revive the No. 3 auto maker's fortunes and propelled the value of its common stock to a new peak.
Referring specifically to the Grand Cherokee, John Franciosi, the plant manager of the Chrysler Corporation's Jefferson North assembly plant, said the workers at the plant aren't to blame for the defects. Instead, engineering design glitches and defects in parts from suppliers caused the problem.
Mr. Franciosi said the Grand Cherokee's design was inherited from the American Motors Corporation when it was acquired in 1987 by Chrysler. Since then the auto maker has shifted to a different system of engineering development that is expected to produce higher-quality vehicles.
"There's no such thing as a defect free vehicle," said Mr. Franciosi. "One could say the gap between American and Japanese quality has narrowed to the point that it's statistically insignificant. That doesn't mean we've stopped trying."
Mr. Franciosi said Chrysler's internal surveys show the 1994 Grand Cherokee's quality has improved 27 percent over 1993 levels. J.D. Power & Associates, an automotive research firm that measures quality, declined to publicize the model's initial rating, which Chrysler said is "above the industry average."
In January, 1993 Chrysler recalled 700 Grand Cherokees for faulty break pedal clips. Last April it recalled 30,000 vehicles for possibly defective suspension bolts and, in the same month, 87,000 vehicles were recalled for potentially defective liftgate latches. Last month 115,000 vehicles were recalled for possible faulty steering columns.
The Grand Cherokee has proven to be quite popular as a station-wagon replacement for more affluent suburban families. Most workers at Jefferson North, who have been taking home $50,000 a year and more, say they like the vehicle, but say they can't afford to buy one, even with a company discount. The manufacturer's suggested retail price starts at $21,156 and can reach more than $30,000 with all options.

HEADLINE: Business Diary: February 13-18

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Redstone Stands Victorious on a Littered Battleground
Well, it's over -- the Super Bowl of corporate soap operas. After five months, the winning bidder for Paramount is . . . Viacom. The price: $9.7 billion in cash and stock. The loser: Barry Diller and his QVC Network Inc. (which, in grief or relief, quickly downsized itself to QVC Inc.). Standing alone amid the rubble is Sumner Redstone, Viacom's chairman. And rubble it is: Viacom stock fell so far during the fray that Mr. Redstone's stake fell by $3.1 billion, and the merged company will have $10 billion in debt -- a time bomb if interest rates rise. Shareholders of Blockbuster, which Viacom agreed to buy to help cover that debt, aren't too happy with Viacom's stock slide. And Martin Davis, Paramount chairman, got left by the wayside as the battle raged. So it's up to Mr. Redstone to make it work. And though there's been talk of spinning off properties like Simon & Schuster, he hopes to avoid selling anything. 

A Drizzle on Chrysler's Parade
American auto makers have been staging a rust-to-riches drama, mainly because they're just making better cars. In fact, Consumer Reports rated Chrysler's new sedans, the Intrepid et al., slightly above the Camry and Accord, the longtime stars -- the first time in 12 years Detroit has seized that medal. On its dash to glory, though, Chrysler has been plagued with recalls -- the Neon (twice), Dodge Ram and Grand Cherokee, all since December. And last week the gremlins struck again, as it recalled 110,000 sedans for an electrical problem. The glitches are all minor -- no injuries involved -- but their persistence is a sobering note at Chrysler's party.
 
Wang Dream House, for a Song
Rarely has there been a more vivid image of corporate humbling. In the 1980's, an age that recoiled at the mere mention of moderation, Wang Laboratories spent $50 million or so building a headquarters complex in Lowell, Mass. But times have changed: in 1988 Wang had sales of $3 billion and more than 30,000 workers; now it's fresh from bankruptcy, has downshifted from hardware to soft, and employs 6,000. The final blow: at a bankruptcy auction last week, the sprawling Lowell complex was sold for $525,000, about the price of a house in a fancy suburb.
 
Plug 'er In, Fill 'er Up
Electric cars are coming -- practical ones, that is. Why? For an age-old reason: Where there's a will there's a way. With a growing political will to clean the air, the way must be found. A big snag so far: Either charging takes too long, or, once charged, the cars don't go far enough. If one could be solved, the other would be downgraded to mere annoyance. A company called Solectria, using a method developed by Electronic Power Technology, has smashed the record for miles traveled by an electric vehicle in 24 hours. The charging time was cut to 20 minutes, enough to go 65 miles. One twist: If cars could build up a charge overnight, they'd draw power when demand is low; if they need daytime charges, utilities will find it tougher to meet demand.
 
What Next, Boardwalk at $800?
Life's just not fair. In Monopoly, if there's a bank error, you collect $200; if a real bank messes up, you pay. Chemical Bank made a whopper last week. Because of a tiny computer error, for nearly a day every A.T.M. withdrawal was counted twice, quickly draining $15 million out of accounts and drawing 4,000 complaints. (One wonders how many calls there would have been if the error had left customers ahead.) Chemical vows to take care of any fees or bounced checks, but customers surely had their faith in technology shaken. Now those trusting souls who toss bank statements might take a closer look.
 
Elvis Tilley? Get My Monocle!
For some, the fall of communism was small stuff -- the bark of a faraway seal. The true upheaval came when Tina Brown took over at The New Yorker 18 months ago, bringing -- depending on one's perspective -- either heretical tampering or a breath of fresh air. Emboldened by her success so far, Ms. Brown toppled a sacred image last week by bumping the monocled Eustace Tilley from the anniversary cover for the first time since 1925. In his place: Elvis Tilley, a squinting, pointy-nosed street punk with a marked resemblance to his grandfather. Yes, the seals are barking; yes, the republic still stands.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Saudis Give U.S. a Scratch
This was clearly President Clinton's message to Saudi Arabia: You scratch my back, and I'll scratch yours. Or, put another way: You buy our planes, and if any neighbors bother you, we'll be there -- as we were in the Gulf war. His lobbying made impeccable sense to the Saudis, and last week they said they'd buy $6 billion worth of American commercial jets -- and buy none from Airbus, the European consortium. Figuring that each billion supports 20,000 jobs, that will mean 120,000 jobs at Boeing, McDonnell Douglas and other companies. And it means that Mr. Clinton -- who, with appropriate Olympic spirit, called the deal "a gold medal win" -- is not going to be shy about seeking business the world over for American companies.
 
Trade Tension With Japan
Things are getting nasty on the trade front. The Administration said last week that it would impose sanctions on Japan for not allowing Motorola into the Tokyo cellular phone market. Then it quickly started dropping threats about just how extensive its actions would be. And it didn't help much when, later in the week, the United States reported a record trade deficit with Japan for 1993. All this has left Japanese Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa scrambling to head off a trade war by coming up with some plan by this Saturday, when finance ministers of Group of Seven nations meet in Frankfurt.
 
Diamond Price-Fixing?
Even as the Administration puts a lot of energy into trade matters, the Justice Department is being aggressive in applying America's antitrust laws throughout the world. Last week a Federal grand jury indicted De Beers Centenary, General Electric and two European businessmen, saying they conspired to inflate prices for industrial diamonds -- one of the biggest cases ever to charge such an international antitrust violation. Industrial diamonds, mainly produced synthetically and used for saws and drills, constitute a half-billion-dollar-a-year industry.
 
January: Not the Time to Build
In an age obsessed with the lean and the mean, with solemn, high-energy executives talking on the phone even as they walk down the street, it's nice to be reminded periodically that, in the end, nature is in charge. Even a high-flying economy had to slow down a bit on January's ice and quivering freeways. The latest evidence: Last week's report that housing starts plunged 17.6 percent in January. No one was really worried, though: the figures are seasonally adjusted, but not enough for this nasty season. In any case, as one economist said, the economy may just be "taking a breather" after a strong fourth quarter.
 
More Trouble for Hoffenberg
Remember Steven Hoffenberg? He had a cameo role in The New York Post Follies a year ago, charging in with his checkbook, vowing to save the paper. It turned out the checkbook was not what it seemed, though, as the S.E.C. filed fraud charges against him and his company, Towers Financial. He passed it off as an accounting dispute, but last week the Government said there was an awful lot more to that iceberg, charging that Mr. Hoffenberg had defrauded investors of $450 million over the years in a gigantic Ponzi scheme. Since the Post debacle, though -- even with Towers in bankruptcy since March -- Mr. Hoffenberg keeps starting businesses, in one case advertising for investors in something called Haley Capital. Any takers?
 
Homelessness Redefined
This is the way the Republicans viewed homelessness in the years they ran things: 600,000 Americans homeless on a given night, mainly plagued by drugs, drink or mental illness. A draft report from this Administration puts it a bit differently: a problem "far larger than commonly thought," with poverty, racism and budget cuts shoving many out the door. The report calls for more spending on housing and mental health. And the plan raises a touchy point on housing -- that even as there's talk of cutting housing aid for the poor, housing aid for the middle class (i.e., deductible mortgage interest) stood at a huge $41 billion last year.
 
Inflation Behind Every Tree
The markets keep being spooked by inflation -- even though, officially, there really isn't any. Consumer prices didn't budge in January, the Government said on Thursday, putting the index just 2.5 percent ahead in 12 months. But the markets were so nervous they quickly latched onto a Philadelphia Fed survey showing that inflation may indeed be around the corner. Stock and bond prices fell, and kept falling on Friday, with the Dow industrials ending the week at 3,887.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Individuals Are Buying, but Not Like Old Times

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
BUY on weakness.
Since the rebound from the 1987 crash made bears look foolish, that has been the slogan of your average individual investor. When the Dow cracked under the weight of bad news or institutional selling, it was Ma and Pa who rushed in to buy.
But this time, it's different. In the wake of the Dow's 96-point plunge on Feb. 4, individual investors seem to have been much less eager to buy. To be sure, there has been no big selling blitz. But they are buying a lot less. 
 Dick McCabe, the chief market analyst at Merrill Lynch, reports that Merrill's retail customers sold more on Feb. 4 than they had in previous plunges, and bought less in the period that followed. And figures compiled by AMG Data Services show that while investors are still putting cash into stock funds, the flow is less than it had been. Those facts help to explain why the widely anticipated bounce back has not occurred.
In fact, the last couple of weeks have been remarkable for the negative attitudes being shown by many professional investors. Take the options markets. There are individual speculators, but more and more of the business is done by institutions, some of which are speculating and some hedging. The volume of put trading in the last couple of weeks has been extraordinary. There are a number of ways to measure that, but both Richard Eakle of Eakle Associates, a money management firm in Fair Haven, N.J., and Don Fishback, who publishes newsletters on options in Cincinnati, point to indicators showing put activity has never been higher.
That may be important because, at extremes, option activity is a good contrary indicator. "It is a measure of sentiment among the crowd that is usually wrong," Mr. Fishback says.
Take the five previous bad days since 1990. In four of them, the Dow recovered completely within the next 10 trading days. The only exception was the plunge in November of 1991, when the Dow lost nearly 4 percent in one day. Then it took six weeks to recover, and the first couple of weeks saw substantial institutional selling, notes Jeff Rubin, an analyst at Birinyi Associates in Greenwich, Conn. Institutions have also been significant sellers this time.
It is not hard to understand why investors are nervous now. A hostile Federal Reserve is, in the end, almost always bad news for the stock market. Those who remember 1987's rebound also recall that the crash was proceeded by months of Fed tightening.
But history shows that stocks often rise in the early months after the Fed first tightens, even as bonds prices fall. Money that might have gone into bonds instead chases stock prices higher. In time, after stock prices have risen significantly, confidence develops that this time, higher interest rates are not a big problem. Then they become one. The chances now are for at least one more good rally, before the real bear market arrives.

HEADLINE: At Work;
The Morning After for Health Care

BYLINE: By Barbara Presley Noble

 BODY:
A FRISSON has been traveling up and down the collective spine of the public policy community for the past year, innervated by the prospect of genuine, planned and, yes, rational reform of the nation's health care delivery system. One person's frisson is, of course, another's paralysis. The wizards of compensation and benefits at companies around the country have not been happy for several months, their designs and complications on hold while the Clinton health care task force toiled and spun out a plan -- a plan that might well make moot years of their own work.
Fortunes have flipped since the first of the year, and the wizards are waking as it becomes increasingly clear that whatever reform turns out to be, it will be built on what's already in place and be achieved in the style to which the Beltway is accustomed. Key provisions, like providing health care payments for early retirees and creating risk-pool alliances, seem to be headed already for extinction or reconstructive surgery. 
 And anyone who was worried that the debate over health care in Washington would actually be about health care or about national priorities or even about trying to match market forces to the market-taunting art of healing can return to a state of calm. For many beyond the Beltway, a heavy straw settled on the camel's back two weeks ago when the mainly Republican opposition tried to reframe a Congressional Budget Office analysis of the Clinton plan into another mind-numbing debate about the deficit. By all accounts, Robert Reischauer, the C.B.O. chief, outsuaved those who would obsess about incomprehensible sums of money.
"No one in this country has been able to predict medical cost changes within any reasonable range of error," said Bruce Kelley, a principal at William M. Mercer Inc., the benefits consultants. Mr. Kelley is following the debate from his far-beyond-the-Beltway base of Minneapolis. "I'd call that a heads-up estimate."
Exasperation and relief were evident in conversations with several benefits consultants in the last week. Mr. Kelley indicated the companies he works with are definitely emerging from a funk. "We are coming out of a period where employers have been asking about how they are going to be impacted. Is it good or bad for them?" He added: "They are moving back into a mode of having to make some decision to move forward."
Henry Saveth, a principal at Foster Higgins in New York, another large benefits consultant, said his clients are beginning to realize just how long it will take to put any changes into place. "The 300-pound gorilla which was health care reform is now viewed as substantially slimmed down," he said, adding, "The first thing we saw was that the effective date would slip. Second, there's the emergence of a perception that the inner glue of the Clinton plan is coming undone, so there will not only be a delay, but whatever comes down the pike that is new will be much less than had been feared."
Employers were very nervous about taking what Mr. Saveth described as a "vertical plunge" into Government regulation. "Most employers think there are a number of useful changes that could be made, but done on a building-block basis, not as a big bang."
That reaction points up the limitations of the "convergence of interest" strategy among groups willing to employ similar means to achieve dissimilar ends -- and a plan that, like its instigator, tries to be all things to all people. The Clinton Administration health care reform constituency is a diverse group with several goals, but many in the group rank universal health coverage and reforming the insurance system considerably higher than buffing the bottom line. Mr. Kelley's clients' interests are elsewhere. "Their focus is on continuous quality improvement," he said. "That is in the Clinton proposal, but Clinton wants to use reform for cost control and for equity." His companies don't oppose that, Mr. Kelley said, "but it's not their motivation and it's not a high priority." What employees really want, Mr. Saveth said, is control over their programs and their destinies, and it looks like they will get -- or, rather, keep -- it.
EMPLOYERS are getting what they want but will employees? Mr. Reischauer indicated in his comments to Congress that reform could balance the interests of the two groups. "Changes in businesses' costs, both positive and negative, would be largely shifted back onto workers in the form of lower or higher wages," he told the Senate Finance Committee on Feb. 9.
That savings will be passed on tends to be a faith held more by economists than by employees, but the consultants said competition for good workers, even in a layoff environment, does indeed keep galloping capitalism in check. When medical pricing is down, compensation is more liberal. When it is up, wages flatten. A drop in medical costs has a faster impact on paychecks than it will on the national budget. "Employers tend to react in two- to three-year cycles with their benefit-pricing strategies," Mr. Kelley said. "If we really saw a reduction in costs, we would see employers being more liberal on the compensation side."
 
 
 
ONE COMPANY TAKES THE PLUNGE
AT the corporate headquarters of Snelling & Snelling Inc., the employment services franchiser, senior management did not wait to see which way the wind was blowing on health care reform before instituting changes meant to drive down the cost of health benefits for some 300 employees. As of the first of the year, Snelling switched its corporate employees in Dallas, California and Hawaii from a trust-financed traditional major medical plan to a program that allows them to choose either a health maintenance organization or a preferred provider organization.
According to Claudia Hunt, the company's human resources vice president, the new plan will save Snelling $200,000 this year and reduce the amount employees have to contribute. And why did Snelling proceed, given the uncertainty last fall when the company was first planning the change? As far as Snelling was concerned, the handwriting was on the wall, no matter how loud the static from Washington. The push toward managed care and HMO-type organizations is irresistible, whether it comes from benefits consultants or Mr. Clinton. "We figured with what we knew about Clinton's program, this would help our employees get into that mode," Ms. Hunt said.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Readers' Mail: A Question of Risk

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
Question: In one of your columns, you wrote that "risk is a matter of personal choice." That suggests a subjective personality quirk called "risk aversion," while I think risk tolerance is more a matter of when the investment is to be liquidated.
Answer: You're partly correct. Your investment horizon is one important element of risk. Stocks are normally preferred investments over time because they are the only effective inflation hedge. In the short run, though, equities are much riskier. 
 How short? For investments of less than five years, don't buy stocks, says Harold Evensky, an investment adviser in Coral Gables, Fla. By contrast, Sheldon Jacobs, who edits The No-Load Fund Investor, in Irvington, N.Y., would put up to a third of a short-term portfolio into conservative stock funds like balanced or equity-income funds.
What you've overlooked is interim volatility. For example, Phoenix Growth and Founders Growth Funds have nearly identical 10-year returns, 14.6 percent and 14.5 percent a year, on average. But they traveled very different roads to get there. Phoenix had no losses, while Founders had double-digit losses in two years. Perhaps because it's harder for investors to hold on, Founders has only one-sixteenth the assets of Phoenix, although the two funds were close in size in 1980. The moral: People who lack the discipline to sit tight in tough times are better off with steadier funds.
Q: The mutual fund tables use the footnote "d" to denote both contingent deferred sales charges and redemption fees. In view of the quantum difference between the two types of fees, is that appropriate?
A: While they are constructed differently, both are used to encourage shareowners to hold shares, not cash them in quickly. Contingent deferred sales charges typically start as 4 percent to 6 percent of the amount invested, declining one percentage point a year until they disappear. Any deferred sales charges are paid to the fund sponsor.
By contrast, redemption fees usually run from 0.5 percent to 2 percent of the amount invested and apply to shares held from 60 days up to two years or so. Because they are intended to compensate long-term shareholders for the transaction costs incurred by short-term traders, redemption fees become part of the funds' assets. Many funds limit investors' trades in other ways; only 134 funds charge redemption fees.
The New York Times uses the same footnote for both types of fees to simplify the tables. The "d" alerts you that you may owe a fee when you sell; it's up to you to find out from the fund's prospectus which fees apply.
Q: I am interested in learning more about funds that invest in shares of other funds.
A: The nearly two dozen "funds of funds" are packaged in two ways. First is a package of funds run by one company. For example, the Vanguard Star Fund owns shares in nine Vanguard stock, bond and money market funds, with equities making up 63 percent of the portfolio. Star charges annual expenses of 0.37 percent of assets, the total of fees levied by the underlying funds. T. Rowe Price's version, now three years old, is broken down by investment objective. Price Spectrum Growth invests in six of its stock funds; Spectrum Income owns shares in five of its bond funds, plus an equity-income fund.
These funds are good choices for investors who want to diversify yet own only one fund, especially in a 401(k) or another retirement plan, said John Rekenthaler, editor of Morningstar Mutual Funds in Chicago. They are less useful for people who prefer to mix and match.
Mr. Rekenthaler is less enthusiastic about the second type of funds of funds. These levy a fee on top of fees charged by the underlying funds. Two examples are API and Fundtrust, each of which offers five funds in its series. The Fundtrust Growth Fund, for example, owns shares in AIM Charter, Putnam Vista and Phoenix Capital Appreciation, among others, and charges a 1.6 percent annual fee, plus a 1.5 percent upfront sales load. The fund lagged behind all growth funds by 2.63 percentage points a year, on average, for the five years ended January, according to Morningstar.
Indeed, all but one of the 16 funds of funds with five-year records tracked by Morningstar showed a lag. The exception, Flex-Funds Muirfield, gained 12 percent a year, on average, compared with 11.3 percent for all asset-allocation funds; Vanguard Star lagged behind all balanced funds by only 0.61 percent.
Q: Some funds reserve the right to redeem shares with stocks, but in a free-falling market, stocks are the last thing I would want. How exactly does this work, and how common is it?
A: The Securities and Exchange Commission does not keep track of how many funds can redeem shares with securities. A spokesman says many funds limit payment-in-kind redemptions to accounts worth more than $250,000. For example, all of T. Rowe Price's 50-plus funds can redeem shares with securities in accounts worth more than $250,000, or 1 percent of the fund's assets, whichever is less; Dreyfus's strategy is similar. But Fidelity Investments, the nation's largest fund company, imposes no such limits in its 200-plus funds. While it's certainly possible, the practice has been exceedingly uncommon. For information, call your fund company.

HEADLINE: Institutional Investments That Grow With Trees

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

DATELINE: WAKEFIELD, Va.

 BODY:
IN a scene reminiscent of the movie "Jurassic Park," a customized bulldozer called a "sawhead feller" moves into the forest here like a mechanized dinosaur. It grabs a 70-foot pine tree with its steel teeth and, shaking the tree like a little flower, causes it to come thundering to the ground. The machine then rolls on to take down another tree, and then another.
This is modern forestry courtesy of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, which is busily matching institutional investors and trees to create one of the hottest corners of investing today: timberland. As traditional owners of forests sell off their lands and as the Government gets out of the tree-cutting business, big pension funds are rushing in and earning returns that have far outpaced stocks, bonds and real estate for several years now. 
 Trees have always been fundamental to the nation's economy. In fact, forest products are the country's fifth-largest business segment and represent a full 6 percent of the gross domestic product. By meshing modern financial theory with advanced forestry techniques, pension funds have been able to reap annual returns in the 20 percent to 30 percent range by putting money into trees and watching it grow.
"Trees have been wonderful for us," said John Carroll, president of the GTE Investment Management Corporation, which owns $260 million in timberland managed by Hancock. "It's been our most successful real estate investment. Besides, it's always nicer to own something real than a piece of paper. With timber, you can see it, kick it, feel it or even hug your investment."
The pension funds aren't actually out there buying up trees and chopping them down. Their investments are funneled through a middle man -- Hancock's Timber Resource Group is by far the largest of a small group of intermediaries that have set up forestry investment funds and separate accounts for pension funds. Hancock takes actual title to the forest land, manages it for a fee and passes the economic benefits to the investor -- a structure not unlike other real estate funds. Others in this business include the Wachovia Bank of Winston-Salem, N.C.; Resource Investments of West Lebanon, N.H.; Prudential Timber Investments of Boston, and Forest Investment Associates of Atlanta.
Investors in timberland make their money in three ways: Through timber sales, by selling off small parcels of land to others and through the increase in the value of the land holdings. As real estate investments in general have provided flat to negative returns of late, timber investments have been shown to be effective inflation hedges -- as the economy improves, so does the demand for wood and paper. Most of the timber sold ultimately makes its way into housing and industrial uses or is turned into paper and pulp.
"For most people, it's hard to relate to trees as money makers," said Richard N. Smith, head of Hancock's Boston-based timber management team, as he walked through the forest here, about 50 miles southwest of Norfolk. "It's almost as though it's too obvious or too simple." A forester by training, Mr. Smith started the Hancock effort in 1984 after coming up with the notion that the long-term investment objectives of pension funds could match the long-term demands of sound forestry, which is to manage timberlands so they remain productive for decades, rather than clear-cutting for immediate profit.
Since then, Hancock has grown to manage about $2 billion of the $3 billion of timberland owned by institutional investors -- all of whom have been praised by environmental groups as sensitive stewards of the land. Hancock's holdings represent 1.8 million acres of forests, primarily in the Southeast and the Pacific Northwest. While a growing force, institutional owners still pale in size compared with small private owners, who lay claim to about 60 percent of the 500 million commercial timber acres in the United States, and the Government, which owns about 26 percent of the commercial forests.
"Pension funds, with their long-term liabilities and their objective of capital appreciation, can be a source of capital consistent with this resource and better owners of the land than many others," Mr. Smith said. After pitching the idea to many skeptical institutions, Mr. Smith and Hancock now have a list of investors that includes the California State Public Employees Retirement System, or Calpers, and public pensions in Ohio, Colorado, Detroit and Dallas as well as corporate funds like GTE and A.T.& T. So far, timberland is strictly an institutional investment, but Mr. Smith expects that timber mutual funds for the individual retail customer might pop up in several years.
Recent developments have taken Mr. Smith's idea and pushed it to double-digit return levels. Public pressure in the late 1980's, culminating with the 1991 decision to preserve the northern spotted owl's Pacific Northwest habitat, has caused the Government to protect old-growth forests and halt most Federal timber sales. This has cut the supply of all Western timber by 20 to 30 percent -- which, in turn, has pushed up timber market prices over all. And it is the intention of the Clinton Administration to reduce Federal harvesting even further.
Moreover, the restructuring of forest products companies, which had undergone leveraged buyouts in the 1980's, has put many more acres of timberland onto the market for sale to institutions. Prominent companies like St. Regis Paper, Diamond International, Crown Zellerbach and Pacific Lumber went private through takeovers and buyouts in the last decade. Since then, many have decided to focus more on making paper and wood products and use their forest lands instead as a source of capital that can be sold to pay down debt, especially now that rising wood prices have increased the value of their properties.
"There's been a supply shock that has brought a substantial increase in timber prices," said Courtland L. Washburn, a Hancock forest economist. "And in the last 10 years, a lot of forest products companies have decided to concentrate more on the processing of wood and let folks like us concentrate on growing trees for them."
Most institutions classify timber as part of their real estate or natural resource portfolio. But timber has some strikingly different characteristics from other assets. For starters, a timber portfolio literally grows every day, unlike such resources as coal or gas, which remain the same size, or even, for that matter, commercial buildings. In addition, when timber prices are soft, the trees -- unlike other agricultural products like tomatoes or corn -- can simply remain in the ground, and wait for a market upturn.
"If you have an office building that sits vacant, you've lost that rent forever," said John Imboden, director of real estate assets for the State Teachers Retirement System of Ohio, which has a $100 million investment. "If you don't harvest the trees, you don't lose that value. The tree still grows."
BUT the key to timber returns comes in the management of the trees. And how institutional investors handle that is entirely different from the Government or other private investors -- which makes it more lucrative for them and is why environmentalists favor them. Owning timberland isn't just a matter of planting trees and cutting them down. Hancock employs econometric models to determine future timber demands and wood and paper prices and then decides from that what types of trees to plant, when to harvest them and how to manage that growth.
"Our biggest risk isn't what happens to the trees," said Mr. Smith of Hancock. "It's what happens to the economy."
Right now, Hancock economists are predicting rising prices in the next three to four years as the economy grows and the supply of commercial timber shrinks. But should the economy falter and supplies stabilize, returns could soften. Even Hancock acknowledges that today's returns are high and predicts that returns will settle over time at a 9 to 15 percent annual rate.
By meshing biology and finance, institutional owners try to determine the economically peak time to cut their trees. If a tree is cut before its time, money is forgone; if it grows too much, it runs the risk of becoming infested or damaged and less valuable. Here, where soaring pines form a canopy under the sky, Hancock foresters practice selective cutting: thinning away small, scrawny trees, which allows for more nutrients to reach the healthier trees so they grow bigger and stronger -- and fetch more money. There is virtually none of the clear-cutting that has scarred so much of the West and degraded the landscape. Genetic altering -- or the practice of mixing the seeds of the best-looking trees -- is used to produce better and more marketable trees. What is more, Hancock employs modern equipment, like the sawhead feller, which shields workers in a metal cab from the danger of falling trees and limbs.
"Institutional owners manage the forests better than anyone else," said John Turner, president of the Conservation Fund, a nonprofit group in Arlington, Va., and the director of the Fish and Wildlife Service in the Bush Administration. "They are much more careful in their cutting practices. They invest in good biology. Their people are better trained. They are better at dealing with endangered species. They know the dynamics of the forest, when to plant and when to cut."
This differs from many wood and paper products companies, which viewed their forests simply as a source of raw material to keep their mills running, and from private owners, who cut trees when they needed money and had fewer resources to invest in forest maintenance. In Virginia, Hancock avoids harvesting near streams, knowing that maintaining water quality is important to the future of their forests. It protects the habitat of the red-cockaded woodpecker, an endangered species, by maintaining vegetation needed for it to thrive. And it provides the necessary controlled fires to maintain a rare type of flora that has forest fires as part of its ecosystem.
Fire is the biggest physical threat to these investments and to protect against destruction, Hancock and other forest managers spread out the investors' parcels so they are not all in one spot. As a result, if a forest fire breaks out, it destroys a small number of trees owned by many, not all the trees of one investor. Such geographic diversification also protects investors' trees from localized insect infestations.
Besides maintaining forests so they will produce for decades, such sound forest practices also help attract pension funds, which are sensitive about their public images.
"We are careful in that we want our forest management to be good for the environment," said Roger C. Franz, an investment officer at Calpers, which has seen its $488 million timberland investment in 1988 grow to $832 million today. The same holds true in the corporate pension world. "We think we are adding value to the world," Thomas Judge, a vice president at the A.T.& T. Investment Management Corporation, said of his company's $100 million timber investment.
BESIDES, say investment managers, after hours of looking at complicated prospectuses and holding mind-numbing conversations with investment bankers, spending time learning about the economics of trees and talking to people in flannel shirts instead of suits is a refreshing change.
"The people who call on us are not the financial types," said Terry Denzer, director of investments at the Hoechst Celanese Corporation, which has $5 million in timber investments. "They are usually tree experts with master's or Ph.D.'s in forestry. We learn all about trees, and it's fascinating. It's almost as though the returns are the icing on the cake."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Hancock's Richard N. Smith inspects a tree marked for preservation. (Len Rothman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
A 'Freshened' Jaguar Adds V12 Power

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon 

 BODY:
ALL right, enough about snow and ice and antilock brakes and skids and winter. Let's talk about something less mundane. Let's think sun and clear roads and let's talk Jaguars.
True, there is a certain silliness in it all. The basic car costs $51,750, and if you think that is expensive then you may think the rest of the line exorbitant. Also true, the car is English and has spent years honing a reputation for frequent vacations at the repair shop. But there is a mystique that is equally well earned. 
 Jags have loyal (nay, fanatical) fans, and the cars' sleek and luxurious personas, along with behavior that is quick and taut, have made them icons in the luxury field.
That is the reason Ford paid $2.5 billion for the Coventry company in 1989. At the time, many in the industry thought the price was too high, even for a name that conjures so much reverence. Since then, too, Ford has poured more money into Jaguar in an effort to expunge the persnickety, while keeping the nice.
But sales have grown, albeit slowly in an industry that is still struggling to put recession behind it. Overall, sales were up 22 percent last year, and they rose 47 percent in the United States. New York, California and Florida accounted for much of the increase, continuing a trend that has made this country Jaguar's biggest market.
For 1994, the key word is "freshening," although some of the changes -- like a standard passenger air bag -- are welcome and overdue. Basically, there are three sedans and four versions of the XJS coupe and convertible, with the big differences being in trim and engines. Two powerplants are now available, a 4-liter six and a 6-liter V12. A five-speed manual transmission also can be had in the 4-liter XJS, but the sedans and the V12 sports cars send their power to the road through a four-speed automatic.
Prices for the XJS sports models range from $51,950 for the 4-liter coupe to $79,950 for the 6-liter convertible, and all convertibles now offer rear seating. But the big news is the return of the old V12, which made its first appearance in 1972 and which has been missing for a couple of years after its discontinuance in 1992.
Displacement has been increased from 5.3 liters by lengthing the pistons' stroke, but there are other refinements, too, and the current engine -- originally developed for 1993's limited edition XJR-S high-performance models -- now produces 278 horsepower in the XJS. Only 100 XJR-S's came to these shores, 50 of them coupes and the rest convertibles.
The V12, sorely lacking in the sedans for 15 years, also is back in the XJ12, which is the flagship four-door, and power for the heavier sedan has been increased to 301 horses. The in-line six is rated at 219 horsepower in the XJS and 223 in the XJ6 and in its fancier brother, the mid-level Vanden Plas sedan.
The test car was a bronze Vanden Plas, whose name honors a noted Belgian coach-building firm that was acquired by Jaguar in 1968. And while the talk of specifications may mean a lot to Jaguar buffs, the numbers count for little when you are in a car as smooth as this.
Actually, the sedan's body goes back to 1987, when it was thoroughly revamped. And it will be redone again for '95, with the new car -- code named X300 -- appearing next October.
For now, though, the sedan has been gussied up with new body moldings and new wheels, and its lines retain the pleasant swoop that car-watchers have long admired. The XJS has new cast-alloy wheels as well, but it also has new bumpers, an air dam on the front and a rear-deck spoiler.
While the sedan's exterior has had minimal changes, the interior benefits from the addition of the passenger air bag and a new front-passenger seat bolster for more protection in a crash. Unfortunately, though, the new air bag means no more glovebox, and the remote trunk release has had to be moved to the center console.
The car also now has an electrochomic mirror, which darkens automatically when high beams hit it from the rear, and there is standard wiring for a cellular phone. Foldaway cupholders have been added to the forward section of the console, and the seats have been redesigned.
In the tester, they were covered in cream-colored leather and were thoroughly comfortable -- although the power adjustments leave something to be desired. The buttons are mounted on the vertical sides of the inner footwells, and they are difficult to see and to manipulate. Headroom, too, might be improved, and a medium-tall occupant (my 6-foot-3-inch son) complained that his sandy hair was brushing the roof.
For '94, the company has tried to help driver ergonomics by moving the column stalks upward, but some of the controls -- notably those for cruise control and lights -- look like afterthoughts. A small keypad for the driver information center is located to the right of the steering column, and it too could be handier and better integrated.
Future Jags may not suffer these complaints, minor though they are. According to the company, a new computer technology called "Knowledge Based Engineering" has resulted in a major reduction in the time needed to change things -- as well as warning the designers about possible problems.
Resembling the animated characters in a video game, occupants are simulated and they provide instant feedback on interior design. For example, the "driver" comments on whether instruments are obscured from view or how well switches can be reached. If it's raining, the "computer people" describe visibility of the road ahead, and they tell the engineers about the ease or difficulty of opening the hood or loading the trunk.
The system uses a database that comprises real-world studies, technical manuals, legislation, the input of experienced designers, geometric relationships and structural, material and manufacturing requirements.
As for the speed of the application, Jaguar engineers recently cut the time it takes to design the basic structure of the inner panels of a hood from eight weeks to just one day. And quicker also meant better. Stiffness of the hood was doubled, without an increase in weight.
That bodes well for years hence, and there is an inkling of a small and front-wheel-drive Jag that would appeal to the masses. But for now, we have rear-drive tradition and lovely luxury. And if there is silliness in it, it is the silliness of love.

HEADLINE: On Reducing Employee Commuting

 BODY:
Re: "New Rules Nudging Companies to Reduce Employee Commuting," Jan. 16:
The Department of Transportation tells us that the High Occupancy Vehicle (H.O.V.) lanes that are opening in March will reduce traffic congestion. They hope to entice people into car pools by giving them a special lane in rush hours, thus reducing the number of cars on the road. I have my doubts. 
One problem is that the H.O.V. lanes are on the far inside, away from the exits. We will have cars missing their exits or making wild dives through heavy traffic to get off. The alternative is to get over well in advance, lessening the advantage of having the H.O.V. lane.
A worse problem will occur in the unlikely event of a car pool's obeying the 55 m.p.h. speed limit. Should this occur, there will quickly be 20 or more vehicles backed up behind the slowpoke. What are they going to do? If they just putt along in line, they lose the advantage of driving in the H.O.V. lane.
Instead, they will pass on the right, going into the next lane, which is going faster. This is extremely dangerous and will slow down the other lane too. One driver going 55 in the right lane snarls traffic badly enough. If you have one in the H.O.V. lane as well, it will choke the traffic flow from two sides. Traffic congestion might even get worse.
A better solution would be to raise the capacity of the highway by raising the speed limit. If cars go faster, there are fewer cars on the road. Slow drivers going 65 will impede traffic less than those going 55. Traffic flow, fuel economy and safety will improve. We've had 20 years to see that the 55 m.p.h. speed limit doesn't work. Let's get rid of it now.
 
WILLIAM N. HARRISON
Parsippany

HEADLINE: The World;
Myths Aside, Japanese Do Look for Bargains

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
AS the first-ever shipment of California rice was going on sale in Tokyo this month, 50 people lined up outside a Seiyu supermarket here before the doors opened. The entire load of 5,500 pounds, which would normally take three days to sell, was gone in two and a half hours.
Maybe it was just curiosity. Maybe it was the price -- half that of high-grade Japanese rice. Maybe it was the shortage of domestic rice, which is why the foreign stuff is being allowed in. In any event, it was the shattering of another myth about Japanese consumers. Who said they would never eat foreign rice? 
 With the United States and Japan on the brink of a trade war, on whose side are the Japanese consumers? Are they clamoring for imported products, which would make them a natural ally of the United States? Or do they have a predisposition to buy Japanese, representing just another hard-to-penetrate layer of Japan Inc.?
The United States, in this and previous trade battles, has portrayed itself as the champion of Japan's downtrodden consumers, who would see greater variety and lower prices if only imports could surmount various trade barriers. Japan tends to argue that the market is open and that if foreign products don't sell well, it is because vendors are not doing enough to meet the exacting standards of Japanese consumers.
 
Fear of Rice
 Perhaps the Japanese have a point. In some ways Japanese consumers do differ from Americans. But there is also evidence to support President Clinton's assumption that the Japanese consumer can be courted; for one thing, recession has made for more price-conscious comparative shoppers.
True, Japanese consumers have not poured out in support of recent American demands for greater access to Japan's automobile, telecommunications or insurance markets. But that is because an organized consumer movement barely exists here, and the consumer groups that do exist often seem closely aligned with certain businesses.
Many consumer groups opposed the opening of Japan's rice market with the argument that foreign rice would be tainted by chemicals. A few years ago, such groups also joined with small shopkeepers to oppose easing restrictions on large stores like Toys R Us, even though they usually offer lower prices.
But if consumers don't speak with their voices, they do with their wallets. And many foreign products, from Levi's jeans to Australian beef and French skis, are being snapped up. Take the Big Mac. McDonald's is the largest restaurant chain in Japan. Or the Macintosh. Last year Apple Computer's sales in Japan grew 75 percent, making it the second largest vendor of personal computers behind NEC, the Japanese giant.
"There's never been any evidence that consumers rejected a product because it is foreign," said George Fields, who has been a market researcher here for 27 years. If there is any reason for the failure of more products to sell here, he said, it is that the distribution system can block foreign products or raise their prices excessively. Indeed, others say, being foreign, especially for luxury products, is a plus. Foreign products are becoming even more acceptable because of the rise of the yen, which makes imports cheaper. The latest issue of Nikkei Trendy, a magazine about consumer life styles, features a cover story on the rush of imports under the theme "Beat the Japanese market."
The recession is also helping shatter other myths about Japanese consumers. A few years ago it was the gospel that Japanese consumers cared only about quality and service, not price. Lowering a price often made the product less attractive. But consumers now are shunning high-priced department stores, with their legions of obsequious sales clerks, in favor of discount stores. Mail order is also on the rise.
Still, Japanese consumers are far from identical to American or European consumers, particularly in their emphasis on quality. It's not enough here for a product to work. It must be perfect down to the paint job and elaborate packaging. This is a country, after all, in which farmers hang weights on budding cucumbers so that they will grow straight instead of curved.
Apple quickly learned that what was acceptable in the United States wouldn't pass muster here. "We had complaints from resellers because the manuals were upside down in the box," recalled Ian Diery, executive vice president. Jiro Yanase, whose company is the Japanese distributor of General Motors cars, likes to recall the time, about a decade ago, when he invited the head of quality control at General Motors to the pier in Yokohama, where Mr. Yanase had lined up 20 G.M. cars fresh off the boat and 20 of his customers. All the customers said they wouldn't buy any of the cars, generally because the paint was slightly scratched.
Another big difference between Japan and the United States is in how to advertise. The American approach -- talking directly about a product and showing how much better it is than Brand X -- would not be considered sporting here. "The basic characteristic of the Japanese is to try to be harmonious and avoid confrontation," said Hidekazu Aizawa, a manager at Dentsu Inc., Japan's largest advertising agency. "You do not like to show off clearly that you have an advantage."
Television commercials in particular are indirect. They aim to convey an image or a feeling, or to capture attention with humor or a poignant story. Then, at the end, the product is mentioned, followed by the company logo and perhaps a slogan. English slogans, even if a bit odd, are often used. A while back, when Coca-Cola was describing itself as "the real thing" in most of the world, its slogan in Japan was "I feel Coke."
But some American companies are having success breaking the taboo. A couple of years ago, General Motors ran advertisements that compared its cars with Japanese ones in an effort to dispel the notion that American cars are too large, too expensive and too wasteful of fuel. Pepsi has taken on Coke and Compaq Computer Corporation has compared its computers with those of NEC.
Now, even some Japanese businesses like long distance phone companies are comparing themselves to Japanese competitors, while some retailers blare low prices on TV. "The Japanese are gradually changing," said Mr. Aizawa. "Consumers' eyes are becoming more strict."

HEADLINE: The World;
Mutual Need Ties Dictator And Dissident In Myanmar

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON

DATELINE: YANGON, Myanmar

 BODY:
DAW AUNG SAN SUU KYI, the world's most famous political prisoner, has met her jailer only once. It was in January 1989, and the setting was the airy colonial-era villa at 56 University Avenue in northern Yangon, the family home of the Burmese opposition leader.
Her mother had died, and Lieut. General Khin Nyunt, the powerful head of military intelligence, had come to pay his respects on the eve of the Buddhist funeral procession, a event scented with jasmine and joss sticks that would see thousands of Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi's followers line the streets to mourn her famous mother, the widow of Myanmar's independence hero, Aung San. By all accounts, the meeting was cordial. 
 It was only six months later that this same house became Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi's prison, the detention order approved by the same general. And the question on which the political future of their 43 million countrymen may now hang is whether Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi, the defiant Nobel Peace laureate, and General Khin Nyunt, the cunning strongman, will meet again.
"I think the future of Burma will be determined by two people -- Khin Nyunt and Aung San Suu Kyi," said Representative Bill Richardson, a New Mexico Democrat who last week became the dissident's first non-family visitor since 1989. "What is critically important is for these two individuals to get to know each other."
To a degree that neither is now likely to admit, Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi and General Khin Nyunt have come to need the other's help. Diplomats say she needs the general if she is ever to resurrect the shattered Burmese democracy movement and to win her own freedom, and the general needs her help if Myanmar is to end decades of economic stagnation and political isolation.
Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi (pronounced awng sahn sue chee, with each syllable equally stressed) called for talks with the military even before she was placed under house arrest. She repeated that call last week. "I don't see any problem with sitting down with anybody," she said.
So the next move belongs to General Khin Nyunt. In recent years he has been described by foreign diplomats and scholars as the new strongman of Myanmar, the nation still better known by its colonial name, Burma.
By turns ruthless and pragmatic, General Khin Nyunt almost certainly made the final decision to allow Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi to break her silence last week, a calculated risk intended to blunt international criticism of the junta that has run Myanmar since 1988, when the army killed thousands of her supporters as it crushed democracy demonstrations in Yangon and elsewhere.
General Khin Nyunt is in his mid-50's and is a protege of Myanmar's former strongman, General Ne Win. But he does not appear to share his mentor's penchant for the erratic and the irrational.
During a quarter-century of absolute power, General Ne Win took his policy advice from astrologers and numerologists -- Myanmar currency comes in denominations of 45 and 90 because Ne Win, like many Burmese, thinks 9 and its multiples are lucky -- while General Khin Nyunt is said to prefer the less-mystical counsel of economists.
General Ne Win was willing to turn Myanmar into a pauper nation under inept and xenophobic policies known as the "Burmese Way to Socialism." Diplomats say his protege seems to understand that unless something is done about Myanmar's economic misery, the result could be new public protests, perhaps even a revolution. Despite recent market reforms, Myanmar remains one of the world's poorest nations, with severe malnutrition and some of the highest infant mortality rates in Asia.
The general has still not said whether he will enter into talks with Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi. "It's a tricky decision for him," said a Western diplomat in Yangon. "If he accepts the offer, the international community and foreign investors will obviously applaud the move. But it would also mean admitting that Aung San Suu Kyi is the legitimate leader of a legitimate movement."
Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi is just that. Her political party won a landslide victory in 1990 elections, despite her detention. The military disregarded the results, imprisoned many of the party's leaders and launched a smear campaign against her. The junta said that in her years away from Myanmar -- she was educated at Oxford and married a British academic -- she had forfeited any claim to a political role in her homeland.
If the leaders of the junta had hoped to break Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi's spirit by isolating her for years in the now-dilapidated family compound, they must have been sorely disappointed by what she had to say last week.
"I don't care if they deprive me of all of my privileges," she said. "They should not think that by making my personal conditions easier for me that this would in any way induce me to give up my convictions."
Still, to judge from her silences, there seems to be room for compromise. She was notably mute, for instance, about her neighbor across Inya Lake, General Ne Win, who is now in his early 80's and ailing but is said to retain veto power over the junta's decisions.
It has long been suspected by some of Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi's followers that it was her personal attacks on General Ne Win in interviews in June 1989 that led to her house arrest the following month. At least on the subject of the old general, Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi may have decided to it is best for now to hold her tongue.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi at a meeting with Representative Bill Richardson in Myanmar last Monday. (Kraipit Phanvut for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Nation;
It's Back! The Idea That Senators Hate to Love

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Amending the Constitution used to rank with going to war as an occasion for congressional solemnity. But in the next few weeks Congress may vote to require itself to balance the Federal budget -- a sort of "stop me before I spend again" injunction -- with less gravity, and less public attention than when it debates a crime bill or considers tinkering with campaign finance laws.
Last week, Democratic Senators Paul Simon of Illinois and Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the proposal's leading advocate and its signal enemy, conducted competing public hearings with little company other than their witnesses and C-SPAN camera crews. 
 In fact, the proposed 28th amendment raised two important issues that have received little attention.
One is that the Senate might actually pass it some time in the next couple of weeks. If it does, the House is likely to follow. Nobody is sure whether Senator Simon's side can muster the necessary two-thirds majority -- 67 if all 100 Senators vote. About 60 Senators have said they will support it. Mr. Simon spoke plausibly for himself and for Mr. Byrd when he said, "I don't have 67 solid votes and I don't think he has 34."
The second is that it could make a lot of difference if it becomes part of the Constitution. The debate that begins this week could lead directly, as sponsors hope, to newfound resolve to cut spending and perhaps raise taxes, with serious impact on the economy, although the two sides disagree over whether impact, in this case, would be recession or prosperity. Some recipients of Federal money would surely lose more than others, although everybody wouldn't lose everything, as the Clinton Administration seems to suggest in its arguments against the amendment. And it would be difficult to increase spending during a recession to help the needy.
Of course, come 2001, when the amendment would probably take effect, the Congress and the President might fail to find any new supply of courage. The Federal courts might have to figure out tax rates, troop levels and welfare standards. And, in Senator Byrd's view, the fundamental power of Congress would be crippled and the Constitution not merely amended but transformed.
But the country seems to be paying little notice. Mr. Simon claims broad public backing, shown by polls, but acknowledges "it may not reach the form of letters and telegrams and phone calls." Some of the ennui derives from the fact that the issue has been around a long time and has come close but never passed. However, it may have more to do with the impression that this is all a political stunt pitting proponents (cowardly phonies pandering to the booboisie of call-in radio) against opponents ( greedy phonies cloaking their commitment to pork behind cheap efforts to scare the elderly and unfilled pledges to do better).
Those caricatures are not wholly the product of cynical imaginations. But that picture fails to capture a sizable body of Senators. Take William S. Cohen, a thoughtful Maine Republican no one considers a political panderer. He used to oppose the amendment as disruptive constitutional clutter. He changed his mind last year and decided it was the only way to accomplish an essential end. On the other hand J. Bennett Johnston, a Louisiana Democrat who backed the plan when he thought it had no chance, turned to opposition last fall fearing it would prove to be more than a slogan.
But they are not the whole Senate. Probably about half the Senate thinks the proposal is a good idea on its merits with some political benefit in it too. More than a quarter thinks it is dreadful. The issue will be decided by Senators who are weighing its political value to themselves against the damage they fear it would cause. And they must be wondering just how angry Mr. Byrd, who still controls spending as chairman of the Appropriations Committee, might get with them if they vote for it.
