HEADLINE: The Nation;
Tides That Brought Democrats to G.O.P. Have Turned

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE Republican bumper stickers that proliferated after the 1992 election read: "Don't Blame Me. I Voted For Bush." The Democrats have finally come up with a rejoinder: "Thank Me. . . I Voted Clinton-Gore!"
The market for these newly minted red, white and blue stickers may be bigger than once thought. For all of President Clinton's troubles, for all the conflicting ideological messages and for all the flaws in the Democratic political operation, for all the noise from Senator Bob Dole, the language from the White House seems to be catching on. It is meant to hold on to the liberal camp while building a bridge to more centrist terrain. 
 There has been a small yet significant movement of people to the Democratic fold. It began even before the 1992 election and accelerated throughout Mr. Clinton's first year in office.
For the first time since 1976, the Republican Party is no longer gaining at the expense of the Democrats. While the nation's basic partisanship -- the degree to which people think of themselves as Democrats, Republicans or independents -- remains closely balanced, Democrats have widened their advantage in partisan loyalty to 8 percentage points over Republicans, twice what it was five years ago. The shift comes equally from people who identify themselves as Republicans and independents, according to a series of New York Times/CBS News polls over the last 18 years.
"They're getting credit for going back to the center," said Kevin Phillips, a Republican analyst who predicted years in advance the realignment of the old Democratic South to the Republican Party. "It is significant because if you broke out issues which the Democrats made the most gains -- you'd get crime and welfare reform. That gives them a booster shot. That's also bad news for the Republicans." Yet Mr. Phillips asserted that the movement should not be overemphasized because there is no suggestion that "the Democrats are establishing anything that's got any depth."
Indeed, the trend hardly portends a major party realignment. The biggest question is still where the 19 million people who voted for Ross Perot in 1992 will end up in this year's mid-term elections and in the 1996 Presidential race.
But the Democrats' gains are not simply from fallen-away members who were drawn back to the fold in the afterglow of Mr. Clinton's winning the White House, and they suggest that the party has the potential to win over a significant proportion of independents. The possibilities among younger voters are particularly striking: For the first time since 1984, more Americans in the 18-to-29 age group identify themselves as Democrats than Republicans (31 percent to 29 percent). This is important because the loyalties of younger voters often stick with them for life, and the young tend to reflect the way political forces are moving.
 
The Importance of Loyalty
 Though the position of political parties has declined with the advent of television in recent decades, party loyalty is still important: It gives the dominant party a starting advantage in an election year. And polls on voter loyalty are even more reliable indicators of public sentiment than voter-registration figures, which are incomplete and often biased toward the dominant party in any local jurisdiction.
Martin P. Wattenberg, a political scientist at the University of California at Irvine, said the pattern favoring Democrats is "really reactive to the President's overall approval and the economy." What is more significant, he said, is what the numbers say about Republicans. "The fact that some of the gains have receded is another indicator that the Democrats are going to be a majority party in the Congress and the state legislatures well into the 21st century," he said. "The Republicans are slipping."
The Republicans, of course, are also furious. Mr. Clinton is stealing their best lines on the biggest issues of the day, from crime to welfare reform. (He even cited an old health care proposal of Richard M. Nixon in his State of the Union Message last month.) The American public, polls show, barely distinguishes the parties in their ability to reduce the budget deficit or curb crime.
Frank Luntz, a Republican pollster who advised Mr. Perot in 1992, fears that Democrats could be gaining an edge in winning over the Perot voters. Watching Mr. Clinton deliver the State of the Union Message, he said, "sent a shiver down my spine -- no one's hearing what the Republicans are saying. The Democrats control the White House, the Congress, the bully pulpit."
Even if the Democrats can sustain and build on their gains, a return to the party's dominance of two decades ago would be difficult to imagine. In 1976, as the country was still reeling from Watergate and Jimmy Carter was elected President, 40 percent identified themselves as Democrats, and 20 percent as Republicans. But the edge diminished in the years of the Reagan Administration, as the Republicans absorbed supporters of George C. Wallace and the right-leaning "Reagan Democrats."
Had the Republicans been able to re-elect George Bush, the stage might have been set for them to finally overtake the Democrats in partisan allegiance. Instead, Mr. Clinton fractured the Republican coalition, with considerable help from Mr. Bush, who could not keep up the momentum of the Reagan years, and from Mr. Perot.
Al From, president of the Democratic Leadership Council, a centrist organization from which Mr. Clinton developed many of his campaign positions, envisions a grand era of Democratic dominance that leaves little room for the liberals who are battling for a piece of the Clinton agenda.
"For the last quarter-century, the political debate has been on terms set by Republicans," said Mr. From, who sees the President's victory on the North American Free Trade Agreement as a turning point. More recently, he said, the debate has "been on terms set by Bill Clinton. He's on an agenda that goes right at the heart of what the Republicans have been using to build their party and to anchor their Presidential election dominance."
But Mr. From's analysis may be overly optimistic for the Democrats. After all, Jimmy Carter was unable to expand his party's coalition when he was President. And Gerald M. Pomper, a professor of political science at Rutgers University, contended that the party-loyalty figures are relatively soft -- and could again slip.
"Being in office means you can do good," Mr. Pomper said. "And, that you can screw up."

HEADLINE: Word For Word/North Korea's Press Agency;
Mouthpiece of the 'Great Leader': Bombast, Bile and Bowling News

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
NORTH KOREA may be the Hermit Kingdom, but some of the hermits labor long and hard at the typewriter. Every day, all across Northeast Asia, antiquated teletypes clatter out the official line of the Korean Central News Agency, a mix of bombast, threats, denouncements and, on occasion, quirky glimpses of life in one of the world's most closed nations.
Last week, when the North reversed itself and said the International Atomic Energy Agency would finally be permitted to resume inspections of the country's suspected nuclear arms installations, the press agency barely mentioned it. But there was other big news: the Democratic People's Republic of Korea now has its own bowling alley, a 40-lane extravaganza in Pyongyang for the benefit of the followers of the "Great Leader," Kim Il Sung, and his 52-year-old son, the "Dear Leader," Kim Jong Il. Now the faithful can share a passion for tenpins after a hard day's work up at the reactor. 
 No one examines the agency's dispatches more carefully than the United States, looking for subtle changes in tone that may signal big shifts in strategy. Last week's nuclear concession, for example, was foreshadowed by a report last weekend calling for dialogue to settle the nuclear issue -- an oddly conciliatory change of pitch. But the clues are slim and disconnected, so North Korea watchers, like Kremlinologists before them, have to be on their toes.
"The bowling balls!" one said in Seoul the other day in mock horror. "They're round and dark and heavy, right? We've been looking for the bomb cores everywhere, and we missed the bowling balls!"
Here, in the North Koreans' own idiosyncratic English, are some recent samples of the world according to Pyongyang. DAVID E. SANGER
 
What a guy
On Kim Jong Il's 52nd birthday last Wednesday:
An endless stream of people are visiting the old home at Mount Paektu secret camp, the time-honored holy place of revolution where Comrade Kim Jong Il was born . . . [Historians believe he was actually born in the Soviet Union, where his father had retreated in the battle against the Japanese occupiers of Korea.]
With his rare leadership ability the Dear Leader has brilliantly carried out many difficult and complex tasks in accomplishing the socialist cause of our times, performing immortal feats for the times and the revolution . . . The great trait of the singlehearted unity of our society now is a brilliant crystallization of the Dear Leader's benevolent politics, a politics of love and trust. Feb. 16
 
What a town
On the recent visit of the Rev. Billy Graham:
Pyongyang is beautiful, clean and wonderful and all people have a smile on their faces, he said, adding that their vigorous looks show the spirit of the Korean people . . . He pointed out that the United States and the former Soviet Union are to blame for the division of Korea. Jan. 31
 
Still more good news (sort of)
On the North Korean economy:
A new great progress has been made in all fields of Socialist construction, though the targets of the total scope of industrial output and some major indices including electric power, steel and chemical fiber envisaged in the third Seven-Year Plan failed to be attained due to international events and the acute situation created in Korea . . .
No politico-ideological offensive, economic blockade and military threat on the part of the imperialists and reactionaries can ever frighten the Korean people and no force on earth can block them from advancing under the leadership of the party. Dec. 9
 
The puppet . . .
On Kim Young Sam, the South Korean President:
Only yesterday he reduced the North-South agreement and joint declaration on denuclearization to a waste paper overnight and today he entreated 'tough sanctions against the North' . . . This was an act of a most despicable traitor dyed to the marrow in flunkyist spirit. Nov. 27
 
 We are prepared either for dialogue or for a war . . . The Kim Young Sam puppet clique must stop at once the criminal acts to make the fellow countrymen victims of nuclear holocaust, following outside forces, and unconditionally discontinue flunkyist treacheries and moves for North-South confrontation.
Jan. 30
 
. . . And the puppet-master On America's motives:
The U.S. hard-line conservative forces are promoting in full scale the supply of Patriot missiles to the U.S. troops present in South Korea under the pretext of coping with the D.P.R.K.'s "missile attack."
The U.S. Administration hurriedly dispatched the director of the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency to South Korea at the beginning of the new year to have a confab for "the intensification of intelligence against North Korea" and is operating in South Korea an "intelligence supporting team" composed of specialists of the C.I.A. and the Defense Intelligence Agency. This clearly indicates that the new war provocation moves of the United States against the D.P.R.K. have reached a full-scale stage. Feb. 2
 
Some 'Team Spirit'
On the military exercises held annually by the United States and South Korea:
Now some quarters of the United States are raising a noisy row as if the discontinuation of the "Team Spirit" joint military exercises were a big concession, but, in fact, the maneuvers are an act of nuclear threat . . . The United States would be well advised to give up the idea of using the discontinuation of the war game as a bargaining chip. Dec. 9
 
You should talk
On Japan's plans to recycle reactor fuel into plutonium for civilian power plants:
It is not a secret that Japan has already embarked upon the road of nuclear armament and South Korea, too, is developing nuclear weapons. This notwithstanding, the Japanese and South Korean authorities are perpetrating such rash acts as laying hurdles in the way of the D.P.R.K.-U.S. talks, flouting the world opinion over our non-existent "nuclear problem." Nov. 11

HEADLINE: Downside to Ending of Cold War: Opportunities in Science Dwindle

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

 BODY:
With the end of the cold war, jobs in mathematics and the physical sciences have sharply dwindled in the United States, spoiling the lifelong dreams of some students, throwing professionals out of work and possibly dulling the cutting edge of research itself.
Although Americans still win Nobel Prizes and publish thousands of papers, some scientists are deeply disturbed by this trend. They say the lack of jobs, and declining national support of science when the puzzles yet to be solved are more and more difficult, have begun to sap the vigor of American research. 
 The decline in support is reflected at universities, which are cutting the number of doctoral-level candidates they teach, and in board rooms, where companies are demanding more and more that science have some immediate, practical use.
 
Who Is Hurt Most?
 Those alarmed by the trend see grave consequences, both intellectual and personal. They sense a lessening of the free-wheeling intellectual approach that had given many researchers the freedom to pursue offbeat ideas. And they say that the job cutbacks will especially hurt women and members of minorities, who have long been underrepresented in the classroom and the laboratory.
Reflecting the new practical approach, an executive at a large electronics corporation said: "Our scientists have won enough Nobel Prizes to last the company for a long time to come. What we need now is focused research aimed at making a profit for this company. I'm talking about bottom-line commercial survival."
"Focused research" is also a major new theme at the National Science Foundation, one of the main Federal agencies financing research in the United States. The foundation has received steady increases in money each year, and the White House has called for an increase of 6 percent for the coming year, to $3.2 billion.
 
A Senator Speaks Out
 But a Senate appropriations subcommittee headed by Senator Barbara Mikulski of Maryland has demanded that 60 percent of the foundation's budget "maximize the return on the public's investment in science and technology and to insure that Federal resources are used efficiently and appropriately."
This has translated, many scientists argue, into increased spending on technology applications at the expense of basic scientific research, the traditional role of foundation spending.
The job market appears to be getting worse with each wave of corporate layoffs and university grant reductions. Many scientists and mathematicians have been compelled to seek jobs outside their fields, or to accept temporary academic or industrial positions with neither security nor benefits.
In the magazine Physics Today, Dr. Leo P. Kadanoff, MacArthur Professor of Physics and Mathematics at the University of Chicago, recently wrote that in America "all the props for science have begun to weaken." He added: "Government has become unpopular. The military has started to shrink. Corporations are concerned with tomorrow's stock value and have lost interest in promoting applied research."
Moreover, he said, "Nothing we scientists do is likely to arrest our decline in numbers, support or social value."
Much of the science that academic and manufacturing employers have been buying in recent years has been at cut-rate prices, and professional societies representing scientists object to what they see as exploitation.
Last month the American Mathematical Society passed a resolution condemning "the systematic hiring at United States colleges and universities of unemployed Ph.D.'s part-time at substandard salaries."
 
Too Many Applicants
 The few really desirable academic positions open to physicists are swamped with applicants; two years ago, 813 physicists applied for a single tenured opening at Amherst College.
Many colleges and universities have halted the hiring of permanent tenured scientists, and in some cases scientists who retire are not replaced. The national laboratories -- Lawrence Livermore, Los Alamos and others -- are struggling to shift away from military research to civilian applications, and they face further staff reductions.
Industries have been eliminating jobs in the sciences and engineering. The pharmaceutical industry alone laid off 27,000 people last year.
With the recent decision by Congress to halt construction of the superconducting supercollider particle accelerator in Texas, more than 1,000 scientists and engineers lost their jobs. Many are seeking positions at particle-accelerator laboratories in Europe, but there is a shortage of research money there.
 
Memories of Sputnik
 At a recent meeting of biochemists in New York City, participants said that the same political and economic forces that killed the supercollider are cutting into all branches of science.
"After the Soviet Union launched the first Sputnik satellite in 1957, the United States practically drowned scientists in money, for fear of losing the space race and the cold war," Dr. Richard L. Chappell, a biochemist, said at the meeting. "Big science budgets helped all branches of science. But now Washington and Moscow are at peace, and the supercollider is just one of the scientific enterprises likely to fall victim to the end of the cold war."
As the job market for scientists contracts, some universities -- Cornell and Pennsylvania State among them -- have already cut the number of graduate science students, especially would-be physicists.
Among the likely casualties of the bleak employment situation is a decade-long campaign by educators and government officials to recruit more women and members of minorities into the core sciences -- physics and chemistry, as well as engineering and mathematics. Only about 8 percent of the doctoral degrees in physics are earned by women, and about 1 percent by blacks.
 
Creating Disappointment?
 Some critics question the wisdom of efforts to recruit women and non-white scientists, efforts which include a campaign by the National Science Foundation. "Are they doing these minorities a favor?" asked Kip Kimbrough, an Atlanta consultant, in a letter to Chemical and Engineering News. "They seem to be training them for jobs that do not exist."
Many scientists are angry at the National Science Foundation, which in 1987 predicted that by the year 2010 there would be a shortage of scientists and engineers in the United States of 692,000. The foundation's prediction clashed with other findings that the job market was already shrinking.
The foundation's data seems to have been overtaken by workaday experiences. The most recent job data collected by the foundation are for the year 1991, and they do not suggest a shortage of scientific jobs. The foundation calculated that only 1.4 percent of doctoral-level scientists and engineers in the United States were unemployed in that year, and only another 1.7 percent were under-employed.
But Melissa Pollak, an official of the foundation's Science Resources Division, said figures for 1993, which will be available next fall, may show a large change. "A lot of professional associations have been documenting widespread hardship," she said.
 
Too Many Doctors?
 A recent survey by the American Institute of Physics found that in 1992, the most recent year for which it obtained data, the number of job openings for doctoral-level physicists at universities, national laboratories and industry was about 800. Competing for these jobs, along with older physicists, were 1,350 scientists who received their Ph.D. degrees that year.
Not only are universities over-supplying Ph.D. physicists, critics say, but the employment situation has been exacerbated by highly qualified scientists from abroad. Roughly 48 percent of the new physics Ph.D. degrees awarded in the United States in 1992 went to foreign students, of which the largest group came from China. Under the 1992 Chinese Student Protection Act, these students can apply for permanent American visas, and according to the American Physical Society, nearly all of them do so.
"A lot of able young people are stacked up in the holding pattern," said Dr. Dudley R. Herschbach, a Nobel laureate and chemistry professor at Harvard University. "If the economy picks up, it should help. But meanwhile, many new Ph.D. chemists are taking unconventional jobs."
Dr. Herschbach's daughter Brenda, who was awarded a Ph.D. in biochemistry last July, now works for a Boston patent law firm and plans to study for a law degree.
"Thirty-five years ago when I was starting my work on molecular-beam chemistry," Dr. Herschbach said, "the off-beat ideas of young scientists were met with enthusiasm. I no longer see that. The government providers of science funding no longer seem supportive of free, basic research and the wild ideas that can lead to great science and wonderful applications."
Dr. Herschbach was awarded a Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1986 for his pioneering investigation of chemical reactions taking place in intersecting beams of molecules.
 
Jobs Far Afield
 Dr. Phillip Schewe, a spokesman for the American Institute of Physics, suggested that "physics education must redirect itself," adding: "A physics student probably should no longer aspire to become a physics professor, but should be prepared to take jobs that may seem far afield from science -- jobs in which the training in rigorous thinking a physicist receives can be put to profitable use."
Just such a transition was made recently by Dr. Stella Sung, who was awarded a Ph.D. in chemistry by Harvard University last spring. Dr. Sung's work on the quantum-mechanical analysis of molecular reactions appeared to be the beginning of a very promising career. Instead, she took a job in Boston at Corporate Decisions Inc., a management strategy consultant.
"There aren't many tenure-track academic positions for chemists, and what jobs there are, are not very well paid," she said. "But that's only one reason for my decision. What I loved as a graduate student at Harvard was not specific scientific knowledge about things like harmonic oscillators, but the principles of thinking and solving problems. I have found the intellectual freedom I love in solving that kind of problem as a management consultant. More and more, young scientists are going to have to look outside science."

(Rick Friedman for The New York Times) (pg. 36)

HEADLINE: Croats and Bosnians Hold Talks in Germany

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ZAGREB, Croatia, Feb. 19

 BODY:
Facing the threat of economic sanctions for sending troops into neighboring Bosnia, Croatia joined talks in Frankfurt today aimed at stopping fighting between Croats and Muslims in western and central Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Top officials of the Bosnian and Croatian governments took part in talks organized by Charles E. Redman, President Clinton's special envoy for Yugoslavia. Earlier this week, Croatian officials described the negotiations as an effort toward normalizing relations between the two former Yugoslav republics. 
 After nearly eight hours of talks, Bosnian Prime Minister Haris Siladjzic and Croatian Foreign Minister Mate Granic said that they had made progress in discussing a number of issues, including a possible cease-fire, and that their delegations would continue talks next week.
The Croats said they also put forward a plan of their own to resolve Bosnia's ethnic bloodshed by dividing the republic into seven ethnically-mixed cantons. The Bosnian side, which until now wanted to maintain a single unitary state, did not offer any public reaction to the plan.
The meeting was the latest in a series of high-level contacts between the two countries, including a meeting in Bonn last month between President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia and President Alija Izetbegovic of Bosnia.
Just as NATO and the United Nations now threaten air strikes on Bosnian Serb artillery positions over the siege of Sarajevo, the talks in Germany represent one of the more concentrated diplomatic efforts by the United States and Germany and other European sponsors to end the fighting between Croatian forces in Bosnia and their Muslim neighbors.
Nominal allies against the Serbs during the early fighting that followed the breakup of Yugoslavia, Bosnian Croats and Bosnian Muslims have become bitter enemies over the last year as they have fought over the 30 percent of Bosnia that is not controlled by Serbs.
Among other things, the warfare has led to the eight-month siege of the ancient town of Mostar, where thousands of Muslims remain trapped and harassed by Croatian snipers and heavy guns hiding in the surrounding valley. According to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, the siege claimed 37 lives just during the first nine days of February.
Arguing that it is defending its Bosnian brethren with armed "volunteers," Croatia has become deeply involved in the fighting, with the United Nations estimating that Zagreb has deployed 5,000 regular troops alongside Bosnian Croat irregulars.
Two weeks ago, the United Nations Security Council demanded the immediate withdrawal of the Croatian troops, telling Zagreb that it faced serious measures, including sanctions like those imposed on Serbia for its role in the Bosnian Serbs' war against the Bosnian Government.
But until now, United Nations observers here say, there is little sign the Croats are pulling out. Rather, there is some evidence the Croats are deliberately concealing their presence.
Even so, there are signs the Croats are not faring well against the Muslims. By one account, they have lost 40 percent of the territory they held only last April in central Bosnia.
The decision to seek a diplomatic solution may derive from a growing feeling on the part of both Bosnian Muslims and Croats that the time has come to seek mutual advantage once more against the more powerful Serbs.
At the same time, some people in the Croatian Government, prodded by the United States, have moved to distance themselves from Croatian militias.
Earlier this month Mate Boban, the hard-line Bosnian Croat leader, was forced to resign under pressure from Zagreb. Mr. Boban has advocated the division of Bosnia along ethnic lines.
Just as Croatia may now be turning to negotiations to help resolve a deteriorating military situation with the Muslims, Zagreb embarked last month on an effort to normalize relations with Serbia, with whom the Croatian Government fought a war in 1991.

HEADLINE: TYING EDUCATION TO THE ECONOMY

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 19

 BODY:
As the television camera lights glared, 17-year-old Kevin Weismann made his plea to the educators and politicians assembled in a conference hall here.
"All students should have the opportunity to explore the work world while they are still in high school," the high school senior said. "Sooner or later, everyone is going to be out in the workplace." 
 Mr. Weismann's brief comments went to the heart of the subject at hand: how to improve education in California.
The unusual two-day conference, called by the Speaker of the California Assembly, Willie L. Brown Jr., drew Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich and Education Secretary Richard W. Riley via satellite and more than 200 national and state education officials. The conference focused on the link between schooling and the economy, with a long discussion about job training for the many students who do not go on to college.
 
Staggering Deficiencies
 The national discourse on job skills and schooling has taken on new urgency here because of a widespread perception that California's flagging economy needs a strong public education system both to recover and to flourish. But the state's once-envied public school system now faces a staggering array of deficiencies: declining spending, growing class size and rising violence.
A voter-led ballot initiative to provide parents with vouchers to pay for private-school tuition also pressured lawmakers to organize the conference. Though voters rejected the initiative last year, the measure was an indication of Californians' rising dissatisfaction with public schools.
To counter the downward spiral, educators and state officials are urging stronger programs for students not bound for college, particularly school-to-work transition programs.
 
Looking to Job Training
 The Clinton Administration's education legislation, Goals 2000, already approved by Congress, emphasizes job training for high school students, as did the Bush Administration's plans. At the meeting, Mr. Reich announced a $750,000 grant to California to help overhaul its school-to-work transition programs, linking high schools to community colleges with apprenticeship-like components built in. To approach job training any other way, he said, "no longer meets the needs of the American economy or the American workplace."
States like Oregon are at the forefront of the movement. Three years ago the Oregon Legislature passed a broad education bill that included a redesign of its high school curriculum, in an effort to teach better job skills to students who are not bound for college.
The model, designed in part by Ira C. Magaziner, now a senior policy adviser to President Clinton, allows students in the 10th grade to choose courses that lead either to higher education or into the workplace. Those who select the workplace can pick forestry, telecommunications, commercial shipbuilding, a range of health professions and other careers. At the same time, they must take mathematics, science, technology and other academic subjects. Ten high schools have such programs; by the 1996-97 school year, all schools will have to offer this choice.
 
The Education-Business Gap
 While there is widespread support in California for such efforts, there are also hurdles. The recession has significantly cut education spending, leaving little money beyond existing programs. And some people at the meeting said there was a communication gap between educators and businessmen.
"Business has sent mixed signals," said Lawrence Kemper, president of the California Association of School Administrators, which represents school superintendents, principals and assistant principals. "At one time, businesses told us they wanted people who would show up on time, treat our customers well and take coaching. Now they are demanding more, but so are we."
Corporate executives acknowledge that problems remain in overhauling public education to accommodate students more interested in work than in college. "This is a real mindshift for our society," said Jere Jacobs, assistant vice president of Pacific Telesis Group in San Francisco and a member of the education committee of the California Business Roundtable. To help public schools, he said, industries like telecommunications and banking are finishing an outline of academic courses and skills that students need to find jobs. But, he said, "there is a lot of work ahead of us."
 
Money and Political Will
 Indeed, educators and lawmakers said, it will take much more money and an equal part of political will to overhaul this state's job-training for students, 60 percent of whom do not graduate from four-year colleges. Mr. Brown, the Speaker, said that in the next month he and other legislative leaders would try to frame a legislative package for education, though he added that it was too early to be sure what issues would be addressed.
But Kevin Weismann, the student from Placer High School, north of Sacramento, said that if educators and politicians were listening to him they would know what to do. He works after school at a local Hewlett-Packard plant, where an engineer steeps him in the principles of advanced electronics.
"All of this will help me know what I need to know when I get into the workplace," Mr. Weismann said.

HEADLINE: A Hard Lesson on Trade for Mondale

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 19

 BODY:
To understand how deeply President Clinton was seeking to change the tone of trade diplomacy with Japan last year, it took only a few minutes with his Ambassador to Tokyo, Walter F. Mondale.
Mr. Mondale spoke not in the negotiator's patois of tariffs, import barriers and market-share targets but of his confidence that if Washington eased some of the public pressure on Japan's new reform-minded Prime Minister, he would open the country without the need for threats. 
Just weeks after arriving, Mr. Mondale seemed to validate what he described as a more dignified approach by personally negotiating an opening of Japan's construction market.
Today, Mr. Mondale speaks little of dignity. The former Vice President, who has said he was not drawn back into public service to spend his time badgering Japan over semiconductors and wood products, has nevertheless been forced to don the traditional trade warrior's garb of threats of sanctions and timetables.
 
'It's Getting Worse'
 Japan's trade surplus with the United States set a record last year, $59 billion, and President Clinton's yearlong experiment lies in tatters after the collapse of talks a week ago.
Mr. Mondale, like the Government he represents, has endured a harsh education in the way Japan works, an education made all the more bitter because Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa said from the time he took office last summer that he wanted the same sort of changes Washington was demanding.
"I don't think I came over here naive, but I thought I could do things a little differently, and I tried very hard," Mr. Mondale said in a conversation that he filled with details of the Japanese markets for cellular telephones, supercomputers and housing. "But what I found was that this pattern persisted.
"This isn't getting better, it's getting worse. We cannot sustain these current account and trade imbalances, and we are not going to just wait for the Government of Japan to take measures."
Mr. Mondale even dismissed his construction-market breakthrough last fall as a product of special circumstances, including a bribery scandal that turned the public against the protected construction companies.
 
One Import Item at a Time
 In a briefing for a group of reporters on Friday and in an interview later, Mr. Mondale made it clear that his thinking and that of the Clinton Administration had evolved in a number of critical respects.
One likely result appears to be a more adversarial posture in public as well as over the negotiating table, and a policy focused less on the abstract ideal of reducing Japan's surplus and more on specific instances where Washington believes Japan discriminates against imports.
That is one reason the Administration has put so much energy into the dispute over opening the Japanese market for cellular telephones. The Administration believes that this offers a blatant example of how an American company, Motorola Inc., was thwarted in its efforts to sell a product in Japan because of Government-sanctioned barriers.
There may well be more such narrowly focused offensives. The only remaining question is whether President Clinton will favor sanctions if disputes cannot be resolved.
 
Measuring the Markets
 One thing, however, will not change: the United States appears likely to become even more forceful in demanding that Japan agree to explicit goals in opening its markets. That was the key sticking point in Washington, and it is the point on which the Japanese have insisted they will not budge because, they say, such goals violate the principles of free trade.
"I think we have to have some way of measuring progress," Mr. Mondale said. "That's what history teaches us."
Jeffrey E. Garten, Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade, said: "One of the lessons from dealing with the Japanese for decades is that just because you don't get what you need the first time, doesn't mean you change your strategy. Our policy was right and we have no intention of changing it. Part of our problem was in how we presented our policy to the public."
One of Mr. Mondale's greatest disappointments has been the distance between the promises of change offered by Mr. Hosokawa and the reality.
Mr. Hosokawa has succeeded in enacting legislation to change the scandal-tainted electoral and campaign-financing system, the central promise he made last summer when his coalition replaced the Liberal Democratic Party after its 38 years in power.
In economic matters, however, it has been a very different story. Mr. Hosokawa has insisted that he will overcome resistance within the bureaucracy and deregulate consumer markets and the business world. But he has proven a good friend of the bureaucracy in a number of critical decisions.
"I don't mean to say that this is hopeless," Mr. Mondale said, "but I do mean to say that his record over the past four or five months has not been one of an economic reformer. We don't see any difference in the position of the bureaucracy and the Government."
 
An Omen Proves False
 The first signs that Mr. Hosokawa might not be as committed to economic change as expected came shortly after the construction-market agreement.
The Prime Minister had established a commission to propose measures to lift burdensome regulations and to jolt the economy out of a two-year recession, but when it issued its interim report in early November, the proposals were relatively toothless.
Then, at the summit meeting of Pacific nations in Seattle, Mr. Hosokawa met twice with President Clinton. At the second one, attended by Mr. Mondale, Mr. Hosokawa closed the conversation by quickly making several points about the trade talks.
He said that though he was in favor of opening Japanese markets, the talks were two-way; that the United States would have to respond to Japanese demands for change; that his Government did not intend to force changes in the private sector in important areas like the automotive or insurance markets, and that Japan would not agree to the "numerical indicators" of progress that Washington was demanding.
 
Tokyo on the Offensive
 The situation grew even more grim in early January. Not only did the Japanese negotiators stiffen their positions in meetings, but they also began a public offensive.
Just about every aspect of Washington's policy, even assertions that Japan's markets were closed, were refuted. The Ministry of International Trade and Industry and the Ministry of Finance issued papers arguing that in many instances, United States markets were actually the more restricted.
That was when Mr. Mondale began to signal to Washington that the process was going badly wrong.
"He has spent a tremendous amount of time alerting Washington to the shortfalls in how we were making our case to the public," said Mr. Garten, the Under Secretary. "We would have done much better if we had listened more to him, and at an earlier stage."
In the weeks preceding his Feb. 11 summit meeting with Mr. Clinton, Mr. Hosokawa finally passed his political reform bills. He then offered a package of measures to stimulate the economy that shocked many here, including some political allies: Mr. Hosokawa accepted the Finance Ministry's advice over that of some of his closest advisers and announced an immediate income-tax cut and a huge increase in a national sales tax after a few years.
 
No One Likes Taxes
 It was a bombshell that Mr. Hosokawa was forced to recant a day later, and that caused his high approval ratings to plummet. The proposed tax increase was wildly unpopular.
"Intellectually, it was not much of a surprise, but for an old Western politician, it was a shock," said Mr. Mondale, who has had some bitter experiences of his own after proposing tax increases in public. "Why would a sitting politician drink that hemlock?"
The move was of direct interest to the United States, since the Administration had insisted that Japan take bold measures to revive its economy. Faster growth would draw in more imports and naturally reduce the trade surplus.
Thus the failure to enact a strong stimulus package and the lack of progress in the talks on specific markets appeared to doom the summit talks this month in Washington. It also changed Mr. Mondale's message back in Washington considerably.
 
Change in Tone Is Complete
 "It would have contributed immeasurably to a successful summit conference because it would have been something we could have hung our hat on," Mr. Mondale said of the stimulus package. "It was a sour way to get started. It told us that deep down, we couldn't communicate with the Finance Ministry or the Government."
A week before the scheduled meeting, Mr. Mondale sent a toughly worded cable to Washington, arguing that the United States should not accept a watered-down deal just to have a deal. The message represented almost a complete reversal from the patient tone of Mr. Mondale's advice five months earlier.
He was thus not surprised when the summit meeting failed to produce an agreement. He will not comment on whether Washington will resort to sanctions in trying to force change in Japan. But he is firm in demanding change in a system that he clearly feels has let the United States down.
"I believe there's a chance for change here," he said. "Whether that occurs or not, I don't know. But if it doesn't, we will not accept the status quo."

HEADLINE: Mexican Rebel Leader Sees No Quick Settlement

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 19

 BODY:
On the eve of talks to resolve the peasant uprising in the southern state of Chiapas, the rebels' military commander discounted Government hopes of a prompt settlement, saying his troops would lay down their arms only after fundamental changes were made to democratize the Mexican political system.
In an interview on Thursday at a safe house in the mountains of Chiapas, the rebel leader, who calls himself Subcommander Marcos, said his Zapatista National Liberation Army would also demand broad autonomy for Indian regions of the country and a reorientation of the Government's economic policies. 
 The Zapatistas' insistence on sweeping national political and economic changes came weeks after Government officials announced that the insurgents had agreed to narrow their agenda to the problems of Chiapas, Mexico's second-poorest state.
 
Rift Within the Government
 Officials had described that condition as essential to persuading hard-line members in the administration of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari to support a negotiated settlement. But Marcos said the rebels had accepted the agenda only under Government pressure to get the dialogue started. He said they had never put aside their demands for national change and would not sign a peace agreement that did not fulfill them.
"We cannot believe that there can be a democratization of the state of Chiapas or the municipalities where the Zapatista National Liberation Army is located but not the rest of the country," he said. "We don't fool ourselves. Either the democratic process is national or there is not a democratic process."
The rebels' stand appears considerably tougher than what Government representatives were expecting to hear when they sit down with 15 rebel leaders and Catholic Church mediators on Monday in the colonial city of San Cristobal de las Casas.
Several officials have rejected the Zapatistas' position as impossible. And while Marcos said the rebels would not break a cease-fire that has held for five weeks unless attacked, others raised the prospect that the conflict, which began with barely a week of fighting, might drag on well beyond the presidential elections scheduled for Aug. 21.
 
'We Cannot Give Up'
 "We cannot give up things that will destabilize the political order, the social order or the basic economic strategy of the Government," Manuel Camacho Solis, the President's envoy to the talks, said in an interview on Friday in Mexico City. "The cost of doing that would be to increase conflict rather than reduce it."
The Zapatista demands clearly represent a bargaining position. But they also seem to reflect the rebels' belief that in the weeks since they declared war on the state just as the North American Free Trade Agreement was took effect on Jan. 1, they have galvanized an opposition to Mr. Salinas's policies that transcends their limited military strength.
"What is at stake in Chiapas is no longer just Chiapas or even Mexico, but perhaps even the free trade agreement or the whole neoliberal project in Latin America," Marcos said, referring to the wave of economic changes in Mexico and other Latin American countries. These have included openings to foreign trade, the privatization of state enterprises and the restoration of growth with little if any improvement in the lives of the poor.
 
Interview Site Concealed
 "Not because we have that moral force," Marcos added, "but because people are saying, 'All right, what happened here? What is going to happen elsewhere? What costs are there going to be?' " Motioning to the three reporters before him, he added, "If that were not true, you all would not be here."
The interview was the second that Marcos has given since he led the Zapatistas' seizure of San Cristobal and several large towns on Jan. 1, and the first to include a foreign news organization. It was also granted to reporters from the Mexican news magazine Proceso and an independent Mexican daily, El Financiero, on the condition that they not try to identify the remote location where it took place.
To make such identification impossible during a journey of more than six hours from San Cristobal, the reporters were transported in the back of a closed truck or required to cover their eyes. Their watches were taken away until the interview began at 3 A.M. on Thursday, and had to be surrendered again when it ended four and a half hours later.
As he has in the past, Marcos declined to divulge his real name or age. While he now stated directly that he had commanded the Zapatistas' military offensive, he continued to say his role was subordinate to the leadership of various "clandestine committees" made up almost entirely of Mayan Indian peasants.
He said the committees had not yet decided whether he would attend the peace talks.
As he sat on a rough-hewn bench, covered in a black wool poncho and bandoliers, wearing a black wool ski mask and guarded by young Indian guerrillas who dozed by their weapons, Marcos's manner suggested a man perhaps 35 or 40 years old, charismatic, highly intelligent and extraordinarily self-confident.
 
Speaks Some English
 His Spanish sounded only lightly Mexican, and he peppered his conversation with jokes and occasional phrases in a rough English. He said he had learned the language from Playboy magazine and Pentagon manuals.
Of his origins, he would say little more than that he had come from the Mexican provinces and completed college and graduate studies before setting out to form a guerrilla movement in Chiapas 10 years ago as part of a core of a dozen urban-born Mexicans.
He will not remove his mask in public, he said, because the Government refuses to recognize the Zapatista army's identity as anything but that of a "political party in formation." The rebels, he said, have no interest in becoming a political party.
Yet the recognition of autonomy that Marcos said the rebels would seek in the peace talks seems to be a far more difficult request.
Noting the tradition of self-government among the Indian communities that make up about one-third of the 3.2 million residents of Chiapas, he said the rebels would demand that elected leaders of predominantly Indian regions be given control over local political administration, regional economic development priorities and most police functions.
 
'Co-governors' Proposed
 He said the Zapatistas would also propose the election of "co-governors" from each of the six main Mayan-descended tribes of the state, and would push for the same sort of administration in other Indian communities around the country.
Government officials described this idea as virtually unthinkable, and they said the same for Marcos's call for the reorientation of Mexican economic policies so that states like Chiapas would not lag so far behind more prosperous manufacturing and agricultural states in the northern and central part of the country.
The officials said they would have little difficulty responding to other, more narrow demands that the insurgent leader detailed: for new hospitals and schools in Chiapas, new loans or subsidies for poor farmers, the redistribution of some agricultural lands, and small-scale manufacturing projects in areas where new land could not be had.
But to the broader demands for political and economic change that Marcos said the insurgents would present, the officials suggested that their response would be unyielding.
 
Government Seeks a Deal Now
 "If they do not take a deal now, they will turn into an extremist group isolated from the rest of the country," one official involved with the Chiapas conflict said. "If they don't see that, they will throw away the enormous prestige and support they have received, and bring all of the conservative forces in the country together against them."
If the Zapatistas were concerned by such a threat, Marcos gave no hint of it.
"We did not take up arms to appear in the newspaper," he said, his eyes flashing through the mask. "We took up arms so as not to die of hunger. If the Government does not heed our demands, the problem is going to continue and the war is going to continue, whether we appear in the newspapers or not.
"The Government does not have a lot of choices: either it solves the problems, or what happened on the first of January will take place again."

HEADLINE: Political Fanatics Find Pastime That Can Pay

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Feb. 18

 BODY:
The raucous United States Senate race in Virginia has a new side show: cash wagering. Befitting the age, the gaming takes place on computers in the form of a political stock market.
It is the latest offering of a 6-year-old experiment at the business school of the University of Iowa, in Iowa City, which has offered ventures resembling futures markets in 13 elections in seven countries. 
In the Virginia contest, participants set up an account of $5 to $500 and trade in shares of the three best-known candidates. The incumbent, Charles S. Robb, a Democrat, has been challenged by two Republicans who were officials in the Reagan Administration: Oliver L. North, the former National Security Council aide, and James C. Miller 3d, the former budget director.
Shares in a candidate will be worth a penny for each percentage of the vote he receives, so if a player buys Mr. North at 46 cents a share, and he wins 51 percent of the vote, it means a profit of a nickel a share.
"This is like the financial markets, only there is a definite day of reckoning -- Election Day," said one organizer, Dr. Douglas D. Davis, an economist at Virginia Commonwealth University in Richmond. "You read a bad press report about one of the candidates, and you can see the effect on the stock price that day."
And the prices seem to be a relatively accurate barometer of an election's outcome. Professors at the University of Iowa said that in the last two Presidential elections their venture came within two-tenths of a percentage point, closer than public opinion polls.
Dr. Robert Forsythe, a professor at Iowa and a founder of the market, said that in the 1992 Presidential election a journalist invested $500 and wound up with 7 cents, while a graduate student at Princeton University turned $35 into $800. One $500 investment paid $1,884, which was covered by the losses of other participants.
Although the Iowa Electronic Markets, as the venture is called, conducts business over Internet, the global computer network, Dr. Forsythe said a businessman from Cleveland who was fervent supporter of Ross Perot and had just discovered the market was so excited that he flew to the campus in 1992 to bet in person on Mr. Perot. When Mr. Perot withdrew briefly, the market recorded 1,500 computer transactions in half a minute, dropping his standing to near zero from 30 percent, the professor said.
 
Amusement and Diversion
 Although 90 percent of the venture's 2,000 traders now in the market are from universities, Dr. Forsythe said he hoped to broaden use by people with intense interest in politics by adding a service with a toll-free number. He said that in addition to the Virginia Senate race, organizers expected to start markets this year in the Senate contest in New Jersey and the campaign for governor of Maryland.
In Virginia, campaign officials say the market provides some amusement and a welcome diversion from a contest that involves virtually daily rounds of name calling. "If I buy Chuck Robb, is that insider trading?" asked his spokeswoman, Peggy Wilhide.
Students here at the University of Virginia began setting up accounts when the market opened on Jan. 31. Noah Flaxenburg, 21, a junior from Pottstown, Pa., said he was learning as much about political reality as economic theory. "To make money, you buy the more popular person, not the better person," he said.
The Virginia market has two sectors: the Republican nomination, to be decided at a convention on June 4, and the general election on Nov. 8.
Late Friday, Mr. North's nomination futures were priced at 64 cents, to 35 cents for Dr. Miller. Dr. Charles A. Holt, a University of Virginia economist, said that although Mr. North maintained a wide lead, the market led much of the public in realizing that Dr. Miller was likely to be a strong contender.
On Friday, Mr. Robb's general election price was 49 cents to 32 cents for Mr. North and 16 cents for Dr. Miller.
Dr. Holt said he had no concerns about candidates' sneaking peeks at the latest quotes. "What they care about is the polls," he said.

HEADLINE: Rutgers Seems to Like Its Stately, Stateless Image

BYLINE: By KIMBERLY J. McLARIN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Feb. 18

 BODY:
Proud, put-upon New Jersey, the butt of endless jokes, is also the only state in the country without a university to bear its name, exclusively speaking.
Oh sure, the system's official name is Rutgers, the State University of New Jersey. But during casual conversation, and more importantly it seems, during televised sports events, what is highlighted is Rutgers, while everything after the comma tends to be lost. 
 Which is why Donald T. DiFrancesco, President of the New Jersey Senate, has proposed dropping everything before the comma. If Rutgers truly is the state university of New Jersey, it should be the State University of New Jersey, he told The Associated Press. Or the University of New Jersey. "Or whatever's appropriate," he said.
"I went to Penn State University," he said. "You know when they play Southern Cal that these kids are from Pennsylvania. When Rutgers plays Southern Cal, the kids in California don't know Rutgers is the state university of New Jersey."
 
A Predictable Firestorm
 Predictably, Mr. DiFrancesco's comments have touched off a minor firestorm among Rutgers students and alumni, who say changing the name would diminish prestige, erase national name recognition and wipe out 227 years of the school's history.
The student newspaper, The Daily Targum, ran a front-page article in which a history professor called the proposed change "a crime of historic proportions." Rumors flew across the university's main campus in New Brunswick: the state would give Rutgers more money for changing its name; the state would reduce financing if Rutgers refused to acquiesce.
"I think its horrible," said Nicole Brown, president of the Douglass College Governing Association. Douglass is Rutgers' women's college. "The University of New Jersey could never carry as much prestige or tradition as the name Rutgers does."
Sean Reddington, a senior majoring in history, said: "If we changed the name, we'd lose the whole nostalgia bit," adding, "It'll become just another state institution."
 
Paul Robeson and 7 Governors
 Rutgers was founded in 1766 as Queens College and renamed in 1825 to honor Col. Henry Rutgers, a Revolutionary War hero and trustee. A year later, Mr. Rutgers gave the college $5,000.
The nostalgia includes beating Princeton in the first intercollegiate football game in 1869 and a slew of notable alumni, including Paul Robeson and seven New Jersey governors.
Today Rutgers graduates more than 9,000 students annually in nearly 100 different fields and is gaining ground in its drive to be recognized as a leading public research university.
"Rutgers is a very special institution," said Jotham Johnson, senior alumni director. "We enjoy a distinguished reputation as one of the leading public universities. People know Rutgers far and wide and any effort to wipe that clean would perhaps be a mistake."
This week, in an effort to stem what officials called a slow but steady decline in state aid, the university released a study detailing its impact on the New Jersey economy. In 1993, state funds made up 46 percent of Rutgers's $826.9 million budget.
 
No Reward or Penalty
 Rae Hutton, a spokeswoman for Mr. DiFrancesco, said the Senate President had no plans to penalize Rutgers for not changing its name, or to reward it for doing so. She said Mr. DiFrancesco, who was out of state for much of the week and could not be reached, was taken aback at the reaction to his suggestion.
"I don't think he expected there to be such controversy immediately," she said.
Ms. Hutton said Mr. DiFrancesco had been considering the name change for about 15 years and decided the time was right. He still plans to introduce a bill on the name change, possibly as early as Feb. 24, she said. But he will not spend a lot of time pushing legislators to act on the matter, she said.
"He realizes there are many other important issues," she said.
Not everyone associated with Rutgers is appalled at the idea. Wil Tenburg, a graduate student, says he doubts that most Rutgers students even know who Henry Rutgers was.
"A change in the name wouldn't affect me the least bit," he said.
 
Sweatshirts Would Change
 Kristen Sullivan, a sophomore, said, "There's a lot of school spirit here and I don't think that would change if we became the University of New Jersey. The only thing that would change would be the sweatshirts."
Rutgers alumni say that contrary to Mr. DiFrancesco's suggestion, they are proud of Rutgers's status as a public university and do not wish to hide that fact.
"We're proud to be a state university, but that alone is not enough," said Dorothy Stanaitis, president of the Rutgers Alumni Federation. "So many of us Rutgers people are, well, Rutgers people."
Whatever happens, Mr. DiFrancesco can take solace in the correctness of his suggestion that some students in California might have trouble locating Rutgers on a map.
"Yeah, Rutgers," said Don Hansen, president of the student senate at the University of Southern California, in Los Angeles. "It's in New York."
No, actually it is in New Jersey.
"New Jersey." he said. "Same deal."

HEADLINE: Team's Motto: 'They Call; We Haul';
On the Road With the Crew of an E.M.S. Ambulance

BYLINE: By ASHLEY DUNN 

 BODY:
Fifteen minutes after dropping off a man with chest pains at Brookdale Hospital in Brownsville, ambulance 30H is blazing through Brooklyn's rush-hour traffic, its siren an excruciating wail.
The ambulance cuts a tight passage through the streets of Bushwick until it is confronted with a stalled Cadillac on a snowy patch of road. As it impatiently inches forward, drivers leap from their cars to push the crippled Cadillac out of the way. 
 Ambulance 30H -- three-oh-Henry, the dispatchers call it -- races on. For all the commotion, the emergency toward which it is rushing is a child with diarrhea.
"They call; we haul," said John Hartmann, an emergency medical technician assigned to 30H. "That's the job."
Politicians are debating the latest plan to merge the Emergency Medical Service with the New York City Fire Department, and a furor continues over a baby's death last weekend after a dispute between the family and an emergency crew. But for the men and women at the center of the storm, the world continues to turn at its usual, weirdly chaotic pace.
It is a world ruled by the constant possibility of death, but dominated by the small, mundane problems of life: calls about chest pains or diarrhea, and broken-down Cadillacs in the street.
Since the Emergency Medical Service was created 14 years ago, the agency has been a lightning rod for criticism, weathering perennial complaints of abuse, mismanagement and incompetence.
Over the years, measurements of the agency's performance show a marked improvement. Average response times in the nation's busiest ambulance system have dropped to 8.5 minutes today from 18.8 minutes in 1980, even as the number of emergency incidents has gone up to nearly a million from 560,667. The ratio of highly trained paramedics to basic emergency medical technicians has also increased, with paramedics representing about a quarter of the corps today.
At the same time, the New York system is an exception to the national pattern: it is one of the few independent emergency services left in a big city. Three-quarters of the emergency systems in the nation's largest cities are operated by fire departments, private contractors or some combination of the two.
 
Everyday Heroics
 Supporters of a merger in New York say that it would be more efficient and point to the quicker response times of the city's Fire Department. Critics counter that despite the latest rush of headlines, the system does work and is getting better all the time.
For the crews, though, the controversies and the heroics that capture public attention are mere flashes on the horizon.
"It's not like the movies," Mr. Hartmann said. "I've had your ingrown toenail jobs, your hemorrhoid jobs. They all want to go to the hospital. We take them."
The current system grew out of a consolidation of a chaotic system of city-run and private ambulances, which sometimes ended up battling over patients at accident scenes. In 1969, all ambulances were placed under the control of the Department of Hospitals, which took charge of dispatching vehicles, establishing standards and operating policies.
In 1970, the state legislature created the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation, which then ran the ambulances through the Emergency Medical Service.
The system is now made up of about 490 city ambulance teams that are available on any given day and 110 more teams that are contracted from private hospitals. In addition, there are about 30 volunteer ambulance services, with workers donating their time and money.
All the ambulances are dispatched by the Emergency Medical Service communications center in Maspeth, Queens, based on availability and proximity to a patient. Ambulance 30H roves through Brooklyn and specializes in cases involving hazardous materials. Patients are charged fees ranging from $350 to $450 a run, but the agency still requires a public subsidy of about $100 million a year.
 
Distant Words
 Brenda Steffan, a spokeswoman for the California-based American Ambulance Association, said the trend in recent years has been to move to fire department or private systems, or both, for economy and efficiency. And Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has promised that a merger of the city's ambulance corps with the fire department will bring faster response times.
But how such a vast systemic change would affect service on the streets of New York is difficult to determine. As ambulance crews explain, it is a world ruled by so many obscure factors, from traffic flow to weather conditions, that shifting uniforms may have no effect on service.
"As long as I have a job, I don't care what uniform I wear," said James Foley, Mr. Hartmann's partner in 30H.
The debates that swirl around their work often seem distant and detached. Asked about the case of the baby who died in Queens last weekend after a dispute between family and crew over the choice of hospital, they said they had never encountered a situation that required extensive argument.
In fact, disputes like that are not as common as those with patients who do not want to go to the hospital at all, Mr. Hartmann said. "I mean, here you are and you think they're going down the tubes before your very eyes and they don't want to go," he said, adding that in those cases, they call a doctor.
"We just don't argue with people," Mr. Hartmann said.
 
Rewards, but a Price
 The reality is that although their work is perceived by the public as a matter of life and death, it often is not. Of nearly a million emergency incidents a year, nearly 60 percent are classified by the Emergency Medical Service as not life-threatening.
Emergency medical technicians, whose pay starts at about $24,000 a year, go through 10 weeks of training before going out in an ambulance. Paramedics, who can administer certain drugs, must go through about 10 more months of training; their pay starts at about $29,500.
In five years with the service, Mr. Hartmann has earned one "pre-hospital save," for bringing back a patient in full cardiac arrest. Whenever they save a patient, ambulance workers receive a red-and-orange medals which most wear on their shirt pockets.
Mr. Hartmann has also brought 18 babies into the world, delivering one in a tenement hallway. Most ambulance drivers have at least one of the distinctive blue-and-pink "baby bars" on their shirt pockets.
Some proudly wear the solid-black "black sheep" bar, an unofficial medal usually awarded by colleagues for saving a patient in unconventional and perhaps unauthorized ways -- like a technician who rappelled off the Williamsburg Bridge to rescue someone threatening to jump.
Mr. Hartmann said he intended eventually to take the course to become a paramedic, although most of his co-workers have their sights set on joining fire or police departments, which pay better.
Most ambulance workers last only a few years, often burning out from the constant fits and starts of the business and eventually finding other jobs, he said.
He said he also knew of co-workers who had committed suicide. "You always see blood and gore and abuses of the system," he said. "Some people don't handle it well."
But for real "trauma junkies," he said, nothing matches the satisfaction of doing the job right.
 
A Big Job? Maybe
 In the middle of burgers and fries after a call in Williamsburg, Mr. Hartmann and Mr. Foley run out of a restaurant and head to their ambulance when a call comes in about a major fire possibly involving hazardous material, several miles away in Midwood.
"This is our specialty," Mr. Foley says as he swerves the car into the street. "Probably a biggie. I love this job."
With the siren wailing, they get on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway. Even as they hit 75 miles an hour with their lights flashing, cars occasionally cut in front of them, while others fall in behind for a slick ride down the expressway.
They get off the expressway and fall in behind a line of firetrucks. "Five blocks away, bro," Mr. Foley yells to the back of the ambulance.
At Avenue O, the street is packed with fire engines and ambulances. They hear on emergency radios that 20 to 25 firefighters may have been exposed to asbestos in a house fire, requiring a full decontamination.
Mr. Hartmann and Mr. Foley unpack their sealed contamination suits and wait for the arrival of the Fire Department's shower trailer.
One ambulance worker comments ruefully that the trailer used to be controlled by the Emergency Medical Service. Now "they bring it, we staff it," he says.
 
Hurry Up and Wait
 After the initial burst of activity, the ambulance crews settle in, waiting to hear if the firefighters will need to be sprayed with water to remove all traces of asbestos.
The crews up sitting for an hour on Avenue O in a line of flashing emergency vehicles before word comes that the decontamination has been called off. The ambulance workers who gathered in 30H roll their eyes and head off to pack their equipment.
As they prepare to end their shift, Mr. Hartmann tallies the total for the night: two case of diarrhea, one case of chest pain, one stomach ache, one case of Mace in the face, a possible beating, a fire in a subway station and a canceled decontamination.
"All in all, a pretty good night," Mr. Hartmann said.

HEADLINE: NEW CALLS TO LIFT EMBARGO ON CUBA

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19

 BODY:
Now that the United States trade embargo on Vietnam has been lifted, a growing number of Cuban-Americans and members of Congress are pushing President Clinton to ease the embargo on Cuba. But because of domestic political pressures, the Administration seems unwilling to budge.
Though still a minority among Cuban-Americans and on Capitol Hill, these voices are telling the Administration that the best way to undermine Fidel Castro is to increase Western involvement in Cuba. In their view, that means easing or ending the embargo. 
 Supporters of such a move, like the Miami-based Cuban Committee for Democracy and Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan, assert that the 32-year-old embargo has failed to achieve its goal of forcing out Mr. Castro or getting him to embrace democracy. Worse, they say, the embargo has hurt the well-being of average Cubans and given Mr. Castro a convenient explanation for why Cuba's economy is in such a sorry state.
Representative Rangel, whose bill to end the embargo has 25 co-sponsors, said: "I have talked with Cuban business people and they tell me, 'The embargo is helping Castro.' They say, 'The Cuban people believe it's the embargo, not Castro, that's causing all their pain.' "
 
Cuba Is Different
 Administration officials say that while the recent small and tentative economic reforms in Cuba offer some glimmers of hope, they have no intention of easing the embargo because they are convinced that Mr. Castro has no plans to hold free elections or improve human rights.
"Vietnam is at least doing something on economic reform, but Cuba isn't really doing anything on economic or political reform," one official said. "Our feeling is the embargo has an impact. Lifting it would produce a short-term inflow of capital that would enable Castro to retard reform."
Administration officials acknowledge that domestic politics comes into play. They see little political gain in softening their policy toward Cuba, when the main Cuban-American group, the Cuban American National Foundation, remains vehemently anti-Castro.
"This Adminstration doesn't want to be seen as soft on Castro," said Jorge Dominguez, a Cuban-American professor of political science at Harvard. "You hear talk from various parts of government that they're concerned about elections in Florida, and not just in 1996."
Administration officials say they have learned that even if they want to reach out toward Mr. Castro, they can end up getting burned. One official noted that shortly after the 1992 election, President Clinton's emerging foreign policy team was reassessing Cuba policy when they heard that several prominent Cuban human rights workers were beaten up on International Human Rights Day.
 
No Easing on Travel
 Showing the Administration's continuing determination to isolate Cuba, the State Department has recommended against easing travel restrictions to Cuba. Representative Howard L. Berman, Democrat of California, who asserts that liberalizing travel is vital for disseminating pro-democracy ideas, has suggested he would push a bill to ease travel restrictions to Cuba and other embargoed countries if the Administration did not do so on its own.
To woo the Cuban-American vote in the 1992 Presidential elections, Mr. Clinton moved faster than former President George Bush to endorse a tough bill on Cuba that tightened the embargo by prohibiting the overseas subsidiaries of American companies from trading with Cuba.
Administration officials say that law, the Cuban Democracy Act, ties their hands on Cuba policy. But many experts on Latin America say the act leaves the Administration plenty of latitude to tinker with Cuba policy.
The act's sponsor, Representative Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of New Jersey, takes a hard line, saying, "the question of American foreign policy toward Cuba is largely settled."
In the view of some foreign policy experts, the Administration is so attentive to domestic political concerns that it finds itself trapped with a policy that is counterproductive.
"It's a remnant of the cold war," said Peter Hakim, president of Inter-American Dialogue, a Washington research group. "Many senior officials say in private it's an absurd policy. It's not achieving its goals. And it's more likely than not to help create a violent situation in Cuba that will produce large flows of refugees."

HEADLINE: Unemployed Man Is Charged With Threat to Kill President

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18

 BODY:
An unemployed limousine driver from Florida has been accused of threatening to kill President Clinton.
The man, Ronald Gene Barbour, 39, of Orlando is being held in the Seminole County jail in Sanford, Fla., after his indictment by a Federal grand jury in Orlando. 
 WUSA-TV in Washington reported on Friday that Mr. Barbour was in the Washington area from Jan. 11 to Jan. 17 and intended to shoot Mr. Clinton during one of the President's morning runs on the Mall. Mr. Clinton was in Europe at the time.
