HEADLINE: One Health Care Vote: A periodic look at a lawmaker;
For Freshman in Congress, Finding Opinions on Clinton Plan Is the Easy Part

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 19

 BODY:
Lynn Schenk is a freshman Democrat in Congress who would like to support President Clinton in his efforts to change the health care system. But in a district with 14 major hospitals and nearly 100 biotechnology companies, where one of her Republican opponents is a doctor, there are plenty of experts to tell her what to do.
So many, in fact, it's almost paralyzing. 
 On a visit back home during the Congressional recess this week, Ms. Schenk was besieged by lobbyists talking about health care.
Executives of two local companies that developed simple tests to help detect osteoporosis wanted Congress to require coverage of such tests, which cost $30 to $50, as part of any national health plan.
Retail druggists pleaded with Ms. Schenk to provide coverage of prescription drugs.
 
A Swing Vote
 Some retirees advocated a program of national health insurance like Canada's, a "single payer" plan financed by the Government, which would virtually eliminate the role of private insurance companies.
Restaurateurs told Ms. Schenk that employers should not be required to buy health insurance for their workers. Susan Ham Baumann, general manager of two San Diego restaurants, said her company spent $110,000 a year on insurance for 70 employees and would have to pay $190,000 under Mr. Clinton's proposal. "That's $80,000 more a year to me, which is money I don't have," she told the Congresswoman.
Ms. Schenk, a 49-year-old lawyer with liberal Democratic instincts in a fiscally conservative district, has a pivotal position as a member of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, which will begin drafting health care legislation soon after Congress reconvenes on Tuesday. Hers is a swing vote; she is not committed to any specific health care bill.
 
'Couldn't Take It on Faith'
 "My background in health care is as a consumer," said Ms. Schenk, who knows her way around Washington from her days as a White House fellow in the Carter Administration. "Having to make a momentous decision on health care reform, one of the most significant social policy decisions of the last 30 or 50 years, I want to know a whole lot more than I do now. I've been trying to learn for the last year.
"With a Democrat in the White House, my inclination is to be very supportive of his proposal, but I couldn't just take it on faith. It's too important a decision."
Ms. Schenk is engaged in what she describes as a methodical "intellectual and technical study process." But the discussions with the experts in her district -- the coastal 49th District, which begins south of Del Mar and includes northern and downtown San Diego and Coronado -- tend to focus on small fragments of a very big picture.
From this continually shifting kaleidoscope of concerns, no coherent theme readily emerges. If there is any consensus on overhauling the health care system, it was not evident in the meetings that Ms. Schenk held this week. The conflicting pleas from constituents make her decision all the more difficult.
 
Big Test for Congress
 But she recognizes that Congress is on trial, and she says Congress as an institution will fail the test if it cannot synthesize consensus from the jumble of competing interests.
Those in the "bioscience industry," an engine of economic growth in Southern California, tend to support modest changes of the type proposed by Representative Jim Cooper, Democrat of Tennessee, she said. The Cooper bill would make health insurance more easily available, but would not require employers to buy it.
George W. Dunbar Jr., president of Metra Biosystems, which has developed the blood test for signs of osteoporosis, told Ms. Schenk, "Let's fix what needs to be fixed, rather than turn things upside down."
In general, the Cooper bill envisions a smaller role for the Federal Government than Mr. Clinton proposed. But when Ms. Schenk and Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich held a forum for older residents of San Diego this week, there was substantial sentiment for a bigger Federal role.
 
Opposition in the Wings
 Joseph Stern, 83, a local coordinator for the American Association of Retired Persons, whom Ms. Schenk described as the "king of seniors," said: "Single-payer is the most sensible plan. It's the simplest, the most economical to operate. It gives consumers full choice, and it permits doctors to operate freely."
After the forum, Mr. Reich said, "I was surprised at the support for a single-payer plan."
Lawmakers who seek re-election this year naturally expect to be rewarded or punished at the polls for their votes on health care. But Ms. Schenk has special reason to be careful and cautious. A local urologist, Dr. John F. Steel, the former chief of staff at Scripps Memorial Hospital in the La Jolla district, is seeking the Republican nomination to oppose her. He says she will be more vulnerable if she supports the President's proposals.
Dr. Steel acknowledges some serious problems in the medical system, but, like many Republicans, he insists that "there is no crisis." He said his philosophy of health care was simple: "Keep the government out of it."
 
Concern About Drug Pricing
 As a junior member of a powerful committee, Ms. Schenk is focusing on several issues: women's health care, the fate of biotechnology companies, the concerns of small businesses and the need for Federal aid to help finance the care of illegal aliens.
She is a pro-business Democrat. In the early 1980's, when Edmund G. Brown Jr. was Governor, Ms. Schenk served in his Cabinet as Secretary of Business, Transportation and Housing.
She worries about the effects of Mr. Clinton's proposal for the Government to review the "reasonableness" of new drug prices. "The plan as it now stands would have a detrimental effect on research and development of breakthrough drugs," she said. "That's a constituent problem. These companies are a source of job growth. Cutting-edge research may help me, my family and friends and fellow citizens by finding treatments for AIDS, cancer and Alzheimer's disease.
"If we, by our actions in Washington, dry up the venture capital that is the lifeblood of these companies, then we will have done something harmful to ourselves and to future generations," Ms. Schenk said. She quickly added that "some of these drugs are incredibly expensive to the consumer" and said, "We've got to fix that," but has not endorsed a specific remedy.
 
A Model Medical Market
 Ms. Schenk has formed a panel of advisers from local biomedical companies. The head of the panel, David F. Hale, president of Gensia Inc., said the growth of these companies was one of the few bright spots in California's economy, which has been battered by recession and by cutbacks in the defense industry.
San Diego is already a model for the kind of medical market that Mr. Clinton wants to create nationwide. Patients and doctors here are comfortable with health maintenance organizations like Kaiser Permanente, which provide a full range of medical services in return for a flat fee, set in advance. Competing networks of doctors and hospitals already provide much of the care here.
With 5 hospitals, 15 clinics, 4 nursing homes and 1,100 doctors in the San Diego area, the Sharp Health Care network is a model of the integrated care Mr. Clinton wants to encourage. But when Ms. Schenk visited Sharp's headquarters this week, she got a mixed message.
Peter K. Ellsworth, president of Sharp Health Care, told her that a network of doctors and hospitals could provide excellent care and control costs if it was paid a flat monthly amount for each person enrolled in the health plan.
 
Bureaucracy on Bureaucracy
 But he said the market was already "moving in the right direction," and he expressed concern about the authority Mr. Clinton would give to large health insurance purchasing pools, known as alliances.
"I worry about alliances that create yet another layer of bureaucracy between people paying the medical bills and the ultimate deliverer of care," Mr. Ellsworth said.
Ms. Schenk, who observed the burden of insurance paperwork in a doctor's office earlier this week, said, "It's hard to imagine it could get worse."
But Mr. Ellsworth said, yes, it could get worse with the alliances envisioned by Mr. Clinton.
"I'm a cynic when it comes to insurance companies," Mr. Ellsworth told the Congresswoman, a longtime friend. "They're big. They're rich. They're very powerful. I don't believe they will go away. I fear that we'll have new Federal, state and local bureaucracy plus the insurance company bureaucracy. That would be worse."
In Washington, Administration officials continually woo Ms. Schenk, seeking her support for Mr. Clinton's plan. Some of the officials, she said, are "breathtakingly knowledgeable." Others tell her simply, "You owe it to your President; you owe it to your party."
But the appeal to Ms. Schenk's sense of political loyalty has so far been unavailing. Those who would win her vote, she says, must address the substance of her concerns and those of her constituents.

HEADLINE: Single Women and Poverty Strongly Linked

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19

 BODY:
Single mothers and "displaced homemakers" are four times as likely to live in poverty as the population as a whole, according to a study.
"What we have discovered can only be characterized as grim," said Gilda Nardone, president of Women Work, an advocacy group that came to its conclusion by analyzing census data. "Even though these women's work-force participation rose significantly during the decade, their likelihood of living in poverty remained high." 
 The report, released on Thursday, focused on the plight of single mothers and what it calls "displaced homemakers" -- women whose primary occupation had been homemaking but who did not find full-time, year-round employment after they became divorced, separated or widowed.
There were 17.8 million such displaced homemakers in the United States in 1990, an increase of four million since 1980, Ms. Nardone said. The number of single mothers also rose, to 7.7 million in 1990 from 5.8 million a decade earlier.
While 11 percent of households in the United States lived in poverty in 1990, 42 percent of displaced homemakers who headed households and 44 percent of single mothers were impoverished, the study found.
"For millions of single mothers and displaced homemakers, the American dream is proving elusive because jobs are not providing economic security," Ms. Nardone said.
Displaced homemakers had a significantly higher rate of employment in 1990 than they did in 1980, the study found. About half were employed either part-time or part of the year in 1990, compared with a third who were employed a decade earlier. But the poverty rate improved only slightly, to 35 percent in 1990 from 39 percent in 1980.
"Part of the reason is that displaced homemakers and single mothers are over-represented in service jobs," Ms. Nardone said. "Service jobs offer low wages, few benefits, part-time work and little or no job security."
The study also found that single mothers and displaced homemakers tended to have "unstable housing situations." Three in four single mothers rented or shared their housing, and three in five single mothers with children under age 2 had moved within the previous year.
Jill Miller, executive director of the organization, said displaced homemakers were not a phenomenon that would soon disappear. "Future generations of stay-at-home mothers and women whose employment is interrupted by family caretaking responsibilities are likely to find themselves with little or no immediate income when they are displaced," Ms. Miller said.

HEADLINE: Late Donations Shore Up the Neediest

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
As its 82d annual appeal draws to a close, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund is in danger of ending the campaign with a decrease in contributions for a second straight year, jeopardizing services for thousands of the city's poor.
The amount collected so far this year, $4,135,714.05, represents a drop of $91,106 from collections at this time last year and a drop of more than $600,000 from the 1991-92 campaign, the most successful in the fund's history. Every dollar donated is used for direct services for the needy because The Times pays the campaign's overhead. 
 The shortfall comes at a time when the fund's ability to help is especially crucial because the seven charities the fund supports have been doubly besieged by decreased private giving and increased need as a result of the economic downturn.
For example, the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, a branch of the UJA-Federation, one of the charities supported by the fund, is struggling to help dozens of recently unemployed men and women and a rapidly increasing pool of people in danger of being evicted. But last year, the board suffered a 10 percent decrease in support from the UJA-Federation. It has also lost two of five staff positions over the last two years.
The Children's Aid Society, which runs eight community centers throughout the city that provide food, medical care and supervision for hundreds of thousands of children, will have to curtail mental-health counseling and other services if private support continues to fall, said Philip Coltoff, the society's director.
"A decrease of even 10 percent compared to what we received last year would have an effect, particularly for those children who are prone to violent acting-out," Mr. Coltoff said. "It could mean as many as 150 fewer counseling sessions next year for these children."
 
Individuals Count
 Hundreds of donors, among them Rosalie S. Walton of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., have already responded to news of the lag in the campaign, which ends on Feb. 28. "I read your column about the fund being down this year, at a time after dispiriting, seemingly endless ice and cold," Mrs. Walton wrote in a letter accompanied by her $100 donation. "But my house is warm, my husband and children are well and my friend in Los Angeles reached me to say she is O.K. and is picking up everything from her floors."
Despite increased giving by such dedicated donors -- some who have given even though they are unemployed, and some who have given three or four times to try to bridge the gap -- the fund continues to trail previous years because of a decrease in giving by estates and trusts.
This means the continued largess of individual donors will determine whether the campaign is a success this year, said Arthur Gelb, the president of The New York Times Company Foundation, which administers the fund.
"There is little more than a week to go before the drive's end, and those of us who keep track of the Neediest Fund are hoping there'll be a final splurge of giving by individual donors so we can meet last year's total or even beat it," Mr. Gelb said. "The seven charities that depend so much on our readers' generosity are particularly hard pressed for support this year, and they're hoping along with us."

HEADLINE: The Invisible Parade

 BODY:
For over a decade, the homeless have been parading, shivering, ranting, eating, drinking, sleeping and occasionally dying within view of the north-facing windows of the family quarters of the White House. At last, perhaps, we have a President who can see them. It is about time.
Homelessness in America is a spectacle to crack any caring heart. The scores of homeless who shuffle among the springtime tulips and winter snowbanks of Lafayette Park in Washington are the unelected representatives of a far-flung constituency. During the Reagan and Bush Administrations, neither these Washington representatives of the homeless nor the Congress itself could get the residents of the White House to open their eyes. 
Finally, the Clinton Administration seems ready to make the Federal Government look at and respond to homelessness. The new report prepared by the secretaries of Veterans Affairs, Health and Human Services, and Housing and Urban Development argues that addiction and mental illness account for about half of the adult homeless population.
It also blames structural changes in society and the economy for causing growing numbers of poor Americans -- there are 37 million of them -- to lose their shelter. In the 80's, available jobs and wages for unskilled workers declined. Among women with dependent children, the buying power of welfare benefits has eroded in the last 20 years. Meanwhile, the study asserts that "huge numbers" of cheap units have disappeared from the rental market. In short, some poor citizens who were not addicted or mentally incompetent became homeless because the cost of bad apartments increased as the amount of money in their pockets declined.
The new report was written by Andrew Cuomo, the Assistant Secretary of Housing who produced a much praised and largely ignored report on homelessness in New York City in 1992. As in the earlier report, Mr. Cuomo called for a mix of remedial and preventive measures as well as new programs that enlist nonprofit organizations in delivering services to the homeless.
The report does not pretend to answer every question. For example, its finding that up to seven million people were homeless at some point in the late 80's does not answer how many are homeless at this moment. Guesses range from 500,000 to several million.
It does not take a head count to affirm the evidence before our eyes night and morning. Nor should the White House's formal commitment to the spirit of this draft report await clearance from the Office of Management and Budget. After 12 years of willful myopia, the numbers are less important than the commitment to behold the mundane suffering outside the windows of Pennsylvania Avenue and Main Streets across America.
A few weeks ago, Mr. Clinton described the residents of our door stoops and underpasses as "people who are battered and bruised and broken, but who still have a lot of God's grace left in them." To have left them so long to the grace of God alone is an insult to our national values.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Tower Explosion's Legacy: Security Improves in Year And Is Also Lost Forever;
The Manager: A Changed World Is Oddly Normal

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR

 BODY:
Telephone calls pour into Charles Maikish's 35th-floor office at the World Trade Center constantly, sending him running to hear tenants' complaints, answer contractors' questions and attend the myriad meetings resulting from the explosion a year ago.
Since the moment of the blast, when he was rocked in his chair while signing a lease, Mr. Maikish, the director of the trade center, has seen his world change. He is now on a first-name basis with construction workers and engineers and secretaries and executives he scarcely knew before. As he walks the corridors of the concourse, he seems to marvel at the fact that on its face, the trade center 
 seems back to normal, if not a little better.
For the Port Authority, as well as the New York region, the explosion appears to have had little long-range economic impact. Losses that were not covered by insurance were offset by the temporary construction and security boom.
At the trade center, occupancy is higher than before the blast. Commuters and other pedestrians hustle by what was the Big Kitchen, an old food court, now replaced by a sleek new Gap clothing store. Just after the blast, one corner of the court was the control center for emergency workers. Now black leggings and athletic bras are displayed there.
 
New Restaurant for Tower
 Alexander's Department Store, which became an emergency tenant assistance center, will soon be converted into the Limited and several other stores. Though a few businesses, including Deloitte & Touche, the accountants, moved out after the blast, a slew of other stores and restaurants, plus the Bank of America, are moving in. They did not get financial incentives, Mr. Maikish said. Instead, he said, the trade center defied its reputation as a lethargic, bureaucratic landlord and hustled to accommodate them.
The Port Authority is spending more than $300 million to fill the bomb crater, repair other structural damage and renovate. It is now weighing bids from owners of the Rainbow Room, Smith & Wollensky Steak House, Bouley and Tavern on the Green to replace the Windows on the World restaurant, which was closed after the blast.
In recent weeks, Mr. Maikish says, the incessant telephone calls have included requests from tenants asking about parking in the underground garage, which is to reopen on March 30 -- but to tenants and government and security officers only. And about once a week, he said, there is a call about a suspicious package somewhere in the complex. So far, he said, they have been false alarms. MARY B. W. TABOR

HEADLINE: Clinton Plan Means New Era of Family Doctor;
Tax Burden for Poor

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Jim Cooper's Pointless Plan," by Henry J. Aaron (Op-Ed, Feb. 13), is right. The Cooper plan will, at the margin, leave low-income workers facing confiscatory taxes because of phase-out of its low-income subsidy. 
 Unfortunately, the Clinton health plan is not much better. It leaves most low-income workers paying roughly 11 cents more of each dollar they earn through its 7.9 percent payroll tax, plus an additional 3 percent tax from the phase-out of its subsidy to low-income families.
Add this 11 percent marginal tax to the 18 percent marginal tax associated with the phase-out of the earned income tax credit, the 15 percent Federal income tax, the 15 percent Social Security payroll tax and an assumed 5 percent state income tax, and one gets a combined 64 percent marginal tax for low-income workers. This rate is smaller than that under the Cooper plan, but it's still outrageous.
The Clinton plan also produces extraordinarily large distortions for employers in deciding whether to hire high-wage or low-wage employees and workers younger or older than 55.
Both the Clinton and Cooper plans are seriously flawed in economic incentives. Neither should be adopted before their distortions are addressed.
 
LAURENCE J. KOTLIKOFF
 Prof. of Economics, Boston U.
 Boston, Feb. 14, 1994

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: WINNERS' CIRCLE;
Destination Albany: The Newest Faces

BYLINE: By MARTIN STOLZ 

 BODY:
ON Tuesday, five special elections were held in the city for seats in the State Legislature. Here are profiles of the winners.
 
28TH ASSEMBLY DISTRICT 

NAME -- Melinda Katz
 
AGE -- 28
 
PARTY -- Democrat
 
RESIDENCE -- Forest Hills
 
EDUCATION -- Hillcrest High School, Jamaica, Queens; University of Massachusetts at Amherst, 1987, and St. John's Law School, 1990.
 
PROFESSION -- Associate Attorney with Weil, Gotshal & Manges.
 
DISTRICT BOUNDARIES -- Forest Hills, Rego Park and Middle Village.
 
MARGIN OF VICTORY -- 46 percent, or 2,519 votes, for Ms. Katz; 38 percent, or 2,001 votes, for Michael Cohen, the Democratic candidate; and 16 percent, or 924 votes, for John Haggerty Jr., a Republican-Conservative.
 
TURNOUT -- 9 percent.
 
POLITICS OF THE RACE -- The election was for the seat vacated by Alan G. Hevesi when he became Comptroller. HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SUNNSYSIDE;
On the Drawing Board: Rail Yard to Rail Hub

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
Just blocks from the planned subway link in Long Island City lie the 200-acre Sunnyside rail yards, a sprawling site that has been the subject of scheme after scheme, including a domed sports stadium, an office skyscraper and a race track, none of which have materialized.
Now a new, grand plan for the yards is slowly taking shape. 
 Transportation planners and local officials are envisioning a regional rail transit hub with more links than Grand Central and Pennsylvania Stations combined. Housing and commercial buildings would be built on top of the hub, and the combined effect, the planners say, would turn Long Island City into New York's fourth central business district, after lower Manhattan, midtown and downtown Brooklyn.
There are many obstacles, the biggest being cost -- hundreds of millions of dollars or more for the new station, for which no money is now dedicated -- and the complexity of uniting diverse transportation and governmental agencies. The local economy is considered too anemic now to finance the housing and commercial development.
A task force named by the Queens Borough President's office is drafting a plan for the project and has applied for a Federal grant.
The City Planning Department has long advocated a hub plan. Floyd Lapp, the department's director of transportation, said the project might be realized because of a trend toward rail building. He cited the planned link of subway lines using Queens Boulevard with those using the new 63d Street tunnel as an example.
At the heart of the plan is a center connecting Amtrak's interstate trains, three suburban commuter lines (the Long Island Railroad, Metro North and New Jersey Transit) and up to nine subway lines (the B, E, F, G, N, Q, R, 7 and a line being developed on the new link) and trains to John F. Kennedy International and La Guardia Airports.
With most of the track in place, creating a hub would require building a station at Sunnyside. The subway stations are a bit far for a pedestrian connection and might require a shuttle or moving sidewalk.
There is no major opposition so far. The Regional Plan Association, a nonprofit organization, has advocated a hub since 1929. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is also doing its own study of a Sunnyside hub. Amtrak explored it in 1989, drawing up a plan for 950 housing units and five million square feet of commercial space but not acting on it. B.L.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SUNSET PARK;
Thumbing a Sail to Work

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY 

 BODY:
A high-speed ferry line to connect Sunset Park to lower Manhattan and midtown is being planned, officials at the City Planning Department say, in part to offset the traffic congestion that is expected to accompany a planned overhaul of the Gowanus Expressway.
The ferry would dock at 58th Street and Second Avenue in the Brooklyn Army Terminal, but the Manhattan stops have not yet been announced. The Scandinavian Marine Corporation, which runs ferries in Connecticut, Florida and Scandinavia, has been chosen to run the service, said Ann Buttenwieser, vice president of waterfront development for the Economic Development Corporation. 
 The demolition and replacement of a dilapidated pier and the construction of a parking lot for 500 cars, along with walkways and streets to the ferry, would cost an estimated $25 million, to be paid by the state Department of Transportation. The project would also an esplanade, benches and a railing.
The reconstruction of the Gowanus, which lies only two blocks from the pier site, is scheduled to begin in 1997 and is expected to cause traffic snarls from Bay Ridge to Brooklyn Heights. The city, which plans to open bidding for the project within two weeks, hopes to begin construction in about three months and believes the ferry could be running by 1996.
Plans are also being made to present the ferry project to residents and community leaders in the coming weeks, but there are rumblings of dissatisfaction already.
Anthony Giordano, executive director of Sunset Park Restoration, a community group, said the ferry would work best at 39th Street and Second Avenue, which was home to a ferry service that was discontinued in 1958. But he was doubtful about the success of any ferry in the area.
"It just doesn't seem plausible that commuters would trek from New Jersey, Staten Island and Long Island, be within sight of the Manhattan skyline, park their vehicles and take the ferry," Mr. Giordano said. "I just don't see it happening. If they really want to do something, they should do it in terms of improving the subway service."
The ferry would carry up to 350 passengers, but no cars. There is no estimate yet on how much the fare for the 10-minute ride would be. Bus lines may also be added to funnel passengers into Sunset Park.
The emphasis on ferry service is a result of the High-Speed Ferry Task Force appointed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo in 1993 to study ways to relieve congestion on traffic routes leading into New York City.
He has called ferry transportation a key element of his "New New York" economic revitalization program for the metropolitan area and has described the boats as an "environmentally sound means of travel" and "a great way to get to and from work."
It would be Brooklyn's second ferry to Manhattan: one now runs from the 69th Street pier in Bay Ridge to Pier 11 at Wall and South Streets. LYNETTE HOLLOWAY

HEADLINE: MAKING IT WORK;
Mentor, Hell-Raiser. . .

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE 

 BODY:
JOHN H. BESS, sitting in his cave of an office in the basement of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, had no time to mince words. The telephone was ringing, his schedule went on for pages and all this talking put him two beats behind his fast-forward rhythm as head of the youth agency called the Valley.
"We are a society that is manufacturing monsters," Mr. Bess said. "I call this the microwave generation. Everything is resolved to the extreme and quickly. These young people have plenty to be legitimately angry about, but often it's not a rational anger, it's an explosive anger. 
 "They're angry at their mother, they're angry at their sister, they're angry because the train is late," he said. "Then someone looks at them the wrong way or steps on their new shoes. . . ."
When Mr. Bess founded the agency 15 years ago in the Manhattan Valley neighborhood just east of Columbia University, things were bad for children living in the margins. Now, he says, they are dreadful. Crack, homelessness, guns, joblessness, combined with an existential ennui that early engulfs the poor, have devised a separate America steeped in pessimism.
"It is so different from 1979," Mr. Bess said with a shake of his head. "The young people mostly wanted a job or a place to develop leadership or communication skills. Young people today come in: No. 1 they're a teen mother; No. 2 they're being abused by a parent and/or boyfriend. They've dropped out of school and want to do something with their life. It's a multiplicity of problems."
And so it is that Mr. Bess, 41, acts as mentor, role model, hell-raiser, fund-raiser and go-between in this little world. He presides over a scope of services from leadership training programs to dropout-prevention counseling. The title on his business card, chief executive officer, does not begin to describe his peripatetic existence.
He goes to conferences, he buttonholes politicians, he badgers parents, he insists that successful black and brown visitors to Valley headquarters tell his young people how they made it. He works late into the night, his beeper on his hip and his mind focused on redemption.
Mr. Bess's vision 15 years ago was to develop an organization to nurture a new generation of leaders, he said. He miscalculated how hard it would be. The economy took a dive. Where there was no hope there were drugs, and where there were no jobs there was the opportunity to work for drug dealers. Plenty of children succumbed to despair.
If there is any secret for success, Mr. Bess said, it is disarmingly simple: caring people who give youngsters a chance to channel their energies. That can mean a lot of things. For the Valley, it means helping them organize to combat problems in their neighborhoods or teaching skills like how to silkscreen T-shirts. It can mean just listening.
There is no dearth of brilliance or creativity in the young people who flow through the warren of rooms beneath the great cathedral at Amsterdam Avenue and 111th Street, Mr. Bess said, but many have not been given the proper discipline, exposure, direction and opportunities.
The Valley, which is nonsectarian, serves 5,000 young people a year, with programs ranging from teen parenting to substance-abuse treatment, from fine arts to help preparing for college. The youngsters, from all over the city, are referred by peers, parents, schools, clinics or community-based programs. About half are black, half Hispanic.
One recent day, about 20 teen-agers in a biweekly leadership training group discussed a visit by Bill Cosby, a friend of the Valley who had just participated in an anti-violence program. Mr. Bess poured himself into the mix. He admonished people to stand up and speak clearly. "We can use this technique called standing," he said. He prodded others to stop and collect their thoughts.
"He is by far one of the most masterful teachers of young people I have ever seen," said Geoffrey Canada, head of the New York-based Rheedlen Centers for Children and Families. "He is a great mimic. He uses their own language in terms of the most hip words. He makes connections with young people.
"He is also caring," Mr. Canada added. "I sometimes stop to see him at 10:30 at night and he is there in the cathedral and I have to drag him out to get a bite to eat. I know of no time a young person cannot call John."
Waayl Shahid, 22, the director of leadership training, recalled that when he came to the Valley eight years ago, he was on the verge of dropping out of high school. "Just being involved and being around other people doing it in school, who found different ways, it just motivates you," Mr. Shahid said. "I wanted to emulate John. John is a very eloquent speaker. He can come across as very preachy if he wants to, but he can also come across as humorous."
Mr. Bess relishes the task. He grew up in a Harlem tenement and was active in community work as a student at Rice, a Catholic high school in Harlem. His mother was a homemaker and his father a photographer who worked with James Van DerZee, famous for his dreamy, stylized pictures of blacks.
It was a time when the country was taking a chance on poor kids, and so Mr. Bess was whisked off to Columbia University in Morningside Heights. Just a short distance away from home, it nevertheless belonged to that other world he had glimpsed as a boy when he rode the trains with his mother. His father died when he was 5 years old.
While a freshman, his girlfriend became pregnant with his son, Khalil, who still lives with him and is an engineering student. Khalil's mother wanted to be a physician and had years of rigorous preparation ahead, so Mr. Bess became Khalil's primary caretaker, though his mother remained part of his life. Mr. Bess eventually married another woman, but she died two years ago.
It was the experience of early fatherhood, combined with the zest to change the way things are, that led Mr. Bess to a number of jobs working with young people and finally to founding the Valley. In 1979, when the cathedral was completing two towers, Mr. Bess convinced the people there that they had a bigger mission than architecture -- helping the struggling community. The cathedral gave him space and money, though it is no longer a financial supporter. (Today, the Valley's 60 full-time and 30 part-time employees operate on a $5 million budget financed by individual donors, corporations, foundations and the Government.)
"It was a hunger to see young people fed in terms of what they needed" Mr. Bess said about founding the Valley. "It was something I had a calling to do."

SECTION: Section 10; Page 1; Column 5; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: Hotels in West 30's Recover Their Aplomb

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
THE tourist was succinct: "It's good. It's simple." Hege Flatas of Trondheim, Norway, offered this judgment on a $65-a-night room she chose at the Wolcott Hotel on West 31st Street early this month for her four-day visit to New York City. She shared the room with her traveling companion and fellow-Trondheimite, Lill Schumann.
The two 23-year-olds had spent a year working at Disneyworld in Orlando, Fla. Then they went on a one-month travel spree, ending in New York for sightseeing and theater. They used a tourist pamphlet at Penn Station to pick a hotel. 
 They wanted a low rate and a central location. They wanted cleanliness, a private bath and personal security. Handsome appointments were unimportant and so was space. They didn't care about room service or bellmen. They didn't need a bar or restaurant within the hotel. They just wanted a place to sleep.
The fact that they and other budget-minded travelers have been finding satisfaction in the West 30's lately is in good measure a commentary on the resurgence of the area since the city relocated the homeless families that were given emergency housing there in the 80's. Overoccupancy in small rooms ill-fitted for family use, plus inadequate supervision, damaged the area as destination for leisure and business travelers.
The business travelers are typically foreign buyers, often from South America, who shop the district's import-export outlets for stock to ship back home.
The principal tourist hotels are the Roger Williams, the Herald Square, the Stanford, the Wolcott and the Grand Union, all of them offering modest rooms for under $100 a night.
There is also a new hotel, the Gershwin. It is at 7 East 27th Street, in a building that formerly formed the rear portion of the Hotel Latham at 4 East 28th Street. A group led by Urs B. Jakob, a Californian who got his start offering bunk beds in a former rooming house in Venice, Calif., to visitors to the Summer Olympics in Los Angeles in 1984, is gradually converting it to a dormitory-style hostelry. Sixty-five of the 164 rooms are run as dormitories, usually with four beds to a room. The charge is $17 a bed per night.
Elsewhere the plans are more ambitious. Anthony J. Rotonde, director of development for the Orient Hotel Group, a Hong Kong company whose American operations are based in Stamford, Conn., said the group had undertaken a $25 million redevelopment of the 500-room Prince George Hotel, at 10 East 28th Street, vacant after a period of heavy occupancy by homeless families.
The 5,000-square-foot ground floor of an office condominium at 72 Madison Avenue is being purchased for reconstruction as the main entrance. Average room rates are projected at $90 to $100 a night. The project is scheduled for completion in October, Mr. Rotonde said.
The Orient Hotel Group is also the owner of the 600-room Inn on West 57th Street, a former Days Inn at 454 West 57th Street.
But the long-anticipated redevelopment of the 600-room Martinique Hotel, which also had a heavy occupancy of homeless families in the 80's, is reported to have stalled. A lessee who started a reconstruction inside the closed building halted the work because of costs, hotel sources say, and now is in litigation with the owner. The Martinique is on the northeast blockfront of Broadway between 32d and 33d Streets.
Nevertheless, one way or another the hotels of the 30's are gradually moving to strengthen their ability to compete with the rising number of economy-class rooms elsewhere in Manhattan.
IN the general decline of room rates since the late 80's, a number of larger medium-priced hotels have cut quoted rates below $100 for some rooms. That also helps to lower taxes. Rooms that rent for more than $100 pay a 5 percent "luxury" tax imposed by New York State in 1990.
As for occupancy, the over-all picture improved in the city last year. Smith Travel Research, based in Gallatin, Tenn., reported that occupancy rose to 69.4 percent last year from 66.6 percent in 1992. It was a 4.2 percent increase, compared with a 2.9 percent increase nationally.
The firm's New York figures are based on a room count developed by InterBank Brener Hospitality Consultants, of Manhattan. These show a total of 58,300 hotel rooms in New York City in 1993, down from 61,900 in 1992. The temporary closing of the New York Vista Hotel after the World Trade Center explosion in February 1993 alone accounted for the loss of 820 rooms.
Average room rates in the city fell in 1993 to $114.86 from $115.23 in 1992, and $117.80 in 1991, according to Smith Travel Research. These are averages of the actual rates charged rather than the "rack" rate quoted to the individual traveler.
Average rates -- based on actual charges, which include lower rates given to tours and other group travelers -- do not include taxes. When taxes are added in, the prices paid by travelers make New York "the most expensive market in the country," said Randy Smith, president of Smith Travel Research.
The true budget hotels are those that have rack rates under $100 for all or nearly all their rooms. Occasionally, under new ownership, a rundown property is ambitiously overhauled as a budget facility. An example is the Ameritania Hotel, formerly the Bryant, at Broadway and 54th Street.
In some cases new owners are trying to bring back properties after a failed renovation in the 80's. In the budget category, the Woodward, at Broadway and 55th Street, now the Best Western Woodward, is an example.
Some of the lower-priced midlevel hotels that also offer budget rooms are the Wellington, the Edison, the Pennsylvania, the President and Milford Plaza. InterBank Brener defines midlevel as hotels with average rates between $100 and $200. The firm also has a definition for "luxury" hotels (average rates between $200 and $300) and "superluxury" hotels (average rates over $300).
But last year the decline in rates made these thresholds somewhat obsolete. The Waldorf-Astoria had average rates below $200 a room in 1993 and the Plaza Athenee, the Pierre and the Lowell all slipped below the $300-a-night threshold, said Stephen W. Brener, the chief executive of InterBank Brener. He says he now defines luxury hotels as those with average rates of $150 to $250, and superluxury hotels at $250 and above.
All the city's hotels are looking forward to a summer demand stimulated by the presence of the World Cup soccer matches in the United States from June 17 to July 17. The New Jersey Meadowlands is one of the nine locations in the country where matches will be played.
Already travel agencies from abroad are booking blocs of rooms for groups. One agent, Yvonne Cronin, 27, of Shandon Travel in Cork,Ireland, was encountered a few days ago at the Wolcott during her one-day inspection trip on behalf of a group of 50 soccer fans from Cork seeking budget rooms.
"Some rooms in more expensive hotels are not much better than these," Ms. Cronin said. "But you pay for decor and bar facilities that many people don't need." The visitors will pay $80 to $90 a night for the rooms, she said.
THE resurgence of the 30's as a destination for travelers seeking economy lodging is the latest chapter in the ever-changing commercial life of the area. In the early part of the century the East and West 20's and 30's were the center of the city's luxury hotels.
But luxury had long since marched uptown by the time the Department of Social Services, in the mid-80's, flashed the opportunity for extraordinary short-term financial rewards if the hotels agreed to fill vacancies with homeless families. No one believed the hotels were suited to the purpose, even for temporary family occupancy.
Eventually the city implemented a plan to vacate transient hotels and armories that were used for the homeless. The Martinique and the Prince George in particular were left with a need for major reinvestment before they could become successful commercial hotels again. But other properties accepted few if any homeless families and seem now to be benefiting from their low-cost operation and their central location.
At the 120-room Herald Square, Abraham Puchall, a partner in the ownership group, said the hotel has been the beneficiary of demand for hotel space in the neighborhood by Latin American buyers, who represent about 25 percent of the occupancy. Many of them come to purchase costume jewelry at nearby outlets like Metro Charles and Bay Sales, Mr. Puchall said.
The Herald Square, like many other budget hotels, upgrades itself gradually, as revenue permits. It has essentially three tiers of prices -- $40 a night for rooms that share bathrooms with another room; $90 for recently upgraded rooms; and $60 for midlevel rooms with private baths. The hotel was built in 1893 as the original home of Life magazine. The Puchall family bought it in the 60's.
The 280-room Wolcott Hotel, at 4 West 31st Street, was designed in the Beaux-Arts style by John H. Duncan, who was also the architect of Grant's Tomb, and leased by its developer, William C. Dewey, to James H. Breslin, a leading hotel operator of the day.
The lobby is decorated in the Louis XVI style, with marble pillars, mirrored panels and a lofty, ornate ceiling from which an elaborate chandelier hangs. But the lobby ends abruptly with a modest check-in desk, which shuts off what was formerly an equally elaborate ballroom.
The ballroom has been leased out to a restaurateur who runs it as The Five Spot. Other commercial space once part of the hotel also has been leased out.
SCOTT ERLICH, the manager for the last five years, said business had improved at a rate of 5 percent a year since he took over. Many of his guests find out about the hotel through travel publications in Europe. "Right now occupancy is 53 percent, but April to November is the high season," he said. "We have close to 90 or 100 percent on certain days."
The nonseasonal travelers include buyers like Alejandro Valderrama of Barquisimeto, Venezuela. He loads up on perfumes, watches, sports accessories and other consumer items at wholesale establishments in the West 30's, and has them repackaged for shipment back home. "On this trip I was here from Monday to Thursday and I bought 4,000 bottles of perfume and 300 watches from Korea," said Mr. Valderrama.
The repackaging and shipping has itself become an important business in the West 30's. A travel agency specializing in Latin America, Edward Travel, has established a freight-forwarding operation, E. D. Travel & Transportation Inc., in ground-floor space leased from the Wolcott Hotel. It does packaging and shipping for buyers so they don't have to clutter hotel lobbies and rooms with their purchases.
Alexander Duran, senior vice president, said the company moves over two million pounds of goods a year. "With the North American Free Trade Agreement, the Mexicans will be coming to buy without the 13- to 14 percent duty," he said.
Four blocks away, at 7 East 27th Street, is Mr. Jakob's hostel-style Gershwin Hotel. Pop-art sculpture has been installed in its lobby and small lounges have been created to help young international travelers get to know each other. There are private rooms, with single or double occupancy, renting for $70 a night.
"I came to New York with a mission to find a facility where I could service international travelers, beginning with young European, Canadians, New Zealanders and Japanese," said Mr. Jakob.
His first venture was at the 1,000-room Hotel Carter at 250 West 43d Street. He leased two high floors for his youthful worldwide clientele. Later he found the 27th Street property with the help of Jeffrey Wilder, a broker, who is now a partner.
"We are a social facility," he said. "People don't stay here just because it's cheap."
The typical room in an older Manhattan hotel operated at the budget level is about 15 by 15 feet, or 10 by 15 feet -- sometimes 15 by 20 feet. There are usually one or two 4- by 6-foot double beds, rather than the queen- or king-sized beds found in more recently built, larger hotel rooms.
There is a small and simple private bath with a shower, a small closet, a bureau, a color television set and a wall air-conditioner, and not much more. The halls may or may not be carpeted, and are not too bright. The probability is that if the hotel is genuinely seeking out business with tourist or leisure travelers it will either be in upgraded condition or in the process of upgrading.
AT the 96-room Newtown at 2528 Broadway, near 94th Street, a $2 million upgrading was done in the last year and a half after the hotel was purchased empty by an operating group led by Glenn Isaacs. Rack rates are $55 a night for a single and $65 for a double. Mr. Isaacs, who is responsible also for marketing rooms at two other economy-class hotels, the Travel Inn at 515 West 42d Street and the Hotel Belvedere at 319 West 48th Street, said that young German travelers were 40 percent of his business. "Give them a backpack and a clean room with a sink and friendly service and they are happy travelers," he said. "They don't need amenities or large rooms or concierges. They are self-confident travelers."
The 12-floor, 250-room Ameritania, at Broadway and 54th Street, was developed by Hank Freid, who also transformed the Broadway Arms Hotel, at Broadway and 103d Street, into the Malibu Studios in 1985.
MR. FREID said he had invested $5 million in the Ameritania project after purchasing a 49-year leasehold at a favorable price in 1990. There is a new lobby with granite walls and darkly lit modernistic decor, and new carpeting and new furnishings and decor throughout. Rooms rent for $89 to $99 a night.
"The Japanese business has fizzled quite a bit," Mr. Freid said. "The Italians are down 40 percent. We're making a push to get known domestically."
Twenty-one unfranchised budget hotels in the city utilize the reservation and representation system of Utell International, based in Omaha, a division of the Reed Travel Group. David Chestler, director of the mid-Atlantic region, estimated that there were 10,000 "quality" budget rooms in Manhattan.
"Twenty percent of them show up on no maps, and they don't advertise," he said.
Convention business in New York City is not directly the key to high occupancy in budget hotels, but a lack of it increases the supply of lower-cost rooms in standard hotels, undercutting the budget business. Hotel people say the city is hurt in the competition for convention business by the extraordinary state and city taxes on room rents.
First, there is an 8 1/4 percent sales tax. On top of that the city added a 5 percent tax in 1986 and an additional 1 percent tax in 1990. In 1990 the state imposed a 5 percent tax on rooms renting for more than $100 a night.
Thus a room renting for $100 or more has a basic 19 1/4 percent tax -- 8 1/4 percent plus 6 percent plus 5 percent. In addition, there is a flat New York City tax of $2 a room if the basic charge is more than $50 a night.
So the traveler renting one room for $150, for example, will pay a $30.87 tax for a total bill of $180.87. A room renting for $99, which is free of the 5 percent state tax, will cost $116.11 -- 14 1/4 percent plus the $2 room tax. Both Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani have proposed reductions in the hotel taxes.
Taxes were not on the minds of the young budget travelers encountered at the Wolcott, however. Safety and prices were. "The hotel was recommended as cheap in the guide I used," said Michael Bray, 34, of Belfast, who was traveling with his younger sister and staying in a room that he said cost $59 a night. "Not knowing New York, I was nervous at first. But we've walked all over Manhattan."

HEADLINE: South Hackensack Journal;
County's Takeover of Police Department Angers Residents

BYLINE: By TOM TOOLEN 

DATELINE: SOUTH HACKENSACK

 BODY:
THIS tiny town so closely knit that parents know not only the whereabouts of their own children, but also those of their neighbors' children most of the time -- remains in a state of shock over the Bergen County takeover of its Police Department after charges of widespread ticket fixing, favoritism and illegal gambling by police officers.
John J. Fahy, the Bergen County Prosecutor, took over the 17-member Police Department Jan. 31. The Police Chief, Arthur Montenegro Jr., 44, resigned along with three of his officers. One officer, Anthony Giaquinto, 29, is charged with illegal gambling. In addition, a South Hackensack Councilman, Lucien Zeppone, is accused of running a gambling operation in his bar. 
 Instead of being outraged that their police officers might be acting illegally, however, many of the 2,100 residents of this one-square-mile borough are squarely backing the former Police Chief and the officials.
Many of those residents say that everyone makes bets sometimes -- so what's the big deal? Even the accusation that Chief Montenegro squelched a cocaine arrest in 1993 as a favor to a friend of a South Hackensack municipal employee didn't disturb many people interviewed here. "It was only a small amount of drugs, and he was doing a favor for someone," said one resident who insisted on anonymity.
Many here also back Officer Giaquinto, who was charged with official misconduct, conspiracy to promote gambling and promoting gambling. Office Giaquinto is accused of dropping bets off at two New York City betting parlors, both of which have Mafia connections Mr. Fahy said. The two other police officers who resigned were not charged criminally, but they had admitted placing bets with Mr. Giaquinto. Police officials raid a bar owned by Officer Giaquinto's parents because of suspected illegal gambling there.
Mr. Fahy contended Councilman Zeppone with maintaining a gambling operation at his saloon, the Stats Sports Bar, on Super Bowl Sunday. Mr. Zeppone has remained on the Council. All the defendants were released on their own recognizance and are awaiting hearings.
William Scheeler, 57, who lives on Phillips Avenue, said that he didn't know about the charges against the Chief and the others, but that he thought "the welfare hotel on Route 46 is the real problem in this town, not the gambling."
Mr. Scheeler, an unemployed sheetmetal worker who was shoveling snow in front of his well-kept house the other day, said that instead of worrying about gambling, the Bergen County Prosecutor ought to worry about cleaning out the crime and drugs going on at the hotel. "In the summer, we are outside and we have to watch all these criminal types walking up and down the front of our house," he said. It's a disgrace."
Mr. Fahy placed one of his lieutenants, Alan Grieco, as acting chief the Police Department, saying there was strong evidence that a rash of ticket-fixing and other favors were going on right in police headquarters.
Most of the incidents, Mr. Fahy said, involved fixing tickets or reducing charges for motor vehicle violations, minor drug offenses and driving while intoxicated cases.
"We believe it was happening for quite a few people for quite a long time and these people were either residents or had friends in the Police Department," Mr. Fahy said.
In taking a stand against the county takeover, many residents called Mr. Fahy's actions unfair and said he giving the town a bad name.
"South Hackensack is a good family town and they are making us out to be some sort of gangsters or something just because people bet on football games," said Arlene Spano, 37, who has lived in town for a year.
The only resident interviewed who said anything bad about the Police Chief or the others would not give his name. After some mildly disparaging comments about "big shots" and "things getting out of hand," a reporter asked for his name. "What do you think, I'm crazy?" the man replied.
This togetherness code in South Hackensack has a lot to do with the small size of the town. It may be the only municipality in the state to consist of three sections that are divided and separated by other towns -- Little Ferry, Hackensack and Teterboro.
Most of the residents, living in tidy, Colonial houses with postage-stamp lawns, live in the section north of Route 46, a busy east-west highway lined with car dealerships, welfare hotels and go-go bars. The second piece lies about a mile south on the other side of the borough and is set apart by Little Ferry. The third section is a tiny square housing factories and discount market. It is west of the police headquarters on Phillips Avenue, one of the two main streets of the town.
Ms. Spano said that most of the residents of South Hackensack feel the same way, and that a rally in support of the former Chief and the others was being organized. "We expect hundreds of people to attend," she said, adding that most people feel that betting on the Super Bowl is not such a serious crime.
As for the charges that the former Chief had charges dismissed on drugs, many residents also feel that this is no cause for alarm. At Tony D'Ambrosio's barber shop on Huyler Street, the main street in South Hackensack, Mr. D'Ambrosio, 72, a barber in town for 42 years, said Mr. Montenegro was "just a nice guy who was doing a favor for somebody."
Wouldn't you help a friend who was in need if he asked you to?" he said. The barber shop is directly across the street from Stats Sports Bar, in the hub of the town. Stats has more than 20 television sets, flashing lights, loud music and nonstop go-go girls. A patron in the bar the other day said the town was getting a bad name "for no good reason at all."
"It's a shame, all this over some two-bit charges," he said.
There isn't much of a town center, Huyler Street and Phillips Avenue being pretty much the main streets. But the merchants on those streets all feel that the town got a bad name from the county takeover.
"We will send a message that we are good people here and we are not some sort of Mafia-dominated town like they are saying," said one resident. As South Hackensack maintains its way of life the best way it can, the residents can see the spire on the courthouse and the county seat of Hackensack a short distance away. Many see Hackensack as the enemy. "That's where Fahy is, and he is the enemy," said one resident, staring at the courthouse dome.
 In addition, the map with the article was incomplete. It showed only the main section of South Hackensack.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 22; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 1164 words

HEADLINE: HERS;
Where Mothers Matter

BYLINE: By Gabrielle Glaser; Gabrielle Glaser reported from Eastern Europe for
The Times and The Economist.

 BODY:
It was a muggy Washington day, and my daughter and I were in the midst of our daily rounds: the bank, the dry cleaners, the Italian deli. She drifted off to sleep, and I wheeled the stroller into a crowded cafe for an iced tea. Finally, I could read my newspaper.
 The only empty chair was opposite another woman, young and red-haired, absently guarding a dozing infant. Would she mind if I sat with her, I asked. She gestured to the table, patting the seat beside her. We chatted; she seemed, as I often am during the day, eager for adult conversation. My daughter woke, and I leaned over to stroke her plump cheek. Finished with my tea, I kissed her neck to elicit a stream of giggles as we prepared to go. Curious, the woman mused: "She really likes you." 
I should hope so," I answered.
 "Have you been with her long?"
 Puzzled, I said: "Since birth."
 "Oh," she said, embarrassment flickering on her face. "You're her mother." Pause. "I only meet other nannies."
 Having lived in Washington before, I had steeled myself on my return for the verities of this city: that what you do is much more important than who you are; your job matters as much here as style in New York or looks in Los Angeles. Still, I was startled. I knew that Washington, with the highest percentage of dual-income couples in the country, was an exceptional place. But was I really the only woman inside the Beltway who wasn't back to work after a few weeks of maternity leave?
 My daughter was born in 1992, just before we returned to the United States after three years as journalists in Poland. Since my husband's new job here began almost immediately, the task of finding and eventually renovating the house we bought fell to me. I could write from home when I wanted, and besides, I was looking forward to sharing those precious firsts of her new life: first steps, first swims, first words.
 Abroad, I'd had the job of a lifetime, covering Eastern Europe's struggle to redefine itself after nearly a half-century of Communism -- its rocky transition to a market economy, the resurgence of nationalism, a growing theocracy, a war. My work was fascinating. But to the people I lived among, quite simply, it was unimportant.
 For them, the most important fact about me seemed to be my reproductive life. After the cursory glance for a wedding band came the question: "Do you have children?"
 What really alienated me from Poles was my childlessness. As the gap between me and 30 narrowed, I was admonished by everyone from the greengrocer on the corner to my neighbor's gardener: "You Americans, you're crazy, waiting so long for life's real joy!" Others were more solicitous, inquiring into the delicate issue of "female problems." What else could explain such a predicament?
 To me, the sorry state of Polish womanhood was summed up by the maternity wards: anyone delivering her firstborn after the age of 25 was designated a stara matka -- an old mother.
 All this only reinforced my view of the Polish male attitude toward women: that beneath the courtliness and incessant hand-kissing, females were merely the vessel to the next generation. I idealized the United States, telling Polish women friends how lucky American women were, how respected we were, how we were treated as equals.
 So the reaction of my American friends to the news that I was pregnant, at 27, was as baffling as the Poles' insistence that every woman start her family at 22. "What were you using?" asked one friend, eyes wide. "What are you going to do about it?" asked another, as if I were in high school.
 Among Poles, however, the response was ecstatic. I was given flowers, jars of pickles and plenty of unsolicited advice. One friend, a father of four, became positively weepy when my husband and I broke the news.
 For two years, I had laughingly recounted tales of Polish "backwardness" in missives back home: the indolent service in stores that closed without warning in the middle of the day; food greasy enough to clog the healthiest of arteries, and, above all, the antiquated approach to women. But suddenly, I found myself appreciating Poland's charms -- at least in matters maternal.
 The Poles, even the Communists among them, seemed to have at least one thing right. Fifty-year-old laws, still on the books, grant a year or more of maternity leave. The many Polish doctors, professors and lawyers who are also mothers think nothing of taking off several years to be with their kids; indeed, it is expected. There is a Polish saying: You have a lifetime to work, but children are only young once.
 On a visit back home a few months later, I escaped the post-Communist malaise, only to find myself adrift in post-feminist America. Of my friends and colleagues here, I know just a handful of women with young children -- and only one who is home with her year-old son. Most of the women I know are waiting until their late 30's to have children; others feel great ambivalence toward motherhood altogether.
 My final return trip from Poland to the United States signaled, once again, just how out of step I would be with local views on maternity. Three hours into the flight from Warsaw, the Polish pilot strolled out into the aisle and made a beeline for my seat. "What a beautiful child, and so round," he said. "I hope you're still breast-feeding." (Such familiarity seems strange only in retrospect.) Before I could respond, I was surrounded by a crowd of Poles: mothers, fathers, aunts, uncles -- each chiming in with their opinion of nursing. What I had dreaded -- an endless flight with a tiny baby -- turned out to be quite pleasant. The grandmother behind me offered to hold my daughter every hour so I could stretch. The flight crew couldn't have been more attentive.
 So it was a rude surprise to land in Chicago en route to visit my family in Oregon. The on-ground assistance I'd requested from my American carrier, which I desperately needed to traverse O'Hare, was nowhere to be seen. Never mind, I thought, this is America; I'll manage fine. But even getting through immigration was tough. Customs, it turned out, had confiscated my stroller. Baby strapped to my chest, $20 bill clutched in my fist, I flagged down a skycap and, braving a blizzard, we took an outdoor shortcut. Finally, huffing and puffing, diaper bag and car seat dangling from both arms, I reached the gate and the two ticket takers barked at me to speed it up.
 Today, as I continue to be mistaken for my daughter's au pair, I find myself in a quintessentially Polish state of mind, wanting something that is in all likelihood unattainable. I long for a land that does not yet exist, a place where women are valued both for their intellects and their motherhood, and where the choices between career and nurturing are somehow less stark. I find myself feeling what the Poles call tesknota -- a sweet-sad nostalgia -- for an unliberated land in which I was for a time very pleased to be an old mother.

SECTION: Section 13WC; Page 10; Column 3; Westchester Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1170 words

HEADLINE: A Conference Center Expands, Lovingly

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

DATELINE: TARRYTOWN

 BODY:
SPECTACULARLY situated on 26 acres overlooking the Hudson River in Tarrytown, two splendid 19th-century mansions link past and present.
The large stone Gothic (the Biddle House) and a white columned Greek Revival (the King House) make up the nucleus of Tarrytown House, the first corporate conference center in the country and possibly still the most beautiful. This year, Tarrytown House is celebrating its 30th anniversary with a $3.5 million expansion of the Biddle mansion, which, when completed, will be equally suited to corporate functions during the week and social events on weekends.
 
Proceeding on Schedule
 "The interiors have been designed to make the transformation from a serious meeting space, with state-of-the-art audio-visual equipment, to a romantic ballroom seamless," said Frank X. Fisher, general partner of the Manhattan-based Fisher Hotels Group, which owns the conference center. "Despite the bitter weather, thankfully the project is on schedule. We are aiming for a late summer opening, and since we have already accepted bookings for Labor Day weekend -- a meeting for 110 and a wedding for 250 -- in the new wing, we had better be ready." 
 Expansion of the conference center, Mr. Fisher continued, will add 17,000 square feet of space to the Biddle mansion: a 5,500-square-foot room for banquets and meetings, a reception area of 1,800 square feet and a bridal suite on an upper level. In addition, the larger space is expected to create 40 new jobs.
 
Extensive Research Required
 "And it will give us much greater flexibility in the groups we can accommodate for both corporate and social events, which will be a boost for business," Mr. Fisher said. "What happens is that we frequently get requests for both from the same client. For example, a businessman who has participated in a conference here will come back as father of the bride, and the reverse is true, wedding guests translate into business clients. Now we will be able to offer banquet seating for 400, meeting space for 500 and space for receptions for up to 600 people. And with the new kitchen, we will be capable of preparing 750 dinners at one time."
Laurence M. Harman, the architect for the project, said that designing an addition to a historic property required extensive research of the period. "Tarrytown House has the distinction of being one of the historic hotels of America listed by the National Trust for Historic Preservation for preserving its historic character and architectural quality," Mr. Harman said. "In our practice, we frequently work on landmark buildings, and on this project we have tried to protect the integrity of the building by retaining its residential feeling. I like to think Mrs. Biddle would approve of the addition."
This is the second major renovation Mr. Fisher has overseen since the conference center was acquired by his group of investors from Robert Schwartz in December 1986.
 
Paying for a 'Labor of Love'
 "Bob Schwartz was the founder of the conference center concept, and we were bowled over by the beauty of the place when we bought it," Mr. Fisher said. "Nevertheless, shortly afterward we spent $7 million on restoring the mansions to their former glory and completely re-doing all the furnishings in our 150 guest rooms and 30 meeting rooms."
Restoring the King House alone, Mr. Fisher said, called for an outlay of more than $1 million.
"And what a job it was!" he said. "A labor of love. In the library, for instance, we uncovered beautiful wooden paneling that had been brought over from one of the great estates in England. It had been covered by layers and layers of paint for over 100 years. And the carved marble fireplaces in many of the rooms had suffered the same fate. The craftsmen working on the house never knew what they were going to find, but eventually they meticulously restored all the fireplaces and wooden carvings."
Mr. Fisher continued: "King House is really a gem. There are 10 guest rooms, each of them individually decorated in the original period, some with private balconies. The house has its own kitchen and five other rooms that lend themselves to meetings for groups of 10 to 18 or for banquets for up to 100. The house is completely private and self-contained, making it suitable for a wedding with accommodations for out-of-town guests or for a high-level, very private business conference."
 
More-Competitive 90's
 Despite the recession, conferences still play a vital role in the way business is conducted.
"It's more competitive in the 90's, but Fortune 500 companies and global companies still have to meet," Mr. Fisher said. "Most of our business comes from past clients and corporate word-of-mouth recommendations. In the 80's, planners booked conferences a year in advance, but now the lead time is shorter -- about three to six months down the road. And the principal players are different. In the 80's computer companies and pharmaceuticals dominated; now it's Wall Street firms and banks who are holding most of the meetings."
Changes in management and marketing, he added, have helped produce a rise of 15 percent in business each year for the last several years.
"The net result is that we have been able to fund the addition from cash flow," he said. "And we have just named James David Ball as general manager, so we are even more optimistic about increasing business. Mr. Ball is an experienced conference center manager who is coming to us from Woodlands, in Texas."
Most meetings are held during the week, Mondays through Thursdays, and last two or three days in one or more of 30 rooms suitable for groups of 10 to 150 participants. Conference planners are assigned to every group and a conference business service desk handles administrative details.
Francine Harris, acting director of sales, said that a complete meeting package, priced at $350 a person, includes breakfast and lunch and buffets, sit-down dinners, frequent coffee breaks and recreational activities. "We have a fully equipped sports center with tennis, indoor and outdoor pools, racquetball, bowling and billiards with a physical fitness instructor on staff," she added.
 
'Magic Mountain Feeling'
 The ratio of staff -- 180 -- to guests, she said, is very high. "One-on-one service is available 24 hours a day," she said. "Snacks are unlimited, and clients tell us frequently that they would come back for the food alone. We are known for the excellence of our kitchen, which is under the direction of our executive chef, Peter Calchera, who has been here for over 20 years."
Although companies from all over the globe come to Tarrytown House to hold meetings, Mr. Fisher said, a surprisingly large number also come from New York City.
"I think it is because there is a magic mountain feeling about the place, and it's free from distractions," he said. "That makes for a very productive meeting. Sometimes it's hard to believe that we are only 24 miles away from mid-Manhattan."

HEADLINE: New Job: Selling Pizza

BYLINE: By JUDY POKRAS

DATELINE: EAST HANOVER

 BODY:
UNABLE to find work when they were laid off two years ago, Ann Marie Carragher, an architect, became a nanny, and Oscar Aguilar, an electrical engineer, took a job delivering pizza.
One year later, last September, with a loan from her parents, Ms. Carragher and Mr. Aguilar bought the pizza shop where he had been employed. Now the couple, who became engaged on Christmas Eve, work 12 hours a day, seven days a week in their growing takeout business, the Gourmet Pizza Shoppe at 7 Ronald Drive. 
 "We didn't know the business," Ms. Carragher, 28, said. "My parents decided to lend us the money because it would take a few years till the construction industry turns around."
When she lost her architectural job at a Manhattan company, she tried freelancing, but couldn't find architectural work. When her unemployment ran out, she found a job in Denville caring for a little girl "and tidying up the house." She missed architecture, she said, but "you've got to do what you've got to do, you know?"
 
'Honest, Clean Living'
 She said the pizza shop "is an honest, clean living."
"I didn't want to be part of politics," Ms. Carragher said. "In this little pizzeria, I do my work. You've done your job and then go home."
Mr. Aguilar, 29, said he missed engineering, but wouldn't want to go back to an office.
"I feel a lot of freedom here," he said about the pizza shop. "I'm here all day, but being that it's our business, you feel better about it."
The couple learned the ropes from the shop's previous owner in three weeks. They barely had time to get up to speed when, three weeks after they took over the business, they were deluged with orders, like a $350 order to be delivered within an hour.
That was when a steady customer, Image Construction Studio, expanded by 11,000 square feet, making for a lot more catering business, Ms. Carragher said. "It was a godsend," she said.
Having expanded, Image Construction Studio, a rental stage for film and video production, sometimes needs food for as many as 50 people at a time, said Bill Kempner, an owner of the studio. He said the Gourmet Pizza Shoppe provides generous portions that "Ann Marie sets up herself."
"The clients just rave about their food,." Mr. Kempner said
 
Menu Offers Pizza Soup
 Besides such items as pizza -- available with pepperoni and extra cheese -- and an assortment of entrees,the menu features pizza soup. A local police officer who buys one soup or another from the shop every night has asked the couple if they would make their soups available commercially, Ms. Carragher said.
Mr. Aguilar said they have been trying new products and "taking the time to make things right."
The couple recently experimented with closing the store on Sundays, but not to have a day to relax. They needed a day in the store without orders to make preparations for the rest of the week.
"The pace that you're under is just . . . it keeps us busy," Ms. Carragher said. "It's great to be busy. We'd be in a lot of trouble if we weren't."
A visitor to the shop remarked that the two must get along well with each other, as they spend all their time together in an often high-stress atmosphere.
"Thank God for small favors," Ms. Carragher said.
Mr. Aguilar said, "We really do."
Ms. Carragher added: "When it gets busy, he's really calm. I get stressed out."
 
He Makes the Pizzas
 Ms. Carragher prepares the non-pizza items while Mr. Aguilar makes the pizzas. Cooking is a job that he enjoys. "I always cooked," he said. "Since I was a kid. My dream was to have a restaurant. My mother taught me how to cook."
But now, any chance they get, they go out to eat, mainly Mexican food. "I don't even look at Italian anymore," Ms. Carragher said.
Home is Madison. Ms. Carragher said she missed Manhattan, where she lived previously, and where she had been working on a master's degree in real estate, before her fiance "dragged me out here, kicking and screaming," she said with a smile.
What she misses most now is her inability to catch up on her reading. Before the couple left New York, they took advantage of the culture. "We went to seven operas, Carnegie Hall, Radio City, museums," Ms. Carragher said. "In this world, nothing's forever. You have to hit it when you can."
The couple's dream is to open a vegetarian restaurant in San Francisco.
"Before we bought this, we were going to become vegetarians," Ms. Carragher said. "We were trying to be vegetarian, but with this kind of business, it's difficult."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ann Marie Carragher, an architect, and her fiance, Oscar Aguilar, an electrical engineer, working in the East Hanover pizza shop that they bought after losing their old jobs. (Tom Jackson for The New York Times)
