HEADLINE: Jewish Emigres With High Hopes

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON

 BODY:
RITA and Yuri Shneider left behind their professions, their homeland and an extended family when they and their two sons boarded a flight to Kennedy International Airport in 1991. On the pretext of taking a vacation, the four Jews from the former Soviet Union disembarked in New York City with only their suitcases and a few photographs from their past to begin the new life they had secretly planned for years.
"For the children, we did this for them," said the 35-year-old mother, who was a doctor in a small town near Riga in Latvia. "We said we were coming only to visit, but really we never planned to go home." 
 Emblematic of their dreams, there are now seven trophies displayed on top of the television in the family's tiny living room here. The awards belong to 9-year-old Dimitri, their oldest son, who recently won a series of regional chess championships.
Dr. Shneider, the mother, smiled and said: "You see, it says: 'Dimitri Shneider: First Place.' Anything is possible here."
The Shneiders are one of about 75 Jewish families from the former Soviet Union who have arrived in Westchester recently, said Dr. Gene Sosin and Gloria Donen Sosin, who have written a guide for newcomers in Russian and English called "Welcome to Westchester."
These families are part of a new wave of immigrants resettling in the United States to escape growing anti-Semitism and a difficult economy in the former Soviet republics. The recent immigration figures, 32,204 Jews from the former Soviet Union last year, are higher even than during the late 1970's -- before the normalization of relations between the Soviet Union and the United States, when large numbers of refugees fled for political reasons.
Robin A. Grenell, chairman of the Russian services committee of the Mosholu Montefiore Community Center in the Bronx, a resettlement center, said, "These new people are not like Anatoly Scharansky," referring to the former Soviet dissident and human rights champion who immigrated to Israel in 1986. "The current group of immigrants needs to eat. They are not refugees of conscience. They come here to get ahead."
The new nationalism in the former Soviet republics worked against many like the Shneiders, who grew up in Ukraine and later moved to Latvia to work and raise a family. Mr. Shneider, 37, a chief engineer of repairs for a Baltic rail system in Latvia, was dismissed from his position shortly after the country's independence, and his job was given to a native Latvian.
Dr. Shneider said she, too, had expected to lose her job at the clinic where she was a doctor of sports medicine. "We became like extra people for them," she said. "Although we did not like Communism, things were more stable for us then."
Also, the intensifying nationalism, combined with economic instability in the former republics, said Dr. Misha Galperin, associate executive vice president for the New York Association for New Americans, "has unleashed a new wave of anti-Semitism among individuals and fringe groups that is not untypical in times of economic difficulty."
He added, "Traditionally, Jews have been singled out for blame in such circumstances." The association is one of the largest refugee-resettlement organizations in the country.
Many Jewish refugees live in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx, where resettlement groups help them learn English, adjust to a new culture and find jobs. But Norman Levine, director of field service for the international Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society, said there was no way to determine the number of refugees living in the New York City area, and the Census Bureau said it does not keep figures based on religion.
 
No Close Relatives in the U.S.
 Ms. Grenell, however, estimated that there were 7,500 Jewish refugees living in the Bronx, and she said the figures for Brooklyn and Queens were substantially higher. Some unofficial estimates place the number of Jewish immigrants from the former Soviet Union in New York City at 65,000 and the number for the entire New York City area at 150,000.
Jewish refugees living outside metropolitan areas have little access to services provided by resettlement organizations, and Ms. Grenell said: "In a real sense, they have to hit the ground running. They tend to go it alone in areas like Westchester, where there is little sense of a Russian Jewish community."
Although most Jews from the former Soviet Union begin the emigration procedure formally through the American Embassy in Moscow, the Shneiders used their visitors' visas to leave, because they had no close relatives in the United States as required for refugee status (cousins are not considered immediate family members). Since arriving, they have applied for green cards, which will allow them to continue living and working here. But they are also officially seeking political asylum so they can obtain permanent-residency status.
 
Temporary Working Papers
 A green card is an indication of legal permanent residency. An immigrant can apply for the card after one year of residency in this country. Immigrants like the Shneiders, who came on visitors' visas, must first obtain political asylum status before becoming eligible for a green card. The Shneiders have temporary working papers while they wait for a ruling on their application for political asylum.
The Shneiders settled in this riverfront village -- a suburban community of 10,000 people, which they said reminds them of home -- to be close to cousins who live here. Also, because they immigrated with visitors' visas, they did not work through established immigration channels, which might have encouraged them to find housing and jobs in New York City.
"Families that settle in the county tend to be risk takers," said Dr. Howard Rubin, director of the Westchester Jewish Conference, an umbrella organization representing 86 synagogues or other organizations. "But being in a place like this also tends to accelerate their assimilation, because they aren't speaking Russian 24 hours a day as they might in Brighton Beach."
Dr. Rubin said that "even though there is no center for emigres here, for the most part, Russian Jews in Westchester are faring well."
Initially, Dr. Shneider worked as a baby sitter and house cleaner, but she is now employed by the physical-therapy department of Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco. She is also studying for a degree in physical therapy at Mercy College and is taking an English-as-a-second-language course there as well.
 
A Son in Ukraine
 Mr. Shneider works for All Makes Heating and Air Conditioning in Eastchester and is taking technical courses offered by the Board of Cooperative Education Services so that he can advance in his job.
Their sons, Igor, 6, and Dimitri, attend Hillside Elementary School. Polina Shneider, Mr. Shneider's mother who lived in Israel, has since joined the family here, and she is responsible for most of the cooking and child care while the parents work and study.
In Dobbs Ferry, Vera Fedorovskya, 47, also immigrated to the United States on a visitors' visa, although she had originally planned to return to Ukraine, where her 24-year-old son lives.
"It was a bad life for Jews there," said Ms. Fedorovskya, an accountant. "My eyes just opened when I came in 1990, and I did not want to go home."
She now works as a bookkeeper for Children's Village in Dobbs Ferry, where she has an apartment, and has applied through the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society for a green card. Although she said she is alone much of the time and worries about her son, she added that she is glad she lives in the United States.
 
Responsible for One Another
 In part, a local synagogue, the Greenburgh Hebrew Center in Dobbs Ferry, has provided a support network for the Shneiders and Ms. Fedorovskya.
"It gives the congregation a sense of fulfilling several commandments of the Jewish tradition," Rabbi Barry Kenter said. "There is an overarching concept that all Jews are responsible for one another."
Even though they have established themselves in homes and new jobs since arriving and have made new friends, the Shneiders and Ms. Fedorovskya -- like many Jewish refugees -- have experienced setbacks professionally since leaving their homeland. Dr. Shneider is not pursuing her career as a doctor because, she said, she cannot afford to take time out to study for American medical exams or for the required medical residency.
Mr. Shneider said he was grateful to find a job in a related technical field and was willing to retrain.
And Ms. Fedorovskya said that she, too, was happy to be supporting herself here, even though it meant starting over again in her field.
In terms of their backgrounds, adjustments to a new country and their aspirations for the future, Mr. and Mrs. Shneider and Ms. Fedorovskya are typical of many Jewish refugees from the former Soviet Union, immigration specialists said.
As a group, these emigres tend to be technicians and professionals in white-collar jobs, with strong educational backgrounds -- computer programmers, engineers, nurses, doctors, bookkeepers and teachers, Dr. Galperin said. Some are entrepreneurs -- owners of food stores, nightclubs, taxi and limousine services -- and only a few rely on public assistance during the first year, he said.
He added that many emigres "experience a sense of loss at first."
But a follow-up study by the Council of Jewish Federations and the City University of New York showed that over a 10-year period most refugees from the former Soviet Union make up for their initial setbacks. Within a decade, the average family income for the emigres reached $34,000, compared with the $29,000 average for all American families, according to the 1990 study.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Rita Shneider and her son, Igor, at their Hastings-on-Hudson home, where they have lived since leaving Latvia in 1991. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: There id No 'Middle East'

BYLINE: By Robert D. Kaplan; Robert D. Kaplan is a contributing editor of The Atlantic Monthly. His most recent books are "The Arabists: The Romance of an American Elite" and "Balkan Ghosts: A Journey Through History."

 BODY:
Last July, in the course of a briefing at a policy foundation in Washington, I asked a question about the effect of the Clinton Administration's Balkan policy on the Middle East. A high-ranking State Department area expert turned to me in derision, and said, in effect, that there was no connection. After an embarrassed silence the session resumed, concerned entirely with the inside baseball of the Arab-Israeli peace process. Indeed, the State Department has been trying -- without notable success -- to move the Balkans out of the President's "in" box to make room for the Middle East.
This is less a strategy than a dangerous bureaucratic convenience, for the false borders erected by area experts are fast being superseded by history. Middle East specialists today are like Sovietologists in the late 1980's -- on the brink of a rude upheaval they can't see coming. The reason, simply, is that Turkey, the Balkans and the so-called Middle East (and to lesser degrees the Caucasus nations and Central Asia) are re-emerging as one region -- what historically minded Europeans have always referred to as the greater "Near East." The former Ottoman Empire and even the former Byzantine world are fusing back together following the aberration of the cold war. The implications of this tectonic shift are, needless to say, enormous. 
 There are four reasons why we fail to conceive of Turkey and the Balkans (as well as the Caucasus and Central Asia) as part of the region that we have falsely labeled the "Middle East." First, Turkey's membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization has allowed it to be identified with Europe. Second, Communism imprisoned the Balkans, the Caucasus and Central Asia in a historical black hole from 1945 to 1989. Third, the Arab-Israeli conflict -- institutionalized for decades partly on account of superpower competition -- permitted us to separate the Arab world from the rest of the region.
Fourth, and most interestingly, the global responsibilities thrust upon the United States after World War II led to the creation of area experts in government, academia and think tanks. Their effect on policy and public opinion has been to splinter and compartmentalize what used to be geographic wholes. The academic and policy-making nomenklatura invented a new world based not on real borders so much as on the borders of their knowledge, and lack thereof. As someone who has written extensively about Turkey and the Balkans, as well as the Middle East, I have seen how these areas constitute two entirely different subcultures of Washington society and wonkdom, with little or no cross-fertilization between the two.
These artificial divisions have warped the world view of Westerners and erased some historical truths from public consciousness. Turks led the House of Islam for almost 850 years, from the Seljuk conquest of Anatolia in 1071 to the defeat of the Ottoman Empire in 1918. Yet, as far as the West is concerned, Islam is predominantly Arab and synonomous with fundamentalism. Until the Iranian Revolution in 1978, even the 50 million Muslims of Persia were largely invisible to us -- just as 60 million Muslims in Turkey, and a greater number of Turkic-speaking Muslims in the Caucasus region and Central Asia, are still relatively invisible. While we in the West have gained acquaintance with Arab Islamic history and, since 1978, with some precepts of Shiite Islam in Iran, we know little of such things as the great Sufi tariqats (somewhat mystical sects, literally "fraternities"), which have defined Islamic identity in Turkey and the Balkans.
For example, if we knew a little more about Jalal ed-Din Rumi, the 13th-century Turkic founder of the tariqat that was associated with the whirling dervishes, Islam might not seem incompatible with democracy, and Islamic fundamentalism might not seem so monolithic and threatening.
Rumi dismissed "immature fanatics" who scorn music and poetry. He cautioned that a beard or a mustache on a cleric is no sign of wisdom. Rumi favored the individual over the crowd and consistently spoke against tyranny. Rumi's legacy is more applicable to democratizing tendencies in the Muslim world than are figures of the Arab and Iranian religious pantheons with whom the West is more familiar.
Indeed, the experience of Turkey, a huge Muslim nation bordering Syria, Iraq and Iran, is rarely considered, even though Turkey's democratic system has incorporated orthodox Islamic elements for decades. Given Turkey's social and political dynamism (unlike those of many Arab states and Iran, its industry and middle class were not created out of thin air by oil revenues), its influence on contiguous countries will likely increase as nearby dictatorships slowly crumble.
While this might shock policy wonks, it won't surprise historians. In fact, through long stretches of history, movements in the northwestern part of the former Turkish Empire (the Balkans) have influenced and even determined events in the southwestern part of the former Turkish Empire (the Middle East). The national independence struggles of the 19th century in Serbia, Bulgaria, Romania and Greece encouraged the rise of Arab nationalist societies in Damascus and Beirut. Similarly, modern terrorism was born in Macedonia and Bulgaria, before filtering into Greater Syria.
THE MURDER OF 12 BOSNIANS AND Croats, all of them Christians, by Muslim militants in Algeria last December went virtually unnoticed in America, but was a wake-up call to Europeans about the link between religious wars in the Balkans and those in the Middle East. That Muslims in Bosnia are secular and Westernized is irrelevant to what their suffering -- the razing of 800 mosques, not-to-mention their human losses -- may eventually symbolize for Muslims elsewhere.
It is no accident that the Balkans and the Arab world have accounted for a disproportionate share of the violent headlines of recent years. The Ottoman Empire took so long to die, its decrepitude burdens us still in the form of political underdevelopment among its formerly captive peoples; especially as Communism in the Balkans and the state of war with Israel -- providing, as it did, a basis for sterile military rule in places like Iraq and Syria -- arrested history for so long.
Turks have been something of an exception, since for so many centuries they were the rulers instead of the ruled. Thus, they lack the bitter complexes that afflict Balkan and Arab peoples. This and other factors -- like Rumi's tradition of tolerance and respect for the individual -- provide the backdrop for what, if only by regional standards, is a coherent national entity, already four decades into its experiment with democracy. Whatever further bloodshed Turkey faces over its continuing failure to compromise with the Kurdish minority there, its troubles pale beside the turbulence that has engulfed the former Yugoslavia and will surely engulf Arab states, especially Syria and Iraq.
For alas, there is a fifth reason why the "Middle East," particularly in Washington policy circles, is still seen in splendid isolation, separated from the rest of the region. It is this: While the cold war has ended in the Balkans, the Caucasus region and elsewhere, its effects still linger in Syria, Jordan and Iraq, where dictatorships of dubious legitimacy -- products of cold war military largesse, east-bloc security and torture technology and Arab-Israeli confrontation -- stagger on.
Have leaders like Hafez al-Assad, King Hussein and Saddam Hussein, merely by being in power so long, created national-communal organisms at least as well-rooted as, say, Turkey's?
In 1982, in Hama, where troops of the Alawite regime murdered more than 20,000 Sunni Arab civilians, we got a glimpse of just how little of a nation post-totalitarian Syria may turn out to be -- whether or not it gets back the Golan Heights. Given the preponderance of Palestinians in Jordan and the absurd degree to which that state's identity is tied to its ailing ruler, one can credibly wonder whether Jordan will even exist beyond the early 21st century. And Iraq? Well, the only questions there are how much blood will be spilled after Saddam departs and whether Iraq is going to break up into two pieces or three (Kurdistan and Arab Mesopotamia or Kurdistan, Sunni northern Mesopotamia and Shiite southern Mesopotamia).
Like Yugoslavia, all these Arab states were artificial creations of post-World War I peace treaties that represented the imperial powers' best attempt to impose order in the chaos that followed the collapse of the Ottoman Empire. The notion that these states -- little more than lines drawn on a map by Winston Churchill and others -- will have an uneventful transition to legitimizing-democratic rule is rather tenuous.
Even Turkey experienced three coups and (in the 1970's) veritable civil war in the course of a democratic experiment that the Arab world, for the most part, has yet to embark upon.
HISTORY, IN ITS ORIGINAL GREEK sense, implies a thematic narrative, as in a good novel (mythistorema in modern Greek). If history, then, is a narrative, the Arab-Israeli conflict, as an appendage of the cold war, has been a long and bloody footnote.
As that footnote concludes, we return to the main story, whose theme is not what new alliances will emerge, but which states from the post-World War I peace treaties will survive. With the Arab world about to rejoin the rest of the Near East, the Arabs will become less isolated from religious and political crosscurrents in neighboring, non-Arabic speaking nations. Thus, an expulsion of Muslims from the Balkans later in this decade might encourage an expulsion of indigenous Christian communities from Egypt and Syria.
Given what has happened in the Balkans and in the Caucasus states, it is naive not to expect redefining, even violent, turmoil in the Arab world.
In the future, historians may describe the struggle against Israel not as the bane of certain Arab states but as their very foundation. Patrick Seale, a specialist on Syria, ventured in 1986 that, " 'Greater Syria' is a sort of mirror image of 'Greater Israel' and its inevitable opponent. Both cannot win." Seale, who has always demonstrated more sympathy for Syria than for Israel, could turn out to be right in a way he would not want.
Whatever the territorial lines of any future peace treaty, Greater Israel will come into being as a regional economic magnet on the Mediterranean toward which the West Bank and Gaza will have to orient themselves. Syria and Jordan may, partly as a consequence, crumble under the weight of their sectarian contradictions and be reconfigured along different lines. We may someday look back upon the Arab-Israeli conflict as an almost romantic, sepia-toned chapter of the cold war in which calculations of morality and strategic advantage were relatively simple, just as they were in that other part of the Ottoman imperial domain, the Balkans, before history resumed.

HEADLINE: Growing Up Apart

BYLINE: By Ben Macintyre; Ben Macintyre is the New York correspondent for The Times of London and the author of "Forgotten Fatherland: The Search for Elisabeth Nietzsche."

 BODY:

INNOCENTS IN AFRICA
An American Family's Story.
By Drury Pifer.
Illustrated. 338 pp. New York:
Harcourt Brace & Company. $24.95. 
 IN 1932 Drury Pifer's parents, young, poor and ambitious, left the United States for the mines of South Africa because the country "promised an outside chance to marginal people." White, educated, English-speaking marginal people, that is.
They returned in 1945, when the author was 11 years old. During the intervening years this American family had been exposed to a strange colonial amalgam of privilege and austerity as Pifer Sr., a mining engineer, worked his way up within Sir Ernest Oppenheimer's awe-inspiring, ore-producing empire -- first in the gold mines of the Rand, then in the diamond mines in Oranjemund in the Namaqualand desert and finally in Kimberley.
From time to time Mr. Pifer, a playwright and former pilot, alludes to the adult brutalities of nationalism and economic disaster marching across the world in the course of his childhood. But "Innocents in Africa" is truly a child's-eye record of a small corner of that world -- unsophisticated and fascinating.
As Americans, the Pifers belonged to none of South Africa's tribes: African, British or Afrikaner. They were innocent, the title implies, in the sense of being naive, as well as guiltless of the tribal hatreds that have shaped and scarred South Africa. Yet soon enough the Pifers became part of South Africa's British white elite, their world circumscribed by tea parties, gossip, music, gardening and advancement in the hierarchy of mine management. In the case of Pifer Sr., this rise was less than meteoric.
Some of the author's memories are vivid and well wrought. His earliest years in Oranjemund consisted of a gritty existence on the edge of the continent, where the Atlantic gales whipped the desert sand as Afrikaner miners dug, fought and stole for Sir Ernest's diamonds. Other recollections are rather less intriguing, including the detailed accounts of the father's (ultimately unsuccessful) struggle for Sir Ernest's favor.
If this is a book about childhood and the wide-eyed wonder of an adult looking back at a child growing up in a strange land, it is as well -- almost in spite of itself and perhaps inevitably -- a book about race. Mr. Pifer's views on South Africa's grim racial divide are clear enough. He writes with hindsight, "I was conscious of the dislocation between their world and mine, but I accepted the disjunction without strain."
He claims also to "detect in that complacent small person the mental embryo of the skepticism that later formed me." This is thoroughly laudable, but the young Mr. Pifer, as recalled in maturity, appears not so much complacent as almost completely ignorant of the lives of black South Africans.
Certainly they are part of the picture, sitting under trees, dancing, singing or toiling in the mines. And they are in the procession of family servants, whom the author valiantly tries to depict as individuals, but who never quite attain personality. Here, Mr. Pifer's childhood memories accurately reflect the apartheid of South African society, the rigid barriers that operated at all levels long before they were enshrined in an ugly law described by an ugly Afrikaans word.
As the author emphasizes, his family was more enlightened than most. His father had advanced views on improving relations between white and black workers, and Mr. Pifer himself pours scorn on racists while mourning the passing of the Hottentots. But the family had settled in a land where race, color and nationality were the defining facts of existence, where the British South African did not care to mix with a German or an Afrikaner, any more than he would regard the Zulu as an equal. Simply reflected through the eyes of a child, those barriers appear still more chilling.
The Africans were not the only people set apart from the life of the young, white Pifer. He recounts how as a schoolboy he was regularly ambushed by resentful, brutish Afrikaner youths; he remembers how the Nazi-leaning Germans of Oranjemund were rounded up and herded away at the start of the war. But neither Afrikaners nor Germans were truly a part of his life: they too were apart, for apartheid grew out of divisions within races as well as between them.
Mr. Pifer's wistful book is subtitled "An American Family's Story," but it could as easily be the story of any privileged white family in South Africa, a chilling, rather brave portrait of an unknowing child watching the cancerous growth of apartheid from the inside. "Innocents in Africa," like the boy it recalls, is only half-knowing about the world it re-creates -- a vast, uncompromising land with vast, uncompromising spaces between its peoples.

HEADLINE: Over There, and There, and There

BYLINE: By David Reynolds; David Reynolds is a fellow of Christ's College, Cambridge. His book on G.I.'s in wartime Britain will be published in the fall.

 BODY:

A WORLD AT ARMS
A Global History of World War II.
By Gerhard L. Weinberg.
Maps. 1,178 pp. New York:
Cambridge University Press.
$34.95. 
 IT was Dr. Win-the-War at his most pedagogic: President Franklin D. Roosevelt's fireside chat of Feb. 23, 1942, was an extended geography lesson. Millions of Americans sat by their radios with maps open as the President took them around the globe. "This war is a new kind of war," he insisted. "It is warfare in terms of every continent, every island, every sea, every air lane in the world."
Gerhard L. Weinberg does not mention that fireside chat in his book "A World at Arms: A Global History of World War II," but Roosevelt's approach mirrors his own; it certainly is global. For Mr. Weinberg, the grotesque ambition of Nazi foreign policy is the theme that ties together the years 1939-45. But what Hitler started, others developed and finished. His triumph in Europe in mid-1940 encouraged Italy and Japan down their own primrose paths to conquest and defeat. And it spurred Germany into a hubristic assault on Russia in June 1941, with victory expected by the fall.
Mr. Weinberg puts that "eastern front" back at the center of the land war against Germany. As we near the 50th anniversary of D-day, it is worth remembering that between June 1941 and June 1944 more than 90 percent of the German Army's battle casualties were inflicted by the Russians. By comparison, the British and American battles in North Africa, Sicily and Italy counted for relatively little.
As Mr. Weinberg also emphasizes, this was not a conventional struggle for territory and resources. At stake was the life or death of whole peoples. Hitler's goal of living space in the east encompassed the genocide of so-called inferior races. The Jews of Europe were his most notorious victims, but the Slavs were also deemed Untermenschen and this gave the eastern front an additional horror generally lacking in the west.
Mr. Weinberg's insistence that this war was novel in both extent and intent seems to me entirely correct. But to distill a few themes in this way cannot convey the scale of his enterprise. Unlike many recent histories of the war, this is not a mere synthesis of published material. It is also the fruit of a decade and a half of archival research. As one would expect of an eminent historian of Nazi foreign policy, Mr. Weinberg, a professor of history at the University of North Carolina, is strongest on Germany, but he has also worked extensively in the American and British documents.
The result is not easy reading. The book is constructed like a vast scheme of lectures, with points clearly enumerated. There are few pithy quotations or anecdotes, and virtually no humor -- though it was nice to be reminded of the wartime joke that the Royal Navy lived on rum, while the Italians stuck to port.
Yet the prose is clear, the detail arresting and the arguments carefully deployed. Repeatedly Mr. Weinberg's own research illuminates old controversies. He notes, for instance, that the failure of the Allies to take Tunisia quickly had grave consequences for plans they had been working on to invade France in 1943. And his insistence on Hitler's malevolence toward Britain, from the war plans of 1940 to the V-weapons of 1944, is a healthy antidote to some of the nonsense that appeared in the British press a year ago about the chances of a compromise peace. If you read the 920 pages of this text in conjunction with the 180 pages of notes, you will gain a real insight into how academic historians work and where current research is going. This is a tour de force, classical diplomatic history at its best.
Mr. Weinberg's global view of the war pays dividends again and again. Stalingrad, rightly, becomes the pivotal event of 1942-43, but the battles of Midway and Guadalcanal, on the one hand, and Alamein and the invasion of French North Africa, on the other, are given due weight. Together they helped prevent Germany and Japan from joining forces in the Middle East, which would have presented the Axis powers' only real chance of victory.
A global war is also a naval war, as Mr. Weinberg makes clear in a separate chapter. In the Pacific, American submarines throttled the Japanese war effort. In the Atlantic, German U-boats nearly did the same to the Allies in 1942, and the delay in mounting the second front can be understood only against this backdrop. When Mr. Weinberg talks of "the most disastrous defeat ever suffered by American naval power," he is referring not to Pearl Harbor but to the loss of 2.6 million tons of merchant shipping off the American coast during the first eight months of 1942.
Yet his globalism is not as comprehensive as one might think. His coverage of books and archives from Germany, America and Britain is remarkable (and there is an excellent bibliographic essay). But the Russian story, and the war in Asia, are written almost entirely from those same sources. The result, at its worst, is a shadowy factual summary. Thus, the Russian Army's victories of 1944, though given due significance, are endowed in Chapter 12 with little of the drama and detail that Mr. Weinberg lavishes on Normandy. In March and April, in June and again in August, the Russians inflicted a third of a million casualties on the Germans in a few weeks. Each time they get a page for their pains. Yet each "body count" was comparable to that of the Battle of Normandy.
Mr. Weinberg's Asian war is even more bloodless. Extended accounts of Leyte and Okinawa have no parallels on the Chinese mainland. Of course, Chiang Kai-shek's armies atrophied in 1942-43 and were then crushed by Japan in 1944. Mr. Weinberg is good on the effects of this for American strategy and China's international standing. But he gives us little sense of the magnitude of the war between Japan and China, which dated back to 1937 and even, arguably, to 1931. Then at the end, almost casually, he suggests a figure of 15 million Chinese war dead, a quarter of his estimate for the global death toll (the Soviet Union's losses were at least 25 million; America's, 300,000).
These are not really criticisms of Mr. Weinberg. As he notes, reliable material on Russia, China and even Japan is limited. And the language skills required to master them would be formidable -- "Lingua longa, vita brevis," one might say. What this suggests (and what historians increasingly recognize) is the need for international collaboration. A truly global history of a truly global war is beyond any one scholar, however gifted.
Less forgivable, in my view, is the book's anonymity. Mr. Weinberg is a historian of policy. He spends most of his time on diplomacy and strategy, skillfully interweaving both with the new revelations about wartime intelligence. On Nazi genocide he is moved and moving, but for the most part this is not a people's war, except for the people at the very top. The separate chapter on the home fronts is one of the weakest in the book, becoming ever more fragmented as it races round the world. The suffering entailed by victory and defeat requires a less cerebral historian.
"Geography costs," Carl Sandburg lamented. "Why does the map of Europe never stay put?" In 1939-45, the cost of geography was global in scale, and the account has still not been settled.
 
 
 
60 MILLION DEAD AND STILL COUNTING
 The Soviet Union had suffered the largest number of deaths. . . . New research . . . has been pointing to figures . . . possibly in excess of 25 million deaths. . . . Chinese casualties are much more difficult to estimate than those of the Soviet Union, but 15 million dead is a reasonable approximation. In Poland, close to 6 million lost their lives, while Yugoslavia suffered between 1.5 and 2 million deaths. About 400,000 United Kingdom soldiers and civilians lost their lives; about 300,000 from the United States. Germany lost over 4 million and Japan over 2 million lives in the war. The total for the globe as a whole probably reached 60 million, a figure which includes the 6 million murdered because they were Jewish. . . .
The costs in human life and suffering, in destruction and economic dislocation, had been of absolutely unprecedented magnitude. If the question is asked, was victory worth such tremendous exertions and the price paid for their success, one is obliged to consider the consequences of Axis victory.
 From "A World at Arms."

HEADLINE: How the West Was Fed

BYLINE: By Molly O'Neill; Molly O'Neill is a reporter with the Style section of The New York Times and the author of "New York Cookbook."

 BODY:

HOME ON THE RANGE
A Culinary History of the American West.
By Cathy Luchetti.
Illustrated. 238 pp. New York:
Villard Books. Paper, $25.
 
WAGON WHEEL KITCHENS
Food on the Oregon Trail.
By Jacqueline Williams.
Illustrated. 222 pp. Lawrence:
University Press of Kansas.
Cloth, $29.95. Paper, $14.95. 
 NOTHING beats a dose of the Wild, Wild West to ease the anxiety that accompanies change. For most Americans, cowboys, covered-wagon caravans and Wild Bill Hickok are icons of rugged individualism that simultaneously stimulate and soothe.
The last time the bloom was on the Wild West rose, for instance, Roy Rogers and Dale Evans, Matt Dillon and Miss Kitty, and the boys of the Ponderosa galloped into the American living room. Their mission was simple: to triumph over a variety of bad guys on a weekly basis. At the same time, those who wore the white hats battled the ambient anxieties of their era. By carving out and then defending a homestead in an unfamiliar and unpredictable landscape, the good guys reassured a society made itinerant by company transfers, the demise of farm and small-town life, the growth of suburbs.
The current craze for the West isn't as much about adventure as it is about intimate daily life. The droves of the rich and chic that began buying second homes in Montana, Colorado and Utah several years ago don't ride the range, they create their own little (weekend) houses on the prairie. Movies like "A River Runs Through It" are real life, not larger than life. Likewise, there has recently been a passel of books about the Wild West dedicated to the details of daily living.
Two of those books, "Home on the Range," by Cathy Luchetti, and "Wagon Wheel Kitchens," by Jacqueline Williams, delve into the eating habits of the 19th-century American West. Both are histories culled from diaries and are more impressionistic than they are scholarly. Neither expands on the food history available in "Eating in America," by Waverley Root and Richard de Rochemont, and "A History of Food and Drink in America," by Richard J. Hooker. But both books give a deep sense of how the unpredictable adventure that was the West shaped lives and meals, how scarcity fostered invention, how opposites reconciled to survive.
Making dinner along the westward trails is a soothing parable for a generation that is making life up as it goes along, with recon figured families and real economic limits. After the indulgence of the 80's, who doesn't have a little sympathy for the overlanders Ms. Luchetti mentions who were forced to downsize their covered wagon halfway across the country, casting aside "champagne, East India sweetmeats and olives"?
"To travel, to shift occupation and to re settle was to alter life in unforeseen ways," Ms. Luchetti writes, and with more than 200 pages of text, historical photographs and recipes, she shows how manifest destiny eroded the European bias of the early American table.
Mealtimes shifted as the main meal was served between noon and 2, generally the hottest time of the day and also a perfect time for loading up on the fuel the travelers would need to travel until dark. Beef replaced pork as the favorite meat. Six courses gave way to one or two -- bacon and beans, or mush with rough bread, leavened with bicarbonate of soda or sourdough. Men, Ms. Luchetti notes, "could point proudly to their
own food discoveries." Sourdough, for instance, was the invention of a male cook. Role switching was as common as hoe cakes fried in suet in the Wild West. And it wasn't uncommon for Scandinavians to trade cooked dishes with Mexicans, who in turn traded with Irish immigrants, just for variety. For a brief period the unmeltable pot melted a little.
Ms. Luchetti, the author of "Women of the West" and "Under God's Spell: Frontier Evangelists, 1772-1915," offers a narrative that is as genial as it is general about the eating life along the trail, in the trapping camps, in the chuck wagons of cattle drives, in the hotels and boarding houses during the California gold rush and in a handful of other settings.
Like food historians before her, she describes how pioneers borrowed Indian techniques to preserve beef as jerky and to dry wild berries and fruits for pies. She includes recipes for pine-seed popcorn and instructions for "cooking puppy," as well as for preparing "coon cake." It is difficult to understand why the author, having unearthed such recipes, chose to include so many from "Housekeeping in Old Virginia," a place better noted for its Federalists than its frontier.
But for the most part, Ms. Luchetti's history, studded with diary entries, recipes and provision lists, sketches an era of improvisation and perseverance. Those who dared the unknown West lived a fluid life, in which nothing, particularly water, was taken for granted and nothing, not even a one-egg cake, was impossible.
"Wagon Wheel Kitchens" contains more discovery, yet somehow less charm, than "Home on the Range." Focusing on the estimated 300,000 people who traveled from Kansas to California on the Oregon Trail from 1840 to 1860 and the approximately 133 million meals they presumably consumed (calculated on a travel time of five months), Ms. Williams gives detailed lists of provisions, cooking techniques and utensils.
In 190 modestly illustrated pages, the reader learns how the European settlers, partial to meat rather than vegetables, learned the virtue of eating off the land. Citing travelers' diary entries, Ms. Williams -- the co-author of several books on nutrition, including "Hold the Fat, Sugar and Salt" -- details the discovery of a natural leavening in the foam of hot soda springs and explains the craft of cooking in cast iron over open fires, as well as the preparation of the Indian-inspired jerky. She describes how game, from antelope to sage hens, was cooked. Dedicated campers take note: trail mix and Power Bars alone won't satisfy after you have read "Wagon Wheel Kitchens."
For history buffs and armchair cooks, these two books about eating in the Wild West make absorbing reading. For everybody else, the books are another face of the old cowboy, more personal, more vulnerable, less heroic and excruciatingly human.

HEADLINE: Garbage In, Garbage Out

BYLINE: By Carl Levin; Carl Levin, a Democrat, is junior Senator from Michigan.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In the floor debate scheduled to begin in the next few days on the proposed constitutional amendment to balance the budget, Senate proponents will deliver impassioned speeches. As an antidote, a reading of the Senate Judiciary Committee's report favoring the amendment would be useful -- because it makes some of the best arguments against it.
Many foes of the amendment, including President Clinton, believe as strongly as its supporters that the deficit should be reduced and the budget balanced. But this proposed fiscal sleight-of-hand amendment doesn't do the job. 
 First, when speaking of the amendment's requirement that the President propose a budget in which total outlays do not exceed total receipts, the Judiciary Committee states: "The committee anticipates good faith on the part of the President with respect to projected economic factors."
Really? What in the 1980's would give us confidence in the "good faith" of the economic assumptions of any future administration? The first Reagan budget forecast economic growth of 4.2 percent; the economy declined by 1.9 percent.
David Stockman, President Reagan's first budget director, described in the "Triumph of Politics" how the forecasts in the first budget Ronald Reagan submitted were developed: "[Murray] Weidenbaum [chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers] unfurled his scenario . . . . Someone finally taunted the professor, 'What model did this come out of, Murray?' Weidenbaum glared at his inquisitor a moment and said, 'It came right out of here.' With that he slapped his belly with both hands. 'My visceral computer,' He smiled."
What in this amendment would prevent a future administration's visceral computer from re-emerging as the President's economic forecasting device? Nothing.
Second, when describing the need for constitutional instead of statutory language, the committee says: "Statutory efforts to balance the budget previously have failed because it is too easy for Congress to simply change its mind and rescind its previous declarations."
The trouble is that the amendment itself relies on statutory definitions that can easily be changed. It says the term "fiscal year" in the amendment is "intended as a term defined by statute and, as such, is to have no constitutional standing independent from its statutory definition."
Thus, under the committee's interpretation, Congress can change its mind and redefine "fiscal year" in order to encompass 11 months or three years. When faced with a budget that is hopelessly out of balance over the standard 12-month time frame, the President and Congress may decide to "save" billions of dollars by shortening the fiscal year by one day so that a payday for Federal employees falls into the next fiscal year. A form of this manipulation was used in 1986 to "save" almost $700 million dollars in revenue-sharing funds.
The nation should be under no illusion that this effort to mandate a balanced budget will succeed where past statutory efforts have failed. It will just require Congress to be more creative in searching for more loopholes as a substitute for real policies.
If the amendment works as advertised, it could prevent remedial action such as deficit spending in times of economic emergencies and exacerbate recessions by requiring tax increases or spending cuts, which would further slow economic growth. Because the amendment requires 60 Senate votes to waive a balanced budget, it would put dangerous power over the economy in the hands of a minority.
In short, the Judiciary Committee, in trying to put the best face on this amendment -- which does not specify how to balance the budget -- is leading with its chin.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Yes, Ask Why We Need This Stuff in Our Milk

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"The Milk Brouhaha" (editorial, Feb. 10) seems typical of an insidious and myopic variety of thought in our economy: If a company (in this case, Monsanto) is capable of producing something (in this case, a genetically engineered drug that boosts milk production) and spending millions of dollars creating a need for it, let's use it. 
 What apparently bothers you is that this time, more than a few people are asking, "But why?" And well they should ask. With farmers from California to Vermont being paid Federal money to produce less milk, and in the wake of a program in the mid-to-late 1980's in which the Federal Government purchased and disposed of entire herds of dairy cows to decrease milk production, there is little reason to increase milk production.
Perhaps some small farmers think they would benefit because they could achieve the same or better milk production with smaller herds and thus fewer costs and less maintenance. However, clearly -- and as is usually the case with recently created agricultural technologies -- the real winners will be the biggest agribusinesses, the most powerful middlemen and, naturally, Monsanto.
It is ironic that the producers of milk, after having worked so long and so hard to create an image of wholesomeness for their product, appear quite eager to step even further into the arena of our perverse meta-economy, where people with dollar signs in their eyes sit around boardrooms and manufacture false needs. Maybe the "milk brouhaha" will encourage more people to ask "why?" on a greater variety of wondrous new products.
 
THOMAS HENRY MOORE
River Edge, N.J., Feb. 10, 1994

LENGTH: 212 words

HEADLINE: Did Anybody Check Out Economic Wisdom of Hiring Sliwa?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
As a daily listener of WNYC, New York City's public radio station, and a contributor to it for more than 10 years, I am one of many upset at the appearance of interference leading to the hiring of Curtis Sliwa, Guardian Angel turned radio personality, despite statements alleging Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's nonintervention. 
 I am more concerned about the economic wisdom of his hiring for the station. Did market research clearly indicate that Mr. Sliwa's audience will expand WNYC's support base enough to compensate for a dropoff in support from current listeners?
Will the hoped-for increase in listeners stay with the station long enough to satisfy the fund sources that look at audience-base figures? Will Mayor Giuliani promise to wait and see if the expected new revenue meets or exceeds the city's subsidy of a mere 10 percent of WNYC's budget and promise hands off if it does?
If we who have supported the station are to continue to do so, we must be assured more credibly that the offer to Mr. Sliwa was prompted by solid analysis, not political pressure. WNYC is New York's last bastion of consistently interesting radio, and I for one cannot willingly give it up without a fight.
 
SUZANNE FASS
New York, Feb. 9, 1994

HEADLINE: With No Clear Leader or Strategy, Unions Prepare to Face Giuliani

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

 BODY:
For decades, New York's mayors shared the public stage with a well-known cast of irascible, flamboyant leaders of municipal labor. There were the titans who could welcome a new mayor into office with a strike on Inauguration Day, and later the labor statesmen who worked with the city in the fiscal crisis of the 1970's.
Now the last of the union leaders who catapulted to prominence in the fiscal crisis has left the stage, clearing the way for less visible, less bombastic and, in some cases, less tested successors. And the change has come as the municipal unions face the twin challenges posed by the city's worst financial difficulties since the 1970's and by the new Republican Mayor's pledges to reduce the size of the city government.
 
Test for Unions
 The leaders and tactics that emerge over the next few months -- and in contract negotiations this year and next -- could not only decide the short-term success of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's fiscal strategy but also be crucial to the long-term power of the unions. 
 Many of Mr. Giuliani's proposals for erasing the $2.3 billion budget deficit -- changes in health benefits and vacation and sick days, new productivity measures and the elimination of 15,000 jobs -- can be carried out only with labor support because they affect contracts already in place or civil service rules. But Mr. Giuliani has said that without cooperation from the unions he will have to resort instead to as many as 35,000 layoffs over four years.
Some in the labor movement contend that unless the unions engage Mr. Giuliani in a public debate over the budget and offer alternatives, they could lose a larger political battle to a Mayor who has made the size of New York City's government an ideological issue.
"The issues are much bigger than is there a couple of thousand jobs lost here and there," said Gregory Tarpinian, the director of the Labor Research Association, a union-financed group. "Giuliani is waging a philosophical war."
The municipal unions boomed during the 1980's, adding members by the thousands as the city payroll expanded and winning strong wage settlements that were the envy of their hard-pressed brethren in the private sector. But the bubble burst as the recession hit, with layoffs and smaller wage settlements coming even under their ally, Mayor David N. Dinkins.
Now, as the unions brace for a face-off with Mr. Giuliani, their task has been made more difficult by the departure of Barry Feinstein, the brash negotiator who resigned last April as president of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters to settle charges that he misused $500,000 of the local's funds to maintain a life of luxury.
Quotable and combative, Mr. Feinstein wielded power disproportionate to the small size of his union. He often seemed to be the dominant partner in a negotiating duo with Stanley Hill, the executive director of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, the city's largest union, with 131,000 members in 56 locals.
This fight will be Mr. Hill's first without Mr. Feinstein at his side. Mr. Hill, 57, insists that he is up to the task, saying he should not be underestimated simply because his style is more low-key. "I'm a very competitive guy," he said. "I don't like losing."
 
Doubts About Leader
 But many of his allies describe him as a conciliator and not the strategist needed when Mr. Giuliani is signaling his intention to start shrinking the public sector. They say Mr. Hill is further hampered by his own need to satisfy the leaders of his separate locals.
"Stanley spends a great deal of his time creating consensus rather than marching at the front of a parade," said Norman Adler, a political consultant who made his name as a political director of District Council 37. "By predisposition, he's not a band leader. At best he's a concertmaster."
Whether anyone else will acquire Mr. Feinstein's stature is not clear. While Sandra Feldman, the president of the United Federation of Teachers, is considered a powerful and skilled labor strategist, she has worked to separate the teachers from the rest of the municipal work force, so that they are judged in comparison with other teachers during wage talks.
"It's not a secret that we've been fighting a battle for some years now to create some differences in the way the management in the city government has treated us," she said. "There's a problem with teachers being compared with other municipal employees other than teachers."
Another potential leader, Sonny Hall, resigned as president of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union in October to become the international president of the union, and the transit workers, who negotiate with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and not the city, pulled out of the Municipal Labor Committee, the coalition of city municipal unions.
 
Others Hampered
 Carl Haynes, Mr. Feinstein's successor at the teamsters, is less visible and represents only 21,000 workers. Arthur Cheliotes, president of Local 1180 of the Communications Workers of America, is also hampered by the small size of his local, which represents only 10,000 administrative employees.
Peter Scarlatos, who became president of the 7,000-member Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association just over a year ago, is highly regarded by his colleagues. But he is thought to have enough of a task negotiating for his own workers with a Mayor who has already identified nearly 1,500 jobs for elimination in the Sanitation Department and who singled out the sanitation contract for criticism during his campaign. And the unions representing uniformed workers have rarely made much of a common front with the nonuniformed ones.
So far, labor's response to Mr. Giuliani's proposals has been relatively muted. Union officials point out that they have not yet been given any specifics of Mr. Giuliani's plans, ranging from which jobs he wants to cut to the details of severance packages.
And with such details missing, one union official called it foolhardy to rush into confrontation with a Mayor who has cited the success of his Philadelphia counterpart in winning concessions from unions after a brief, abortive strike.
The unions have joined in their opposition to Mr. Giuliani's proposal that their members make co-payments for health care. But with no strong figure setting strategy, differences in approach quickly emerge. Some union leaders are ready to propose that Mr. Giuliani find many more savings in the ranks of the police and the firefighters, who rallied around him during his campaign, and who were left untouched in his budget.
"I think the Mayor will lose credibility about making tough decisions if there isn't a sense of fairness," Ms. Feldman said.
 
An Alternative Approach
 Some union leaders say the municipal unions cannot afford to ignore the fiscal problems or minimize them and should work with Mr. Giuliani. "I believe it's time for responsible union leadership in this city to pool their research personnel, apply that expertise in examining the city's budget and bureaucracy stem to stern, using the people who know this city best -- its own workers -- and identify waste and redundancy," said Jan D. Pierce, a regional vice president of the Communications Workers of America, which represents administrative employees. "I believe it can be done without the need to cut services, cut the employment levels or raising taxes."
Mr. Hill said he planned to release a "state of the city" proposal on behalf of labor sometime soon that would challenge some of Mr. Giuliani's statements about the size of the work force and its productivity. And he said it would contain alternative proposals for dealing with the deficit, suggesting that options would include some new ways of raising tax dollars as well as seeking more aid from Albany and Washington.
Mr. Hill has been meeting with the city's Democratic officeholders and City Council members, a number of whom receive strong campaign support from District Council 37. And with the black and Hispanic caucus of the City Council among the strongest backers of his union -- whose members are largely from minority groups -- Mr. Hill has also demonstrated a willingness to cast the fight in racial terms as he searches for allies.
Last week Mr. Hill shared the steps of City Hall with a group of Baptist ministers and elected officials who proclaimed Mr. Giuliani's budget "a plan of pain for people of color and city workers."
The unions are also supporting legislation in the City Council that would require the city to carry out cost-benefit studies before contracting out city services to private companies and allow the Council to hold a hearing on the contracts before they can be put in place. Deputy Mayor Peter J. Powers spoke against the measure at a Council hearing last week, saying it was "designed to further hinder the process," and the Mayor and Council are hurtling toward a confrontation over the bill.
But in the long term, some labor strategists say, they need new tools to build public support for city workers and to make some of their points: that many of the people likely to be laid off could still be a burden to the city on unemployment or welfare rolls. The teachers are running a $1 million television campaign showing teachers and students succeeding despite deteriorating school buildings. And the Communications Workers of America has suggested that the other unions put a similar ad campaign on cable television to spread a more positive image of the civil servant.
"One of the things we have to do is stop assuming people know what we do," Mr. Cheliotes said. "We're invisible to much of the city."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The I.R.S. faces a costly threat from thieves using electronic filing technology to receive fraudulent refunds. More than 25,000 fraudulent electronic returns were detected in the first 10 months of 1993, more than double the number a year earlier. [Page A1.] 
 The Justice Department is investigating whether networks that link automated teller machines have been putting pressure on banks to buy other services as a condition of participation. [D1.]
The labor union leaders and tactics that emerge in New York in the next few months -- and in contract negotiations this year and next -- could decide the short-term success of Mayor Giuliani's fiscal strategy and the long-term power of the unions. [A1.]
When Congress approved the trade agreement with Canada and Mexico, contrary to the wishes of organized labor, union leaders vowed to retaliate against Democrats who supported President Clinton. So far, the unions' bite has not matched their bark, and most of the retribution has been far more symbolic than substantive. [A1.] The Administration and labor unions are natural allies on many issues and are now devising strategy on several matters of mutual interest. [A12.]
The drug AZT has so sharply reduced transmission of H.I.V. from infected mothers to their newborns in a federally financed study of American and French medical centers that the Government has stopped the study ahead of schedule. [A1.]
 
International
U.S. executives are praising President Clinton's decision to take a tougher stance with Japan over trade but are divided about how much the Administration can improve the situation. [D1.]
There is growing concern in Warsaw that too many Polish investors are inexperienced first-time buyers who have put their savings into a volatile and sometimes illiquid market. [D1.]
Mexico's largest construction company has joined with Canada's biggest development company to build a housing, office and entertainment complex on the outskirts of Mexico City. [D2.]
Zaire's state-owned mining company has collapsed, and the copper mines abandoned to scavengers, amid growing political and economic chaos. [A3.]
 
The Media Business
Stars and Stripes seems under siege itself. Many American soldiers no longer see the military newspaper as a primary source of news and its financial picture is cloudy as thousands of American troops and their families have been pulled from Europe. [D6.]
Magazine publishers are scrutinizing newly released 1993 circulation figures to check out the winners, the losers and the competition. [D6.]
Book publishers have come to regard Valentine's Day as a major marketing opportunity, a time to put out much of the year's selection of books that are even tenuously connected to romance. Sarah Lyall: Publishing. [D6.]
Michael Bloomberg's all-business-news radio station had barely turned a year old when he decided to celebrate by going national with the New York outlet -- just one more way in which Mr. Bloomberg is taking advantage of WBBR-AM. [D6.]
 
Today's Columns
The Spectrum Information Technologies soap opera has a new leading man. Heiko Thieme, who manages the American Heritage mutual fund, has become the self-appointed arbitrator in the spat between Spectrum's management and Apple's former chairman, John Sculley. [D1.]
Maternal-child nurses in Texas received a patent for a tiny pacifier designed specially for low-birthweight babies.
Teresa Riordan: Patents. [D2.]

HEADLINE: Clinton and Unions, Burying Hatchets, Focus on Common Interests

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 20

 BODY:
Their name-calling, saber-rattling ruckus over the trade agreement with Mexico and Canada aside, the Clinton Administration and labor unions are natural allies on many issues and are now devising strategy on several matters of mutual interest.
In testimony to the effort to mend fences, the largest delegation of Administration officials and Congressional Democrats that labor leaders can remember is descending on the week-long annual winter meeting here of the 35-member executive council of the American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations. 
 Vice President Al Gore, who in his television debate with Ross Perot helped the President win enactment of the trade agreement, will be here on Monday bearing olive branches. George Stephanopoulos, a senior Presidential adviser, came in today. Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich, like his predecessors a regular at these affairs, comes on Tuesday and has dispatched nearly all his top appointees here.
 
Continued Influence
 And however acute the long erosion of union membership in the work force and labor's lost battles with Congress, other visitors testify to its continued influence. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, running for re-election, and Treasurer Kathleen Brown of California, seeking her party's nomination for governor, will be soliciting votes and campaign contributions.
The issues of mutual interest for the Democrats and the A.F.L.-C.I.O. include enacting the President's overhaul of the health care system, writing more union-friendly labor laws, tightening worker health and safety regulations and expanding aid to the chronically unemployed, among them those who lose jobs because of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
Today, the union presidents, their staff and families, and Administration officials, many recruited from unions, were packed around poolside tables and lounge chairs at the Sheraton Bal Harbour, hearing one another out in the clammy heat of the South Florida sun. Meetings start on Monday.
Rare for these affairs, no one wore buttons or passed out leaflets criticizing someone or something. "Are we better off than we were three years ago?" asked Richard L. Trumka, president of the United Mine Workers. "Unquestionably. Is it utopia? Definitely not."
How durable these renewed links will be is anybody's guess. The union leaders, many past 70 years old, are creatures of the New Deal and the legacies of Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson. A senior federation official said Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore, as "new" Democrats in their 40's, were less persuaded by the appeal of big government solutions to problems.
On the other hand, said Lynn R. Williams, president of the United Steelworkers of America, the two have a compelling interest in breaching the divide. "There's no possibility of Clinton's being a second-term President without the support of the labor movement," Mr. Williams said. "And I think he understands that."
 
'Some Scars Left Over'
 Steven Rosenthal, a deputy Assistant Secretary of Labor, said, "Look, on 99 percent of the issues, we're in virtual agreement."
Donald R. Sweitzer, political director of the Democratic National Committee, said, "There are some scars left over from Nafta, some of which will never heal. But these are pragmatic people. We want to move on to things we can agree on."
Mr. Sweitzer has a special interest in courting labor here. In a rare show of pique over the trade pact vote, the federation leadership recently declared a moratorium on financial contributions to the national party and one other group, the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee -- a signal to unions to withhold their contributions, too. "We want to patch that up," Mr. Sweitzer said.
Some vocal foes of the law eliminating barriers to trade with Mexico and Canada, which opens opportunities for American industry to build factories outside the country, have mellowed. Rather than try to defeat members of Congress who voted for the agreement, Morton Bahr, president of the Communications Workers of America, said, "I'd rather go the extra mile for those who stood up for us."
And George J. Kourpias, president of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, said: "We knew where Bill Clinton and Al Gore stood on Nafta before they were elected. Certainly, we're disappointed. But we must go on now, and we will."

HEADLINE: Students Plan Ways for Colleges to Act on Environmentalism

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 20

 BODY:
Yale University's switch to fluorescent lighting in its library is expected to save $3.5 million over the next 10 years. Connecticut College's reduction of room temperatures by 1 degree Fahrenheit has saved $8,000 a year. Putting energy-efficient lights in 2,200 exit signs will save Brown University $65,000, it estimates.
Universities have found that environmentalism may be good for their budgets. At a planning conference this weekend, campus environmentalists from around the world focused on specific proposals for improving campus environmental programs. 
 Over 400 students, faculty members and administrators attended the Campus Earth Summit this weekend at Yale University, organized by Yale's Student Environmental Coalition and sponsored by the Heinz Family Foundation, which aids environmental and other charitable causes.
Teresa Heinz, chief executive of the foundation, said that universities' buying power and educating mission make them powerful agents for environmental change. Mrs. Heinz said the conference's practical proposals added a new dimension to campus advocacy. Student groups have traditionally staked out the high moral ground on environmentalism and left the messy work to others, she said.
 
'Starting With Ourselves'
 Abdi Soltani, a Stanford University junior, said: "We're not telling other people how to live their lives. We're starting with ourselves and the institutions where we have power."
Participants drafted a 19-page document, Campus Blueprint for a Sustainable Future, outlining strategies for improving campus environmental practices and education. The Heinz Family Foundation plans to publish by December a book rating universities on their environmental efforts.
Among the report's suggestions were: adding environmental problems to natural science courses; ending parking subsidies to encourage mass transit, and using alternatives to paper, like computer messages.
But at the conference's end, some students said that the discussion was still too vague. Amy Powers, a Bates College senior, urged local and regional conferences to provide more specifics.
Linnea Brudenell, a first-year student from Reed College in Portland, Ore., said that the conference was frustrating at times and that the strategy sessions were sometimes handicapped by participants' ideological differences.
 
Fivefold Increase Reported
 There are over 2,000 American campus environmental groups, up from 400 since 1989, according to Brian Trelstad of the Center for Environmental Citizenship.
In her address to the conference, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, Carol M. Browner, compared current efforts by environmentalists to the early American labor movement.
"You too will meet with resistance; people will tell you that environmental protection and economic progress are incompatible; they'll even call you things like 'Granola Head' and 'Tree-Hugger' and probably some things that are worse," she said. "But you must stick to your convictions."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Satellite Service Will Extend the Reach of Bloomberg Radio

BYLINE: By JOSHUA MILLS

 BODY:
His all-business-news radio station in New York had barely turned one year old when Michael Bloomberg decided to celebrate by going national with it.
The decision was easy, because the radio station, WBBR-AM, can tag along at no additional expense on the satellite service that Mr. Bloomberg is leasing to start a 13-hour-a-day television service of business news. 
 Along with the video channel, called Bloomberg Direct, which will be part of GM Hughes Electronics' satellite-to-home broadcasting service, will come an audio channel carrying WBBR. A subscriber to the satellite service, which will start about May 1, will be able to hear the station through a television set, with the screen blank, or by connecting a radio to the system.
 
A Station of Many Uses
 The audio channel is just one more unusual way in which Mr. Bloomberg is taking advantage of the radio station he bought (the former WNEW-AM, at the frequency of 1130) in the fall of 1992 for $13.5 million. Mr. Bloomberg is the founder of Bloomberg Financial Markets, which provides computerized financial data to business customers, and Bloomberg Business News, a news service that reports and interprets the data.
Another innovation from Mr. Bloomberg is to put the radio programming inside the computer terminals he leases to business customers for $1,000 a month. The terminals are used to retrieve and display all the data gathered by Bloomberg Financial Markets -- and the Bloomberg software runs only on the Bloomberg hardware. But more than 20,000 of Bloomberg's 34,000 terminals now have built-in speakers for the radio programming.
Because WBBR broadcasts a digitally encoded signal, it can be captured and stored electronically on the Bloomberg computer system, then played on demand. If a broker, instead of typing a stock symbol on the keyboard, types in "WBBR," the terminal displays a menu of recent radio programming, like the most recent market report, news broadcast, weather or traffic report, or perhaps Alan Greenspan's speech of the day. Hit the number of a menu item, and the selection is replayed.
WNEW-AM, which played big band music and crooners, attracted about 1.6 percent of the listening audience in the New York area. Since WBBR began broadcasting on Jan. 3, 1993, the station's share, as measured by the Arbitron Company, has averaged about three-tenths of 1 percent.
While others in the radio business deride the station and its paltry ratings, Mr. Bloomberg, in the time-honored fashion of stations with low Arbitron numbers, prefers to bash the rating service.
"The people who listen to my station, investment bankers and the like, don't take the time to talk to market researchers on the phone, or to fill out Arbitron phone diaries," Mr. Bloomberg said in a recent interview at his Park Avenue office.
To prove his point, Mr. Bloomberg has commissioned "qualitative ratings" from Accuratings of Chicago, a relative newcomer that is offering its services to radio stations as a way of getting beyond the raw numbers of Arbitron to measure the wealth, education and buying habits of radio listeners. Many classical-music stations also use qualitative ratings, hoping to demonstrate that they, too, have an attractive audience in terms of buying power and taste.
"A bigger percentage of WBBR's listeners have bought a new car in the last six months than at any of the top 20 stations in New York," Kurt Hanson, the president of Accuratings, said. "A bigger percentage of WBBR's audience went to graduate school than of any station in New York except that of WQXR," the classical-music FM station owned by The New York Times Company, he said.
Whatever Accuratings may show, and however tony the advertisers WBBR attracts -- at rates of $500 a minute in morning drive time to $150 in off hours -- executives at New York's all-news stations, which Mr. Bloomberg likes to call "all-crime" stations, are happy to sneer in return.
"We don't look at them as competition," said Scott Herman, the vice president and general manager of WINS-AM, the all-news station owned by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation. In the latest Arbitron ratings, WINS had 3.9 percent of the listening audience, or 13 times that of WBBR.
"They're not in the business of attracting listeners," he said of WBBR. "He's just trying to sell his data."
At WCBS-AM, Harvey Nagler, the director of news and programming, said the countermeasures that his station took when WBBR began broadcasting had proved unnecessary. "When we first heard about WBBR, we started a small-business report that airs twice a day," he said, "and we increased what we were doing off-air. Four times a year, we rent a hotel hall and do breakfasts for the community with well-known figures to talk about business and economic issues."
But aside from losing two part-time employees to Bloomberg, Mr. Nagler said, WBBR had had no effect on WCBS, which had 2.9 percent of the audience in Arbitron's latest ratings.

HEADLINE: Intel Market Share Rises

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif., Feb. 20

 BODY:
The Intel Corporation increased its share of the worldwide microprocessor market last year, the research firm Dataquest Inc. said last week.
Intel controlled 74 percent of the market in 1993, up from 69 percent the year before, Dataquest said. 
 "Such dominance of an entire semiconductor product segment is unprecedented," Jerry Banks, director and principal microprocessor analyst at Dataquest, said.
Microprocessors are the "brains" of personal computers. Most companies that make such chips enjoyed higher sales in 1993 because of the rising demand for PC's.
Intel, based in Santa Clara, Calif., designed and is the leading maker of of X86-type microprocessors, used in most PC's. The company's sales of microprocessors amounted to $6.57 billion last year, up from $3.79 billion in 1992.
