HEADLINE: Business Chiefs Praise Clinton for Stand on Japan

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Feb. 20

 BODY:
Business executives are praising President Clinton's decision to take a tougher stance with Japan over trade but are divided about how much the Administration can improve the situation.
"It's time the Japanese understood that this chronic deficit is intolerable," said George Fisher, chairman and chief executive of the Eastman Kodak Company. 
 President Clinton is drawing the highest praise for refusing earlier this month to pretend that any progress had been made in trade talks with Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa.
Japan is arguing that any agreement should focus on opening up Japanese markets by changing regulations and whittling away at traditional customs that inhibit access to its markets.
The United States has concluded that such tactics have failed to dent the deficit, which exceeded $59 billion last year. It wants agreement on specific benchmarks for progress, like growth in market share over certain periods of time for American products that are clearly competitive in price and performance.
 
Applauded on Motorola Stand
 The Clinton Administration is also being applauded for following up on its stand with a highly publicized move last Monday. The Administration announced that it was moving toward imposing trade sanctions in retaliation for what it sees as Japan's failure to meet commitments to grant Motorola Inc. unfettered access to Japan's biggest cellular telephone market.
The exact sanctions have not yet been determined, but most business executives said they were sure such moves would be limited. They said they doubted that there would be much impact on American manufacturers who used Japanese components or that Japan would see any need to respond with measures that would lead to an all-out trade war.
"The stakes are much too great for either side to let it go that route," said James Whittaker, international public policy manager for the Hewlett-Packard Company, when asked whether his company was prepared for a damaging series of escalating sanctions. The company, based in Palo Alto, Calif., makes computers and other electronic equipment.
Lynn Michaelis, chief economist for the Weyerhaeuser Corporation, a timber company based in Tacoma, Wash., that exports lumber and finished products to Japan, said: "We understand the concerns of those facing trade barriers, but countervailing duties is a risky approach. It could raise the cost of goods to American consumers and cause people that have an established trade position with Japan to lose some of it."
It is important to note, some executives say, that sanctions and other industry-specific trade measures would have a minor direct impact on the overall trade deficit but that talking about them draws attention to the imbalance, which can affect currencies. Indeed, the dollar dropped as trade talks foundered last week, imposing a far bigger penalty on Japanese competitiveness than any particular sanctions contemplated by the Clinton Administration.
The falling dollar at least delights American auto makers.
"The recent rise in the yen's value and its stability at the higher level over the past year has done more to level the playing field than all of the Government negotiations over the past 20 years," said John F. Smith Jr., chief executive and president of the General Motors Corporation in an address Monday in Washington to the U.S.-Japan Business Council.
The strong yen is "the most powerful means for correcting the trade imbalance over the long run," said Martin B. Zimmerman, executive director of government relations and corporate economics for the Ford Motor Company. And from a public policy standpoint in the short term, he said, "it does put pressure on the Japanese Government."
There are wide-ranging assessments of how much leverage the Government has to help various industries, reflecting the variety of trade barriers American companies face in Japan. Some consumer-product companies say the biggest barrier they face is the Japanese distribution and retailing system, which government-to-government talks cannot affect in the short run.
Kodak, for example, which has more than half the color-film market worldwide, has less than 10 percent in Japan, a discrepancy that Mr. Fisher says may cost the company as much as $1 billion a year in revenue. But the main problem is that film in Japan is mostly sold in kiosks and small stores that traditionally stock only one brand, usually Fuji
Until Japanese consumers become disgruntled enough with the higher prices under such a system to demand alternatives, it will be hard to make much headway against entrenched Japanese producers. The best Kodak can hope for is strong Government support at home for moves like its recent complaint that Fuji illegally cuts prices on exports to the United States.
In other sectors, like computers and telecommunications equipment, where American vendors are trying to win more contracts from Japanese Government agencies, the Clinton Administration's willingness to take a tough stand is possibly encouraging changes in Japanese policy.
"There's concern about the Japanese reaction, but the Government is smart to let the Japanese Government know in no uncertain terms that the lack of progress is unacceptable," said Kenneth R. Kay, executive director of the Computer Systems Policy Project, which represents the views of the chief executives of 13 large computer companies.
The group has asked the Administration to complain to Prime Minister Hosokawa about the lack of growth in the use of American computers by the Japanese Government, where they have a falling share of less than 4 percent compared with a growing share of 36 percent in the Japanese commercial sector.
Similar views are expressed in the medical equipment business, where American companies often find themselves at odds with the Japanese Ministry of Health and Welfare. The ministry combines product review, physician reimbursement and research-financing responsibilities that in the United States are handled by separate Federal agencies. American companies have frequently complained of regulatory actions aimed at slowing penetration of the Japanese market by foreign products until homegrown products can be developed.
"A lot of our problem has to do with their regulatory system," said Terri Ethridge, director of global strategy and analysis for the Health Industry Manufacturers Association, a Washington-based trade group representing more than 300 medical equipment makers. The trade group says that the American companies have slightly more than 20 percent of Japan's $16.9 billion medical equipment market, compared with more than 50 percent in the rest of its export markets.
One uncertainty hovering over the medical sector as trade tensions grow is whether Japanese bureaucrats will be more likely to impose proposed cuts in reimbursement payments in four categories: heart valves, catheters used in heart surgery, oxygenators and orthopedic implants. The health ministry has said it wants to make the cuts to control rising health payments, but American companies say that the categories cover just 1 percent of Japanese spending on equipment and that it must be more than a coincidence that all four areas happen to be sectors where no significant Japanese companies are active.
William George, president and chief executive of Medtronic Inc., a Minneapolis-based equipment exporter that also has both research and manufacturing operations in Japan, said that he was concerned about how the pricing dispute might be affected by recent events in Washington but that he remained enthusiastic about President Clinton's policy.
"If you don't take a strong position, they'll keep doing what they've done as the path of least resistance," Mr. George said.

HEADLINE: Vittorio Rieti, Prolific Composer In Neo-Classical Style, Dies at 96

 BODY:
Vittorio Rieti, a prolific American composer who fashioned bright, elegant Neo-Classical scores for the ballets of Serge Diaghilev and George Balanchine, died on Saturday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 96 and lived in Manhattan.
The cause was not immediately clear, said his son, Fabio, but Mr. Rieti had suffered a bad fall at his home, breaking several ribs. 
 In a career that spanned eight decades, Mr. Rieti wrote music for more than a dozen ballets, seven operas, five symphonies, several concertos, chamber music for a wide variety of instrumental combinations, songs and choral works. His music was widely performed; among the conductors who led performances of Mr. Rieti's works were Fritz Reiner, Frederick Stock, Willem Mengelberg and Arturo Toscanini.
Mr. Rieti was born in Egypt, to Italian-born parents, and educated in Italy. But his music -- in its wit, craft, lack of pretense and economy of means -- shares similarities with the work of the French group of composers who called themselves Les Six, particularly that of Poulenc. The music of Stravinsky, a close friend, was also an important influence.
Mr. Rieti continued to compose until shortly before his death. He used to say, "Composing every day is what keeps me alive." In his 75th, 80th and 85th birthday years, there were commemorative concerts in New York that included many new works. "Vittorio Rieti is becoming something of a wonder," Allen Hughes wrote in The New York Times after a 1985 concert. "He will be 87 years old on the 28th of this month, but he is still composing music that is as sprightly and cheerful as anything he ever wrote."
Other commentators remarked upon the jaunty cheer in Mr. Rieti's music, yet some professed to find its obverse as well. "Rieti's oeuvre stands apart in its specific clarity, gaiety and sophistication of a kind only he possesses," the composer Alfredo Casella once said, "yet it hides a good deal of melancholia."
In 1973, Mr Rieti said: "I go on writing music. I started when I was 12, and it has become a habit. I maintain the same esthetic assumptions I have always had. I have kept evolving in the sense that one keeps on perfecting the same ground."
 
Three and Six
 Mr. Rieti was born in Alexandria, Egypt, on Jan. 28, 1898. As a musician, he was largely self-taught, although he acknowledged a debt to the composer Alfredo Casella, to the piano pedagogue Giuseppe Frugatta and to some "finishing touches" from Ottorino Respighi. In the early 1920's, he belonged to a group that called itself I Tre, an Italian imitation of Les Six. His first international success came in 1924, when Casella conducted his Concerto for Winds and Orchestra in Prague.
From 1925 to 1940, he lived in Paris, where he formed close ties with Les Six and with Stravinsky. He wrote ballet music for Diaghilev -- "Barabau" (1925) was particularly succesful -- and incidental music for Louis Jouvet.
In 1940, Mr. Rieti, his Italian wife, Elsie, and their son moved to the United States, where Mr. Rieti established a close working relationship with Balanchine, whose ballets "Waltz Academy" and "Native Dancers" are set to Mr. Rieti's music. However, Mr. Rieti's best-known collaboration with Balanchine remains "La Sonnambula," in which he orchestrated melodies by Bellini.
 
Late Works for Strings
 The compositions of the last 20 years of Mr. Rieti's life were mostly works for string ensembles, mostly string quartets.
"He was like Verdi and Tintoretto in the sense that some of his most beautiful works were composed near the end of his life," said Robert Fizdale, a duopianist who, with Arthur Gold, played and recorded much of Mr. Rieti's work. Mr. Rieti wrote numerous compositions for them over the years. Mr. Gold died two years ago.
While Mr. Rieti was in his 90's, a well-attended annual concert of his chamber music was given in New York, most recently at Merkin Concert Hall, by members of the Orchestra of St. Luke's. Much of the work that was performed was new, and all of it, Mr. Rieti's admirers said, sounded fresh.
His son said yesterday that Mr. Rieti's final compositions, done in the last two months, were for a string quartet, and another chamber work titled "The Glorious Ensemble."
Mr. Rieti taught at the Peabody Conservatory from 1948 to 1949, at the Chicago Musical College from 1950 to 1953, at Queens College from 1955 to 1960, and at the New York College of Music from 1960 to 1964.
He was often encouraged to write his memoirs but said he wasn't interested. "I haven't got records, and I have a bad memory," he told an interviewer in 1973. "Too bad. I've known so many people, but I've lost track."
Mr. Rieti was married in 1924 to Elsie Rappaport, who died in 1969. He is survived by his son, a painter in Paris; two grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Corrections

 BODY:
An article and a chart in Business Day on Friday, about consumer prices in January and the prospects for inflation, described a statistical index incorrectly. The index, based on a regional survey conducted by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, measures the difference between the percentage of manufacturers in the Philadelphia area who said the prices they paid for raw materials and parts had risen from the previous month and the percentage who said prices had fallen. The index does not measure the prices themselves.

HEADLINE: New York's Information Underclass

 BODY:
Child number one owns a fancy computer setup that taps into electronic libraries all over the country. Child number two is computerless and poor in a rural area where the library is a single cramped room above the local gas station.
The first child is already primed for the Information Superhighway. The second child is stuck on what can only be called an Information Dirt Road. If Albany continues to starve the state library system, the gap between these information haves and have-nots will continue to grow, creating an information underclass that the state can ill afford. 
 The task of getting information to the small, isolated libraries falls to New York's library system, a loosely knit entity administered by the State Education Department. The system consists of 77 groups made up of nearly 9,000 libraries, including public libraries and those associated with schools, universities and hospitals. Local public libraries are financed mainly by municipalities.
The system, funded by the state, links local libraries through electronic catalogues, group buying agreements, inter-library loans and other supports. These services have grown dramatically more important since cash-starved cities and towns started cutting funds to local libraries. School libraries, meanwhile, are in scandalously bad shape; many cannot update even their encyclopedias.
Ideally, the state-financed library system would link the library in the mountains with the impressive holdings of the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue. That might never happen if the state continues to cheat the system out of money that it was promised and that it desperately needs.
In 1990, the Legislature passed a bill to give the system $15 million above the allocation at that time. But the state withheld the money because of the recession. Until last year, when a fraction of the promised funds were released, the system's budget had been frozen for seven years. Book acquisition fell to a dangerous low, journal subscriptions were dropped and computerization all but stopped.
Meanwhile, the demands have soared as immigrants continue to pour into the state, many turning to the libraries to learn about their new nation.
Gov. Mario Cuomo's current budget shortchanges the system yet again, by allocating only an extra $3 million instead of the balance of the $15 million previously promised. That is the difference between stabilizing a damaged system and letting it sink further into decline.
Mr. Cuomo and the Legislature need to stop starving the libraries. New York can pay in mere dollars now, or it can pay in illiteracy and work-force inferiority later.

HEADLINE: Frustration Over Haiti

 BODY:
It is not the business of the United States to forcibly reimpose democracy on Haiti. But neither is it the business of the United States to twist the arms of Haiti's democratically elected President. If he refuses to endorse proposals for political compromise or cabinet appointments urged on him by American and international mediators, it is wrong to ignore him.
In its double frustration with murderous and unyielding generals and a messianic and unbending President, that is just what the Clinton Administration has begun to do. It would do better to stick to democratic principles and learn to live with some of the resulting frustrations. It is for Haitians, and their elected leader, to decide if and when to yield. 
 Granted, President Jean-Bertrand Aristide can be a difficult man to deal with. Over the years, the strength of his political convictions has led Duvalierist gunmen to try to kill him and to burn his church to the ground, the Vatican to dismiss him from his religious order, and Haitian voters to make him the overwhelming winner of the freest election in Haiti's long history.
Less than a year after that election, those same unshakable convictions provoked soldiers, police and a tiny economic elite to depose him and drive him into exile. And almost ever since, those convictions have complicated the plans of two American Administrations to resolve Haiti's crisis with split-the-difference compromises between amoral usurpers with guns and a righteous exile with the country's only legitimate democratic mandate.
The unpleasant truth is that unless the United States is prepared to invade Haiti -- which it rightly is not -- no significant political changes are likely to take place without the ruling generals' consent. And if President Aristide has been a stubborn bargainer, the generals have been even more stubborn.
They have made it clear that they are dead set on staying put in Haiti and reaping the substantial profits of institutionalized corruption. And they remain utterly unmoved by the international sanctions that grind the faces of all those too poor and poorly connected to avail themselves of any of the numerous available loopholes.
So it is only honest for the United States to tell Father Aristide that he has little hope of returning to power without making large political compromises. But when the deposed President refuses to make the deals that Washington urges upon him, honoring democracy requires taking him at his word. Simply put, there can be no democracy in Haiti, at least during the current presidential term, without President Aristide.

HEADLINE: Executive on Hot Seat In Tokyo Trade Dispute

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 21

 BODY:
Depending on one's point of view, Takeo Tsukada is either the culprit responsible for an escalating trade crisis between the United States and Japan or an innocent bystander caught in the crossfire.
Mr. Tsukada, who prefers the latter description, is president of the Nippon Idou Tsushin Corporation, known as IDO, a provider of mobile telephone service that the United States Government accuses of failing to provide adequate access to Japan's cellular telephone market for equipment made by Motorola Inc. 
 Last week, the Clinton Administration said it would impose sanctions on Japan for violating a 1989 trade agreement intended to open Japan's market to the American cellular technology.
 
 
Motorola Called Selfish
 In an interview, Mr. Tsukada lashed out at Motorola for making what he called selfish demands that threaten to drive his company to bankruptcy.
At the last minute, he said, Motorola said sanctions could be avoided if IDO placed an immediate order for 225,000 Motorola portable telephones, which would have guaranteed Motorola a 50 percent share of IDO's anticipated cellular customers. IDO, he said, rejected the request as being impossible to fulfill and against free consumer choice.
Mr. Tsukada also expressed surprise that the American Government would bring all its weight to bear in the service of a single company.
"It's a dirty, collusive relationship between the Government and a private company," Mr. Tsukada said.
Motorola's main building in Tokyo has been splattered with graffiti in recent days. Slogans like "Crush the hard-selling diplomacy of U.S. imperialists" were painted on the walls.
As Mr. Tsukada tells it, there is no plot to keep Motorola out of the Japanese market. In 1987, Japan's Government decided to allow one company in each market to compete in cellular telephone service with the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, Japan's main phone company.
IDO won the franchise for the corridor from Tokyo to Nagoya. It built its system using technology developed by N.T.T., Mr. Tsukada said, not to block Motorola but because it already had a proven track record in Japan. The DDI Corporation, which won the franchise for the rest of Japan, chose Motorola's technology.
Still, the United States complained that it was unfair that the Motorola system was not being used in the highly populated corridor. In 1989, the cellular phone trade accord was signed to open the Tokyo-Nagoya market to Motorola. IDO was persuaded by Japan's Government to build a second system using the Motorola technology.
IDO could not afford to build two systems, Mr. Tsukada said. So it put more emphasis on the N.T.T. system, not to block Motorola but simply because it had started on the N.T.T. system first and needed to build it up quickly so it could compete. The result is that today, IDO has about 310,000 customers for its N.T.T.-compatible system and only a few more than 10,000 for the Motorola system.
Even Motorola executives say that IDO was saddled somewhat against its will with the franchise for the Motorola technology. But that has not stopped the company, based in Schaumburg, Ill., from complaining that IDO has dragged its feet in building the system.
Mr. Tsukada, a former Toyota executive who helped to establish that company's joint manufacturing venture with General Motors in California, said Motorola had overstepped its bounds. "Motorola has been behaving as if it has the authority to intervene in IDO's operation or as if it is representing the U.S. Government," he said.
Mr. Tsukada said IDO had proposed to build up the Motorola system over the next three years as fast as it could without endangering its already fragile economic health.
In the fiscal year that ended in March, IDO, which is privately held, had pretax profits of only 856 million yen, or about $8.3 million at current exchange rates, on sales of 81.1 billion yen, or $787 million, according to Teikoku Databank, a credit research firm. The company's debt of about 200 billion yen, or $1.94 billion, dwarfs its equity of 11.4 billion yen, or $110 million. The company has never paid a dividend and will not do so until the end of the century, Mr. Tsukada said.
 
Motorola's View
 Both Motorola and the Clinton Administration have rejected IDO's proposed construction schedule as inadequate. "We obviously do not want to see any of our customers in a loss," said Arnold S. Brenner, executive vice president and general manager of the Japan Group of Motorola. But he said that since Japan's Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications chose IDO, "it is the M.P.T.'s responsibility to make sure the company is financially and technically able to handle both systems."
In light of the looming American sanctions, Mr. Tsukada said, IDO is ready to review its investment program again, but has no practical ideas for what it could do to satisfy the Americans.
He rejected an idea proposed by Washington -- that the frequencies for the Motorola system be given to another company with more of a financial incentive to promote the American technology.
Mr. Tsukada also said that IDO is now shifting its strategy to favor the Motorola technology because it is better than N.T.T.'s.

HEADLINE: As Market Pressures Build, Fed Chief Goes to Congress

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, will deliver his semiannual report on interest rates to a Congressional panel on Tuesday against a backdrop of pressure from financial markets for a second increase, a move the Fed is believed to be trying to avoid for now.
The pressure from bond traders, who are steadily pushing up long-term interest rates and pushing down bond prices, is only one reason Mr. Greenspan's testimony before a House Banking subcommittee could scarcely come at a more awkward time for the nation's central bank. 
 The Fed's last increase, a quarter-of-a-percentage point rise in the Federal funds rate for overnight loans between banks, was made on Feb. 4, and was intended to hold down long-term rates. But it has had the reverse effect in the bond market. Long-term rates have also risen, to a yield of 6.62 percent on the 30-year Treasury bond, with most of that increase in the last several days.
"There are some Congressmen and Senators that are regular Fed-bashers, and this is an opportunity for them to do some bashing," said Laurence M. Ball, a macroeconomist at Johns Hopkins University.
White House economists count themselves among those who had not expected the recent increase in long-term rates from daily trading. "This has caught us by surprise just as it has caught most people by surprise," said Alan S. Blinder, one of three members of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers. He added that long-term interest rates now slightly exceed Administration estimates for this year.
Mr. Blinder said investors were overreacting to recent signs of the nation's improving economic health and the resulting possibility of inflation. "That is no reason for the kind of interest-rate creep we have," he said.
Many economists, including some with close links to the Fed, predict that Mr. Greenspan will give few clear signs that another rate increase might be imminent. They predict that Mr. Greenspan will instead forecast that the economy will grow about 3 percent this year and conclude that such a growth rate can be sustained, at least this year, without fueling inflation.
But they nonetheless expect Mr. Greenspan to repeat his many warnings that the Fed would be ready to change direction quickly if prices do begin to rise.
"I do not expect to see any change in the Federal funds target in the next several months," said Andrew F. Brimmer, a former Fed governor.
The Fed's defenders say an increase in long-term rates this spring may have been inevitable, given the widespread perception that a strengthening economy can eventually lead to higher inflation and lower bond prices.
"The Fed acted responsibly -- it was the correct thing for them to do," said Michael J. Boskin, chairman of President George Bush's Council of Economic Advisers. "If the Fed had not done this, there would have been a much larger adjustment down the road."
Other economists say that the recent sharp drop in the value of the dollar against the Japanese yen may have badly hurt speculative traders, who then pulled back from the American bond market. The decline of the dollar, and the possibility of further declines, given Japanese-American trade tensions, made dollar-denominated investments less desirable to international investors, and thus interest rates needed to rise to attract those investors.
 
Chain Reaction of Sorts
 The most common explanation among economists of why short-term rates sent long-term rates upward is that the Fed's action on Feb. 4 changed investors' expectations of future inflation. By raising interest rates, the Fed signaled that it was worried about inflation, and that convinced many investors that they should also be worried, Mr. Ball said.
"I suspect that the Fed's action had some effect on the psychology of the market," he said, "and that had the effect of pushing long-term interest rates higher."
Still, compared with many interest-rate moves in the last dozen years, these shifts are tiny. In the last two months of 1991, for example, the Federal Reserve lowered short-term rates by a full percentage point.
Gene B. Sperling, a senior White House economic adviser, tried to present the bright side of recent interest-rate increases, pointing out that "30-year bonds are still a point below where they were when Bill Clinton was elected." These bonds yielded 7.65 percent on Nov. 3, 1992, the day after the election.
The timing of Mr. Greenspan's testimony on Tuesday is especially awkward for the Fed because it is also fighting an effort by the Treasury Department to take away most of its responsibilities for bank supervision.

HEADLINE: Disappointing Year for Mexican Economy

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DEPALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 21

 BODY:
Contrary to recent Government projections showing a moderate rebound, Mexico's economy grew only four-tenths of 1 percent last year, the weakest performance in the five years of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's administration.
In November, Mexico's Finance Minister had projected that the economy would increase 1.1 percent in 1993. 
 The fourth-quarter results were especially disappointing, coming after the passage in November of the North American Free Trade Agreement with the United States and Canada. The Mexican economy expanded only two-tenths of a percent in the quarter, allowing the economy to barely escape a classic recession, which economists consider to be two consecutive quarters of decline. In the third quarter, the Mexican economy fell 1.1 percent.
 
 
Worrisome Figures
 The year-end figures, released late Friday, present a worrisome picture for a country adjusting to a free trade agreement with a powerful neighbor while also trying to settle an armed uprising in the southern state of Chiapas. The rebellion was based in large part on the feeling among many Mexicans that they have not benefited from the economic changes of the last few years.
Mexico's manufacturing sector showed particularly poor results in 1993. Over all, manufacturing dropped 1.5 percent, but certain industries did much worse. Textiles, for example, dropped 7.4 percent, paper and printing fell 6.4 percent and lumber was down 10.1 percent.
"Only very late is the business community waking up and expressing concerns about how we translate macroeconomic policy to growth-related activities," Gabriel Szekely, a consultant in Mexico City, said. "The picture for 1994 is not very promising because of the reluctance of policy makers to come up with some type of industrial policy to identify sectors where Mexico can aspire to some competitive advantage."
There were a few bright spots in the year-end report. The financial services sector grew 4.9 percent, more than double the rate in 1992. And the agricultural sector rose 1.8 percent, compared with a drop of 1.5 percent a year earlier. However, that figure generally represents large growers, not the majority of the country's subsistence-level farmers.
And Mexico's trade deficit dropped 15.1 percent last year, to $13.54 billion.
Jonathan Heath, director of Macro Asesoria Economica, a consulting firm in Mexico City, said the lack of growth was caused by strict Government fiscal and monetary policy related to uncertainty over the fate of the free trade agreement. He said the Government maintained high interest rates for treasury notes to prevent an outflow of capital while the trade pact was being decided.
The Government was also intent on taming inflation. The money supply was kept limited and inflation increased at 8 percent, the lowest rate in 20 years.
The economic forecast for 1994 is substantially different from last year's. The trade pact is now in effect and 1994 is an election year. Even before the Chiapas uprising, the Government had decided to increase social spending substantially and stimulate the economy with public works projects.
Finance officials said last year that this could be done while still maintaining a balanced budget, but most analysts now expect a 1994 deficit that will be the equivalent of about 1 percent of the gross domestic product. Government officials have forecast a growth rate for 1994 of 3 percent, with 5 percent inflation. Mr. Heath finds those projections on target despite the economy's present weakness.

HEADLINE: Buffalo Rethinks Downtown Car Ban

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUFFALO, Feb. 21

 BODY:
It's been years since anyone arrived by cab beneath the marquee of the Shea's Buffalo theater or jockeyed for a parking space in front of A M & A's department store.
It's been a decade, in fact, since this city ripped up the busiest section of its Main Street, banishing the automobile in a quest for urban renewal and better mass transit. 
 Now some are having second thoughts.
Local officials have begun discussing the possibility of allowing cars back on the 1.2 miles of Main Street that were transformed into a pedestrian-transit mall, one of the largest malls of its type in the nation. The $42 million project, which includes a trolley-like light-rail line, formally opened as Buffalo Place in 1987.
Some now say it was a mistake to eliminate auto traffic completely. Chief among them is Richard T. Reinhard, executive director of Buffalo Place Inc., the nonprofit corporation responsible for maintaining and promoting the mall.
 
Seasonal Variance
 "Our transit mall works exceptionally well May through September, Monday through Friday, 11 A.M. through 2 P.M.," Mr. Reinhard said. "There are sidewalk cafes, sidewalk vendors, street performers. It's almost a storybook environment."
But, he added: "The rest of the time, it doesn't work. People can't find Main Street. Pedestrians feel all alone on Main Street. People don't enjoy Main Street."
Mr. Reinhard would like to keep the cafes and outdoor concerts that are so popular with summer lunchtime crowds, while allowing auto traffic alongside the Metro Rail line that now runs down the street's center. That would make businesses and theaters along the street more accessible, while the traffic would create a sense of activity during off-hours, he said.
Transforming the mall, again, would be expensive, involving the replacement of Metro Rail passenger stations, which also house the electronics controlling the transit system.
 
Another Round of Financing
 Richard T. Swist, executive director of the Niagara Frontier Transportation Authority, said that getting money for car lanes would mean going back to the Federal and state transportation projects that provided the bulk of the original financing.
"I think their view would be, they've already invested in this once and if they're going to do it again, they'd want to know why," he said. "And the reasons better be compelling."
Buffalo is among scores of American cities that have turned downtown streets into pedestrian malls since the 1960's in an effort to compete with the suburbs. And it is far from the first to question whether the transformation was a mistake, said Fred Kent, president of the Project for Public Spaces, a nonprofit group based in New York City that advises communities on the design of public spaces.
"A shopping mall is a shopping machine," Mr. Kent said. "A main street is different. It's a public space, and there are all kinds of things going on."
He said some of the more successful downtown pedestrian malls, such as one in Portland, Ore., allow limited auto traffic. "You need cars to be part of any environment, but in a more compatible way," he said.
Despite some vacant storefronts, the mall is far from a ghost town -- during the day, anyway. Since Buffalo Place opened, a new hotel, office buildings, a movie theater and an outdoor ice rink have been built in the district.
As many as 60,000 people visit the mall daily, at least on the sunny summer weekdays when pedestrian surveys have been made.
"But that's still not enough to support a significant amount of retail and restaurants," Mr. Reinhard said.
Patrick Fagan, executive vice president of Shea's Buffalo, a 3,183-seat theater on the mall, said most of his audience for touring Broadway shows and other performances now enters through a side door, which faces an open street.
It is his belief that reopening Main Street on at least a limited basis could change things only for the better. "To me, a traffic jam ain't bad," he said. "That means there's activity."
Still, the auto-less mall has its defenders.
Harold L. Cohen, a member of the citizen committee that worked with the transportation authority on the project's design, said the mall should have been more inviting to pedestrians, but construction costs took money meant for shelters, heated walkways and additional lighting.
"All the things that were supposed to be done to make it a pedestrian mall weren't done," said Mr. Cohen, dean emeritus of the State University at Buffalo's School of Architecture and Planning. "You can't blame the poor flower if it didn't grow because you didn't water it."

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS;
U.S. Offers Pact To the Muslims And the Croats

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ZAGREB, Croatia, Feb. 21

 BODY:
While attention over the last two weeks has focused on the showdown around Sarajevo, United States diplomats have been pressing a peace plan for other regions of Bosnia and Herzegovina where there has been fighting between Croatian forces and the mostly Muslim Bosnian Army.
A broad outline under consideration would end their battle for territory and create a joint sovereign state from land they control in a economic and commercial federation with Croatia. The next step, Croats here said, would be to invite the Bosnian Serbs to join a new Bosnian state under a political arrangement that has not yet been defined. 
 At this point there seems to be little reason for the Serbs to accept such an agreement, but Charles E. Redman, the United States special envoy to the former Yugoslavia, told reporters here today: "The Croats do not want to close the door on the Serbs. The question is, how does one best arrange the table so we can get to the Serbs with something that can be acceptable?"
 
Cease-Fire Sought
 People close to the talks, including high-level Croatian officials, said they and the Bosnian leadership were in full agreement on an eventual confederation between Zagreb and any joint Croatian-Muslim Bosnian state.
As a key part of the political proposal, Croatian officials here said they also hoped that Croatian and Bosnian Government military leaders would sign a cease-fire as early as this week covering central and southern Bosnia. Until a year ago, when they began battling over territory they shared in central Bosnia, they had been nominal allies against the Serbs.
In their search for a negotiated settlement in Bosnia, representatives from the United States, Russia, Canada and European nations are to meet in Bonn this week to consider extending the Sarajevo demilitarization effort to eastern Bosnia, including Tuzla and Srebrenica, where the United Nations has been prevented from delivering aid and relieving peacekeeping troops.
Mr. Redman said he was working with the support and cooperation of the European Union to broker a deal between Croats and Muslims, and he took pains to describe his negotiations as being on a "parallel track" with talks under way in Geneva.
But in some ways, the new proposal seems to offer an entirely new basis for settlement: Rather than trying to get all three sides to accept a settlement in which Bosnia is divided into three ethnic republics, as the latest United Nations and European plan proposed, Washington appears to be encouraging the Croats and Muslims to reach a separate settlement.
 
Several Obstacles Remain
 The plan faces several obstacles, not the least of which have been months of war between Muslims and Croats. Croatian gunners around the southwestern city of Mostar have enforced an eight-month-old siege that has killed or wounded hundreds and have cut off electricity and food to Muslims trapped in the city's ruins.
Croats here acknowledged that the two sides had not yet worked out the political framework for sharing power within the joint Bosnian state. The Croats prefer the federal state to be divided among two republics, while the Bosnian Government leaders want power shared among an undisclosed number of ethnically mixed cantons. No maps or geographical details are available, but the two groups combined control only about 30 percent of Bosnia at the moment.
Croats and Muslims have discussed confederation before, and Lord Owen, the Europe Union mediator, discussed it at length with the two sides. But the idea has been given new momentum by Washington, which is making its first serious foray into the peace efforts.

HEADLINE: Democrats Face Hard Choices in Welfare Overhaul

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
Something strange happened last week in the office of Leon E. Panetta, the White House budget director, and it illustrates the topsy-turvy forces now shaping the Administration's welfare plan.
Desperately seeking ways to pay for it, Democrats began talking about cuts in the food stamp program. Big cuts. Cuts as large as the ones Ronald Reagan proposed. 
 Mr. Panetta seemed skeptical of the idea, which was offered by an aide, and when word spread later in the week, his spokesman ruled it out. But across the Government similar conversations are occurring daily.
Democrats, straining to finance President Clinton's welfare promises, are searching for the money in the same anti-poverty programs they spent the last decade defending.
 
Facing Tough Bind
 For some people involved, the revenue hunt has become the equivalent of eating their young, and the process is aggravating nerves, tempers and the occasional friendship.
The Administration is in this bind because it is striving to avoid tax increases, a decision that has left some officials disgruntled. They point to a memorandum that Robert B. Reich, the Labor Secretary, sent President Clinton in December.
The memo suggested that tens of billions of dollars could be raised by changing provisions it called "tax breaks" for the prosperous. Mr. Reich, for instance, suggested reducing interest deductions for expensive homes or raising taxes on inherited stock.
But the subject of taxes is so sensitive that a call to the Labor Department on the matter brought an unsolicited response from the White House.
"This is not a memo that's under serious consideration, I just want to tell you," said Gene Sperling, a White House economics adviser. "We want a no-tax budget."
 
Choices Are Uninviting
 The failure to find a politically acceptable solution would doom one of Mr. Clinton's most popular campaign promises. He has pledged to expand training opportunities for welfare recipients and then force those still unemployed after two years to join a work program. His aides have said that the plan could cost as much as $7 billion a year when fully carried out.
Antipoverty programs can, of course, become as fat or flawed as any others. "Just because a program is targeted on the poor doesn't mean we shouldn't touch it," said one Administration official. "It might not be doing a good job."
But the biographies of those involved are not ones of typical budget cutters.
David T. Ellwood, an assistant secretary at the Department of Health and Human Services, came from Harvard University, where he was a prominent advocate for low-income people. Wendell E. Primus, his chief assistant, had been a Capitol Hill legend for finding money for antipoverty efforts.
Isabel V. Sawhill, a White House budget aide, was an academic specialist on rising income inequality. Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, was chairwoman of the Children's Defense Fund.
Now they are thinking about cutting disability payments, denying help to legal immigrants and reducing homeless prevention programs. But they are not discussing it. "Some of these ideas may be distasteful to the people who draft them," said Avis Lavelle, a spokeswoman for the Department of Health and Human Services.
 
Many Competing ClaimsA Binding Deficit
 The process also shows how a Government can spend $1.5 trillion a year and still consider itself broke. The 1990 budget law requires any new spending to be paid for with offsetting taxes or cuts.
Dee Dee Myers, the White House press secretary, would not flatly rule out a tax increase to pay for the welfare plan. But on Friday she repeated the guiding assumption: the proposal, which Mr. Clinton pledged to deliver to Congress this spring, "would be paid for by offsetting cuts in other programs."
And since welfare is an "entitlement program," the budget law requires the cuts to come from similar programs. Social Security, which costs $335 billion a year, is the largest. But the Administration has already shot down a suggested $1.2 billion trim, fearing the reaction from the lobby for the elderly.
Medicare and Medicaid, which together account for $273 billion, are the next two largest. But President Clinton is trying to restrain their growth to finance changes in health care.
Most of what is left affects poor people, and since those programs are much smaller, the cuts loom larger in proportion. The largest welfare program, Aid to Families with Dependent Children, costs about $23 billion a year. Food stamps cost about $24 billion. The Supplemental Security Income program, which provides payments to the indigent elderly and disabled, accounts for about $22 billion.
 
Making Some Suggestions
 In outlining possible tax increases, Mr. Reich was suggesting ways to get more money for the domestic agenda in general, not for the welfare plan. In his memo to the President he took pains to write that these were suggestions rather than firm recommendations.
Mr. Reich, for instance, took a dim view of the law that allows homeowners tax deductions for the interest on mortgages of up to $1 million. He wrote that "lowering the cap to $500,000 would raise about $4 billion over 5 years." He also talked about ending what he called tax breaks for companies with foreign subsidiaries and those involved in mergers and acquisitions.
A copy of the memo was provided by a White House official who argued that the hunt for revenue should be broadened. "Most of the things on that sheet are giveaways to rich people," the official said.
Mr. Reich, who was traveling, could not be reached. But Eugene Steuerle, a Washington tax expert, said many ideas on Mr. Reich's list had been proposed in the past, only to die from political opposition and technical complexity.
Mr. Ellwood and Mr. Primus, the human services officials, presented their proposed cuts at a meeting at the White House on Jan. 25. One still being considered is a plan to curb S.S.I. and Medicaid payments to legal immigrants until they become citizens. The move could raise $1.8 billion a year.
Several other items on the list have already been ruled out. After learning that the White House was thinking about taxing welfare benefits, Representative Robert T. Matsui, a California Democrat who is on the Ways and Means Committee, called the idea "just damn stupid."
Mr. Clinton, who is courting allies like Mr. Matsui for his health plan, publicly buried the idea last week with a single word. Asked if he would consider it, he said, "No."
The scene in Mr. Panetta's office last week captured the difficult dynamics that may continue to play out in the weeks ahead.
Ms. Sawhill, the budget aide, suggested giving fewer food stamps to people who get housing aid. There is a fairness argument involved. People who receive housing assistance have arguably more money left over for food than other low-income people, but they receive the same amount of food stamps.
The idea was opposed by Thomas J. Downey, a former Democratic Congressman from Suffolk County, and Robert Greenstein, an advocate who ran the food stamp program under Jimmy Carter.
Mr. Greenstein gave Mr. Panetta a memo that called the cuts devastating.
"About two million households would have their food stamps terminated or cut," said the memo, which has circulated at the human services department, the Agriculture Department, and the Department of Housing and Urban Development. And 60 percent of the families with children affected "have cash incomes below half the poverty line."
Mr. Greenstein would not comment on the issue, saying that his discussions with the Administration were confidential. But his strategy seemed to work. Barry Toiv, the budget office spokesman, said on Friday that the food stamp idea had been "ruled out."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Leon E. Panetta, the White House budget director, whose office has come under pressure to find ways to pay for the Clinton welfare plan. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Japan, Bowing to Pressure, Defers Plutonium Projects

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 20

 BODY:
Bowing to international pressure, Japan has decided to postpone, for as long as 20 years, a series of multibillion-dollar nuclear power projects that would add tremendously to the world oversupply of plutonium, Japanese and American officials say.
The decision, to be announced in the next few months, came after a yearlong reassessment of Japan's ambitious but politically troublesome nuclear energy program and stemmed largely from the international outcry last year over Japan's sea shipment from Europe of more than a ton of plutonium, a highly toxic and radioactive material that is a fuel for nuclear weapons. Several of Japan's Asian neighbors banned the shipment from passing through their waters, fearing an accident or terrorist incident. 
 The Government's decision affects the schedule for building several breeder reactors -- which are nuclear power plants that both consume and produce plutonium -- and a second reprocessing plant, which turns ordinary nuclear waste into plutonium. It also seems bound to cut sharply the shipments of plutonium from Europe because Japan will have far less capacity to use the plutonium fuel.
The Government's decision is also motivated partly by fears among Japan's huge utility companies that the country's policy to create a "nuclear fuel cycle" -- turning nuclear waste into plutonium fuel -- was quickly becoming a financial fiasco, one that could cost them billions of dollars.
 
Policy Is Retained
 Japanese officials say they have no intention of abandoning their fuel-recycling policy. But the delays are clearly an effort to back away, and many of them concede that they were shocked by the scope of international protests generated by the first plutonium shipment. Officially, about two sea shipments of one to two tons are planned annually for the next 18 years, although that plan also seems bound to be drastically changed.
What to do with that plutonium is becoming a major problem: Tokyo clearly fears that the political liabilities will mount in coming years if Japan is unable to burn all the plutonium it plans to produce or import. Plutonium stockpiles would only add to suspicions abroad, denied by Japan, that Tokyo has ulterior motives and is keeping its options open in case it ever needs to develop nuclear weapons.
Looming large against this background is North Korea, which is widely suspected of operating a nuclear weapons program. Even without a weapons project in Japan, many Asian nations say, the mere presence of large amounts of plutonium in the country constitutes a latent nuclear capability.
"Our basic policy is still in place, but now we are looking out at the year 2020, or maybe 2050," a senior Government official involved in the debate said last week. "Politically, it is clear that this is not the time to be producing plutonium, shipping it around the world or storing it."
The Clinton Administration, fearful of adding to its tensions with Washington's biggest ally in the Pacific, has never publicly opposed Japan's plans to build breeder reactors or the reprocessing centers needed to convert nuclear waste. In fact, the non-proliferation policies issued by the White House last year gave a specific exemption to Japan's project, and to reprocessing centers in England and France that depend heavily on Japan's business.
 
U.S. Halted Program
 But the United States halted its own breeder reactor program 15 years ago, largely to stop the spread of bomb-grade materials. American officials have made little secret of their concern that Japan's program would add tremendously to the glut of plutonium created by the dismantling of nuclear weapons in the former Soviet republics.
While Japan's plutonium is "reactor grade," meaning it is made for energy production instead of weapons, the National Academy of Sciences recently concluded that such material could be used to make a bomb, heightening the concerns that the supplies could fall into the hands of terrorists or aspiring nuclear nations, including Iran, Iraq and North Korea.
"The overall program is now seen as more trouble than it is worth, in terms of the money and the politics," said Paul Leventhal, the president of the Nuclear Control Institute, a group in Washington that has led the lobbying effort against Japan's plutonium plans. It has suggested instead that Tokyo buy and stockpile large amounts of uranium, which is far more difficult to turn into nuclear weapons.
"The increasing international pressure because of the program has created a perception abroad that Japan is interested in preserving the nuclear weapons option," Mr. Leventhal said. Tokyo, he added, "is finding it more difficult to blunt that perception."
 
Trying to Avoid Debate
 While the wisdom of Japan's energy strategy has been widely debated abroad, the Government here has done everything it can to suppress open arguments that could stir a Japanese public when there is growing sentiment against nuclear power, especially as the authorities try to find sites for new plants. But some Japanese scientists are beginning to chafe.
"There are almost no open arguments on the issue," Prof. Kazuo Furukawa of Tokai University wrote recently in Asahi Shimbun. With the Government and some Government-controlled nuclear institutes commanding the research money, he added, "there is no democratic climate, and the debate has created factions and authoritarian tendencies."
Nonetheless, as a study commission has worked in secret on Japan's long-term energy plan, details have gradually been leaking out. Every week now Japanese news organizations are reporting that one element or another of the program will be delayed.
Next month, for instance, Japan will finally activate a $5 billion breeder reactor called Monju, named for the Buddhist divinity of wisdom, several years behind schedule. The huge complex, on a remote peninsula on the Sea of Japan, was originally supposed to be the first of a series of breeders that would fundamentally change the nuclear power industry here.
But Monju will be so expensive to run that the construction of a second reactor, originally planned to begin immediately, will now apparently not start until the year 2000, at the earliest. In fact, the Government has yet to find a site for the next reactor; so far, none of the country's local prefectural governments wants it to be built in its region.
 
Another Project Delayed
 Several days ago the Asahi Shimbun, one of Japan's largest dailies, reported that the completion of another major project, a second "reprocessing plant," which would convert the fuel to reactor-grade plutonium, would be also delayed -- from the year 2010 to the year 2030. Construction of the first reprocessing plant has already begun, but many experts say they have their doubts about when it will open.
By American standards, delaying huge technology projects by a generation, rather than canceling them outright, may seem ludicrous. But in Japan, few big projects are ever killed. Instead, they remain forever in the planning stage, keeping a vast bureaucracy at work. Already the Government-created corporations managing the nuclear fuel cycle have employed thousands. Terminating it would be politically unacceptable.
By slowing the program drastically, however, the Government appears to be betting that it can silence its international critics without visibly cutting back on employment. If the political atmosphere changes, or another energy crisis strikes, the program would be waiting in the wings.
The program that Japan is being forced to delay is already nearly 30 years old. In 1966, encouraged by the United States, Japan adopted a plan to build a series of breeder reactors around the country and become a leader in the technology. It seemed to make tremendous economic sense. By the 1990's, the Government said, uranium would be scarce and expensive, making the high cost of recovering plutonium from spent nuclear fuel a bargain.
 
Uranium Prices Plunge
 But the projections went wildly awry. Uranium prices have plunged, making the breeder reactors 5 to 15 times more expensive to run than conventional nuclear power plants. The United States dropped out of the breeder reactor business. Then the end of the cold war created the glut in plutonium. That heightened fears that the world oversupply was worsening, just as Japan set about producing more.
But once Japan was on the road to recycling, it seemed that there was no turning back. It has already shipped undetermined number of tons of nuclear waste to Europe, reportedly spending as much as $3 billion in secret agreements to help Britain and France build reprocessing installations that would convert the waste to plutonium.
The shipment that caused the protests in January 1993 was the first load of plutonium to arrive back in Japan from Europe. Along the way, South Africa, Brazil, Argentina and the Philippines asked Japan to keep the ship well away from their waters.
Based largely on Japan's commitments, England recently commissioned its new nuclear reprocessor, after a long political battle. But Japan has scheduled no further shipments, in part because it does not have the installations to burn the plutonium.

HEADLINE: Columbia Journal;
Prison Lures Them In (as Tourists)

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: COLUMBIA, S.C., Feb. 19

 BODY:
South Carolina's state penitentiary has been both an eyesore and a curiosity on the riverside in this stately capital city since shortly after the Civil War.
The subject of a Federal court order for overcrowding, and with a section condemned by the city government, the prison was closed by the South Carolina Department of Corrections last month. 
 But now the "prison from hell," as it came to be known, is the object of curiosity. Thousands of people asked to see the inside before the prison is torn down, so corrections officials decided to open it for tours, starting today and continuing on weekends until mid-March.
"People have driven by it all their lives and are curious about it," said Robyn Zimmerman, the director of public affairs for the Department of Corrections.
The first day of tours drew 3,300 visitors. Among other things, they saw the chair that electrocuted 243 inmates and a tunnel that was the site of untold inmate stabbings and other violence.
The City of Columbia has a contract to buy the prison property for $3.2 million but will not take possession until this summer. City officials hope to use the 25-acre site, which is beside the Columbia Canal and the Congaree River, for shops, restaurants, loft residences and offices. The South Carolina Film Commission is trying to interest Hollywood in using the oldest part of the prison as a movie set.
Until the last group of inmates was moved on Jan. 21, the prison, Central Correctional Institution, was one of the oldest state prisons still in use in the nation. When it was built in 1867, the five-story castle-like structure cost the state $65,000. The building, which eventually included several additions, was South Carolina's only maximum-security prison until 1975, when another opened.
South Carolina imprisons more people, per capita, than any other state, and has 32 state prisons.
Executions were performed at Central Correctional from 1912 until 1986, when the death house was relocated to the Broad River Correctional Institution, the state's main prison complex, also in Columbia. Among the executions was that of a 14-year-old black boy, George Stinney Jr., whose electrocution in 1944 made him the youngest person legally put to death in the United States in this century.
South Carolina's most notorious criminals spent time at Central Correctional, including Donald H. (Pee Wee) Gaskins, who in 1991 became the only white man to be executed in South Carolina for killing a black man. Mr. Gaskins, who was serving a life sentence for murder, was put to death for constructing a bomb that killed another inmate, Rudolph Tyner, in his cell. The cell where Mr. Tyner died is on the tour, said Charles Cepak, the outgoing warden.
The tunnel was designed to link all major parts of the prison and is a feature that made the prison one of the hardest in the state to manage.
"I don't know how many stabbings have occurred in this tunnel," said Corrections Commissioner Parker Evatt, "and it might be because someone got a bigger piece of chicken." In 1968, a riot began in the tunnel and spilled out onto the yard. Dozens of inmates were injured.
The prison's oldest section, Cellblock 1, was condemned some years ago. Its cells have floor space of only 5 by 6 feet and ceilings only 6 1/2 feet high. The walls are of 18-inch-thick granite and the door openings are only 25 inches across. Nevertheless, many inmates preferred Cellblock 1 because it often meant they could have private quarters.
But not always: as recently as the 1970's, there were cases of three inmates sharing one of those cells.
Preparing for the public tours has involved a great deal of cleaning -- and some interesting findings. "You wouldn't believe the filth," said Nelly Gasaway, a Central Corrections guard for two decades.
Officials found a plaque on a wall that had been set in place in 1904. When they pried it loose, they discovered behind it a battered copper box about the size of a shoebox, Ms. Zimmerman said. She said the box might be a time capsule because something can be heard rattling inside. It will not be opened until March 3, when a reunion of prison employees is held.
Prisoners left behind a wide variety of items, including toasters, radios, television sets, fans and about 50 cats that lived mainly in the prison yard. The cats are being taken to an animal welfare organization, and the appliances, probably part of the prison's underground economy, will be donated to charity.
"It's like an abandoned village," Mr. Cepak said.

HEADLINE: The Pain of British Privatizations Has Yielded a String of Successes

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
Not too long ago, the idea would have been laughable: BMW, a name synonymous with German quality and industrial prowess, paying $1.2 billion to acquire Rover, the struggling car maker and a name once synonymous here with British clunkers and industrial decline.
But in the five and a half years since the British Government privatized Rover and cut off the billions of dollars in subsidies that had sustained it for more than a decade, the company has completed a remarkable turnaround. Quality, design and efficiency have improved tremendously. Last year it was one of the few European auto makers to weather a sales slump profitably. 
 BMW, which announced last month that it was buying Rover from British Aerospace P.L.C., said it saw great potential to increase Rover's sales at home and around the world.
The transformation of Rover is just one example of how a number of companies, from British Airways to British Steel, were put through the crucible of Britain's aggressive privatization program during the 1980's and have emerged stronger and more nimble.
 
 
Mass Layoffs
 Freed from the embrace of Government bureaucracy and cut off from its financial support, many of the country's biggest corporations have remade themselves for a world in which their survival depends not on subsidies but on satisfying customers and shareholders.
They and their employees have suffered considerable upheaval, including mass layoffs. In the process, however, they have helped big British industries become more competitive internationally. Although it is impossible to quantify their effect on economic growth, they have clearly helped restore something of the nation's economic reputation.
The question of how much credit to give the privatization program remains hotly debated here, as is nearly every aspect of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's legacy. But with many of the companies involved having continued to expand and strengthen themselves despite a deep recession in Europe and Britain, there is little doubt that the whip hand of privatization is at least partly responsible for the change.
Here are some of the most prominent examples:
*At a time when nearly all the world's airlines have been suffering financial losses, British Airways has been among the world's most profitable for several years, and despite the recession has built itself into one of the world's few truly global carriers through investments in airlines like USAir and Qantas.
*British Telecommunications, long a stodgy, high-cost phone company with poor service, has slashed prices and improved service to stave off intense new competition at home and has taken a $4.3 billion 20 percent stake in MCI of the United States, a move that should allow it to expand worldwide.
*British Steel is the only big steelmaker in Europe that is profitable.
*BAA, the company that owns and operates Heathrow, Gatwick and other international airports in Britain, has more than doubled its profits since privatization in 1987 and is expanding its management services into the United States and Asia.
*NFC, formerly National Freight Consortium, bought Allied Van Lines in the United States as part of an ambitious expansion drive. Privatized through an employee-led buyout in 1982, the company went public in 1989 and has pushed sales and profits consistently higher since then. A share that was worth 1 at the time of the buyout would now be worth 160.
*Cable and Wireless slashed the work force at its headquarters, pushed authority and responsibility out to its operating units around the world and has seen its profits rise to an estimated $1.5 billion last year, from about $100 million a year, as it began privatizing in the early 1980's.
"All these companies that were moribund parts of the state sector are now out competing around the world," Lord Young, who was an early proponent of privatization, said. "It's been incredibly important for Britain."
Not every privatized company has flourished or even survived. Moreover, analysts, economists and business executives said it would be wrong to attribute all the improvement to privatization. The move away from state ownership, they said, was only important in the context of a wide range of Government policies that had the intention of deregulating industry, creating more competition and removing barriers to foreign trade and investment.
"I can be fairly unequivocal in saying that we're better off than if privatization had not happened," said John Kay, the chairman of London Economics, a consulting firm, and an economics professor at the London Business School. "But the other market-oriented reforms are in many ways as important a part of the story as privatization itself."
 Still, it was privatization that was the most visible and in many ways the most far-reaching change to sweep through British industry starting in the early 1980's. Both because it helped raise money for the Government -- more than $80 billion so far -- and because it fit neatly with the hard-line free market ideology espoused by Mrs. Thatcher upon taking office as prime minister in 1979, Britain has privatized or sold controlling stakes in 47 big companies and dozens of smaller ones. The bulk of the privatizations took place from 1981 to 1989 through public share offerings, management buyouts and direct sales to private-sector companies.
Privatization has not been uniformly successful. Leyland Bus, once the country's dominant bus manufacturer, was privatized through a management buyout in 1987 and sold to Volvo of Sweden a year later. Last year, after $150 million in losses, Volvo completed the closing of nearly all the company's operations.
Jaguar, the car maker that was privatized in 1984 and acquired by the Ford Motor Company five years later, continues to lose money, in part because of the worldwide downturn in auto sales, and Ford recently took a charge of $109 million to account for the latest costs of its turnaround effort.
Even for those companies that benefited, the process was far from pain free. In many cases there was considerable upheaval, including large-scale job losses.
 
 
'Major Shift'
 "Nationalized companies were insulated from the markets," said Keith Bradley, the director of the Business Performance Group at the London School of Economics. "You didn't have incentive for management change, and you didn't have incentive for organizational or technological change under that type of management culture. There was a major shift when these companies were suddenly exposed to markets and the realization dawned that they could go bankrupt or be taken over."
At Rover, for example, employment fell to 42,300 in 1988, from 157,000 in 1980, a drop of 73 percent, as the company was prepared for private ownership; it now stands at 33,000. At the same time, however, Rover's quality and efficiency were improving sharply, largely because of a partnership forged with Honda, the Japanese auto maker, which was encouraged by the Thatcher Government to invest in Britain.
[Honda, which owns 20 percent of Rover's car-making operations, was clearly rankled when BMW moved it aside to acquire control. As a result, Honda said Monday that it would cut its ties to Rover.]
In addition to cutting costs, most privatized companies have successfully remade their corporate cultures along less bureaucratic and more entrepreneurial lines, enabling them to respond more quickly to opportunities and changes in the market.
At British Steel, most of the plant closings and work force reductions took place in the years before privatization. The move into the private sector, by eliminating the need for consultation with the Government on every big decision, allowed the company's management to move more quickly to make acquisitions at home and abroad, and to close inefficient plants without political interference.
"The principal advantage for British Steel has been in shortening the decision-making chain," a spokesman for the company said.
 
 
Paying Attention to Customers
 The process has also forced companies to pay far more attention than before to their customers. British Telecom, which had become infamous for its uncaring attitude toward consumers, quickly changed its stripes at the time of privatization.
Responding to widespread complaints that there were not enough pay phones available and that many were not working, the company added 45 percent more of them and increased the number working to 95 percent last year, from 77 percent in the early 1980's. Faced with competition for the first time from upstart providers of residential and business phone service, the company reduced rates by 27 percent from 1984 to 1993, according to Government figures.
Prime Minister John Major, who succeeded Mrs. Thatcher (now Lady Thatcher) in 1990, has pressed ahead with the policy, although even some members of his Government have questioned whether the remaining industries are appropriate for privatization.
Mr. Major pushed through a plan in the fall to sell British Rail's passenger and freight service to regional franchisees only over opposition from commuters and travelers who said they feared it would lead to higher fares and deteriorating service.

Two of its phone booths, left, compete with those of Mercury Communications on Charing Cross Road in London. (Jonathan Player for The New York Times) (pg. D4)
