HEADLINE: Disney Drums Its Fingers as Virginia Debates the Worth of a Theme Park

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAYMARKET, Va., Feb. 20

 BODY:
The Walt Disney Company's plan to build a huge American history theme park next to this northern Virginia village 35 miles west of Washington is suddenly taking more political and economic twists and turns than a roller coaster ride.
The state's new Republican Governor, George F. Allen, is squabbling with the Democrat-controlled Legislature over whether to try to entice Disney by subsidizing some of the park's development costs, like highway construction and staff training. 
 Mr. Allen has proposed a $142 million subsidy, which is $17 million more generous than the legislators have so far been willing to offer. But given the potential economic impact of the $650 million park, which by some estimates could eventually rival the Disney parks in Florida and California, the debate is far from over.
Disney says it remains optimistic that a compromise will be found. But it has warned that its plans will collapse if they are delayed.
The company wants to open its fifth theme park in 1998 on 3,000 acres, which it has options to buy, just outside this town of 500 people. According to Disney calculations, the park should attract six million visitors a year, many of them tourists visiting Washington. State and private calculations indicate that directly or indirectly, the park and its surrounding new hotels, shops and houses could create 19,000 tourism jobs and a billion-dollar building boom.
 
Politics Comes Into Play
 In a state hard hit in recent years by recession and military cutbacks after a decade of above-average growth, some officials say new development is needed. Disney and Governor Allen are betting that the need will ultimately bring around balky legislators, as well as doubtful zoning officials and environmentalists.
Complicating the debate over how much inducement to give Disney is a host of other issues, including the political byplay between a new Republican Governor and a Democratic Legislature, state development policy, regional economic jealousies, pollution concerns and fair distribution of park jobs for members of minorities.
There is also debate over the American history attractions that Disney's "imagineers" propose to mix in with Mickey Mouse, Goofy and the usual assortment of Disney rides. The 100-acre park would be split into nine "playlands" with themes that include slavery in America and the wrenching era of the Vietnam War.
The politically savvy Disney, whose lobbyists are aswarm at the Capitol in Richmond, where they are referred to collectively as "the Mouse," says it must have a development subsidy -- and soon. Disney says it must have help building roads around the park, which by some estimates will cost more than $100 million, and argues that delaying or denying the subsidy would threaten the economic underpinning of the park and ruin its building schedule.
Last week, Disney officials said the company would not tolerate delay. Their warning came after the state Senate and House approved bills with differing subsidies, neither as generous as the Governor wants. Furthermore, the House version carried numerous qualifiers.
Still, the Disney officials, in the spirit of Mickey, found a silver lining.
"We're optimistic," said Mary Anne Reynolds, a Disney spokeswoman, noting that although the Legislature differed sharply with the Governor, it had at least moved toward approval of a subsidy.
 
Seeking a Second Vote
 In proposing a $142 million bond issue to help Disney, Governor Allen, the state's first Republican chief executive in 12 years, asked that the money be free of strings.
But when the state Senate voted on his request on Tuesday, the Democrats held the subsidy to $125 million, with Disney to pick up half of the annual $12 million in debt service. The House approved only $82 million, adding that if Disney would contribute another $44 million, the state would repay the company over several years.
Then the House threw in the biggest roadblock Disney has yet to encounter in its effort to create "Disney's America." The chamber attached a rider to its bill that requires a second legislative look at the park proposal, along with a second vote, just before the Legislature adjourns early this spring.
"This is hardly the way to welcome 19,000 jobs and a $650 million investment," the Governor said after the votes, accusing Democratic legislators of playing "partisan games."
But the debate over a Disney subsidy goes well beyond money and how much of it Democrats and Republicans can agree on. Also in dispute is whether Virginia should break with its long habit of drawing new industry by simply promoting its central location on the Atlantic Coast, low taxes, solid education system and the absence of strong unions.
Many other states, especially those in the South, use development subsidies to attract industry. But Virginia has mostly avoided this approach, arguing that the state has plenty of cost-free incentives to offer and that, besides, taxpayer money should not be risked on business ventures that could fail.
 
'Chilling' Mistake
 That was precisely the position taken last week by the House majority leader, C. Richard Cranwell.
"If we make a mistake on Disney," he warned, "it'll have a chilling effect on our ability to do anything constructive in the future because it is such a big-ticket item. I hope nobody thinks the message to Disney is, 'Don't come to Virginia.' The message is, 'Virginia is a well-run state.' "
Though Disney has had great success with most of its theme parks, the success has not been universal. Its Euro Disney park just outside Paris has lost hundreds of millions of dollars.
Legislators are also squabbling over whether other regions of Virginia should be given some kind of economic aid if a big subsidy goes to Disney to help it settle in northern Virginia. In the southwest, many miners are out of work, and on the Tidewater coast, many military installations are closing.
Nor do the twists in the Disney dispute end there.
Environmentalists say a huge Disney development would further degrade the environment in the ever-growing Washington area. History buffs say that they fear Disney will distort history and that the influx of visitors could harm genuine historic areas like nearby Manassas Battlefield Park.
And civil rights advocates warn Disney that they will protest loudly if the company does not hire as many members of minorities as they want.
Senator Henry L. Marsh 3d of Richmond, who is black, argued during last week's debate that the legislature should require Disney to let black history experts review the historical accuracy of the park's theme attractions.
"There's a possibility of abuse when you show slavery in an entertainment fashion," he said. He was rebuffed.
In a few days, the conferees from the Virginia Senate and House will begin efforts to reconcile the two subsidy bills passed last week. No one is predicting just how much money will eventually be put out for Disney, but the betting is that the legislators will be generous enough to bring its new fantasyland to life.
"They're not going to be able to look their constituents in the eye and say, 'I just blew it, just messed up 19,000 jobs in Virginia,' " the Governor confidently predicted the other day.

HEADLINE: Panel Finds Threat to Great Lakes

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
The United States and Canada have not kept a promise in 1978 to halt the flow of dangerous chemicals into the Great Lakes, an international commission says.
"The integrity of the Great Lakes and life forms that depend on them remain at an unacceptable level of risk from persistent toxic substances," the International Joint Commission said last week in its seventh biennial report on water quality in the Great Lakes. It called for a more specific strategy for ending the flow of dangerous chemicals from industry and incineration. 
 Among its recommendations, the commission repeated a plea it made two years ago for the United States, Canada and the chemical industry to find a way to end the use of chlorine in manufacturing.
Coming just weeks after the Clinton Administration promised to study the possible phase-out of chlorine and chlorine compounds, the report was enthusiastically embraced by environmental groups and assailed by the chemical industry. "The debate is no longer whether to phase out these chemicals, but how," said George Coling, a Great Lakes specialist with the Sierra Club.
 
Chlorine Industry Objects
 The environmental group Greenpeace called the commission's report "one of the most important statements ever made for the future of environmental policy in North America."
But Brad Lienhart, managing director of the Chlorine Chemistry Council, said, "The I.J.C. report is not a sound-science approach to decision-making."
And the Dow Chemical Company, the world's largest producer of chlorine, said, "There is currently no evidence that would support a total ban on chlorine chemistry, and the social and economic consequences of such a ban would be disastrous for the public."
The joint commission's American co-chairman, Gordon Durnil, said that the panel had been trying for years to discuss chlorine and chlorine compounds with the chemical industry but that the industry refused to be involved.
"We're now having really a pretty good dialogue with lobbyists," Mr. Durnil said. "But the chemical industry has not brought forth any evidence that their views have any merit.
"It appears to us that the weight of evidence says there is a danger from organochlorides. You've got some really major problems going on: increases in breast cancer, prostate cancer, endometriosis. You can in many cases, trace it to an organochloride."
The chlorine industry said any analysis must take account of the risks of not having the chemical available to society.

LENGTH: 419 words

HEADLINE: The Boat People: A Chapter Closes

 BODY:
They first floated into the world's consciousness in 1977, fishing boats crammed with desperate men, women and children fleeing the hardships and persecutions of a newly united Communist Vietnam. They encountered pirate attacks at sea and hostile receptions on nearby Asian shores. Still, nearly a million of these "boat people" eventually set sail, most in the late 1970's and early 1980's.
That chapter of history has now been officially closed by the United Nations High Commissioner on Refugees. The U.N.'s refugee arm declared last week that fleeing Vietnamese would no longer be automatically eligible for consideration as political refugees; they will be judged on an individual basis like other applicants. Most of the 60,000 boat people remaining in Asian refugee camps can now be legally sent back home. 
 That is unwelcome news to the affected Vietnamese. But sending them home is no more cruel than leaving them to rot in refugee camps -- if they can be assured of freedom from reprisals on their return. Asian countries, fearing unemployment and ethnic conflict, will not admit them as residents. And Western countries other than the United States have been almost equally unwelcoming.
Though the world likes to pretend otherwise, the treatment refugees receive always has a lot to do with international politics and the current standing of their homeland. The Vietnamese exodus of the late 1970's shocked a world that had been lulled by Hanoi's rosy -- and false -- postwar picture of liberation, peace and national recuperation. Vietnam is still a poor country and remains arbitrary in its treatment of those suspected of political nonconformity. Yet it offers more hopeful economic prospects and less systematic repression.
It is also being officially welcomed back into the community of nations that isolated it during the long Indochina wars. Only this month, the U.S. finally dropped its 19-year economic embargo. The Association of Southeast Asian Nations, once virtually an anti-Vietnamese alliance, now weighs accepting Hanoi as an associate member.
International law defines a refugee fairly strictly. Most people trying to escape poverty and dictatorship do not qualify, only those who can demonstrate a "well-founded fear of persecution." International agencies like the U.N. High Commissioner on Refugees have a dual mandate: to protect legitimate refugees and to organize their return home after it becomes safe to go back. For Vietnam, that moment now seems to have arrived.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Tax-Rate Scare Hides Real Health Plan Fear

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In "Jim Cooper's Pointless Plan (Op-Ed, Feb. 13), Henry J. Aaron writes: "Such taxes are almost confiscatory. It is hard to believe that any member of Congress would knowingly support the creation of a near-poverty trap like the one that would result from the Cooper health proposal." 
 Strong words from one of the most respected economists around. Yet before we rush to accept Dr. Aaron's views on financing health reform, we need to ask: How much more will the family he profiles pay in taxes because of the "confiscatory" phase-out of their health insurance subsidy? The answer is $0.
The issue Dr. Aaron raises is a favorite of conservative Republicans -- the effect of high marginal tax rates on work behavior. But Congress, having just raised the top tax rate close to 20 percent, cannot now start shouting that rates matter.
More disturbing, Dr. Aaron has indicted any proposal that suggests people should pay for their own health insurance (with a promise of help for those who need it).
But the design of a transfer program must concern itself not only with its effects on the beneficiaries, but also on the benefactors. It is because the costs to those asked to pay for the plan are so high that we see such opposition to the President's proposal.
 
CARLOS E. BONILLA
Chief Economist
Employment Policies Institute
Washington, Feb. 14, 1994

HEADLINE: Don't Label All Young Germans as Neo-Nazis;
Home-Grown Variety

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re Stephen Silver's "Music of Hate" (Op-Ed, Feb. 8): Germany is not the only country in which neo-Nazi rock music has flourished. It can be found in many other countries, including the United States. Neo-Nazi or "white power" rock, as it is sometimes called, has inspired countless violent crimes in this country. 
 In Arlington, Tex., Donald Thomas, a 32-year-old black man, was killed by neo-Nazi skinheads in a drive-by shooting. In the car were three skinheads driving around while listening to white power rock.
"Sounds of Hate: Neo-Nazi Rock Music From Germany," a 1992 study by the Anti-Defamation League, reported that Rock-O-Rama, the record company mentioned in the Op-Ed article, was the leading producer of this type of music not just in Germany, but also in the world. The American groups they recorded were no less extreme than their German counterparts, as in the following song, "A Call to Arms," by Bound for Glory, a Minnesota band:
Zionist illusions, state of confusions
Are decaying away my mind,
Feelings of hate, can't get it straight,
Am I the only one of my kind?
Massive inflation by the racial infestation
Has turned our streets to decay
Racial domination, swift termination
Has become the only way.
Close the border, start the New Order
Gather your guns, it's time to fight,
A call to arms!
It is to the German Government's credit that it cracked down on Rock-O-Rama last year. However, other such companies remained free to operate, including Skull Records in Germany, Rebelles Europeens in France, RAC Records and White Power Records in Britain, Resistance Records in Detroit and White Terror Records in Garden Grove, Calif.
Our Constitution prohibits Government suppression of hate music, but it also protects the public's right to rise up and shout to those who promote it, "Enough!"
 
IRWIN SUALL
New York, Feb. 15, 1994
 
The writer is director of the fact-finding department of the Anti-Defamation League.

HEADLINE: U.S. TELLS ARISTIDE TO BEND ON PLAN

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Feb. 22

 BODY:
In a change of strategy, the Clinton Administration has decided against imposing tighter economic sanctions on Haiti unless the exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, agrees to broaden his government and grant immediate amnesty to military officers who ousted him in 1991.
Administration officials said today that in effect Father Aristide must do more to embrace a recently formulated plan to restore him to office. The plan was drawn up in Washington by a visiting Haitian parliamentary delegation that has consulted closely with Administration and United Nations officials.
 
President Rejects Plan
 The plan, which Father Aristide has so far rejected, calls on the exiled President to name a new Prime Minister, who would form a new, broadly based Government and obtain immediate passage of legislation giving amnesty to Gen. Raoul Cedras and other Haitian officers involved in the coup. 
 Father Aristide has said that because the army has violated all of its agreements in the past, General Cedras and other military leaders should be required to relinquish power before any new political arrangements are made.
Nevertheless, the rejection of the plan by Father Aristide, who lives in exile in Washington, has irked officials of the Clinton Administration and United Nations diplomats. Many of the plan's elements were contained in a negotiated settlement of the country's crisis that Father Aristide signed in New York last July.
That settlement collapsed when Haiti's military leaders violated their agreement to step down in October and began a campaign of widespread violence, including assassinations of business and political leaders who supported Father Aristide.
Last week, the Haitian leader initially declined to meet with the parliamentary delegation, which included some political leaders nominally supporting him. Father Aristide later relented, agreeing to a meeting but rejecting requests that he name a new Government.
The Clinton Administration has openly expressed its frustration with Father Aristide's position. Asked last week if Father Aristide was considered to be intransigent, the State Department spokesman, Mike McCurry, replied, "That's close to our reading."
Many supporters of Father Aristide have maintained that as Haiti's first democratically-elected President, he should not be required to compromise with the military and its allies who supported his overthrow. Diplomats have said, however, that if the Haitian leader is ever to return to office, he will have to reach out to people who have opposed him in the past and reassure his enemies that his return will not result in reprisals.
Diplomats said a vote by the United Nations Security Council to broaden the embargo on Haiti, which currently covers oil and arms, would still be submitted for approval, possibly as early as this week. But a senior official involved in the diplomacy said the sanctions would be "conditioned somehow on political initiatives."
The Administration said as recently as last month that it would move ahead with broader sanctions against Haiti in spite of reports of widespread hardship among the poorest Haitians living in rural areas. A senior official said today, however, that the situation had changed as a result of the current initiative, and a decision was made to postpone further punitive measures to allow it to bear fruit.
The next round of sanctions before the United Nations Security Council would have barred all forms of trade except for food and medicine, a step that would close down factories and businesses in Haiti. The new sanctions would also have barred flights to and from Haiti by noncommercial aircraft.
Insisting that the country's military leadership must be removed before any new political arrangements can be made, Father Aristide has asked in recent weeks that the United Nations impose a blanket embargo on Haiti to force the army to relinquish power.
"It remains our view that since a commitment was made in December that the sanctions would be increased if the army did not give up power by Jan. 15, the U.N. should move quickly to fulfill that promise," said Michael Barnes, a senior adviser to Father Aristide.
Administration officials and diplomats said the decision to postpone the sanctions grew out of concerns that they would inflict great suffering on the Haitian people and further radicalize elements of the country's far right who oppose Father Aristide's return.
Equally prominent in their thinking, however, is persuading Father Aristide to accept a series of recent proposals aimed at jump-starting efforts to restore him to office.
"What we are talking about are things that would be done very quickly," a senior Administration official said. "The retirement of Cedras, the naming of a new commander, changes in the general staff and the separation of the police from the army. All of this would take place in maybe six days."
If Father Aristide agreed to the plan and the army then balked, officials said, broader sanctions would follow.

U.N. Aide Defends Plan
 UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 22 (Reuters) -- Dante Caputo, the United Nations mediator for Haiti, today defended an interim plan to restart the stalled peace process.
 "This is not a comprehensive plan," Mr. Caputo said at a news conference today. "This is a mini-plan to break the impasse."

HEADLINE: Consumer Confidence Declines in New Survey

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Consumer confidence fell in February after three consecutive monthly increases, the Conference Board said yesterday in a survey suggesting that Americans' faith in the rebounding economy may be faltering a bit.
The business research group, based in New York, said it was premature to attach any significance to a one-month reading because February's results might have reflected nothing more than the impact of frigid weather. Fabian Linden, executive director of the board's consumer research center, characterized the dip as "very slight." 
 The results were an early economic indicator for the month, and included responses taken after the Federal Reserve's move on Feb. 4 to raise interest rates for the first time in five years.
The Conference Board's consumer confidence index, derived from answers to questions sent to 5,000 households nationwide, fell to 80.8, from a 82.6 in January. The index, considered a gauge of future economic activity, totaled 79.8 in December, 71.9 in November and 60.5 in October. A reading between 50 and 70 forecasts moderate economic growth.
Mr. Linden attributed the decline to lower optimism about future business conditions and the outlook for jobs. He expressed doubt that the Fed's raising of interest rates played any significant role, "simply because the ordinary citizen isn't an economist, mercifully."
 
Frigid Weather a Factor
 Mr. Linden also said the severe winter cold that gripped much of the country during February might have influenced the results. Economists who follow the Conference Board's survey said they also thought the weather contributed to the results.
"I think people are allowed to feel a little unhappy and disgruntled because of the natural disasters we've had," said Sandra Shaber, a consumer economist at the WEFA Group, a forecasting firm in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa.
Another measure of consumer confidence, a survey by the University of Michigan, also showed a drop in confidence in the economy in February. The Michigan survey was reported on Feb. 11.
The Conference Board survey seeks insight into consumer behavior by asking questions on topics ranging from home-appliance buying plans to the local job market. When people feel more secure about their personal financial outlook, the survey finds, they are more likely to borrow and spend.
The Conference Board said fewer respondents than in past months felt current economic conditions were bad. But fewer believed that the next six months would show improvement.
The number who feared business conditions would worsen increased in February, and more respondents forecast that the number of jobs would decline.

HEADLINE: President of Ukraine Says He Will Not Run

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KIEV, Ukraine, Feb. 22

 BODY:
President Leonid M. Kravchuk was quoted today as saying he will not run for re-election in June, raising anew questions about the accord Mr. Kravchuk signed with the United States and Russia to hand over all of Ukraine's nuclear weapons.
In a front-page interview in the newspaper Demokratichna Ukraina, Mr. Kravchuk said he had made "a final decision" not to seek a second term because he could not "defend the current economic situation." The interview came a little more than a week before Mr. Kravchuk is to visit Washington for talks with President Clinton. 
 Mr. Kravchuk's press secretary, Victor I. Stelmakh, confirmed the decision not to seek a second term, but declined to offer an explanation.
In an opinion poll in December, only 11 percent of Ukrainians said they had confidence in Mr. Kravchuk and only 17 percent said they would vote for him again. Mr. Kravchuk's poor showing is generally blamed on the state of the Ukrainian economy, which was underscored today when the Government announced a sharp new increase in credits to support industry and agriculture.
The inflationary move came despite a high-level joint International Monetary Fund and World Bank mission.

HEADLINE: Clinton Tells Educators Youths Are Not Getting Practical Skills for Jobs

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
Challenging American educators to move away from pure academics and toward applied skills, President Clinton said today that one of his Administration's top goals would be to help the nation's schools prepare students for work.
"In the 19th Century, at most, young Americans needed a high school education to make their way," Mr. Clinton told 1,500 educators at a luncheon during the American Council on Education's annual conference. "It was good enough if they could read well and understand basic numbers. In the 21st Century, our people will have to keep learning all their lives." 
 In a 40-minute speech in which he raced through issues about preschools, community colleges and the most prestigious universities, the President said the American imagination must be gripped by the need for new links between learning and jobs.
"We have to have rigorous academics and practical learning," he said. "We have to tie the workplace to the learning environment in high school for young people who know they are not going on to four-year colleges."
 
Series of Speeches
 The President's remarks, just two days before the House plans to take up the $10 billion Elementary and Secondary Education Act, dovetailed with those made in recent days by the Secretaries of Labor and Education. At various times, in various venues, each has underscored the need for radical educational reforms that would help reorient schools prepare the next generation to compete in the global economy. Today, the President urged the educators to meet the "realities of this economy, not the economy of a generation ago."
To accomplish that, he said, "we have an opportunity to do something that Americans have resisted for too long -- which is to merge instead of keep divided our notion of vocational education and academic education."
Meeting afterwards with reporters, the President said much of the responsibility for those changes would fall to the states and school districts.
No great amount of new money has been set aside in the Federal budget for such a transition. Though the Department of Education is slated to receive a 6 percent overall increase, half that amount would be lost to inflation.
 
Limited Federal Help
 The Administration's most talked about programs -- one encouraging national educational standards and another urging schools to prepare students for work -- are backed by relatively little money. And the Federal grants through the school-to-work program are scheduled to end in three years on the theory that individual states would adopt both the concept and the training to prepare students for the workplace.
"The Federal Government provides a relatively small share of the overall school funding," Mr. Clinton said. "We're trying to help some by just -- in the Elementary and Secondary Education Act -- by changing the way we distribute the funds and trying to give it to the more needy districts."
Speaking of the need to diminish Federal intervention in the day-to-day operations of local schools, President Clinton said he favored waivers to let states direct money to projects best tailored to their needs.
Sipping a caffeine-free diet soft drink, he referred at one point to an Arkansas program that combined Chapter 1 support with money for special education and said a result of that fusion was class work that held students to higher standards. Several students who had been held back to repeat a grade quadrupled their test scores after participating in that program, he said, and most students showed overall improvement.
Stressing the need for states to take more interest in the fate of their students -- as well as their specific studies -- he said states should track dropouts to see what kind of work they find. "We need to set up a system to keep up with those folks," he said.
Most schools, he said, have already begun moving forward with reforms and innovations. "Most people get this thing," he said. "Most people have figured this thing out, particularly in terms of life-long learning."
 
An Education Gap
 In his speech, he called America the only country without a system to help students make a smooth transition from school to work, "where they've got a chance to have a good job with a growing income."
One result of this failure, he said later, is that prisons have better libraries than schools.
"How did my country come to this?" he asked. "Why, when it's so much cheaper to educate somebody than it is to keep them in prison, can you get a better library in the prison than you can in the school?"
Later, speaking broadly of the need to revamp the school system, President Clinton said changes had to start with safety. In a leap to the situation in Bosnia, he compared the crisis in the country's educational system to that war.
"It's kind of analogous to what we try to do with Sarajevo and Bosnia," he said. "I think finally it became possible to do this thing in Bosnia because people realized that Sarajevo was like Humpty Dumpty. And if Sarajevo was destroyed, you'd never put the pieces back together.
"I think, psychologically, people view schools that way. I think it is very hard for families and communities to thrive if they're scared to send their kids to school, and the kids are scared in the schools."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Clinton after a speech in Washington yesterday to the American Council on Education. He told the educators that schools had to improve the way they were preparing young people for good jobs and warned that practical knowledge was being given short shrift. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS;
A Fractional Peace

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
Behind the self-congratulation and assertions of victory in the Clinton Administration over the military respite in Sarajevo lie two stark realities: fighting still rages in parts of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and any peace settlement that emerges may very well give the Muslims less territory than they could have gotten a year ago.
The NATO allies can plausibly take credit for finally giving the Bosnian Serbs an ultimatum that worked, proving that the credible threat of force can get at least short-term results. But their very success raises the question of why it took the United States and the rest of NATO so long: the Serbs have been seizing territory, after all, for nearly two years. 
 And now the Administration must figure out what to do next.
 
Tit-for-Tat
 The Russians have begun to "deliver" the Serbs, who more or less did what the United Nations demanded of them around Sarajevo, and now the United States is being called on to "deliver" the Bosnian Government without appearing to force it to make concessions.
Last year, the Administration initially refused to endorse the peace plan proposed by the United Nations envoy, Cyrus R. Vance, and the European emissary, Lord Owen, because they thought it demanded unfair concessions by the Muslim-dominated Government. That plan, however, offered more territory than the Muslims are now likely to get in any settlement.
President Clinton held out the tantalizing possibility on Monday that a broader use of power and diplomacy could extend the calm in the Bosnian capital to other parts of the country.
But his top military advisers warned lawmakers at a Congressional hearing today that the White House did not want to press ahead with new measures in other parts of the country until the capital is securely under control.
The unpredictability and volatility of Bosnia was highlighted again today when five Swedish peacekeepers were wounded while drivingin a particularly dangerous area near Tuzla, 50 miles north of Sarajevo.
That sent NATO commanders and United Nations officials scurrying to determine whether NATO should retaliate. After all, shouldn't the peacekeeepers continue to behave boldly, knowing that if they get into trouble, NATO aircraft will protect them?
Finally, however, United Nations commanders decided the attack was too small and the source too vague to justify defensive strikes.
Even if it wanted to, Washington cannot push too hard to spread the peace because it refuses to join the 15 countries that have peacekeeping troops in the former Yugoslavia, though American pilots deliver most relief goods and would participate in any NATO air strikes.
 
Withholding Ground Troops
 Mr. Clinton came into office proclaiming a moral imperative to take action against Serbian aggression. But he quickly learned how complicated Bosnia was and had second thoughts, opposing the dispatch of United States ground troops as part of a misnamed "peacekeeping" force.
Only when there is a comprehensive peace will the United States help enforce a settlement with troops, a commitment Secretary of State Warren Christopher reiterated on Monday in a meeting with the Bosnian Prime Minister, Haris Silajdzic. Even then, the Administration knows that it faces a brutal battle with Congress.
Senior officials in countries with peacekeepers in Bosnia reacted with varying degrees of frustration and bemusement on Monday when Mr. Clinton congratulated NATO, the United Nations, the Russians, "and above all, the American military personnel and those from our NATO allies, whose courage and skill provided the muscles that made this policy work."
Malcolm Rifkind, the British Defense Secretary, underscored the Europeans' frustration on Friday when he noted, "Britain at the moment has in Bosnia over 2,500 men, Russia is to have 400, the United States has 15."
On the diplomatic front, the Administration has stepped up its effort to help the Bosnian Government identify its basic demands without forcing a settlement that would be militarily unenforceable and morally unacceptable.
But in his talks with Mr. Christopher on Monday, Prime Minister Silajdzic sketched an ambitious framework that included a kind of Marshall Plan to reconstruct Bosnia, assurances that refugees could return to villages purged by the Serbs and long-term security guarantees so Bosnia could flourish as an ethnically mixed state.
But he refused to offer specific territorial demands, except to say that the "quality" of the territory offered under current plans must be improved.
 
Looking Toward Croatia
 The Administration has also tried to broker a deal between the Muslims and the Croats to consolidate territory under their control in a sovereign state that would form an economic federation with Croatia. But the Croats and the Muslims, who are currently fighting each other in central Bosnia, have discussed federation before, in vain.
At this moment, whatever territory the Muslims might accept would almost certainly be less than they would have received a year ago under the Vance-Owen plan, which the United States initially did not endorse.
The plan would have divided Bosnia into 10 ethnically dominated provinces. But it would have been a nightmare to enforce because it called for an illogical mosaic based on the premise that people who had been forced out of their homes would eventually return.
Mr. Christopher called the plan "repugnant" because it validated Serbian gains from "ethnic cleansing." The Bosnian Serbs were chiefly responsible for sabotaging that plan.
 
An Offer of Radar
 In recent weeks, the Administration has become convinced that since it was not prepared to go to war to help the Bosnian Government, it had to promote the fairest settlement possible. In exchange for an active diplomatic role, the Europeans agreed to allow NATO air strikes to enforce the ultimatum despite the risk to their troops.
Now Mr. Clinton is back to stating that American "interests" are at stake. In a small gesture of involvement, he has offered to provide NATO with radars to help trace artillery attacks. But there will be no United States ground troops to operate the radars. Washington has told the United Nations that other countries familiar with the technology -- including Egypt and Jordan, who have peacekeepers in Bosnia -- will be asked to operate it.

HEADLINE: Senate Debates Budget Amendment

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
The Senate began a long and solemn debate tonight on a proposed constitutional amendment to require the Federal budget to be balanced. Its chief sponsor asked Congress and the states to take away the "blank check" that Government had used to build the national debt to $4 trillion.
"The deficit grows and grows, ad infinitum," said Senator Paul E. Simon, Democrat of Illinois, the main sponsor. Pointing to the young messengers who serve the Senate, he added, "It is hurting these pages and their future right down here." 
 Senator Robert C. Byrd, the West Virginia Democrat who is President pro tem of the Senate and chairman of the Appropriations Committee, said the proposal, with its requirement of a three-fifths majority in both houses to permit deficit spending, violated "the basic principle of the Constitution," the element of majority rule.
"Take the element of a majority rule away, and this is no longer a democracy," he said.
 
Clinton Opposes Plan
 President Clinton denounced the proposal as bringing the filibuster and other Congressional delaying tactics into the one area where they are now excluded, the budget.
"You will put 40 percent of the Senate and 40 percent of the House, plus one vote, in total control of the American Government and America's future," Mr. Clinton told the American Council on Education.
Both supporters and enemies of the proposal predicted that the margin would be narrow when the Senate votes, no sooner than next week. It takes a two-thirds vote, or 67 senators if all vote, to pass a constitutional amendment.
Another close vote would follow in the House, though Mr. Simon predicted it would pass "very, very quickly." It would then take approval by three-fourths, or 38, of the state legislatures to make the provision the 28th Amendment to the Constitution. If adopted, the amendment would take effect in the year 2001.
Mr. Simon maintained that the three-fifths majority could be mustered if Government spending was needed in a recession, or "when you have an earthquake in California."
 
Liberals and Conservatives
 Mr. Simon, a liberal Democrat who has advocated tax increases and Pentagon spending cuts as a route to balancing the budget, was supported by two Republicans, Senators Orrin G. Hatch of Utah and Larry E. Craig of Idaho. They would prefer to cut domestic spending.
Mr. Hatch argued that past efforts to force a balanced budget by statutory measures, like the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings act, had failed. He also said it was now clear that only a constitutional amendment would "end the long spending binge of Congress."
"Once the constitutional amendment is in place, we will all be forced to be serious," Mr. Hatch said. "We need the discipline that this balanced budget amendment would bring to the Congress."
Mr. Craig defended the requirement for a three-fifths majority to impose deficits and add to the national debt, saying issues of debt "should not be left to the judgment of a transient majority."
Agreeing with Mr. Simon's assertion that the amendment would improve the economy, Mr. Craig said, "I don't see ruinous taxes or a downward spiral in the economy." He added, "There is not a sky-is-falling scenario wrapped in the words of the 28th Amendment."
 
History and Balances
 But Mr. Byrd attacked the proposal as "illusory," saying it would not succeed in balancing the budget.
And he quarreled with Mr. Simon's contention that Thomas Jefferson would support his cause. While Mr. Jefferson had occasionally advocated a constitutional provision against debt, Mr. Byrd acknowledged, he had put the country into debt to pay for the Louisiana Purchase.
Finally, Mr. Byrd contended that the amendment was a sham, because the Judiciary Committee report advocating its adoption said Congress could decide that deviations were "negligible," "small" or "temporary," and therefore inconsequential.
He observed that the report also said that it was all right for Congress to decide that a small shortfall could be made up in the next fiscal year. And, Mr. Byrd said, Congress could then decide that this delayed repayment could be put off again and again. That meant that "Congress may declare that a violation is not a violation," he said.

HEADLINE: AUSTRIA PROTESTS CZECH ATOM PLANT

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
Worried about the potential for a nuclear accident near its border, the Austrian Government has sent a high-level delegation to Washington to protest plans to use American technology to complete a Soviet-style nuclear power plant in the Czech Republic.
In January, the United States Export-Import Bank agreed to guarantee a $317 million loan to the Czech electric utility to buy equipment and nuclear fuel from the Westinghouse Electric Corporation to start up two reactors at the Temelin nuclear plant, 40 miles from the Austrian border. 
 Construction of the reactors, of a type found across Eastern Europe, was started by the former Communist Government in Czechoslovakia. Work was halted in 1992 by the first post-Communist Government because of questions about costs, safety and electricity needs. The Czech Republic and Slovakia separated on Jan. 1, 1993.
Despite considerable domestic and international opposition, the Czech Government has decided to resume the project, modifying the design with Westinghouse's help.
 
The Austrian Arguments
 Austria, supported by environmental advocacy groups, argues that the design is flawed, that the plan to modify it is unproven and that the risks have never been publicly examined.
"An accident at Temelin could result in devastating health, environmental, economic and social consequences for all of Austria's almost eight million citizens," said an Austrian memorandum being circulated in Washington.
Nathaniel D. Woodson, the general manager for Westinghouse's commercial nuclear programs, responded that the company's plan meets all the recommendations of the International Atomic Energy Agency for dealing with Soviet-style reactors.
Similar technology has been used in other reactors in Europe, he said, adding, "It is a proven approach that we are applying to a Russian reactor."
 
Haunted by Chernobyl
 The Austrian protest raised the specter of a Chernobyl-like accident just 60 miles from Prague and 120 miles from Vienna. Even the Chernobyl accident in 1986, 700 miles away, led to radioactive fallout in Austria.
The reactors at Temelin are not identical to the one destroyed at Chernobyl, but their design is widely viewed as flawed. Germany canceled construction of identical reactors in the former East Germany rather than try to correct the safety problems.
If the plan to modify the plants goes forward, it could represent a major opening for Westinghouse in Eastern Europe. There are 31 reactors of this type operating in Russia, Ukraine and Bulgaria, and 16 partly completed across Eastern Europe.
The Administration has favored the plan, which was approved last year, but Congress has until early March to decide whether it should be approved.
 
Questions to Be Addressed
 Congressional hearings on the issue are scheduled on Wednesday.
Among the questions expected to be raised is whether the Export-Import Bank, an independent Federal agency that aids and finances United States exports, has adequately examined the environmental effects of the reactor.
Papers circulated by the Austrian Embassy in Washington said its experts are "very skeptical" of studies, not all of them made public, that are said to demonstrate that a power plant grafting Westinghouse technology onto the Soviet design would be safe.
The Austrian delegation to Washington is led by Peter Jankowitsch, a former Foreign Minister and Austria's envoy to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development; there are several political, economic and technical advisers.

GRAPHIC: Map of the Czech Republic shows the location of Temelin.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Seeks to Push Down Long-Term Rates

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, used an appearance before Congress today to try to talk down the long-term interest rates that rose unexpectedly after the Fed pushed up short-term rates on Feb. 4.
Testifying before a House Banking Committee panel whose members mostly criticized the latest increase in interest rates, Mr. Greenspan sought to calm inflation fears but keep his options open. 
 He played down a recent Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank survey showing manufacturers expected higher prices and he predicted that inflation would be only slightly higher this year than last year. And he repeated his recent warnings that he would be willing to push up short-term rates if necessary to fight inflation.
 
A Dip in Bond Yield
 In response to Mr. Greenspan's testimony, long-term interest rates eased slightly today, with the yield on the Treasury's 30-year bond dipping to 6.60 percent, from 6.62 percent on Friday. [Page D14.]
President Clinton professed to be encouraged by Mr. Greenspan's upbeat testimony on inflation. The Administration's economic plan rests on low long-term rates. With recent increases, long-term rates already exceed the Administration's forecasts for this year, while short-term interest rates remain a quarter of a percentage point below.
Long-term interest rates have climbed by nearly a third of a percentage point since the Fed nudged up short-term rates on Feb. 4 in an effort to restrain possible inflationary pressures. The Fed has no direct control over long-term rates, which depend mainly on investors' expectations of inflation.
Mr. Greenspan said he thought inflation was under control now. "In the current period, overall cost and price pressures still appear to remain damped," he said.
As in his last Congressional appearance a month ago, Mr. Greenspan was vague about when any further increases in short-term interest rates might come. "To promote sustainable growth, history suggests that real short-term rates are more likely to have to rise than fall from here," he said. "I cannot, however, tell you at this time when any such rise would occur."
But Mr. Greenspan left himself some room for an immediate increase in short-term rates. He took the highly unusual step this morning of saying that he was waiting for Thursday's Commerce Department report on manufacturers' new orders and production. Governors of the Federal Reserve seldom note a single economic indicator on a specific date as influencing their decision making.
"It could be a hint that a move may come much earlier than the market expected," said John P. Lipsky, the chief economist for Salomon Brothers. He predicted that the Fed could raise short-term rates again before its next monetary policy review meeting on March 22.
But Darwin L. Beck, an economist at the CS First Boston Corporation, said that he did not expect another rate increase until late March or early April. "I don't think there were any real surprises in the testimony," he said.
Federal law requires Mr. Greenspan to discuss interest rate policy semiannually before members of the House and Senate Banking Committees; he is scheduled to visit the Senate side soon, but no date has been set.
Fed officials like to compare their role in cooling an economy as it begins to gather steam to taking away a punch bowl when a party is becoming lively. But some representatives today accused the Fed of having acted too soon when it raised rates on Feb. 4.
"Many of us feel you are taking the punch bowl away while the guests are still taking their coats off," said Representative Toby Roth, a Wisconsin Republican.
 
A Range of Interpretations
 Economists and bond traders have offered a wide range of interpretations for the rise in long-term interest rates. One popular interpretation is that the Fed's action on short-term rates has prompted investors to take a new look at inflation and raise their expectations of future inflation, prompting them to ask for higher rates in exchange for long-term loans.
Another interpretation is that the fall in the dollar's value against the Japanese yen has made dollar-denominated securities less attractive to international investors. And a third interpretation is that recent indicators suggest that the strong economic growth from the fourth quarter may spill over into the first quarter and fuel inflation.
Mr. Greenspan chose the third interpretation today, and criticized financial markets for assuming that growth would remain strong. "It is too early to judge the degree of underlying economic strength in the early months of 1994," he said. "Wages do not seem to be accelerating despite scattered reports of some skilled-worker shortages, and advances in productivity early this year are holding down unit labor costs."
 
Best Outlook in Decades
 The Fed chairman predicted today that the nation's economy would grow by 3 percent or slightly more this year, and was generally upbeat. "The outlook, as a result of subdued inflation and still very low long-term interest rates, is the best we have seen in decades," he said.
During a news conference in the Rose Garden, President Clinton welcomed Mr. Greenspan's testimony. "Alan Greenspan said that he thought that we had the best conditions for fundamental economic growth in two decades or more -- I think that's quite encouraging -- and that there was no reason to believe that we had any problem with inflation," the President said. "If that's true, if we're going to have steady growth and no inflation, we ought to keep relatively low interest rates."
The Administration's economic forecasts assume that short-term rates will rise by at least another quarter of a percentage point this year.
 
Many Indicators Used
 In his testimony today, Mr. Greenspan gave another indication that monetarism is no longer a dominant influence on Fed policy. He said very little about the money supply today, noting instead that the Fed looked at many different economic indicators in deciding when to change interest rates.
Paul L. Kasriel, an economist for the Northern Trust Company, a Chicago bank, said, "The Federal Reserve is not really telling us in very specific terms what it is making its policy decisions on, and there don't seem to be any objective standards -- it's all very subjective and discretionary."
Mr. Greenspan showed unusual enthusiasm today for using gold prices as a guide to monetary policy. "It's not a perfect indicator, but it is a very good indicator" of price trends, Mr. Greenspan said.
He was also unusually frank in saying that the Fed did not have a detailed plan for future interest rate policy. "Clearly, the Federal Reserve will have to monitor carefully ongoing developments for indications of potential inflation or a strengthening in inflation expectations," he said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Government Securities Rise a Bit

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Following two sharp selloffs in as many days, the government securities market received a little lift yesterday from Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman.
The price of the Treasury's 30-year bond rose 5/16 , to 9517/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, fell to 6.60 percent, from 6.62 percent on Friday. 
 Traders said that Mr. Greenspan's testimony before Congress yesterday offered no details as to when the Fed would move short-term interest rates another notch higher. It is the uncertainty about the Fed's next move, some traders and investors have argued, that has caused the sharp selloff in the bond market since early February, when the Fed raised short-term interest rates for the first time in five years. Since then, the yield on the 30-year bond has jumped a third of a percentage point.
 
Lower Economic Growth Seen
 But the chairman's comments about inflation and lower economic growth were a little soothing, they said.
Gerald A. Guild, senior manager fixed income at Advest Inc., said the Fed chairman's testimony "was typical Greenspan -- just trying to reassure people."
Some analysts believe the market may have just oversold itself a little too much last week, forcing the yield on the long bond to close at its highest level in more than six months. Investors betting that interest rates will continue to rise had to rush to cover short positions yesterday, buying securities to limit their losses or to lock in profits they might have made in several previous trading sessions.
In his testimony yesterday, Mr. Greenspan said short-term rates were more likely to rise than fall, but he declined to say when it would happen.
 
Inflation Control Seen
 "The message was loud and clear," Mr. Guild said. "He will try to control inflation.
"There are people who think it can be done without raising interest rates, but that's impossible," he said. "But then, no one ever really wants to go through any pain. This market is more into psychology than reality.
"My impression was that he was speaking about controlling inflation in the years ahead, from 1995 to beyond, and that ought to be a very good boost, if you are investing in long-term bonds," Mr. Guild continued. "I believe that on a short-term basis, traders remain pessimistic and their mood bearish, but that should not have anything to do with long-term investing."
Some Fed watchers said the Feb. 4 tightening by the Fed could be the first in a series of similar actions, with many dealers expecting the central bank to raise the Federal funds rate by 25 basis points by the end of March. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
 
Higher Fed Funds Forecast
 John Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers, said, "We expect a 75-basis-point increase to 4 percent in the Fed funds rate by midyear."
Bond traders said the Conference Board's February consumer confidence survey, which fell after three consecutive months of increases, had little impact on trading yesterday.
The Treasury's weekly sale of three- and six-month bills, put off until yesterday because of the holiday on Monday, saw bill rates increase over those of the previous bill auction. The average rate for a three-month bill was up five basis points, to 3.33 percent, while the six-month maturity was 10 basis points higher over the rate a week ago.
Other government debt sales this week include today's two-year note auction and five-year note auction on Thursday. In when-issued trading the two-year note was being offered at a price to yield 4.57 percent and the five-year at 5.50 percent.
